articles.title: Freedom from China? The mine at the centre of Europe’s push for rare earth metals
articles.trailText: Swedish producer is trying to to accelerate the process of extracting the elements vital for hi-tech products
articles.summary: At LKAB’s Kiruna mine in northern Sweden, crews tunnel 900–1,365 m deep to access the century-old Per Geijer rare earth deposit, blasting and remotely excavating five metres daily. Europe, currently lacking rare earth mines, stakes €80 m on a Luleå demo plant and Norwegian REEtec tie-up to fast-track extraction and separation. Full mine-to-magnet chain may take 10–15 years, highlighting supply-chain hurdles for EU self-sufficiency. The effort aims to curb the EU’s reliance on China—which processes up to 100% of heavy rare earths—amid geopolitical tensions over supply “weaponisation.”

articles.title: World’s richest 1% have already used fair share of emissions for 2026, says Oxfam
articles.trailText: Richest 1% took 10 days while wealthiest 0.1% needed just three days to exhaust annual carbon budget, study shows
articles.summary: The world’s richest 1% consumed their full 2026 carbon budget within 10 days—and the top 0.1% in just three days—Oxfam finds. Meanwhile the poorest 50% use the same quota over a year. These super-rich, whose investment portfolios emit on average 1.9 million tonnes of CO2 annually (akin to 400,000 cars), exacerbate climate impacts that will hit low-income countries, Indigenous communities, women and girls hardest, with potential £44 trillion economic damage by 2050. To meet the Paris 1.5 °C limit, the 1% must slash emissions by 97% by 2030. Oxfam urges UK authorities to tax private jets, extreme wealth and polluting industries to fund a fair green transition.

articles.title: Snaking around the parakeet problem | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Stephen Pound on using rubber serpents to deal with greedy, ring-necked parakeets. Plus letters from Dr Andrew Bodey and Nigel Walker
articles.summary: Three readers tackle the surge of invasive ring-necked parakeets in the UK. Stephen Pound recounts flashmobs of these tropical birds raiding his west London feeders, then repelling them by draping rubber snakes to exploit their natural fear, restoring native species. Dr Andrew Bodey warns of parakeets stripping blossoms, threatening fruit growers and ecosystems. Nigel Walker wryly cites a Victorian parrot-pie recipe as a drastic control. The letters underscore urgency in managing this ecological challenge.

articles.title: Public urged to grow unusual plants to safeguard diversity of UK blooms
articles.trailText: Plant Heritage says gardening trends mean many species in danger of disappearing as they are no longer offered for sale
articles.summary: Plant Heritage warns over half of the UK’s cultivated garden flowers are no longer sold, threatening biodiversity. To counter garden homogenisation and loss of rare varieties, it invites the public to grow unusual species, create or steward “national collections” of at-risk blooms, and visit its Chelsea Flower Show garden showcasing living libraries (e.g. Geum, Boehmeria) and missing custodians (Aquilegia, Verbascum). The charity also offers propagation tips—cuttings, hygiene, callousing, well-draining media—and encourages sharing plant specimens and stories to safeguard native blooms and support pollinators.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Kosovo floods trap people in homes and cut water supplies
articles.trailText: Emergency rescuers step in as intense rain results in landslips, power cuts and communities left isolated
articles.summary: Prolonged heavy rainfall has flooded Kosovo’s Drenas, Malisheva and Rahovec, with more than 50–80 mm in 24 hours locally (231.5 mm in Junik over two days), triggering landslips, power substation inundation, water cuts and rescues of residents trapped in isolated communities. Meanwhile, Storm Goretti brought red wind warnings to Cornwall and the Scilly Isles with gusts near 100 mph, battered Normandy (132 mph) and Brittany (94 mph), prompted 6–9 m wave and 1.5 m surge alerts, and is forecast to weaken en route to mainland Europe with possible blizzards in Germany and the Benelux.

articles.title: ‘Toughest conditions imaginable’: Victorians urged to shelter inside from heatwave as tropical cyclone heads for Queensland
articles.trailText: Heatwave warnings in place for nearly all states and territories as Sydney braces for 43C forecast on Saturday
articles.summary: An extreme heatwave has engulfed Australia’s south-east, with Melbourne hitting 42.9–45C and Sydney set to reach 43C on Saturday. Victoria is under catastrophic fire conditions and total fire bans; uncontained, fast-moving bushfires are burning near Longwood and Walwa. Anthony Albanese urged residents to heed evacuation and flood warnings. South Australia, NSW and Tasmania also face severe heat alerts and wind gusts over 100 km/h. In Queensland, Tropical Cyclone Koji is approaching a flood‐saturated coast between Innisfail and Bowen. Record highs at Renmark (47C) and Walpeup (46.5C) accompany power outages, train delays and park closures amid warnings to shelter indoors.

articles.title: ‘Profound impacts’: record ocean heat is intensifying climate disasters, data shows
articles.trailText: Oceans absorb 90% of global heating, making them a stark indicator of the relentless march of the climate crisis
articles.summary: 2025’s ocean heat content hit a record high, with over 90% of anthropogenic warming absorbed by the top 2,000 m. Published in Advances in Atmospheric Sciences, analyses from three teams show this unprecedented heating fuels stronger hurricanes, heavier rainfall, longer marine heatwaves and sea-level rise via thermal expansion. Proxy records suggest oceans are hottest in at least a millennium. Warming hotspots include the tropical/South Atlantic, North Pacific and Southern Ocean—where winter sea ice is collapsing. Rising temperature, acidity and deoxygenation in the North Atlantic and Mediterranean are triggering ecosystem upheaval.

articles.title: How falcon thieves are targeting the UK’s protected birds
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: Conservationists have seen nests raided around the country to match demand from the Middle East
articles.summary: An investigation by The Guardian and ARIJ reveals that since 2014 at least 126 UK peregrine falcon nests were raided to supply a multimillion-dollar trafficking network serving elite falconry in the UAE. RSPB and National Wildlife Crime Unit data confirm 21 nest raids via camera footage, DNA and eyewitness accounts, and 15 wild birds discovered in captive breeding centres. While trading captive-bred birds is legal, smuggling wild chicks breaches UK law. Interviewed Emirati falconers prize British birds for their racing pedigree; stolen chicks get ‘passports’, luxury healthcare and travel in Range Rovers. Officials say many breeding centres flout registration rules, though some experts dismiss the scale as minimal.

articles.title: ‘A colossal own goal’: Trump’s exit from global climate treaties will have little effect outside US
articles.trailText: For much of the last 30 years, the rest of the world has been forced to persevere with climate action in the face of US intransigence
articles.summary: Trump’s decision to withdraw the US from the UNFCCC and IPCC, while symbolic, won’t alter rising emissions, economic momentum behind clean energy or global climate science. With low-carbon investment outpacing fossil fuels two-to-one and renewables driving growth in China, India and the global south, countries will press on without Washington. US firms and citizens risk higher energy, food and insurance costs as climate disasters intensify. Legal disputes over treaty withdrawal and potential reentry remain unsettled. Meanwhile, Americans already face costly wildfires, floods and insurance losses exacerbated by unchecked warming. Analysts call it a “colossal own goal”, warning the US risks ceding low-carbon market leadership to China and undermining its own climate security.

articles.title: Exhaust pipe position affects how much air pollution we breathe, research finds
articles.trailText: Cars that emit fumes closer to pavement result in pedestrians experiencing 40% more pollution
articles.summary: Researchers from the University of York led by Prof David Carslaw used kerbside second-by-second measurements on 38,000 vehicles in Milan to show diesel cars still emit the bulk of traffic pollution—81% of NOx, 61% of black carbon and 55% of particles. The top 5% of vehicles produce twice the NOx and seven times more particles than average, reflecting filter failures and maker differences. Critically, kerbside exhaust pipes raise pedestrian exposure by 40% versus centre outlets; centralising diesel pipes could cut roadside pollution by 21%. Electric vehicles’ airflow disperses pollutants without adding emissions, and newer diesels now match petrol for NOx while emitting fewer particles.

articles.title: Country diary: Mermaid’s purses bring riches to the beach | Tom Allan
articles.trailText: North Sands, Salcombe, Devon: They’re my daughter’s favourite find, and I’ve never seen such a concentration. These ones have only just hatched
articles.summary: At North Sands, Salcombe, on a winter day two hours before high tide, Tom Allan and his four-year-old daughter Nina clamber over estuary boulders and collect scallop and razor clam shells. They even mimic rock pipits and wrens as they play. Then they discover an unprecedented concentration of mermaid’s purses—egg cases of spotted and thornback rays—likely freshly hatched. Recording them on the Shark Trust’s Great Eggcase Hunt app, Allan notes that these leathery cases can endure months on the seabed, with incubation spanning five to six months for rays and up to 18 months for species like the flapper skate. Exhausted, they retire to the beach café.

articles.title: ‘They are going after everything rural’: inheritance tax U-turn does little to dampen farmers’ anger at Labour
articles.trailText: At the Oxford farming conference there were signs the government has much to do to win back farmers’ trust
articles.summary: At the Oxford farming conference, frustrated British farmers protested Labour’s proposal to extend inheritance tax to agricultural estates, symbolized by a coffin inscribed “RIP British agriculture, 30th October 2024.” Despite a pre-Christmas U-turn raising the tax threshold from £1m to £2.5m, anger remains high, with reports of farmer suicides, tractor horn rallies and placards decrying rural neglect. Environment secretary Emma Reynolds urged partnership, praising farm contributions and promising no further concessions. But producers and bodies like the NFU warn that unless trust is rebuilt, domestic food production and rural votes are at risk.

articles.title: Masses of toxic litter pours from Rhine into North Sea each year, research finds
articles.trailText: Citizen scientists help in University of Bonn study showing river carries up to 4,700 tonnes of ‘macrolitter’ annually
articles.summary: A University of Bonn study involving citizen scientists finds that up to 4,700 tonnes of macrolitter – pieces larger than 25 mm ��� pour from the Rhine into the North Sea annually, contaminating ecosystems with heavy metals (e.g., zinc from tyres), microplastics and other chemicals. Analysis of almost 2,000 kg of debris trapped in Cologne showed 15 % plastic and 28 % food or drink items. Composition mirrors that in rivers like the Thames, while such macrolitter can impair flood-control infrastructure. Researchers call for broader river surveys to gauge Europe’s pollution pathways.

articles.title: Germany’s dying forests are losing their ability to absorb CO2. Can a new way of planting save them?
articles.trailText: Vast swathes of the country���s trees have been killed off by droughts and infestations, in a trend sweeping across Europe. A shift towards more biodiverse cultivation could offer answers
articles.summary: Since 2018 bark beetle outbreaks fueled by droughts and heatwaves have decimated half a million hectares of Germany’s predominantly spruce monocultures, undermining the forest carbon sink and threatening climate targets. Regional foresters in the Harz mountains now replace uniform spruce stands with mixed plantings of beech, fir, sycamore, oak, maple and Douglas fir to enhance drought and pest resilience. Biodiversity studies confirm species-rich forests better withstand diebacks. Germany and the EU face downward revisions to land-based CO2 absorption, igniting debate over nature’s role in national climate commitments. Strategic mixed-species cultivation aims to safeguard carbon stocks and future-proof Europe’s forests.

articles.title: Supermarkets could help UK shoppers eat more sustainable local fish – study
articles.trailText: Shift from ‘big 5’ imports to British fish such as sprats and sardines would help diets and the planet, say researchers
articles.summary: Researchers at the University of East Anglia warn that British shoppers rely heavily on imported 'big five' seafood—cod, haddock, tuna, salmon and prawns—while under-consuming fish overall (down 25% in 10 years) and missing key nutrients like omega-3. They advocate for promoting local, sustainable small fish (sprats, sardines, anchovies) via supermarket initiatives (promotions, recipe cards) to boost health, cut emissions and support coastal economies. Data from surveys, focus groups and sales analysis show availability shapes purchasing, with 40% willing to try lesser-known species if fresh, local and affordable. Findings align with government Eatwell Guide recommendations and call for further market research.

articles.title: Dog food accounts for 1% of UK greenhouse gas emissions, study finds
articles.trailText: Study of 1,000 products finds wet, raw and meat-rich products have higher climate impact than dry kibble
articles.summary: Research from the universities of Edinburgh and Exeter finds commercial dog food generates 0.9–1.3% of UK greenhouse gas emissions (2.3–3.7% of food system emissions), with wet, raw and meat-rich products emitting up to 65 times more than standard dry kibble. Based on nearly 1,000 labels, high-impact diets use prime cuts; low-impact ones rely on carcass by-products. Owners seeking to cut emissions should opt for non–grain-free dry foods, lower-prime-meat formulations or plant-based alternatives, and demand clearer labeling of ingredients.

articles.title: Country diary: Everything is frozen, but still the finches come | Amanda Thomson
articles.trailText: Abernethy Forest, Cairngorms: Thanks to a local collaborative effort, linnets, bramblings, green and goldfinches are coming to this field in joyful flocks
articles.summary: In –6°C Abernethy Forest (Cairngorms), a field managed by Speyside Fields for Wildlife— a community charity collaborating with local farmers and crofters to sow wildlife-friendly crops like millet, black oat, barley, cornflower, corncockle, marigold and poppy—has become a winter haven for hundreds of small finches. Charms of chaffinches, greenfinches, goldfinches, and bramblings descend on brittle, frost-ed seedheads, while flocks of up to a thousand linnets swirl between birch and rowan in the lowering sun, recalling Jamieson’s “havoc-burds” of 19th-century Scotland.

articles.title: ‘The most dangerous day’: bushfires break out in Victoria as BoM warns of catastrophic conditions to come
articles.trailText: Temperatures recorded included 48.2C at Wudinna airport on SA’s Eyre Peninsula, 45.9C at Walpeup in Victoria, 45.6C at Paraburdoo, WA, and 45.9C at Hay in NSW.
articles.summary: Victoria’s Hume Highway, cancelled regional trains and a total fire ban are in place as firefighters battle bushfires during Australia’s worst heatwave since 2019-20. Friday’s forecast 41 °C in Melbourne, gusts to 90 km/h and catastrophic fire danger across multiple Victorian districts draw parallels with November 2019. Extreme ratings also apply to most of South Australia and NSW’s Riverina. Temperatures peaked at 48.2 °C in SA’s Wudinna, 45.9 °C in Walpeup (Vic) and Hay (NSW). Authorities urge hydration, indoor sheltering and vigilance; climate experts link intensifying heatwaves to emissions.

articles.title: Fly-arousing orchid and zombie fungus among 2025 botanical and fungal finds
articles.trailText: Botanists also name an overlooked snowdrop growing in the UK and a fruit that tastes like banana and guava
articles.summary: Royal Botanic Gardens Kew and partners named 10 standout new plant and fungal species in 2025, including: a spider-killing “zombie” fungus emerging from trapdoor spiders in Brazil; a blood-stained Andean orchid luring male flies; a flame-red Peruvian shrub named after Howl’s Moving Castle’s fire demon; an overlooked UK snowdrop from Mount Korab; a banana-guava–flavoured fruit tree in Papua New Guinea; and a newly recorded Christmas palm from the Philippines. Many face imminent extinction amid habitat loss, highlighting urgent taxonomy and conservation needs. Scientists warn that of the estimated 100,000 undiscovered plants and up to 3 million fungi, three-quarters may be threatened as habitat destruction, mining and climate change outpace naming and protection efforts.

articles.title: Smaller farms in England to be prioritised for nature funding, minister to announce
articles.trailText: Emma Reynolds is expected to say an application window for the Sustainable Farming Incentive will be opened to smaller and new farms first
articles.summary: Environment secretary Emma Reynolds will open Sustainable Farming Incentive applications to smaller holdings and new entrants in June, with larger farms eligible from September. The SFI, which replaces EU-style subsidies, rewards land managers for delivering public goods—biodiversity, soil health and flood resilience—rather than mere land ownership. Limited budgets forced last year’s abrupt scheme closure and blocked 3,000 applications. Reynolds pledged clear budgets, timelines and industry engagement via a new Farming and Food Partnership Board. Defra defended the schemes amid a £100m cut. The Country Land and Business Association urged universal access, while conservation groups hailed the focus on under-resourced small farms.

articles.title: US attack on Venezuela will decide direction of South America’s vast mineral wealth
articles.trailText: Outcome of aggression will determine whether rare earths and other resources drive energy transition – or strengthen US military power and oil interests
articles.summary: Last weekend’s US strike on Venezuela escalates its extractive rivalry with China over South America’s vast minerals. Targeting Maduro’s regime, Washington seeks control of Orinoco Belt oil and critical minerals for defense, aiming to reroute lithium, cobalt, rare earths and oil northward. Trump’s 2025 security strategy prioritizes expelling Chinese influence via military force, courting right-wing allies in Argentina and Ecuador, while provoking backlash from Mexico, Brazil, Colombia and Uruguay. Critics warn this shift undermines the global energy transition, deepens fossil-fuel dependency and threatens regional stability, democracy and climate goals.

articles.title: Revealed: how aviation emissions could be halved without cutting journeys
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Getting rid of premium seats, ensuring flights are near full and using efficient aircraft could slash CO 2 , analysis suggests
articles.summary: Analysis of 27m flights shows halving aviation CO2 is possible without cutting journeys by adopting all-economy seating, 95% load factors and modern fuel-efficient aircraft, cutting fuel use 50–75%. US, Australian and some Middle Eastern flights are most polluting (Atlanta, New York worst), while India, Brazil and Southeast Asia lead efficiency (Abu Dhabi, Madrid top). Premium seats emit 3–13× more per passenger. Researchers call for route efficiency ratings, higher landing fees and phasing out old jets over reliance on sustainable fuels or offsets.

articles.title: Melbourne swelters through hottest day in six years as severe heatwave descends on Australia’s south-eastern states
articles.trailText: Hot conditions for NSW, Victoria, South Australia, the ACT, Tasmania and WA as authorities warn of high fire danger
articles.summary: An extreme heatwave scorched WA, SA, Victoria, NSW, the ACT and Tasmania as Melbourne hit 41C—its hottest since 2020—and Adelaide reached 43C with Port Augusta at 46.3C. Authorities declared severe-to-extreme fire dangers, ordering immediate evacuations in Bungil, Granya, Thologolong and near Seymour; 305 firefighters, 12 aircraft and 30 bulldozers fought sprawling blazes. Rail services slowed by heat restrictions, Monarto Safari Park closed, and Melbourne distributed cool kits to the homeless. Sweltering Cities urged suspension of jobseeker obligations amid ground temperatures topping 69C at tram stops. Health agencies warned residents to stay hydrated and indoors. Australia’s 2025 was its fourth-warmmest year, highlighting climate-driven extremes.

articles.title: Specieswatch: tough times for reindeer as rain increases in warming Arctic
articles.trailText: When rain falls on snow it creates a layer of ice that impedes feeding, which in turn has reduced herds’ birthrates
articles.summary: Researchers warn that increased rain-on-snow events in warming Arctic winters create ice layers that block reindeer from accessing lichen and moss, forcing them to expend more energy and leading to reduced birthrates. Analysis of climate records since 1960 and herd data from Norway and Finland reveals summer birth rates drop after winters with heavy rain-on-snow. These events have become earlier, more frequent and widespread in interior regions, intensifying resource competition in dense herds. Findings could guide land-use planning to secure winter grazing access for herders.

articles.title: Country diary: A palace of sunlight on a short winter’s day
articles.trailText: Inishowen, County Donegal, Ireland: There’s not much light to play with today, deep in midwinter, but this once-coveted fort still puts on a show
articles.summary: On a midwinter afternoon at Grianán of Aileach, a 19th-century reconstruction of an early medieval ringfort atop Inishowen peninsula, County Donegal, the low sun glints off its high walls. Panoramic views sweep over heath, the flooded Inch Levels reserve—home to wintering whooper swans and greylag geese—Lough Swilly and the Atlantic. Once the Owen dynasty’s “sunny upper room” for three centuries after an eighth-century battle, the fort still hosts solstice gatherings and pilgrims. From its grassy terraces, Donegal, Tyrone and Derry unfold as a snipe bursts toward gilded light.

articles.title: Pesticide industry ‘immunity shield’ stripped from US appropriations bill
articles.trailText: Democrats and ‘make America healthy again’ movement pushed back on the rider in a funding bill led by Bayer
articles.summary: In a setback for Bayer, Democrats led by Rep. Chellie Pingree successfully stripped from the 2026 appropriations bill a Bayer-backed rider that would have blocked federal funds for state or local pesticide warnings and shielded manufacturers from litigation over health risks, with Senate Republicans agreeing not to revisit the measure. Industry critics warned it would preempt updated EPA assessments and hinder consumer suits. Bayer disputes that it sought blanket immunity and frames legislation as needed for science-based crop protections. Grassroots ‘make America healthy again’ advocates and Moms Across America mobilized to pressure lawmakers. Pingree warns the push will resurface in future bills.

articles.title: Are crabs animals and should we experiment on monkeys? Major review of Australia’s research code to mull tough questions
articles.trailText: Ending use of animals in teaching and limiting surgery in research settings to veterinarians among suggested changes
articles.summary: Australia’s animal research code is under its first major review since 2013, weighing updated policy on animal sentience, formal inclusion of crustaceans as animals, rehoming lab animals and ending in-school dissection. Proposals include limiting surgeries to veterinarians, mandatory national data collection on lab use, stronger enforcement and inspections, and stricter approval criteria demanding justification for not using non-animal alternatives. RSPCA and Animal Free Science Advocacy call for primate experiment bans and high-harm prohibitions. Public consultation runs to Feb 16, with revised code draft due late 2026.

articles.title: Nature boys and girls – here’s your chance to get published in the Guardian
articles.trailText: Our wildlife series Young Country Diary is looking for articles written by children, about their winter encounters with nature
articles.summary: Nature lovers: Guardian’s Young Country Diary calls UK children aged 8–14 to submit 200–250-word winter nature encounter articles—be it a flower, pond creature or bug. Four entries will be published (two in January, two in February) and paid. Deadline noon on Monday 2 February; early submissions before 16 January may appear in January. Parents or guardians submit via encrypted form; photos or drawings optional. Hints include sensory detail, research and reflection. Spring submissions open in March.

articles.title: Country diary: Twelfth night tugs at the heart, but these decorations must come down | Nicola Chester
articles.trailText: Inkpen, Berkshire: The felted mouse choir, the sleeping fawn … a lot of it has meaning to us. At least the greenery goes up in a blaze of glory
articles.summary: In Inkpen, Berkshire, Nicola Chester reluctantly dismantles her Christmas decorations on Twelfth Night, balancing tradition with personal ritual. After sourcing a sustainably grown tree from Willis Farm, she frees cherished baubles—childhood mementos, a wooden goose, a Banff beaver, silver acorns and golden apples, plus animal ornaments fashioned by her children—and carefully removes wreath and mistletoe to repurpose: berries frozen for spring grafting and withered greenery scattered in the garden. She will dismantle two decades of tinsel swags, send fir and holly up the chimney, watch silver sparks fade and finally consign the cut-up tree to the fire.

articles.title: ‘Mad fishing’: the super-size fleet of squid catchers plundering the high seas
articles.trailText: Every year a Chinese-dominated flotilla big enough to be seen from space pillages the rich marine life on Mile 201, a largely ungoverned part of the South Atlantic off Argentina
articles.summary: Each year for five to six months hundreds of foreign squid-jigging vessels—three-quarters from China, plus Taiwan and South Korea—descend on Mile 201, an unregulated high-sea zone off Argentina. Tracking shows the fleet grows large enough to be visible from space, overfishing one-year-cycle squid and risking ecosystem collapse—whales, dolphins, fish and deep-sea corals are at stake. Investigations reveal widespread seal killing, penguin entrapment and crew forced into debt bondage. Exports hide environmental ruin and human-rights abuse, prompting calls for import bans and a binding global high-seas charter.

articles.title: A passion for pigeons – why we love a Columba | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Ross McQueen and Teresa Rodrigues share their admiration for birds in the much-maligned genus Columba
articles.summary: Ross McQueen and Teresa Rodrigues respond to Toussaint Douglass’s plea for more pigeon-watching, championing the much-maligned genus Columba as ‘working-class heroes.’ In Brussels, McQueen describes a lockdown wood pigeon pair nesting on his flat windowsill, raising multiple broods, exhibiting lifelong monogamy (unless widowed), unique water-sucking without head-tilt, closed-beak ‘coo-coo’ song, and shared parental duties. In Devon, Rodrigues, inspired by urban roosting pigeons outside her former Lewisham bedsit, now crafts and successfully sells pigeon soft sculptures. Both letters underscore pigeons’ resilience, everyday presence, and capacity to delight and connect us to nature.

articles.title: Outskirts of Australian cities at risk of catastrophic fires on scale of deadly LA blazes, study finds
articles.trailText: At least 6.9 million residents on Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra, Adelaide, Perth and Hobart fringes exposed as dry summer follows years of vegetation growth
articles.summary: A new report by the Climate Council and Emergency Leaders for Climate Action warns that 6.9 million Australians living on the fringes of Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra, Adelaide, Perth and Hobart face catastrophic fire risk akin to the 2025 Los Angeles blazes. Up to 90% of homes in these bush-bordered suburbs predate modern fire codes, increasing ember-driven ignition and house-to-house spread. Years of wet growth followed by dry summers, potential for strong winds, steep slopes and abundant fuel loads mirror LA’s “climate whiplash”. Authors urge emissions cuts, emergency investment and retrofitting to modern bushfire standards.

articles.title: ‘A silent majority’: MPs underestimate support for green policies, study reveals
articles.trailText: Exclusive: From solar subsidies to meat taxes, minority rightwing voices appear to drown out the consensus
articles.summary: A University of Cambridge study led by Lisa-Maria Tanase reveals UK and Flemish MPs systematically underestimate public support for green measures—by 7–25 percentage points on policies from windfarms and solar subsidies to meat and frequent-flyer taxes and home efficiency grants. Surveys of 100 UK MPs and 600+ Belgian politicians, benchmarked against Ipsos and University of Antwerp polls, show misperceptions reduce MPs’ willingness to speak up or vote for climate action. Information interventions boost estimates but leave persistent gaps, implicating a rightwing-biased, vocal minority and disinformation in skewing perceived public opinion.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Arctic air grips Europe as severe winds batter Corsica
articles.trailText: Subzero temperatures, heavy snowfall and powerful gusts mark a harsh start to 2026 for many
articles.summary: Europe experienced a freezing start to 2026 as an Arctic air mass plunged temperatures 5-10°C below average across central and eastern regions, with double-digit subzero readings. Heavy New Year’s snowfall hit Poland, Ukraine and the Alps. The cold front also reached South Korea, dumping over 9cm of snow on Jeju and disrupting flights and ferries amid strong wind shear. Meanwhile, Corsica endured unusually fierce winds—gusts of 60mph in L’Île-Rousse and nearly 100mph in Cap Corse—driven by a high-pressure zone over the northern Atlantic and a low in the Gulf of Genoa funnelling cold air via the Rhône valley.

articles.title: How demand for elite falcons in the Middle East is driving illegal trade of British birds
articles.trailText: Exclusive: data reveals hundreds of UK nests have been raided in the past decade amid growing appetite to own prized birds for racing and breeding
articles.summary: Exclusive investigation by the Guardian and ARIJ reveals that booming demand for elite British peregrine falcons in the Middle East—where prized wild-caught birds fetch prices up to £71,000—has driven a shadow trafficking network in the UK. Between 2014 and 2023, RSPB data flagged 126 nest raids (21 confirmed by cameras, DNA or witnesses), with hundreds of chicks stolen from remote sites. Despite CITES rules permitting only captive‐bred peregrines, smugglers forge documents to export up to 5,000 birds annually—88% to the UAE. DNA tests uncovered wild birds in UK breeding centres. Authorities warn this illicit trade threatens the species’ recovery, although some experts downplay its scale.

articles.title: Country diary: The calm after the storm | John Gilbey
articles.trailText: Comins Coch, Ceredigion: The winds have died down, so I head out on an eerily still morning among frozen fallen leaves and emerging catkins
articles.summary: In Comins Coch, Ceredigion, a dawn gale from the east tosses pots and branches before subsiding into an icy stillness. Fallen limbs scatter along an eroded lane while jays squabble near a frost-laced stream. Although grass and leaves glisten in crystalline frost, the unfrozen soil hints at recent warmth. A flock of jackdaws and rooks forages in pasture before I reach an old quarry cloaked in lichen-laden oaks and sheltered from prevailing winds. Eastward views toward the Cambrian Mountains reveal low clouds muting the peaks. As wind picks up, a male blackbird perches among emerging catkins, signaling winter’s wane.

articles.title: Most significant heatwave since black summer to blast Australia’s southern states as band of hot weather moves east
articles.trailText: Parts of Victoria and SA could expect highs of 46 or 47C, with winds bringing bushfire danger later in week
articles.summary: Australia’s southern states face their most severe heatwave since 2019-20’s Black Summer as 40–47°C conditions sweep eastward from Western Australia into South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales from Jan 5. The Bureau of Meteorology expects temperatures 8–16°C above average, with inland highs mid-to-high 40s and coastal areas in the low 40s. Friday’s cold front will push peaks toward Sydney, reaching around 39°C on Saturday. Strong winds from Thursday will elevate fire danger across SA and VIC. Prolonged hot days and warm nights pose serious health risks for the elderly, children and pets. National average temperatures are now 1.5°C above 1910, intensifying extreme weather.

articles.title: It is not the Earth’s future at stake in the climate crisis – it is ours | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: As we edge towards an irreversible point, the climate becomes less a challenge to manage and more a hostile environment in which many will struggle to live, writes Keith Nicholls . Plus letters from Dr David Lowry and Leo Young
articles.summary: Letters warn that climate breakdown threatens humanity more than Earth, framing the crisis as moral: poorer nations, least responsible, pay the highest price while wealthy delay adaptation funding. Keith Nicholls urges emissions cuts as nonnegotiable survival tools. Dr David Lowry highlights the irony of new North Sea nuclear plants—Hinkley C and Sizewell C—being built on flood-prone coasts. Leo Young calls for a ‘government health warning’ campaign, replacing petrol-station branding with hard-hitting facts and images from attribution studies to break public denial and spur political action.

articles.title: Country diary: A wave of relief on the farm with the inheritance tax change | Andrea Meanwell
articles.trailText: Tebay, Cumbria: Small farms like ours contribute to society, but we need help to survive. A huge cloud has lifted over our future
articles.summary: Andrea Meanwell, a hill farmer in Cumbria, describes the relief after the government raised the agricultural inheritance tax threshold from £1m to £2.5m on 23 December. The change spares her family a potential £59,000 annual bill over ten years, securing their three-generation farm and its biodiversity work. She warns that without relief, many small farms would be sold off as holiday lets or party houses, severing vital community ties. While welcoming the move, she urges further reforms so active farmers delivering public goods receive proper support.

articles.title: Long showers can cost the planet dearly | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Having spent many years in Africa, Jenny Tillyard learned how precious fresh, clean water is when you don’t have enough
articles.summary: Jenny Tillyard, reflecting on a Guardian letter debate about excessive home water use, warns that long showers waste precious fresh water. Drawing on years spent in Africa, she highlights how scarce clean water reshaped her view on resource consumption. Questioning why anyone needs 30-minute showers, she proposes incorporating a sitzbad-style seat to promote shorter, more mindful showers. Tillyard urges challenging societal norms that equate increased resource use with comfort and advocates practical solutions to curb everyday water waste.

articles.title: Rapid expansion of ring-necked parakeets in UK sparks concern
articles.trailText: Bird organisations say more research on the species needed to control impact on other wildlife
articles.summary: Ring-necked parakeets, introduced or escaped in the 1960s, have increased 25-fold between 1994 and 2023 in the UK, now exceeding 30,000 birds (15,000 breeding pairs), mainly around London, the southeast and recently in northern cities. Their dense populations, especially in Richmond Park, raise concerns over competition with native cavity-nesting species (nuthatches, woodpeckers), starlings, song thrushes and noctule bats. UK research is limited and outdated (last DEFRA risk assessment 2011), with conflicting European studies on ecological impact. Control measures like culling have been debated but remain controversial; long-term field data are needed.

articles.title: Cop30, Trump and the fragile future of climate cooperation
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: From geopolitics to populism, multilateralism is under pressure – but climate action cannot succeed in a fractured world
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, the weak “Belém deal” highlighted multilateralism’s fragility: it avoided binding phase-out roadmaps, forcing them into side deals while US president Trump’s absence and earlier IMO “thuggery” tactics loom. October’s IMO meeting saw a shipping carbon levy delayed after US threats of visa revocations and trade sanctions. The EU’s new carbon border adjustment (CBAM) deepens North-South tensions despite its cooperation pitch. Ahead of COP31’s Australia-Turkey presidency, nations have formed “coalitions of the willing” for fossil fuel phase-out. As geopolitics and populism rise, only renewed multilateral frameworks can prevent 2.5 °C of warming.

articles.title: Ministers may cut green tech mandate from new homes regulations in England
articles.trailText: Critics say removing battery installation requirement will reduce amount homebuyers save on energy bills
articles.summary: Ministers will publish England’s Future Homes Standard in January 2026 without mandatory battery storage alongside required solar panels, insulation and heat pumps, after housebuilder lobbying. Batteries, costing £2–5K, could save households about £1,350/year when paired with solar and heat pumps. Experts warn omitting them on 1.5 million new homes from 2027 will increase bills, drive up gas imports and forgo grid-flexibility gains. Builders favour switch valves or solar thermal alternatives. Critics, including energy thinktanks and academics, call it a ‘climbdown’ and urge mandating batteries to maximise savings, cut carbon and meet net zero targets by 2050.

articles.title: Country diary: Here for all to see – nature’s remarkable ability to rebound | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Mousley Bottom, Derbyshire: This area was a literal dump 40 years ago, devoid of life. But time and a dedicated council have worked their magic
articles.summary: At Mousley Bottom in Derbyshire, a former toxic municipal dump and sewage outfall beside the River Goyt has been transformed over 40 years into diverse woodland and river park. Led by the late Sir Martin Doughty and his council ranger team, 22,000 trees – including 500 oaks planted by schoolchildren – and habitat works overcame coal-gas toxins and industrial waste. This renewal, fuelled by subterranean microbes and collaborative restoration, now supports redwings, wrens, ravens and rich biodiversity, proving no brownfield is beyond redemption.

articles.title: Winter blooming of hundreds of plants in UK ‘visible signal’ of climate breakdown
articles.trailText: New year plant hunt shows rising temperatures are shifting natural cycles of wildflowers such as daisies
articles.summary: Citizen scientists recorded 310 native species flowering in the UK new year plant hunt 2025—far above the typical 10—with non-native species pushing the total to 646. Met Office analysis links every 1°C Nov–Dec warming to 2.5 extra species at New Year, illustrated by winter daisies and dandelions. Early 2026 data also list Mexican fleabane and dead-nettles. BSBI scientist Kevin Walker calls this a visible signal of climate breakdown, echoed by Met Office’s Debbie Hemming, noting 1.4°C global warming and 2025 as Britain’s likely hottest year have shifted wildflower phenology.

articles.title: Country diary: A novel way to farm this ‘black desert’ | Sara Hudston
articles.trailText: Greinton, Somerset Levels : Instead of drying the peat to make it fit for agriculture, a small group of farmers have decided to work with the wet
articles.summary: In Greinton on the Somerset Levels, a group of farmers is pioneering paludiculture—cultivating reeds on peatland without drainage—to curb carbon emissions and repurpose waterlogged fields once called ‘black desert.’ They sowed Typha latifolia (bulrush) two years ago, harvesting seedheads that expand into insulating fluff. After stripping and drying, the material is sent to Bristol–based Ponda to produce BioPuff fiber for jacket linings. This perennial wetland cropping method revives soggy acres, reduces peat oxidation, and demonstrates a sustainable alternative to conventional drainage-based agriculture.

articles.title: EU’s new ‘green tariff’ rules on high-carbon goods come into force
articles.trailText: The ‘border adjustment mechanism’ aims to create a level playing field while also encouraging decarbonisation
articles.summary: From Jan 1, the EU’s carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) takes effect, obliging importers of high-carbon goods—iron, steel, aluminium, cement, hydrogen, electricity, fertilisers—to buy certificates reflecting embedded emissions or face fines. Designed to curb carbon leakage, it levels the playing field between EU and non-EU producers and supports internal decarbonisation, despite US, China and Australia objections. The UK lacks a CBAM linkage deal with Brussels, risking export charges until its own scheme launches next year. The bloc plans to widen CBAM to products using steel and aluminium from 2028.

articles.title: Greenwashing, illegality and false claims: 13 climate litigation wins in 2025
articles.trailText: Legal action has brought important decisions, from the scrapping of fossil fuel plants to revised climate plans
articles.summary: Thirteen climate litigation victories in 2025 forced greater climate accountability: Scotland’s court voided Rosebank and Jackdaw approvals; Brazil scrapped its largest coal plant; German courts opened carbon liability cases; EnergyAustralia admitted greenwashing; inter-American and ICJ recognized a human right to a healthy climate; New South Wales annulled a coal expansion; Apple dropped "carbon neutral" claims; Hawaii pledged transport emission cuts; Kenya’s Lamu coal plant licence was revoked; France fined TotalEnergies for false climate advertising; JBS and Tyson settled US greenwashing suits; the UK government revised its climate plan; and Norway’s court deemed three North Sea oil licences illegal.

articles.title: It’s easy to feel powerless about climate chaos. Here’s what gives me hope | Nina Lakhani
articles.trailText: I’ve spent six years writing about environmental justice. The uncomfortable truth is that we’re not all in it together – but people power is reshaping the fight
articles.summary: Nina Lakhani, The Guardian’s environmental justice correspondent, reflects on six years of reporting on climate chaos and inequality. Despite worsening fires, floods and food shortages, grassroots movements—from Indigenous communities to youth activists—have scored major victories in 2025. COP30 adopted the first just transition mechanism after sustained civil society protests, while 23 nations led by Colombia and the Netherlands pledged an independent fossil-fuel phaseout roadmap. Landmark ICJ and domestic court rulings now deem failure to phase out fossil fuels a rights violation. Lakhani highlights that people power, legal action and Indigenous knowledge are reshaping climate justice, putting equity at the heart of solutions.

articles.title: Seven environmental wins across the US in 2025 despite Trump-era reversals
articles.trailText: Environmental advocates notched key wins at local and state levels this year despite Trump rollbacks
articles.summary: Despite Trump-era rollbacks loosening fossil-fuel regulations and weakening endangered-species safeguards, 2025 yielded seven state and local environmental wins: California’s $100m cap-and-trade methane-tracking satellite—already one in orbit, seven more planned—spotted 10 major leaks; University of Hawaii fungi degrade >60% of polyurethane plastics and improved rates 15% in months; USDA research pins Varroa-borne viruses and amitraz-resistant mites in honeybee die-offs; Long Island Sound hypoxic “dead zones” dropped to 18.3 sq mi; UCSD’s Snap-X gel increases coral settlement 6–20×; New Mexico’s $50m wildlife crossings funding; solar-powered LED gillnets cut turtle bycatch 63%.

articles.title: ‘They didn’t de-extinct anything’: can Colossal’s genetically engineered animals ever be the real thing?
articles.trailText: The bioscience startup has attracted billions in investment – and a flurry of criticism, but founder tells the Guardian plans to bring back the woolly mammoth will not be derailed
articles.summary: Colossal Biosciences, founded by entrepreneur Ben Lamm and Harvard geneticist George Church, has garnered over $10 billion in investment by claiming to ‘de-extinct’ species such as the dire wolf, woolly mammoth, dodo, Tasmanian tiger and moa through genome editing of related modern animals. High-profile media coverage and celebrity backers fuel hype, but leading scientists argue Colossal has produced edited grey wolves and Asian elephants rather than true resurrected species, warning its overpromises risk undermining trust. Colossal insists its work boosts conservation and public engagement, while critics maintain habitat protection remains indispensable.

articles.title: Curb the cod, park the prawns: top chefs on how to swap out the ‘big five’ seafood
articles.trailText: From moules marinière to scallop, bacon and garlic butter rolls, here’s how to cast your culinary net wider and embrace more sustainable species
articles.summary: Britain’s love of cod, haddock, salmon, tuna and prawns strains marine stocks and ecosystems. Top chefs propose five underused, eco-friendly species with sustainable credentials and simple recipes to broaden palates, cut impact and support ocean health: mussels (rope-grown, purify water, boost biodiversity; steam in wine or Moroccan mouclade – Jack Stein); hake (EU recovery plan, MSC gillnet; panko crust or baked, tarragon mayo – Stein); monkfish (North Sea quotas; yoghurt-garlic-chilli marinade, bouillabaisse – Roberta Hall-McCarron); anchovies/sardines (resilient oils, bottom-of-chain; toast toppings or grilled with lemon – Hall-McCarron, Mitch Tonks); scallops (hand-dived, lighted pots; grill under butter, bacon-garlic rolls – Tonks).

articles.title: Country diary: There’s a new tenant in my rickety old greenhouse | Phil Gates
articles.trailText: Crook, County Durham: In among the dead leaves and stacks of clay flower pots is a wren, in the relative warm of its winter roost
articles.summary: In Crook, County Durham, gardener Phil Gates discovers a wren has taken up winter roost in his dilapidated greenhouse, accessible through a broken pane. Evidence of weeks-long occupancy emerges in droppings amid clay pots and dead leaves. Gates reflects on wrens as Britain’s smallest, solitary breeding birds whose striking spring courtship song belies their stealthy winter habits. As he tidies dead foliage and ivy-leaved toadflax, he decides to leave the greenhouse undisturbed until spring sowing season and sweet-pea planting resumes.

articles.title: EU legislation intended to fight deforestation has been effectively ‘dismantled’
articles.trailText: Law’s original author points to removal of obligations for downstream traders to verify origin of commodities
articles.summary: EU’s flagship deforestation regulation—designed to ban palm oil, soy, beef, rubber, cocoa and coffee linked to forest loss—has been effectively dismantled after stripping downstream traders of traceability duties. Architect Hugo Schally warns fewer data points and weaker geolocation enforcement will hamper prosecutions, while Green MEP Marie Toussaint decries exemptions for printed products and “low-risk” operators. High-risk scrutiny now covers only Russia, Belarus, North Korea and Myanmar. Early-compliant businesses lament sunk tracing-tech investments; Brussels insists revisions ensure a simple, fair and cost-efficient roll-out.

articles.title: ‘People are wrestling with the burden’: Japan pivots to focus on nuclear power ‘maximisation’ alongside renewables
articles.trailText: Post-Fukushima nuclear closures of dozens of reactors forced the country to rely heavily on imported fossil fuels
articles.summary: Japan’s government strategic energy plan aims for net zero by 2050 via nuclear “maximisation” (20% share by 2040) and 40–50% renewables, reducing coal from 63% to 30–40%. Fourteen reactors have restarted, with 30 projected. Post-Fukushima closures drove LNG (2nd-largest importer) and coal dependence. Fukushima prefecture targets 70% renewables by 2030 and 100% by 2040 through wind (46-turbine Abukuma farm), solar and geothermal (440 kW Tsuchiyu Onsen plant) using feed-in tariffs for local aquaculture. Japan cut emissions 4% in 2023–24 but drew COP30 criticism for slow decarbonisation and fossil reliance.

articles.title: Tropical Cyclone Hayley bears down on Derby in WA as man dies in north Queensland floods
articles.trailText: Category-two system brings destructive winds, heavy rain and potential for flash flooding after making landfall on Tuesday night
articles.summary: Category 2 Tropical Cyclone Hayley made landfall Tuesday night 55 km north of Derby, WA, with sustained winds of 100 km/h (gusts to 140 km/h) and potential gusts to 170 km/h, bringing destructive gales and heavy rain across the Dampier Peninsula (Beagle Bay, Cockatoo Island, Kuri Bay). Residents in caravans or older homes were urged to evacuate to centres in Broome. Preparations mirrored post-Ellie flood lessons—stock removal, tree trimming, water, fuel and supplies secured. Meanwhile, a 70-year-old man drowned in his car after heavy monsoon trough rains (up to 796 mm in 72 h) flooded Normanton in north Queensland.

articles.title: UK’s warmest spring on record led to rise in songbirds breeding, data shows
articles.trailText: Dry and warm 2025 spring gave glimmer of hope for threatened wild birds but many remain in long-term decline
articles.summary: Data from BTO’s constant effort sites scheme show Britain’s warmest, driest spring on record in 2025 boosted breeding success for 14 songbird species, including migratory chiffchaff, reed warbler and blackcap, and resident blue tit, coal tit and robin, reversing declines seen after a wet 2024. Volunteers recorded above-average nesting outcomes and likely second broods driven by mild weather. However, adult counts of some species, notably willow and garden warblers, hit record lows, underscoring long-term declines tied to habitat loss, intensive farming and climate breakdown.

articles.title: Young Atlantic salmon seen in three English rivers for first time in a decade
articles.trailText: Species that is critically endangered in Britain is spotted in Mersey, Bollin and Goyt rivers in north-west
articles.summary: Young Atlantic salmon have returned to England’s Mersey, Bollin and Goyt rivers for the first time since 2015, marking a critical conservation milestone after the species was declared critically endangered in Britain in 2023. Their successful spawning in freshwater gravel beds reflects decades of water quality improvements and habitat restoration, reversing a 30–50% population decline driven by climate change, pollution and invasive non-native species. Remaining barriers—dams, weirs and Salford Quays locks—still block access to the Tame and Irwell, spurring calls for new fish passes. The Environment Agency plans an eDNA distribution study in early 2026 to map spawning sites and track recovery progress.

articles.title: Country diary: Meet Houdini, the three-legged hedgehog who’s moved in for winter | Kate Bradbury
articles.trailText: Hove, East Sussex: I’ve had to create a halfway house for him, between the rescue centre and the wild. Only, he’s named after an escapologist for a reason
articles.summary: In Hove, East Sussex, writer Kate Bradbury looks after Houdini, a three-legged hedgehog now in what may be his eighth winter. Found with bone exposed and partially missing nose, he twice escaped en route to a rescue centre, inspiring his name. After veterinary amputation and treatments for infections and parasites, the elderly hog returns each winter to her garden, where limited food and road risks make it a vital halfway house until spring, when she hopes to expand the refuge and welcome other hedgehogs.

articles.title: Stingless bees from the Amazon granted legal rights in world first
articles.trailText: Planet’s oldest bee species and primary pollinators were under threat from deforestation and competition from ‘killer bees’
articles.summary: Peruvian Amazon stingless bees, vital pollinators underpinning over 80% of rainforest flora and cultural traditions among Asháninka and Kukama communities, became the first insects to win legal rights in world-first ordinances in Satipo and Nauta. Campaigners from Earth Law Center and Amazon Research Internacional, led by Rosa Vásquez Espinoza, documented threats from deforestation, climate change, pesticides and invasive Africanized bees, uncovered medicinal-rich honey tainted by chemicals, and mapped bee declines. The laws grant bees rights to exist, thrive, healthy habitat, representation in court and mandate reforestation, pesticide regulation, climate adaptation and scientific research—setting a global precedent.

articles.title: Queensland to continue to allow farmers to shoot flying foxes after revoking ban on controversial practice
articles.trailText: Conservationists and scientists criticise state for backtracking and say alternative non-lethal methods such as netting are more effective
articles.summary: Queensland has rescinded its 2023 decision to phase out permits allowing farmers to shoot up to 1,630 flying foxes annually—130 vulnerable grey-headed, 700 black and 800 little red—for crop protection. The original three-year ban due by July 2026 aimed to force adoption of non-lethal exclusion netting. Conservationists call the reversal “barbaric” and “ineffective,” citing slow deaths of lactating females and pups. Over 20,000 bats have died in a decade; critics demand investment in netting, arguing permits should be revoked once non-lethal options are available.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Polar wind set to end warmth in US south and midwest
articles.trailText: Spring-like weather experienced by many Americans to end, while heavy snow in Japan brings deadly conditions
articles.summary: Arctic air plunging south this week will replace record 15–20 °C-above-normal warmth in the US south and midwest with freezing temperatures and snow risk as a western ridge draws down polar air. Meanwhile, São Paulo hit a record 36.2 °C; heat is expected soon in Chile and Argentina. In Japan, Siberian westerlies over the Sea of Japan will fuel more sea-effect snow after a deadly motorway pile-up in Minakami, Gunma. New Zealand’s South Island endured torrential rain, hail, and a rare supercell; the North Island faces 100–200 mm rainfall and strong winds.

articles.title: Country diary: A rare giant in the quiet of the wood | Sarah Lambert
articles.trailText: Old Sulehay Forest, Northamptonshire: Distant church bells are about all I can hear as I stand below a 500-year-old small-leaved lime – a tree that may be making an unlikely comeback
articles.summary: In Old Sulehay Forest, Northamptonshire, Sarah Lambert marvels at a 500-year-old small-leaved lime shaped by centuries of coppicing, its sprawling fractal canopy and crown shyness set against a hushed winter wood. She evokes past soundscapes of hazel, oak and lime harvest—bark for tanning, lime wood for carving, bast fibers for rope—and notes pollen records that once made lime abundant. Now rare and seed-infertile without hot summers, recent carpets of lime seedlings offer a hopeful sign of its climatic comeback.

articles.title: The mystery of flight MH370: will a new search find the missing airliner after more than a decade?
articles.trailText: In 2014 the Malaysian Airlines jet vanished over the Indian Ocean. Now the team that located Shackleton’s Endurance is looking again with the latest undersea robots
articles.summary: More than a decade after MH370 vanished over the southern Indian Ocean, Malaysia has contracted Ocean Infinity on a $70m ‘no find, no fee’ basis to scour a 15,000 km² high-probability zone. Using Hugin 6000 AUVs—equipped with sonar, lasers, sub-bottom profilers and magnetometers—and surface-deployed ROVs for video and retrieval, the firm resumes its 55-day mission on 30 December after pausing for bad weather. Complex seabed topography, incomplete survey data and rough seas complicate detection, making precise search-area selection critical.

articles.title: Heat, drought and fire: how extreme weather pushed nature to its limits in 2025
articles.trailText: National Trust says these are ‘alarm signals we cannot ignore’ as climate breakdown puts pressure on wildlife
articles.summary: National Trust’s 2025 audit warns that back-to-back droughts and extreme weather—bookended by storms Éowyn and Bram—have pushed UK ecosystems to breaking point. A scorching spring–summer fueled wildfires across 5,000 ha of peatland at Abergwesyn Common, decimating habitats for golden plover, skylark and rare dragonflies; tufted saxifrage in Snowdonia teetered on extinction. Raptors, owls, toads, newts and seabirds (Arctic terns –30%, puffins –33%) declined, while 40% of new saplings failed and mature trees showed stress. Unseasonal blooms and late‐season wildlife movements contrast with winners like grey seals and speckled wood butterflies. A Holnicote wetland restoration spurred a heath fritillary rebound to 1,000. Urgent, joined-up climate action is essential.

articles.title: Rain, fire risk and a cyclone: flood alerts in Queensland’s north as wild weather forecast across Australia
articles.trailText: Warnings of extreme fire danger in SA regions, while Tropical Cyclone Hayley tracks towards WA
articles.summary: An entrenched monsoon trough and low-pressure system are driving 50–150 mm of additional rain across north-west and north-east Queensland, on top of 100–200 mm totals around Innisfail–Ingham and a record 369 mm at South Mission Beach. Major flood warnings remain for the Flinders River, with moderate alerts on the Cloncurry and Western rivers. SES crews logged 34 flood-related calls and delivered supplies to stranded tourists near Cloncurry. Meanwhile, extreme fire danger prompts total bans in SA’s Mount Lofty Ranges and Eyre Peninsula, and active fires at Second Valley, Blanchetown and Meningie. Tropical Cyclone Hayley, packing 85 km/h winds and gusts to 120 km/h, is forecast to make landfall near the Dampier Peninsula by New Year’s Eve, bringing damaging winds, heavy rain and storm surge. Australia’s national temperature is now about 1.5 °C above 1910 levels, a trend intensifying extreme weather events.

articles.title: ‘It brings you closer to the natural world’: the rise of the Merlin birdsong identifying app
articles.trailText: Merlin has been trained to identify the songs of more than 1,300 bird species around the world
articles.summary: Merlin Bird ID, developed by Cornell’s Lab of Ornithology, uses machine-learning on spectrogram patterns to recognize songs from over 1,300 bird species worldwide. Launched in 2021, its sound-ID feature has driven 33 million downloads across 240 countries, with US and 1.5 million UK users (up 88 % year-on-year). Beginners cite rapid progress in species recognition and mental-health benefits, while experts praise engagement but warn of misidentifications (e.g. non-local species, chaffinch vs redstart) and overreliance. Twice-yearly model updates aim to improve accuracy and habitat context.

articles.title: London Eye architect proposes 14-mile tidal power station off Somerset coast
articles.trailText: West Somerset Lagoon would harness renewable energy for UK’s AI boom – and create ‘iconic’ arc around Bristol Channel
articles.summary: Julia Barfield, London Eye architect, leads an £11bn plan for a 14-mile West Somerset Lagoon off Minehead-Watchet, deploying 125 tidal turbines to generate 2.5GW—powering 2m homes and feeding data centres amid surging AI demand. The semi-circular barrage would host a cycle-walker path, marina, lido, observation tower, renewable aquaculture and potential embedded data storage cooled by seawater. Backed by MP Rachel Gilmour and investors, the 120-year project seeks government support, aiming to outlast nuclear costs, boost Minehead’s deprived economy and harness the Bristol Channel’s predictable tides.

articles.title: ‘Ghost resorts’: as hundreds of ski slopes lie abandoned, will nature reclaim the Alps?
articles.trailText: With the snow line edging higher, 186 French ski resorts have shut, while global heating threatens dozens more
articles.summary: French Alps’ Céüze 2000 closed in 2018 after unreliable snowfall cut its season to six weeks and annual losses reached €450K. It is among 186 permanently shut French ski resorts and over 3,000 derelict mountain structures—pylons, cabins and war relics—many leaching asbestos, oil and rust into soil. French law mandates removal of lifts built post-2017, but most rot in situ. Dismantling of Céüze began in Nov 2025 at €123K cost; early regenerative flora and returning wildlife illustrate debates over memorialising ghost stations versus restoring wild Alps as climate change and 2°C warming threaten lower-altitude skiing.

articles.title: Defunding fungi: US’s living library of ‘vital ecosystem engineers’ is in danger of closing
articles.trailText: These fungi boost plant growth and restore depleted ecosystems, but federal funding for a library housing them has been cut – and it may be forced to close
articles.summary: At the University of Kansas, the International Collection of Vesicular Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi (INVAM) houses over 900 living strains of symbiotic soil fungi that support 70% of land plants, boost nutrients, buffer stress and drive ecosystem restoration and carbon sequestration. Established in 1985, INVAM’s meticulous annual culturing enables critical research and high-quality biofertilizers, in stark contrast to failing commercial products. Its current US National Science Foundation funding lapses soon amid proposed budget cuts, threatening closure within a year. Scientists warn losing INVAM would cripple studies on mycorrhizal diversity, regenerative agriculture and habitat recovery.

articles.title: Four species, 160 days, 50,000 images: meet the photographer dedicated to showing the lovable side of flying foxes
articles.trailText: Doug Gimesy’s extreme close-ups of ‘sky puppies’ are designed to trigger an emotional response that endears people to the ‘wrongly vilified’ mammals
articles.summary: Wildlife photographer Doug Gimesy spent over 160 days in the field and captured 50,000 images of Australia’s four mainland flying-fox species, using extreme close-ups to reveal their puppy-like faces, maternal bonds and quirky behaviours—from wings as sunshades to baby blankets. His evocative shots, endorsed by bat experts Merlin Tuttle and Matthew Mo, showcase flying-foxes’ vital pollination role and highlight threats from habitat loss, urban conflict and illegal persecution. Gimesy’s book Life Upside Down brings these ‘sky puppies’ into schools to foster empathy, understanding and stronger conservation support.

articles.title: From gifts that last to sustainable swaps, how we’re encouraging more thoughtful spending
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: as we head into 2026, we’ll be testing products to help you cut waste and lighten your load on the planet
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Filter section champions sustainable consumerism through tried-and-tested gift guides—ethical presents for mums, cyclists and teens, analog items and durable picks from reader and writer feedback—to curb Christmas excess and post-holiday guilt. We’ve evaluated overpriced Advent calendars, artificial trees (seven-to-20-year Carbon Trust footprint), festive foods and reusable crackers, plus run durability tests on mattresses, kettles, coffee machines and more. Offering repair, secondhand and refurb insights alongside leftover and waste-reduction tips, the newsletter equips readers for conscious, lower-impact spending. In 2026, expect deeper dives into sustainable swaps, product longevity, and clear advice on what not to buy.

articles.title: Living on the edge: what young people in England told us about life on the coast
articles.trailText: As part of the Guardian’s Against the tide series, readers aged 18 to 30 share what they love about living in their coastal town, the challenges and why they often choose to leave
articles.summary: In Guardian’s 'Against the tide' series, 18–30-year-olds from six English coastal towns reflect on local life: on the Isle of Wight, seasonal hospitality jobs, scarce affordable housing, a retiree boom and pressure to 'leave to succeed'; in Berwick-upon-Tweed, strong community bonds yet few jobs push graduates away; Great Yarmouth’s conservative culture alienates LGBTQ+ creatives who depart; Ilfracombe’s high deprivation and housing costs mean few sustainable careers without family support; and Eastbourne parents warn kids to 'get out' amid unfulfilled promises of renewal.

articles.title: First of nine new river walks in England announced for north-west
articles.trailText: Mersey Valley Way takes in Manchester and Stockport on its 13-mile route with other walks to be identified in 2026
articles.summary: Mersey Valley Way, a 21km route through Greater Manchester and Stockport, is the first of nine national river walks pledged by government to boost nature access across English regions by parliament’s end. While no new footpath is created, this initiative funds path upgrades, accessibility enhancements for wheelchairs, scooters, prams, cyclists, riders, signage and community nature recovery. Next river walk locations will be chosen via a 2026 competition. The area, home to 30,000 low-income Stockport households, was selected to tackle disparities in outdoor access, says Access Minister Lady Hayman.

articles.title: Staying at home could leave you exposed to indoor air pollution, study reveals
articles.trailText: Secondhand tobacco smoke and routine tasks such as operating the stove shown to be biggest emitters of indoor pollution in UK homes
articles.summary: Indoor smoking bans cut heart attack admissions by 12%, yet routine home tasks also spike pollutants. University of Nottingham measured 20 UK homes for four weeks, finding Defra-approved wood stoves trigger sharp particle peaks during lighting, refuelling and door-opening—results confirmed by studies in southeast England and Cornwall. Researchers advise less frequent, slower refuelling, avoiding fires near vulnerable people, and skipping stoves on low-wind or poor air quality days. Separately, Prof Sarah West’s Bradford study of 310 homes identifies frying as a major source; ‘pan on, fan on,’ extractor use and opening windows when cooking or cleaning can markedly reduce indoor pollution.

articles.title: Country diary: Little rituals to help sparrows and wrens | Paul Evans
articles.trailText: The Marches, Shropshire: Boxing Day has its own more violent customs between humans and animals. That’s not the world I choose to live in
articles.summary: On Boxing Day in the Marches near Oswestry, Paul Evans transforms a backyard bird table—fat balls, seed and mealworms—into a communal haven for over 30 sparrows, whose “telepathic” panic flight reveals complex social bonds with blue tits, robins, jackdaws, collared doves, blackbirds, wood pigeons and wrens. Echoing a revived wren procession once tied to Cutty Wren folklore, these small rituals—feeding endangered sparrows and honoring wrens—embody “what ought to be,” a compassionate alternative to traditional Boxing Day wildlife pageantry.

articles.title: ‘All you need are your eyes’: a stretch of Victorian shore is a magnet for fossil fossickers
articles.trailText: Experts and novices alike hunt for specimens that could change our understanding of evolution – and all only a short day trip from Melbourne
articles.summary: Between the cliffs and the sea at Jan Juc on Victoria’s Surf Coast, powerful swells expose 25-million-year-old fossils—whale bones, shark teeth and early baleen whales like Janjucetus. Experts (Fitzgerald, Long) and amateurs alike can day-trip from Melbourne, scanning beaches without tools, recording finds via photo and GPS, then reporting specimens to Museums Victoria or Found a Fossil. Victoria’s diverse geology yields fossils from Cambrian to Recent: dinosaurs at Inverloch and Bass Coast (ornithopods, ankylosaurs, plesiosaurs), ancient plants, graptolites and Australia’s earliest amniote footprints. Public involvement is crucial: permits guard protected sites, but casual fossicking underpins ongoing discoveries.

articles.title: UK electric car charger rollout slows amid worries over EV switch
articles.trailText: Smallest number of new chargers since 2022 as carmakers persuade government to weaken EV sales targets
articles.summary: The UK installed just 13,500 new EV chargers to November 2025 (87,200 total), marking under 20% growth—the weakest since 2022. EVs made up 23% of new car sales, but slower uptake led carmakers to lobby for weaker zero-emission mandates; a 2028 3p/mile EV levy adds consumer and investor uncertainty. Slow chargers rose 15% to 48,100 and ultra-rapids jumped 39% to 9,800. Rising installation costs, grid bottlenecks and delayed LEVI funding stall rollouts—especially in Northern Ireland, the East Midlands and north-east—though public network supply remains 1½ years ahead of demand.

articles.title: Plant ‘tredges’ to boost England’s tree cover, gardeners urged
articles.trailText: Royal Horticultural Society’s call backs government aim to increase woodland cover from 10% to at least 16.5% by 2050
articles.summary: To help England raise woodland cover from 10% to 16.5% by 2050, the RHS urges gardeners to plant native 'tredges'—tree-hedges like Crataegus laevigata—drawing on ancient-woodland indicators. At Chelsea Flower Show, Ashleigh Aylett’s 'Forgotten Forests' garden will model layered canopies, transitional ecotones and indicator plants, showing how small gardens can boost biodiversity, improve soil, capture pollutants and reduce flood risk. The RHS advises using UKISG-sourced species and diverse roots, and relocating the exhibit post-show to a Newcastle school in a low-canopy area.

articles.title: Crayfish, weevils and fungi released in UK to tackle invasive species such as Japanese knotweed
articles.trailText: Scientists working for government breed biological control agents in lab to take on species choking native wildlife
articles.summary: Under Defra’s environmental plan to halve invasive species by 2030, UK government scientists are breeding and releasing biological control agents—South American weevils to curb floating pennywort, psyllid Aphalara itadori for Japanese knotweed, and Puccinia rust fungus against Himalayan balsam. These biocontrols reduce manual labour and spread naturally. Meanwhile, ‘ark’ hatcheries and protected sites in Yorkshire, Devon and Gloucestershire safeguard native white-clawed crayfish from invasive signal crayfish and plague, relocating over 1,500 individuals. Officials also warn pet raccoons and raccoon dogs risk establishing in the wild, threatening biodiversity and biosecurity.

articles.title: Something gnawed your oak tree? Sink hole in your road? How Zurich’s beaver hotline is reassuring residents
articles.trailText: As the number of the semi-aquatic creatures soars so can tensions. But the Swiss have a tried and tested system to calm the neighbours and restore harmony
articles.summary: Zurich’s Beaver Advisory Centre fields 10–20 calls weekly via a dedicated hotline to resolve conflicts as Switzerland’s beaver population rose from 1,600 in 2008 to 4,900 by 2022. Ecologists assess damage—sinkholes, felled trees costing up to CHF70,000 per event—advise protective measures (wire guards, dam trimming) and allocate compensation from a CHF1 million prevention fund. Unlike culling practices in Bavaria or Poland, Swiss policy bans lethal control, emphasizing state-backed management to maintain public acceptance. Beaver dams, while locally disruptive, reduce downstream flood risk and boost biodiversity, exemplified by 60× increases in species at rewilded Marthalen wetlands.

articles.title: Country diary: Welcome to the woods where bomber aircraft once hid | Jennifer Jones
articles.trailText: Speke, Merseyside: Walking through Stockton’s Wood today, you’d never know it played such a vital role in the second world war
articles.summary: Stockton’s Wood, adjacent to Speke Hall in Speke, Merseyside, conceals a remarkable WWII legacy: this ancient woodland, now an official deadwood conservation site, hosts veteran oak, coppiced silver birch, a diversity of mosses, slime mould, bracket and candlesnuff fungi. Today it’s valued by ecologists as a biodiversity hotspot and by historians as a hidden wartime archive. Originally planted with Scots pine for Victorian game shooting—its evergreen canopy embossing the sky—casual passersby remain unaware that RAF Speke’s shadow factory hid P-51 Mustang fighters and Halifax bombers among its cover. Decades of regrowth—wind-thrown birch embraced by sycamore and snowdrops amid molehills—now cloak these secrets beneath Liverpool John Lennon Airport’s flight path.

articles.title: Organ-tuning books in English churches provide notes on a warming climate
articles.trailText: Researchers have realised the records are a ‘goldmine’ to study changes in environmental conditions
articles.summary: Nottingham Trent University researchers have unearthed 18 organ-tuning books from churches in London, Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire, dating back to 1966, containing regular temperature and humidity logs. Their preliminary analysis reveals winter and summer church interiors have warmed—summer averages rising from 17.2 °C in the late 1960s to 19.8 °C by the 2020s—attributed to both increased heating and broader climate change. Tuners’ annotations on organ damage and pitch shifts underscore the instruments’ sensitivity to climate. The team urges owners to share further tuning records as novel historical climate proxies.

articles.title: ‘Unashamedly capitalist’ rewilders claim ‘Moneyball’ approach could make millions – but experts sceptical
articles.trailText: Rich Stockdale says model of ‘regenerative capitalism’ would maximise profits by planting trees, restoring peatlands, and installing windfarms across its estates
articles.summary: Rich Stockdale’s Exeter-based Oxygen Conservation has acquired 13 UK estates (50,000 acres) to deploy an “unashamedly capitalist” rewilding model—planting trees, restoring peatland, running solar and wind farms, holiday lets and issuing premium carbon/biodiversity credits. Using Lidar, thermal imaging and photogrammetry for a data-driven “Moneyball” approach, it aims to sell 2m tonnes of credits at up to £180/t to deliver 15% yields. Critics warn of heavy borrowing (£106m loans, £20.5m estate-linked debt), speculative land commodification, local opposition and opaque deal terms despite claims of £300m asset value.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Further flood watches issued across California
articles.trailText: Heavy rain and mountain snow forecast for northern and central parts, with river and flooding likely in Los Angeles
articles.summary: Atmospheric rivers will bring 50-75 mm more rain and heavy mountain snow across northern and central California this week, driving flood watches through Friday and raising cumulative totals to 200–300 mm in parts of the northwest and Sierra slopes by Boxing Day. Los Angeles could record 100–150 mm between Dec 24–25, risking river and urban flooding, mudslides and rockslides. Yosemite faces 6–8 ft of snow. Zimbabwe is under a level 2 warning for hail, lightning and over 50 mm of rain from Dec 21–24, while Australia sees temperatures plunge from 40 °C to 22 °C in Sydney and rise to 40 °C in Perth over Christmas.

articles.title: 2025 is ‘year of the octopus’ as record numbers spotted off England’s south coast
articles.trailText: Milder weather led to a bloom in the invertebrates off the coast of Cornwall and south Devon, wildlife charity says
articles.summary: Wildlife Trusts declared 2025 the “year of the octopus” after a mild winter and warm spring triggered a bloom of common (Mediterranean) octopuses along England’s south coast, with 233,000 caught—13 times the normal haul in Cornwall—and groups filmed walking and gathering. Such blooms last occurred in 1950; another may recur in 2026. The review also noted record grey seal and puffin counts, a rare sea slug in Yorkshire, a Mediterranean blenny in Sussex, and two major pollution incidents.

articles.title: Country diary: A seal so close I can see its nostrils flaring | Tom Allan
articles.trailText: River Dart, Devon: It probably came here for the shoals of grey mullet, but just for a second, it’s more interested in me and my paddleboard
articles.summary: On a rare calm morning on the River Dart in Devon, Tom Allan pushes upriver on his stand-up paddleboard, slicing through debris and the ebb tide. Bent double against the current, he glances back to find a grey seal less than a paddle’s length away, whiskers bristling, nostrils flaring, its moon-pocked back reflecting the soft light. It follows the shoals of mullet upstream, then slips away so smoothly he wonders if it now swims beneath his board—all while he battles the river’s pull.

articles.title: ‘Miracle’ of Zealandia: chick is born to rare takahē pair thought to be infertile
articles.trailText: Unexpected arrival is a boon for birdlife in New Zealand, where there are only 500 takahē left
articles.summary: At Zealandia, Wellington’s 225-hectare urban eco-sanctuary, staff discovered in November a roughly seven-week-old chick hatched by Bendigo and Waitaa, a takahē pair previously deemed infertile after a failed 2024 nesting. The bird, sporting fuzzy black down and oversized white legs, was confirmed via trail-camera footage and kept secret to ensure its safety. With only 500 species members left, this “miracle” chick—New Zealand’s largest living rail—marks a vital boost for the longest-running takahē recovery programme. The sex is unknown; at three months it will resemble an adult takahē.

articles.title: Tony Edwards obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Environmental scientist involved in protecting and enhancing the natural world in harmony with industry, across Yorkshire and the Humber
