articles.summary: Tony Edwards, who died aged 77 of cancer, spent 50 years in the Yorkshire and Humber environmental sector, promoting eco-engineering and nature-based solutions like managed realignment. A geography graduate (King’s College London) with a PhD from UEA, he led water quality and resource planning at Yorkshire Water Authority before managing rivers, pollution regulation and flood risk for four million people at the National Rivers Authority and Environment Agency. He lectured in environmental management at the University of Hull and served as CEO of the Humber Nature Partnership (2004-11), uniting industry, authorities and NGOs. Remembered for his integrity, warmth and commitment to balancing conservation and development. Survived by three cousins.

articles.title: The plants that thrive in salt: could halophytes help save coastal farming?
articles.trailText: As rising seas salinise the soils of the Venice lagoon, scientists and chefs are turning to long-forgotten wild herbs
articles.summary: On Sant’Erasmo island in the Venice lagoon, rising sea levels, higher temperatures and reduced rainfall are salinising soils, endangering violet artichokes and other crops. FAO estimates 10% of global land is already salinised, rising to 24–32%. Researchers at the Tidal Garden and University of Pisa are trialling halophytes—sea fennel, samphire, purslane and glasswort—that thrive in 1–1.6% brackish water. Intercropping these herbs with tomatoes improved yields and soil health without sacrificing cash-crop land. Chefs and artists are rebranding halophytes in pizzas, sorbets and gourmet dishes to drive local demand and climate-resilient agriculture.

articles.title: Snails on a plane: Australia flies rescue mission to Norfolk Island for a tiny, critically endangered species
articles.trailText: The Campbell’s keeled glass-snail is officially extinct, but researchers have ‘high hopes’ that translocation will allow the population to thrive
articles.summary: In June researchers airlifted 340 captive-bred Campbell’s keeled glass-snails to Norfolk Island, part of Australia’s first large-scale snail reintroduction. Once declared extinct, the species was rediscovered in 2020 by a citizen scientist. Captive breeding at Taronga Zoo overcame transport stress, boosting numbers to over 800 by 2024. After a mould outbreak killed 260, survivors were acclimated then released into a restored gully with irrigation and predator control. Early monitoring shows dispersal and wild births, prompting further releases and an IUCN status update.

articles.title: This year’s Christmas could be Britain’s greenest yet, energy operator says
articles.trailText: System operator Neso predicts lowest carbon intensity ever on Christmas Day after new wind and solar power come online
articles.summary: Neso forecasts 2025 Christmas Day could see Britain’s lowest ever carbon intensity for electricity, pending mild, windy weather. With an extra 2 GW of wind and 3 GW of solar added this year, renewables capacity has climbed to 53 GW. The 2023 record—30 million grams of CO₂—could be beaten as last April’s grid peak was 97.7% zero-carbon. Over 40% of 2024’s Christmas generation was green (vs 1.7% in 2009), and turbines once powered enough to light “nearly 3 billion” LED strings. Despite cleaner power, UK households discarded 168 million light-up items, while 1.1 billion gadgets and 450 million batteries end up as waste. Neso estimates net-zero spending will peak at £460 billion by 2029.

articles.title: Country diary: There’s more to mistletoe than Christmas kisses | Kate Blincoe
articles.trailText: Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk: Wildlife seems to like it as much as we do, and if you’re patient, you can make like a mistle thrush and spread it around
articles.summary: At Caistor St Edmund in Norfolk, winter’s sculptural trees reveal evergreen mistletoe—a hemiparasite that taps host xylem with haustoria while photosynthesizing. Once revered in Greek myth and druidic fertility rites, modern mistletoe is ecologically crucial: supporting mistle thrushes, mistletoe marble moths, and boosting woodland species richness by 20%. Birds disperse its sticky seeds by wiping berries onto branches; germination takes months. The author collects sprigs and manually rubs seeds onto an apple tree, noting that while some spread festive cheer, she propagates a keystone parasite with year-round significance.

articles.title: The rise of ‘beaver bombing’ across Europe | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof George Holmes and Gabriel Rowland say illicit releases need to be included in our conversations about which species belong in the UK, and who gets to decide this
articles.summary: George Holmes and Gabriel Rowland argue that recent wild beaver sightings in Norfolk and Berkshire reflect a 25-year trend of ‘beaver bombing’, illicit releases of beavers across Europe to bypass bureaucratic obstacles around reintroduction. Genetic analysis ties them to Bavarian stock. Similar unlicensed releases of pine martens, polecats, wildcats and amphibians have occurred in the UK; Scotland requires permits, most other nations don’t. Proponents hail these acts as biodiversity restoration; critics warn of disease risks, ecological disruption and debates over nativity. The authors call for illicit releases to feature in discussions on UK species management and authority.

articles.title: Food becoming more calorific but less nutritious due to rising carbon dioxide
articles.trailText: Researchers noticed ‘dramatic’ changes in nutrients in crops, including drop in zinc and rise in lead
articles.summary: Meta-analysis of ~60,000 measurements across 43 crops from 350ppm to 550ppm CO2 shows average 3.2% nutrient declines, dramatic 37.5% zinc drop in chickpeas and lower protein, zinc and iron in rice and wheat. While yields rise, crops become more calorific, less nutrient-dense and can accumulate more lead. The team established a linear CO2 effect method to unify small paired experiments, noting current CO2 at 425ppm already affects food quality. Researchers warn of “hidden hunger”, call for diet adjustments, breeding programs and further research. Published in Global Change Biology.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Early snowfall in New York and a storm ruins Christmas lights in Spain
articles.trailText: Long Island receives 21cm of snow, while a tornado tears down decorations near Málaga
articles.summary: A Canadian cold front and eastward low-pressure system dumped early snow across New England this week: 21cm fell on Long Island—the earliest total in New York since 2018—while Central Park saw a few centimetres and upstate counties received heavier accumulations. Simultaneously, Storm Emilia tore through southern Spain, generating an 80 mph tornado in La Cala de Mijas, Málaga, that destroyed £67,000 of Christmas lights along the high street and caused around £500,000 in total damage. Wind shear between warm, moist low-level air and colder, drier upper winds created a horizontal rotating tube which, when tilted by an updraft into a vertical mesocyclone and wrapped by downdrafts, intensified into the localized, debris-shifting tornado column.

articles.title: As the US invests in fossil fuels, young climate activists push back in the courts
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: A generation is using the legal system to demand accountability for climate harm
articles.summary: Rikki Held, 24, and other Montana youths won Held v Montana in August 2023, a state judge ruling that Montana’s pro-fossil fuel policies violated their constitutional rights. After the state Supreme Court affirmed the decision late last year, legislators passed new laws defying it. Last week they petitioned the court to enforce the original ruling. Represented by Our Children’s Trust, US youths also sued the Trump administration in May 2025 over energy emergency orders, filed appeals after dismissals, launched suits in Wisconsin and Utah and petitioned the Inter-American Commission, undeterred by setbacks like Juliana v. United States.

articles.title: UK’s largest proposed datacentre ‘understating planned water use’
articles.trailText: Analysis suggests consumption at Northumberland site could be 50 times higher than US operator QTS estimates
articles.summary: The proposed QTS hyperscale datacentre in Cambois, Northumberland—approved by the county council—claims just 2.3 m litres/year of direct water use via a closed-loop “water-free” cooling system. But applying Alex de Vries-Gao’s AI power-to-water methodology, Watershed Investigations and the Guardian estimate indirect water consumption at 124 m litres in phase one and up to 621 m litres annually at full build—enough for 11,000 people. Experts warn this fails to account for embedded water in electricity generation and local air pollution from near-600 diesel backup generators, urging transparency on indirect water and emissions akin to carbon‐footprint disclosure.

articles.title: Country diary: Postcard from a pier, where brent geese are the main attraction | Lev Parikian
articles.trailText: Ryde, Isle of Wight: Lots of commotion here among the hovercraft and herring gulls, but it’s the wonderful, tubby geese that make my winter
articles.summary: At Ryde on the Isle of Wight, off-season resort ambience meets wildlife at a deflated hovercraft and pier where 10 Brent geese join dozens more on mudflats feeding on eelgrass, samphire and sea aster as the tide retreats. These tubby, graphite-bodied, white-arsed geese migrate from Siberia in family groups, mate for life and telegraph a low “warrup” call. A vigilant gander wards off intruders. Meanwhile herring gulls, starlings and a pied wagtail animate the promenade, marking the geese as winter’s main attraction.

articles.title: They survived wildfires. But something else is killing Greece’s iconic fir forests
articles.trailText: In the Peloponnese mountains, the usually hardy trees are turning brown even where fires haven’t reached. Experts are raising the alarm on a complex crisis
articles.summary: In Greece’s Peloponnese, hardy Greek firs are turning brown across hundreds of hectares beyond burned zones, victims of an emerging crisis where prolonged drought, declining snowpack and bark beetle outbreaks compound wildfire damage. Senior researcher Dimitrios Avtzis flagged unprecedented die-offs caused by weakened soils and insect infestations, a pattern mirrored across southern Europe. While climatologist Nikos Markos highlights the region’s regenerative potential, recovery may take five years. Experts urge the Greek government to secure funding, mobilize forest services and implement long-term interventions to counter accelerating climate pressures on high-altitude forests.

articles.title: ‘You learn tricks to reduce it’: the smart bins measuring food waste in South Korea
articles.trailText: Digital facilities that track wastage down to the gram have brought about behavioural change among users
articles.summary: South Korea has cut food waste recycling to 96.8% of 4.81 M t in 2023 using RFID-enabled pay-as-you-throw bins since 2020, charging 130 won/kg via resident cards in Seoul’s 27 289 units. Food scraps are shredded, dewatered and processed into biogas, compost or animal feed, reducing daily waste by 23.9% citywide (51% in some blocks). 81.6% of apartment dwellers use bins, incentivising moisture extraction at home and frequent disposal to curb odour. Nationally, 150.7 k bins serve 8.54 M apartment households in 186 municipalities, though smaller localities face funding gaps. Programme expansion to 90% coverage by 2030 and a 2026 point-reward plan aim for 20% further cuts. Challenges include municipal funding and machine corrosion.

articles.title: ‘Massive disruption’: UK’s worst-case climate crisis scenarios revealed by scientists
articles.trailText: Scientists say government must prepare for unlikely but ‘plausible’ 4C rise in temperature and a 2-metre rise in sea levels
articles.summary: Researchers led by Nigel Arnell outline low-probability but plausible UK climate ‘worst-case’ scenarios: up to 4°C mean warming by 2100 with severe heatwaves and droughts; a 6°C regional cooling if the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation collapses, disrupting agriculture and energy demand; and a 2–2.2 m sea-level rise from rapid ice-sheet loss inundating coastal cities. Monthly extremes could see +6°C hotspots and triple-normal rainfall. Published in Earth’s Future and commissioned by the Met Office, these stress-test scenarios aim to inform long-term infrastructure, flood defences, adaptation planning and emissions policy.

articles.title: Country diary: The clock is ticking for these colourful castaways | Claire Stares
articles.trailText: Hayling Island, Hampshire: Piles of goose barnacles are stranded on the beach after a long journey hitched on a barrel. They’re fascinating creatures, but they won’t survive long
articles.summary: On Hayling Island, Hampshire, storm-tossed debris including a blue barrel beached, revealing a dense cluster of Lepas anatifera goose barnacles. These tropical-subtropical crustaceans hitchhike on floating objects, their heart-shaped capitula and orange-edged plates reminiscent of barnacle geese breeding myths. Ranging 1–8 cm on flexible peduncles and feeding via feathered cirri, most struggled out of water, closing shells to conserve moisture. Stranded for days with no hope of refloat, the barnacles’ fate underscores ocean current drift, marine fragility, and plastic pollution’s unintended ecosystems.

articles.title: ‘It’s an open invasion’: how millions of quagga mussels changed Lake Geneva for ever
articles.trailText: The molluscs are decimating food chains in Switzerland, have devastated the Great Lakes in North America, and this week were spotted in Northern Ireland for the first time
articles.summary: In Lake Geneva quagga mussels, detected in 2014, have exploded to densities exceeding 35,000 per m2, clogging EPFL’s deep-water cooling intakes and jeopardizing critical systems (air conditioning, data centers, experimental fusion Tokamak), as well as municipal drinking-water and airport pipelines. Their year-round spawning and 30-year lifespan allow colonization to 250m depth, where they outcompete native snails, shrimps and plankton, collapse the food web and increase water clarity, driving deeper warming and algal blooms. With no means to eradicate established populations—and the first UK sighting in Northern Ireland—Geneva must build a closed-loop cooling network (2027–32). Lake Geneva’s ecology is irreversibly transformed.

articles.title: Met Office: 2026 will bring heat more than 1.4C above preindustrial levels
articles.trailText: Forecast is slightly cooler than the record 1.55C reached in 2024, but 2026 set to be among four hottest years since 1850
articles.summary: Met Office projects 2026 global temperatures will range 1.34°C–1.58°C above 1850–1900 levels, ranking among the four hottest years since 1850 and marking the fourth straight year above 1.4°C. Though slightly cooler than 2024’s record 1.55°C overshoot—the first temporary breach of 1.5°C—the forecast underscores accelerating warming from greenhouse gas emissions and extreme weather hazards. With 2025 set to be the second or third-hottest year, scientists warn of looming tipping points, failing carbon sinks and jeopardized climate stability as fossil fuel pollution persists. Copernicus reports 2025 anomalies matched 2023’s 1.48°C rise, highlighting the fragile race to curb warming despite the 30-year averaging of the Paris 1.5°C goal.

articles.title: Warmers and Shelley to get through winter | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Raynaud’s syndrome | What follows winter | Beaver bones | Honda Jazz | Maga | Lager
articles.summary: Readers share winter coping tips and reflections: Clare Passingham recommends rechargeable HotRox hand warmers to relieve Raynaud’s syndrome in cold weather; Jacqueline Noble cites Shelley’s line “If Winter comes, can Spring be far behind?” as succinct advice; Jeremy Haslam recounts finding ninth-century beaver bones in Berkshire, evidencing historical beaver ponds; Susan Treagus celebrates her fourth Honda Jazz and anticipates the “no night driving” stage; Paula McKinney quips that “Maga” fits life’s four stages, while Toby Wood jests that composer Steve Clarke likely forgets his childhood. The letters section welcomes readers’ views.

articles.title: These migrants grow the US’s Christmas trees. Trump’s wage cuts may keep them away
articles.trailText: Legal temporary farm workers also worry about the H-2A visa program and Trump’s anti-immigration regime
articles.summary: At Wolf Creek Tree Farm in western North Carolina, hundreds of Mexican H-2A visa holders work year-round to grow and harvest Fraser fir Christmas trees—North Carolina’s leading agricultural crop—despite gruelling hours, pesticide exposure, isolation and fear under the Trump administration’s anti-immigration policies. New Department of Labor guidelines propose cutting H-2A wages by $5-$7/hr, threatening both worker incomes (who remit earnings to families) and the state’s $144m annual tree sales. Growers like René Beutell warn labour shortages could devastate rural economies. Advocates and nonprofits report musculoskeletal injuries, mental-health struggles, and rising anxiety over ICE activity and wage cuts that may deter experienced crews.

articles.title: Greek tragedy: the rare seals hiding in caves to escape tourists
articles.trailText: Greece is hoping that protected areas will help keep daytrippers away and allow vulnerable monk seals to return to their island habitats
articles.summary: Deep in the Alonissos National Park, vulnerable Mediterranean monk seals—one of the world’s rarest marine mammals—now haul out in sea caves to escape unregulated tourist boats. Greece, home to roughly 500 of the under-1,000 global population, has doubled numbers since the 1990s through rehabilitation and strict reserves. But growing leisure traffic in key habitats like Piperi and Formicula is displacing mothers and endangering pups. New large-scale marine protected areas and 200m no-entry zones were announced in 2024, yet NGOs warn enforcement is weak. Conservationists stress urgent investment in patrols and robust management to secure the species’ fragile recovery.

articles.title: Police investigate after white-tailed eagles go missing across UK
articles.trailText: Conservationists appeal to public for help after rare birds disappear in suspicious circumstances
articles.summary: Police forces in Sussex, Wales and Scotland are probing the suspicious disappearances of three reintroduced white-tailed eagles, including one of the first to fledge in England in centuries. Satellite trackers were deliberately cut and dumped, prompting the RSPB to offer a £10,000 reward and the National Wildlife Crime Unit to assist. Conservationists warn this illegal persecution threatens the government-backed reintroduction scheme that has released 45 eagles since 2019, with several wild breeding pairs established. Authorities urge anyone with information to come forward.

articles.title: Country diary: Windowless windows into our industrial past | Derek Niemann
articles.trailText: Frome, Somerset: Suddenly armed with a novella’s-worth of information about this derelict ironworks, we set about getting to know it, room by room
articles.summary: Near Frome in Somerset, Derek Niemann revisits the derelict Ironbridge ironworks decades after first glimpsing its roofless furnaces, collapsed walls and chimney reclaiming by birch forests. A new, towering information panel delivers novella-length insights on 19th-century spade and sickle production, revealing lifelong health sacrifices as workers rarely survived past forty. Guided by its sections, Niemann follows cliff-face forges, blackened hearth niches and humic layers, pausing to recover a heavy, purplish iron bloom he found amid mouse droppings—a tactile reminder of industrial labor, memory and nature’s stealthy reclamation.

articles.title: ‘Magical’ galaxy frogs disappear after reports of photographers destroying their habitats
articles.trailText: Researcher in Kerala rainforest sounds alarm after being told frogs had died after being handled by humans
articles.summary: Endangered Melanobatrachus indicus (“galaxy frog”), the only species in its family, has disappeared from Kerala’s Western Ghats after trespassing photographers destroyed its microhabitat. ZSL fellow Rajkumar K P found seven individuals in 2020 but, returning post-Covid, discovered overturned logs, trampled vegetation and zero survivors. Trackers revealed photographers uprooted logs and handled frogs without gloves, killing at least two. Forest officials’ bans were undermined by visitors using political clout. ZSL experts warn this tiny, star-spotted amphibian represents an ancient, irreplaceable lineage and urge ethical wildlife photography to protect its future.

articles.title: Common household rat poisons found to pose unacceptable risk to wildlife as animal advocates push for ban
articles.trailText: Environmentalists say proposed temporary suspension of second-generation anticoagulant rodenticides ‘doesn’t go far enough’
articles.summary: A government review concluded that widely sold first- and second-generation anticoagulant rat poisons endanger native wildlife—tawny frogmouths, powerful owls and quolls show lethal residues. The APVMA will cancel some products (powder/liquid baits without dyes or bitterants) and suspend SGARs pending public consultation, but allow wax, pellet and block formulations under tighter labelling, pack-size and usage conditions. Environment groups and researchers say partial measures won’t prevent secondary poisoning and call for a full sale ban. Final rules follow a three-month feedback period.

articles.title: ‘No water, no life’: Iraq’s Tigris River in danger of disappearing
articles.trailText: Unless urgent action is taken life will be fundamentally altered for the ancient communities who live on its banks
articles.summary: Sheikh Nidham Kreidi al-Sabahi, a 68-year-old Mandaean leader in Amarah, relies on the Tigris for ritual purity. Once central to Mesopotamia’s cradle of civilization, the Tigris, now polluted by sewage, agricultural and industrial runoff, has lost a third of its flow to Turkish and Iranian dams. Iraq’s decayed water infrastructure, drought and overuse exacerbate contamination, causing health crises and threatening ancient communities. A recent oil-for-water accord with Turkey aims to restore the river but faces criticism over its non-binding terms and lack of detail. Urgent action is needed.

articles.title: Country diary: Here’s the charm of the goldfinch – we want them to be near us | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Hogshaw, Derbyshire : They’re in our paintings, in our folklore. A little opportunistic planting and I’ve got them in my garden
articles.summary: In Hogshaw, Derbyshire, author Mark Cocker recounts how leaving dried teasel stems in his garden attracts goldfinches to feed, prompting him to observe them from a hide. He traces their symbolic role in over 300 medieval and Renaissance Madonna-and-Child paintings—invoked as talismans against plague and thought to heal with their shining red faces, linked to Christ’s crown of thorns. Today, goldfinches still enchant gardeners: Europe imports thousands of tonnes of nyjer seed in a £380m wild-bird-food trade.

articles.title: We must not stop research on solar geoengineering | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Bryony Worthington says the media should not be pushing a western attitude to climate strategies to the detriment of African nations. Plus letters from Prof Hugh Hunt, Dr Portia Adade Williams and Angela Churie Kallhauge
articles.summary: Letters by Bryony Worthington, Prof Hugh Hunt, Dr Portia Adade Williams and Angela Churie Kallhauge push back against calls to ban solar geoengineering research and critique the Guardian’s portrayal of African ministers’ stance. Worthington warns Western NGOs fearmongering stalls vital inquiry. Hunt frames solar radiation modification as a temporary, reversible stopgap—spraying 10m tonnes of aerosol could cool Earth by 1 °C—while underscoring it won’t replace emission cuts. Williams and Churie Kallhauge decry homogenising African views and urge inclusive, transparent SRM research to inform future climate choices.

articles.title: Glaciers to reach peak rate of extinction in the Alps in eight years
articles.trailText: Climate crisis forecast to wipe out thousands of glaciers a year globally, threatening water supplies and cultural heritage
articles.summary: Study finds Alps glaciers will hit peak extinction in eight years with over 100 lost by 2033; western US and Canadian glaciers peak under a decade with more than 800 annual vanishings. Globally, about 200,000 glaciers remain and some 750 disappear yearly now; under current policies (2.7 °C warming), losses will peak at roughly 3,000 per year by 2040 and plateau until 2060, erasing 80% by 2100. Limiting warming to 1.5 °C caps losses at about 2,000 per year, then declines. Glaciers support water supplies, tourism and hold deep cultural and spiritual significance, prompting communities to hold funeral ceremonies and plan adaptation measures.

articles.title: Chances of EU trucking industry hitting zero emissions targets are dire, says industry body
articles.trailText: Only 10,000 out of economic bloc’s 6m trucks are electric and are more likely to be operating on short routes
articles.summary: Industry body ACEA warns EU trucking’s zero-emissions goals are ‘dire’: just 10,000 of 6 million HGVs are electric, confined to short routes. Lack of public charging (1,500 vs needed 35,000), high energy prices, absence of tax incentives and €300k price tag per 40-tonne EV truck deter fleet managers. Under EU law, 43% of new HGVs must be electric by 2030, rising to 90% by 2040, or face €2bn in yearly fines. ACEA calls for urgent market audit and alignment of targets with infrastructure rollout.

articles.title: ‘I consider him my first son’: how living with a baby monkey taught me I’m ready to be a dad
articles.trailText: I went from selling flats in Paris to being alone in a cabin in Guinea looking after primates. It changed my life, but one relationship marked me like no other
articles.summary: Disenchanted with selling luxury flats in Paris, a 26-year-old resigned to volunteer at the Chimpanzee Conservation Centre in Guinea, living alone among 66 chimpanzees for 11 months. Observing chimps’ ritualized conflict resolution and emotional authenticity taught him to release anger and embrace feelings. His bond with Elio, an orphaned baby sooty mangabey rescued from poachers, mirrored parenthood: feeding, grooming and exploring together deepened his patience and self-acceptance. Although Elio was later moved for reintegration and died of infection, the man credits the monkey as his “first son” and finds life purpose in wildlife rescue and anti-poaching advocacy, memorialized by an Elio tattoo.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Bushfires ravage Western Australia as temperatures soar
articles.trailText: Extreme heat follows blazes in New South Wales, while winds plunge Brazil’s largest city into darkness
articles.summary: Extreme heat and bushfires devastated Western Australia with forecasts above 40 °C triggering severe heatwave warnings across the southwest, extending into South Australia and New South Wales after earlier NSW blazes destroyed homes and caused fatalities. In São Paulo, gale-force winds toppled trees and power lines, blacking out over a million residents and cancelling hundreds of flights. California’s Central Valley recorded its foggiest week in decades as exceptional autumn rainfall fueled persistent tule fog and kept daily highs below 8 °C. Meanwhile, Storm Emilia battered Spain’s Canary Islands with intense rain, 50 mph winds and rare snow accumulations on Tenerife’s Teide, forcing park closures.

articles.title: Tabletop tomatoes and drought-resistant roses tipped as 2026’s top garden trends
articles.trailText: RHS predicts big shift in gardening habits as green-fingered Britons adapt to climate breakdown
articles.summary: RHS forecasts 2026’s garden trends: ornamental tabletop veg—dwarf tomatoes, aubergines, chillies and peppers—for windowsills and cold frames; drought-resistant roses bred with Rosa persica; “in-and-out” indoor plants like spider plants, tradescantia and lantana moving outdoors; a 10% surge in potted herb sales and hanging basket cucumbers. Climate adaptation also includes low-tech water-butt slow-release systems and trial AI-enabled self-emptying barrels. After 2025’s hot, dry summer, tomato sales jumped 14%, fuelling compact edible ornamental demand.

articles.title: Country diary: I love these soggy winter bogs – and so do the snipe | Charlie Elder
articles.trailText: Dartmoor, Devon: In these treacherous conditions for the moorland walker, one false move and a wary wader will burst into the air
articles.summary: On Dartmoor’s western ridge at Gibbet Hill, days of torrential rain create ankle-deep puddles and mud on sedge tussocks, shaping what Charlie Elder calls his favourite bleak, empty season. Winter bogs reveal elusive snipe—cryptically plumaged waders that erupt skyward like “stomp rockets” when approached, emitting rasping calls and zigzag flights. Distinguished by long straight bills, about 75,000 pairs breed in UK uplands, rising above 1m in winter with migrants. For rare, unpredictable glimpses, damp off-trail moorland rivals wetland reserves. Muddy boots are worth it.

articles.title: Conservatives would end 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel cars
articles.trailText: Party would also abolish zero-emission vehicle mandate, cutting legal requirement on carmakers to sell EVs
articles.summary: Conservatives propose scrapping the UK’s 2030 petrol and diesel car ban and abolishing the zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) mandate, which requires manufacturers to sell 80% of cars and 70% of vans as EVs by 2030, rising to 100% by 2035, and related non-R&D subsidies—claiming £3.8bn savings over ten years while retaining EV infrastructure funding. Party leader Kemi Badenoch says this balances environmental goals with consumer choice. Labour has reinstated a 2035 ban. Greenpeace warns the U-turn risks jobs and investment, while the government pledges £7.5bn in EV support to meet a 2035 phaseout.

articles.title: Carbon capture was spruiked as a way of limiting our emissions – but has Australia been greenwashed?
articles.trailText: Despite billions in investment, carbon capture and storage technology ‘should be in no way treated as a climate solution’, critics say
articles.summary: Chevron’s $3bn Gorgon CCS project on Barrow Island was meant to inject 4 Mt of CO₂ a year but began in 2019 and has since dropped from 1.72 Mt to 1.33 Mt in 2024–25. Chevron cites reservoir pressure issues, while critics call CCS a marginal ‘greenwash’: Gorgon will sequester under 3% of its lifecycle emissions. Santos’ Moomba and Inpex’s proposed Bonaparte schemes also receive federal backing, yet experts and Australia’s Climate Change Authority warn CCS remains small-scale, costly versus renewables and insufficient to meet climate goals.

articles.title: ‘A shift no country can ignore’: where global emissions stand, 10 years after the Paris climate agreement
articles.trailText: The watershed summit in 2015 was far from perfect, but its impact so far has been significant and measurable
articles.summary: Ten years on, Paris catalysed a 15% jump in renewables—90% of new capacity—and $2 trn spent clean vs fossil. EV sales are ~20% globally; low-carbon sources exceed half of power in China and India. Forecast warming dropped from 4°C pre-Paris to ~2.5°C with existing pledges. Yet China’s emissions hit 12.3 bn t in 2024 after a coal surge despite record renewables deployment, and India, though surpassing renewable targets early, still depends on coal. Delays by rich countries on climate finance and adaptation aid have fractured North-South trust. Political volatility, including US withdrawal threats, threatens progress—underscoring the need to phase out fossil fuels and honour finance commitments to keep 1.5°C viable.

articles.title: Country diary: Clinging to a crag in a place of constant change | Eben Muse
articles.trailText: Neath, south Wales: This quarry built the abbey and the nearby terraced towns – and it’s different every time I visit
articles.summary: At Neath Abbey Quarry in south Wales, Eben Muse traces a landscape in flux: a maze of shifting paths through holly-thickets echoing with a dawn chorus and darting goldcrests. Once quarried for abbey stone and later for coalfield terraced towns, this crag was cleaved by a winter landslip two decades ago, scattering russet boulders. Today, climbers pick their way on iron-nodule chips and fossil-streaked faces, while mosses, lichens and young oaks colonise scree, anchoring fragile rubble. Fist bumps at the top reveal Baglan Bay’s expanse. Tired hikers depart, aware that this ever-changing terrain—sculpted by geology, history and regeneration—will surprise them on their next return.

articles.title: ‘Soil is more important than oil’: inside the perennial grain revolution
articles.trailText: Scientists in Kansas believe Kernza could cut emissions, restore degraded soils and reshape the future of agriculture
articles.summary: Since 2010, Kansas-based Land Institute researchers have bred intermediate wheatgrass into Kernza, a perennial grain crop with deep roots that sequester carbon, reduce soil erosion, cut fertiliser use and curb greenhouse gas emissions. Current yields are 25% of wheat but DNA profiling, modelling and accelerated LED-driven breeding aim to match annual yields within 15 years. Collaborations across 30 countries test perennial cereals, pulses and oilseeds. Despite hurdles in yield, harvest decline, machinery and supply chains, industry partners like General Mills signal emerging markets for this sustainable agriculture revolution. Founder Jackson’s vision stresses soil as non-renewable, vital resource.

articles.title: EA to spend millions clearing Oxfordshire illegal waste mountain in break with policy
articles.trailText: Announcement draws anger from Labour MP over refusal to remove tonnes of rubbish dumped near school in Wigan
articles.summary: The Environment Agency will spend millions to clear 25,000 tonnes of illegally dumped rubbish outside Kidlington, Oxfordshire—an unprecedented break from its policy of pursuing perpetrators over cleanup—citing fire risk near the River Cherwell. Labour MP Josh Simons (Makerfield) condemned the decision as unfair to his Bickershaw, Wigan, constituents who endured a 9-day waste fire beside a primary school. The agency plans to fund removal and landfill tax via internal efficiencies. Ministers meanwhile rejected Lords’ calls for a waste-crime review, despite 38m tonnes of annual illegal dumping by organised groups.

articles.title: Hightailing along city streets and raiding ponds: otters’ revival in Britain
articles.trailText: Still rare only 20 years ago, the charismatic animals are in almost every UK river and a conservation success story
articles.summary: In the past two decades, Britain’s Eurasian otter has rebounded from near-extirpation – once recorded at only 6% of surveyed sites in the 1970s – to now inhabiting virtually every UK river. With an estimated population of 11,000, the species benefits from improved water quality, bans on industrial waste, reduced pesticide loads and targeted reintroductions. Otters – spotted from Lincoln’s high street to Canary Wharf and even Shetland kitchens – reproduce slowly (one to three cubs yearly). Although anglers blame them for depleting fish stocks, diet analyses refute this. Cardiff University’s Otter Project tracks bioaccumulated pollutants, casting otters as river-health ambassadors.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Australia bushfires could be most dangerous since ‘black summer’
articles.trailText: Fires are burning across NSW, with Tasmania also facing an emergency, while in the US, Washington state braces for floods
articles.summary: Australia is facing more than 50 bushfires across NSW, with nine blazes out of control, extreme heat – peaking at 41C in Koolewong – and erratic winds fanning flames that have scorched 3,500 ha, destroyed at least four homes and killed a firefighter near Bulahdelah. In Tasmania, a 700 ha fire at Dolphin Sands has razed 19 homes and damaged 40, prompting evacuations. Authorities warn heatwaves, rising temperatures and abundant dried vegetation from previous La Niña rains could fuel Australia’s most severe fire season since 2019–20’s ‘black summer’. Meanwhile, Washington state braces for an ‘atmospheric river’ deluge, 120–205 mm of rain, 100k+ evacuees and record flood threats.

articles.title: As the UK looks to invest in nuclear, here’s what it could mean for Britain’s environment
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter:​ The government’s bid to speed up nuclear construction could usher in sweeping deregulation, with experts warning of profound consequences for nature
articles.summary: Labour PM Keir Starmer plans to implement the Fingleton review’s 47 recommendations to fast-track nuclear construction by weakening retained EU habitat and environmental laws, limiting judicial reviews and extending deregulation to rail, reservoirs and other infrastructure. Experts warn this could roll back protections for endangered species amid the UK’s steep biodiversity decline, risk breaching free-trade non-regression clauses with the EU and undermine legally binding nature recovery targets. Critics argue such blunt deregulation, framed as a net-zero booster, endangers ecosystems and invites legal challenges.

articles.title: Air passengers exposed to extremely high levels of ultrafine particle pollution, study finds
articles.trailText: Levels during boarding and taxiing were far above those defined as high by the World Health Organization
articles.summary: A French study using portable monitors on Paris Charles de Gaulle flights found ultrafine particle (UFP) and black carbon concentrations soared during boarding and taxiing—over twice the WHO’s ‘high’ threshold—then fell at cruise and rose again on landing. UFPs, unregulated and linked to lung inflammation, cardiovascular issues, fetal risks and premature death, also spread >5 km into nearby communities at levels comparable to busy urban roads. With air travel hitting 5 billion passengers and few emission controls, the research highlights unaddressed health risks for flyers, airport workers, and residents.

articles.title: Country diary: Twenty years ago this thriving woodland didn’t even exist | Phil Gates
articles.trailText: Low Burnhall wood, Durham: The smell of decay, the screech of jays – nearly 100,000 trees planted in 2008 have really come of age
articles.summary: Low Burnhall Wood, two miles south of Durham, was converted from arable fields in 2008 when the Woodland Trust planted 94,500 native deciduous trees. Now five metres tall, hawthorn and rowan bear berries for redwings and fieldfares, while birch and alder seeds feed siskins and redpolls. In this mast year even young oaks self-seed, making the stand self-perpetuating. From a hilltop the new wood mends ancient chestnut, lime and oak fragments, and on its rides and paths the scent of fungal decay and the rustle of leaves is broken by jays caching acorns, shaping future woodland.

articles.title: Changes to polar bear DNA could help them adapt to global heating, study finds
articles.trailText: Scientists say bears in southern Greenland differ genetically to those in the north, suggesting they could adjust
articles.summary: New research in Mobile DNA finds polar bears in south-east Greenland show significant activation of “jumping genes” linked to heat stress, ageing and metabolism as regional temperatures and diet shift. Analysis of blood samples reveals these mobile genome elements are upregulated in warmer, less icy habitats, suggesting rapid genetic adjustments—particularly in fat processing and energy pathways—to cope with scarce food and plant-rich diets. These findings, the first statistically robust link between climate warming and wild mammal DNA changes, offer insights into population vulnerability and guide conservation, but scientists caution bears remain threatened without urgent cuts in fossil fuel emissions.

articles.title: Wild beavers may have spread further than we realise | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: In response to an article about a beaver spotted in Norfolk, Richard Foster reports sightings in Berkshire
articles.summary: Responding to recent reports of a wild beaver in Norfolk, Richard Foster documents the first confirmed wild beaver presence in Berkshire. Two garden trail cameras on the River Kennet captured unmistakable beaver footage (alongside otters) in August and again two weeks later. Verified by the Berks, Bucks and Oxon Wildlife Trust, with no escapees from the nearby Ewhurst Park enclosure, these recordings, three months apart, indicate a resident wild population. Local anecdotal beaver gnawing on trees supports this. Previously identified in Norfolk, Kent, Hampshire, Somerset, Wiltshire and Herefordshire, wild beavers may be more widely distributed than assumed by the Beaver Trust.

articles.title: Will net zero really cost UK households £500 a year?
articles.trailText: An official report lays out different scenarios for the cost of transitioning away from fossil fuels to net zero by 2050
articles.summary: Britain’s National Energy System Operator (Neso) models five net-zero pathways to 2050. In its greenest, investment peaks at £460 bn in 2029 (≈10% of GDP), then falls to £220 bn/year (≈5% of GDP) by mid-century. A “falling behind” scenario cuts up to £350 bn in upfront spending but ignores carbon costs and delays benefits—£36 bn/year in savings, lower bills, health and ecosystem gains. Household impacts depend on policy-driven cost pass-through: grid upgrades, electric vehicles, heat pumps and nuclear are invested now but spread over decades. Neso’s figures hinge on fuel-price and technology assumptions and don’t predict a single government path.

articles.title: Orcas team up with dolphins to hunt salmon, study finds
articles.trailText: Northern resident killer whales appear to use dolphins as ‘scouts’, in a surprising cooperative hunting strategy
articles.summary: Researchers documented the first recorded cooperative salmon hunt between northern resident orcas and Pacific white-sided dolphins off British Columbia. Using drone, acoustic and underwater footage plus suction-cup tags, scientists observed dolphins acting as “scouts,” echolocating to locate Chinook salmon and leading orcas to the schools. Orcas then herded, caught and broke apart fish at the surface while dolphins scavenged scraps without eliciting aggression. Alternating echolocation patterns suggest both species may eavesdrop, potentially expanding acoustic detection. The study highlights unexpected interspecies collaboration, raising questions about mutual benefits and the adaptive hunting strategies of these intelligent predators.

articles.title: Economic growth no longer linked to carbon emissions in most of the world, study finds
articles.trailText: Analysis marking 10 years since Paris climate agreement underscores effectiveness of strong government policies
articles.summary: The link between economic growth and carbon emissions has broken in 92% of the global economy, driven by strong climate policies since the 2015 Paris agreement, finds a new ECIU report. Advanced economies — notably the UK, Norway and Switzerland — and major developing emitters such as Brazil, Colombia, Egypt and especially China (whose emissions have plateaued for 18 months) now expand GDP while cutting consumption-based CO2. Annual CO2 growth slowed to 1.2% post-Paris versus 18.4% prior. Despite gains, faster emissions decline is still crucial to meet 1.5–2°C targets.

articles.title: MP calls for ban on ‘biobeads’ at sewage works after devastating Camber Sands spillage
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Use of toxic plastic beads in treatment works is unnecessary and outdated, say conservationists
articles.summary: Labour MP Helena Dollimore, joined by Wildlife Trusts, has launched a campaign to ban “biobeads” — tiny plastic beads used in 15 aging sewage plants around England’s south coast — after hundreds of millions washed up on Camber Sands, contaminating Rye Harbour nature reserve. Tests by King’s College London found heavy metals (lead, arsenic) and carcinogenic PAHs in the beads, which threaten rare waders and attract toxins when ingested. Critics say modern electric‐current and ceramic biofilters render biobeads obsolete. Regulators lack data on bead use or storage risks, campaigners warn. The Environment Agency and water minister are investigating.

articles.title: Snakes, spiders and rare birds seized by Border Force in month-long operation
articles.trailText: Wildlife smuggling is serious organised crime that ‘fuels corruption and drives species to extinction’, Home Office says
articles.summary: In a month-long Operation Thunder (13 Sept–15 Oct), UK Border Force seized more than 250 endangered species and wildlife products at airports, ports and mail depots nationwide, including over 2,000 live tarantulas (300 protected), two rainbow boa constrictors, 100+ endangered birds (green-cheeked conures, lovebirds) and items like king cobra balm, tiger claw bottles, ivory carvings and shark meat. Home Office warns smuggling fuels corruption, funds organised crime and threatens extinctions. Experts highlight need for intelligence-led, international collaboration and tougher prosecutions; seized animals will be rehomed or used for research.

articles.title: Country diary: A lifelong love affair with a handsome duck | Mary Montague
articles.trailText: Tyrella Beach, County Down: Common scoters are tricky to spot from the shore, but I feel lucky to be seeing them at all
articles.summary: At Tyrella Beach, County Down, Mary Montague describes the elusiveness and beauty of migrating common scoters, attracted by patchy shellfish beds, diving to swallow molluscs whole. Through her scope she spots a soot-black drake against sunlit breakers circling a mixed-sex flock with pale-cheeked females before they drift with choppy waves. The sight evokes childhood memories of Lough Erne’s secret breeding scoter population—the only one in Northern Ireland—lost by 1993 to mink predation and ecosystem decline. Her joy at witnessing flocks now mingles with sorrow over a local extinction.

articles.title: Sea urchin species on brink of extinction after marine pandemic
articles.trailText: Ecologically important Diadema africanum almost eliminated by unknown disease in Canary Islands
articles.summary: Since 2021 the ecologically pivotal Diadema africanum in the Canary Islands has declined by 99.7% in Tenerife and 90% near Madeira due to an unidentified marine pathogen, with related mass die-offs recorded in the Red Sea, Mediterranean, Caribbean and western Indian Ocean. These “ecosystem engineer” urchins graze algae, support coral resilience and feed predators; their collapse has halved Caribbean coral cover and boosted algal coverage by 85%. Researchers suspect human-mediated transmission via shipping, altered currents or wave changes and warn the outbreak could spread.

articles.title: ‘Not normal’: Climate crisis supercharged deadly monsoon floods in Asia
articles.trailText: Cyclones like those in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Malaysia that killed 1,750 are ‘alarming new reality’
articles.summary: A World Weather Attribution analysis found that human-driven warming amplified monsoon downpours during Cyclones Ditwah and Senyar in late November, increasing five-day rain intensity by 9–50% in Sri Lanka and 28–160% in Sumatra/Malaysia. The storms, worsened by deforestation and low-lying urban growth, killed over 1,750 people, displaced millions, and caused $6–7 billion in damage (3–5% of Sri Lanka’s GDP). Researchers warn that without rapid fossil fuel cuts and better land management, such “not normal” extreme floods will become more frequent and devastating.

articles.title: Synthetic chemicals in food system creating health burden of $2.2tn a year, report finds
articles.trailText: Scientists issue urgent warning about chemicals, found to cause cancer and infertility as well as harming environment
articles.summary: Scientists warn that phthalates, bisphenols, pesticides and PFAS in the global food system inflict up to $2.2 trillion in annual health costs—cancers, neurodevelopmental disorders, infertility—and at least $640 billion in ecological losses. Persistent endocrine disruptors could reduce births by 200–700 million between 2025 and 2100. Led by Systemiq with contributors from Boston College, Duke, Sussex and others, the report highlights surging chemical production since WWII, lax safety testing, and planetary boundary transgressions. These ubiquitous additives and agricultural chemicals—found in packaging, food prep, crops and water—pose risks comparable to climate change, demanding urgent policy action.

articles.title: Birdwatch: a rare winter sighting of the short-eared owl
articles.trailText: Once a fairly frequent winter visitor to southern England, they now stay close to their northern breeding grounds
articles.summary: Driving across the Somerset Levels after a starling murmuration, the author stopped to binocular-scan a dark lump and discovered a short-eared owl—once a regular winter visitor to southern England, now scarcer as many remain near northern breeding grounds. The owl’s forward-facing, humanlike gaze held the author’s attention briefly before it silently drifted away into the darkness. Recent family outings also produced sightings of a barn owl low over a golf course and a tawny owl by a lane, kindling shared enthusiasm for birdwatching.

articles.title: Country diary: An unlikely job for a farmer – preserving a roman fort | Andrea Meanwell
articles.trailText: Tebay, Cumbria: We have 30 acres of Roman remains underground here, but thanks to recent storms and a redirected river, I fear they’re not safe
articles.summary: At Low Borrowbridge farm near Tebay in Cumbria, farmer Andrea Meanwell is preserving remains of a first- and second-century Roman fort and civilian settlement spanning some 12 hectares underground, including a parade ground, cemetery, mansio and headquarters. Erosion from the River Lune—aggravated by upstream gabions installed in 2019 to protect nearby Salterwath bridge—now threatens the cemetery. Meanwell is documenting the collapsing bank in freezing conditions to support a funding bid with Historic England. Few visitors venture into this Lune Gorge, whose ancient name 'Alone' remains debated.

articles.title: ‘Even the animals seem confused’: a retreating Kashmir glacier is creating an entire new world in its wake
articles.trailText: Kolahoi is one of many glaciers whose decline is disrupting whole ecosystems – water, wildlife and human life that it has supported for centuries
articles.summary: Kolahoi, a western Himalayan glacier, has lost nearly 25% of its area since the 1960s and retreated 900 m, shrinking its meltwater that feeds the Lidder and Sind rivers, paddy fields, apple orchards, saffron and grazing pastures. Earlier alpine blooms now confuse pollinators; musk deer, ibex and snow leopards encroach on villages as habitat vanishes. Satellite data show 0.65 m of ice lost per 1°C rise; if trends persist, 70% of Kashmir’s 18,000 glaciers could be gone by 2100, imperiling water, agriculture and biodiversity.

articles.title: It’s two years since we were told ‘the age of fossil fuels will end’. When will Australia get prepared for what’s coming? | Clear Air
articles.trailText: The decline of the coal export industry could come even faster than expected, and we need to do more to manage the economic risks
articles.summary: Two years after declaring the ‘age of fossil fuels will end’, Australia’s government still backs expansion of its world-leading coal and LNG export industries, approving 32 new fossil fuel projects since 2022 even as renewable generation nears 50% on the main power grid. AEMO warns ageing coal-plant retirements risk blackouts without faster investment in grid security. Treasury foresees coal export revenues slashing up to 50% in five years and LNG volumes dropping 25% by 2035. Experts urge federal action to manage economic fallout: accelerate clean-energy investment, support fossil-fuel communities and prepare for a rapid export decline.

articles.title: ‘Food and fossil fuel production causing $5bn of environmental damage an hour’
articles.trailText: UN GEO report says ending this harm key to global transformation required ‘before collapse becomes inevitable’
articles.summary: UN’s 2025 Global Environment Outlook finds food and fossil fuel production inflicts $5 billion of environmental damage per hour (≈$45 trillion/year), undermining economies, security, health and ecosystems. The 1,100-page report warns collapse is imminent without immediate governance, economic and financial reform, but faces resistance from major fossil-fuel and agricultural interests. It underlines that climate action could deliver $20 trillion of benefits by 2070 and $100 trillion by 2100, and urges pricing environmental externalities, eliminating $1.5 trillion in harmful subsidies, taxing meat, promoting plant-based diets and scaling wind and solar.

articles.title: UK households bin 168m Christmas lights and ‘fast tech’ items a year
articles.trailText: Consumers spent £1.7bn on festive lighting last year and much of it is treated as disposable
articles.summary: A Material Focus study estimates UK households discarded 168 million light-up Christmas items and ‘fast-tech’ gifts last year, after £1.7 billion was spent on festive lighting (including 39 million fairy-light sets, 28 million garlands and snow globes, 23 million light-up figures and 16 million pre-lit trees). Based on responses from 4,000 adults extrapolated nationally, the report warns battery-powered disposables fuelled over 1,200 bin-fire incidents in 2023-24 (a 71% rise). Separately, 1.1 billion electricals and 450 million batteries are irresponsibly trashed annually. Material Focus urges reuse, donation or separate battery recycling to curb environmental harm and fire risk.

articles.title: Caribbean reefs have lost 48% of hard coral since 1980, study finds
articles.trailText: ‘Destructive’ marine heatwaves driving loss of microalgae that feed coral, says Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network
articles.summary: A Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network study reports Caribbean hard-coral cover has declined 48% since 1980, halving reef habitat. Record marine heatwaves in 2023–24 drove a 16.9% annual loss by making symbiotic microalgae toxic and triggering bleaching, while cyclones break weakened coral. Macroalgae cover has risen 85% amid overfishing, replacing reef species that underpin $6.2 bn in fisheries and tourism. Yet resilient colonies discovered in the southern Gulf of Mexico spurred a new protected corridor. Researchers stress climate action and local measures—water-quality controls, protected areas and reduced tourism—to allow reef recovery.

articles.title: Country diary: A close encounter with a buzzard – but something’s not quite right | Ed Douglas
articles.trailText: Hargatewall, Derbyshire: Cycling towards a frosty Kinder Scout, I was waylaid by a raptor so settled she wouldn’t even move for a passing tractor
articles.summary: Cycling toward frosty Kinder Scout across Hargatewall’s high limestone plateau, Ed Douglas is halted by a broad-winged buzzard perched immobile on a pale stone wall. First mistaking it for a returning red kite, he watches her endure a passing tractor and stiff northerly wind, crouching six feet away. He wonders if hunger, illness or energy conservation grounds her. Their eyes lock in a moment of mutual calculation, underscoring the austere beauty of the Peak District.

articles.title: It’s the world’s rarest ape. Now a billion-dollar dig for gold threatens its future
articles.trailText: Tapanuli orangutans survive only in Indonesia’s Sumatran rainforest where a mine expansion will cut through their home. Yet the mining company says the alternative will be worse
articles.summary: The Martabe gold mine in Indonesia plans a 2km road through the Batang Toru rainforest, slicing critical habitat of the world’s rarest ape, the Tapanuli orangutan (fewer than 800 individuals in 2.5% of their historical range). PT Agincourt Resources, citing $2bn in gold and livelihoods for 3,500 employees, asserts planned conservation offsets and funding will mitigate impacts. Conservationists and scientists warn even small population losses drive the slow-breeding apes to extinction, pointing to hydroelectric dams, forest fragmentation, and failed moratoriums. Ongoing IUCN ARRC talks may pause construction, but experts stress zero habitat loss is needed to save the species.

articles.title: 2025 ‘virtually certain’ to be second- or third-hottest year on record, EU data shows
articles.trailText: Copernicus deputy director says three-year average for 2023 to 2025 on track to exceed 1.5C of heating for first time
articles.summary: Copernicus data shows 2025 is ‘virtually certain’ to rank as the planet’s second- or third-warmest year, with Jan–Nov temperatures 1.48°C above preindustrial levels—matching 2023—and November’s anomaly peaking at 1.54°C. The three-year mean for 2023–25 is poised to exceed the 1.5°C threshold for the first time, underscoring accelerating climate change. The month saw record warmth in northern Canada and the Arctic, alongside cyclones and floods in South and Southeast Asia. Despite renewable gains, greenhouse emissions continue rising, and WMO analysis warns Paris targets remain out of reach as extremes intensify.

articles.title: Cornish activist injured as police remove her from tree-felling protest
articles.trailText: Charity worker had joined 40 demonstrators ‘bearing witness’ to the loss of three lime trees in Falmouth
articles.summary: Charity worker Debs Newman, 60, was injured during a police operation to clear a Falmouth protest against the felling of three mature lime trees on Trelawney Road. Witnesses say she was seized, fell and hit her head, requiring paramedic treatment. The Stop the Chop group argues the council carried out the removals without adequate consultation and lamented the loss of community trees. Cornwall council and Devon and Cornwall police maintain the trees posed a road and property hazard, removal was lawful, security was precautionary, and an investigation is under way.

articles.title: White storks to make historic return to London in 2026
articles.trailText: Species extinct as breeding birds in Britain since 1416 to be reintroduced in Barking and Dagenham as part of rewilding effort
articles.summary: In 2026 white storks – extinct as UK breeders since 1416 – will be reintroduced into Eastbrookend Country Park, Barking and Dagenham, under the Rewilding East London project led by London Wildlife Trust and local council. Following success at Knepp Estate, captive-bred storks will acclimatize in ground-level aviaries before gradual release into restored Thames tributary wetlands. The scheme, backed by £500,000 from the Mayor's Green Roots Fund, also plans beaver reintroductions in 2027 to enhance wetland habitats, and includes community outreach with schools to foster urban nature engagement.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Atmospheric rivers to bring heavy rain and snow to Pacific north-west
articles.trailText: Flood and weather alerts in place across western half of region as parts of Iraq and Iran also face significant rain
articles.summary: Series of atmospheric rivers will hit the Pacific Northwest this week, delivering over 200mm of rain across western Washington and northwest Oregon by Friday, with 100–150mm in Seattle and Portland and up to 400mm on the Cascades’ western slopes. More than a foot of snow is expected above 1,800–2,100m. A National Weather Service flood watch covers northwest and central Washington, warning of urban and river flooding, rapid river rises, mudslides and land instability. Concurrently, 50–150mm of rain is forecast over Iraq’s Zagros foothills and northwest Iran, offering relief after a six-year drought and critically low reservoirs.

articles.title: Country diary: Time for a Christmas cut of holly – and we’ve both come armed | Susie White
articles.trailText: Allendale, Northumberland: Every winter I return to it with my secateurs, but hollies certainly know how to protect themselves
articles.summary: Susie White describes her annual pilgrimage to an Allendale holly to snip female branches bursting with berries—still intact thanks to birds’ preference for softer fruits—and craft a wreath of holly, rosemary, pine, clematis seedheads, ivy, lichens, ferns and honesty. She notes hollies’ dioecious nature, heterophylly-driven spines on lower leaves as deer defenses, and leaf tips’ lightning-conducting role. Pruning mimics browsing, enhancing their barbs and protective symbolism as she layers dark green leaves and scarlet drupes for a resilient, welcome decoration.

articles.title: The restaurateur chronicling hardships of immigrant staff in US kitchens: ‘These are the stories that make it work’
articles.trailText: In Voices from the Kitchen , Marc Meyer pulls the curtain back on the harrowing journeys of the people who run his restaurants
articles.summary: Chef Marc Meyer’s new book Voices from the Kitchen compiles 27 oral histories of immigrant workers in his Bowery Group restaurants (Cookshop, Shuka, Shukette, Vic’s), illustrating how US kitchens depend on foreign-born labor even as intensified immigration enforcement threatens livelihoods. From a former Peruvian nun-turned-supervisor to a Gambian dishwasher separated from family for 23 years, and a Venezuelan lawyer reduced to washing dishes, these narratives reveal systemic resilience, career advancement (e.g., Irish visa overstay to operations director; Dominican line cook to chef de cuisine) and the human cost of nativist policies.

articles.title: ‘No one knows where it came from’: first wild beaver spotted in Norfolk in 500 years
articles.trailText: Cameras capture lone creature collecting materials for its lodge in riverside nature reserve
articles.summary: A lone wild beaver, extinct in Norfolk since the 16th century, has been filmed building a lodge and stockpiling willow at Pensthorpe reserve on the chalk-fed River Wensum. Detected via camera traps after volunteers found characteristic tree-cut stumps, the nocturnal herbivore appears to have inhabited an unmapped wild section of the site for about a month. While Natural England is issuing licences for beaver reintroductions—only one legal release to date—it’s unclear if this individual dispersed naturally from established English or Scottish populations or was illicitly released. Reserve manager Richard Spowage welcomes its ecological role and right to remain wild.

articles.title: Environment Agency faces landfill tax bill worth millions to clear illegal waste
articles.trailText: Exclusive: ‘extremely unhelpful’ policy seen as deterrent to clearing thousands of dump sites across England
articles.summary: Environment Agency must pay millions in landfill tax to clear illegal dumps, deterring cleanup of thousands of sites. Of £15m to clear Hoad’s Wood, Kent, £4m is tax. MPs John Russell and Josh Simons call for urgent reform after EA balked at removing 25,000 tonnes of rubbish near a Wigan school, citing tax costs and complex regulations. The Wigan dump triggered a nine-day fire, rat infestations and toxic stench, with cleanup estimated at £4.5m including tax. Criminal gangs profit £2,500 per lorry by dodging the £126/tonne tax. Critics say the system lacks transparency, accountability and hinders swift action.

articles.title: Country diary: Lapwings are birds of my childhood – finally they have returned | Kate Blincoe
articles.trailText: Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk: I have memories of seeing them at night, on our pyjama-clad safaris round the farm, but they haven’t been here for a decade
articles.summary: In Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk, Kate Blincoe describes the surprise of spotting five or six lapwings—once a fixture of her childhood—shimmering against the low sun after more than a decade’s absence on her family farm. She recalls spring breeding, moonlit ‘pyjama safaris’ to watch their invertebrate foraging, and their famed “broken wing” decoy display. Her father remembers they once trailed ploughs in vast flocks and were even shot or eaten despite 1928 protections. Habitat loss wiped them out locally, leaving corvids dominant. Their unexpected return, often heralding cold snaps, lifts her heart.

articles.title: Homegrown gas is vital for energy security | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Domestic gas production must be incentivised if the UK is to avoid damaging shortages, writes Prof John Underhill
articles.summary: Prof John Underhill warns that Neso’s latest warning of UK gas shortages underscores the critical role of domestic offshore production and subsurface storage. With 85% of UK homes and over half of power generation on cold, windless days reliant on gas, imports via LNG threaten climate goals and price volatility. He argues the government must bolster UK field development—removing the windfall tax and expanding transitional energy certificates—to secure reliable, lower-carbon supplies and avert supply crises.

articles.title: Streets named after birds in Britain on rise as species’ populations plummet
articles.trailText: RSPB says growing trend for honouring species that are in decline is not matched by action on conservation
articles.summary: An RSPB analysis of 2004–24 OS Open Names data reveals a 350% rise in “Skylark” street names (156% for starlings, 104% lapwings, 58% swifts) even as wild populations tumble—skylarks down 53%, lapwings 62%, nightingales 89% and wildflower meadows 97% since the 1930s. RSPB CEO Beccy Speight and historians warn that bird-themed placenames mask inadequate conservation in a “nature-depleted” UK. They call for stronger planning laws—swift bricks in new homes and nature-restoring infrastructure—to reverse declines instead of relying on ironic street labels.

articles.title: Nature recovery plan in England hit by clause allowing contracts to end with a year’s notice
articles.trailText: Conservationists say changes, coupled with underfunding, will curb take-up and leave less land protected for nature
articles.summary: England’s flagship landscape-scale nature recovery scheme, designed to restore thousands of hectares under decades-long contracts, has been weakened by a new clause allowing government termination on just 12 months’ notice and slashed funding – from a planned third of a £2.4 bn annual pot to £500 m over 20 years. Conservationists and farmers warn this creates unworkable risk for landowners facing irreversible habitat restoration costs, deterring private investment and undermining targets for on-farm nature management. Critics say these changes, plus underfunding and diluted ambitions, will curb take-up and leave less land protected for wildlife.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Heavy snow blankets parts of US as winter storms hit
articles.trailText: Snowfall moves south-east over Wyoming and Colorado and combines with dense fog in some areas
articles.summary: A cold spell continues as a winter storm dropped 20–35 cm of snow in Wisconsin before shifting southeast over Wyoming and Colorado, delivering up to 30 cm in central Colorado and northern New Mexico. Denver’s first substantial snow caused nearly 1,000 flight delays or cancellations, while dense fog reduced visibility to 100–200 m in northern Colorado. Snowfall will briefly ease before a new system arrives Friday, bringing heavy snow, strong winds and blizzard conditions to the Rockies. In Australia, summer opened with snow in southeastern mountains and a 40–45 °C heatwave out west, triggering fire weather warnings in southern NSW.

articles.title: What I saw reporting on the American lives cut short by killer heat
articles.trailText: • Don’t get Down to Earth delivered to your inbox? Sign up here
articles.summary: Reporter obtained autopsies from Arizona up to 555 suspected heat deaths in Maricopa county amid a 14-day 43–46°C heatwave; these join 3,100 confirmed fatalities over the past decade. Low-income residents in RVs/mobile homes lacked AC, causing fatal indoor heat – e.g., Richard Chamblee (52) died when his broken AC overheated him; influencer Hannah Moody (31) died hiking. The US undercounts heat deaths due to inconsistent coroner protocols. Vulnerabilities stem from inequality and Trump’s policy rollbacks – Paris withdrawal, cuts to renewables, climate grants, food stamps and resilience funding in Appalachia – despite the US being the second-largest emitter.

articles.title: ‘We can tell farmers the problems’: experts say seismic waves can check soil health and boost yields
articles.trailText: ‘Soilsmology’ aims to map world’s soils and help avert famine, says not-for-profit co-founded by George Monbiot
articles.summary: Non-profit Earth Rover, co-founded by George Monbiot and Prof Simon Jeffery, has developed “soilsmology,” a seismic-wave technique to map living soils at metre-scale resolution. By striking the ground with a metal plate and analysing reflected waves, it detects compaction, moisture, microbial activity, organic matter and carbon levels without extensive digging. A free app will guide farmers to optimise water, organic inputs and tillage, boosting yields, reducing environmental impact and averting famine. Pilots in Kenya show reduced flood risk and fertility gaps. Experts say this affordable, low-disturbance method could transform global soil management.

articles.title: 60,000 African penguins starved to death after sardine numbers collapsed – study
articles.trailText: Climate crisis and overfishing contributed to loss of 95% of penguins in two breeding colonies in South Africa, research finds
articles.summary: Between 2004 and 2012, over 60,000 African penguins — more than 95% of breeding birds on Dassen and Robben islands — starved during their 21-day annual moult as sardine biomass off western South Africa fell to under 25% of its peak. Driven by ocean warming, salinity changes and sustained overfishing, the penguin population has declined 80% in 30 years and is now critically endangered with fewer than 10,000 breeding pairs. Researchers recommend sustainable fisheries management, bans on purse-seine nets near major colonies, and expanded conservation measures — from artificial nests and predator control to rescue and hand-rearing — to boost prey availability and improve survival.

articles.title: Country diary: Green shoots in the ancient forest | Country diary
articles.trailText: Glen Einich, Cairngorms: A wintry walk in the Rothiemurchus woodland is always glorious. To see some of its barer expanses starting to recover tops it off
articles.summary: In Rothiemurchus, Nan Shepherd lamented the wartime felling of Caledonian pines and Frank Fraser Darling likened its loss to a battlefield. A recent wintry walk revealed snow-dusted hills and frozen puddles, but most striking was a rejuvenated woodland of Scots pine, birch, juniper and blaeberry stretching from Whitewell croft. Above the tree line, beyond the Am Benaidh’s former logging dam, clusters of pine saplings now punctuate heath and scree. Thanks to reduced deer numbers and new land-management, this ‘peacetime army’ is quietly reclaiming lost forest.

articles.title: Red squirrels expand across Highlands after 10-year reintroduction drive
articles.trailText: Rewilding charity helps bolster Scottish stronghold of species that once came close to extinction in UK
articles.summary: After a decade-long rewilding drive by Trees for Life, red squirrels have expanded their Highland range by over 25%, establishing more than a dozen colonies from Ullapool to Lairg. Hundreds were translocated from robust Inverness-shire, Moray and Strathspey populations to predator-free woods, receiving health checks, genetic management and supplementary feeding. The charity’s Missing Species scheme will extend this work and reintroduce lynx, beaver and aurochs analogues. New grey-squirrel contraceptives and Isle of Wight refuges bolster recovery amid pox threats.

articles.title: Thank you, Paul Brown, for your final warning on the climate and civilisation | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by the Guardian’s former environment correspondent from his hospital bed
articles.summary: Readers’ letters applaud Paul Brown’s “final warning” from his hospital bed, decrying chronic political failure on climate in the US and UK and the gap between science and leadership. Signatories—scientists, attorneys and former policymakers—hail young Nordic COP30 leaders, urge UK parliamentarians to heed emergency briefings on climate-related economic and security risks, and warn that US NRC’s Advance Act and small nuclear reactors for AI datacentres undermine renewables and invite corruption. They celebrate Brown’s legacy in exposing environmental and nuclear risks and call for urgent action to protect lives, species and societal stability.

articles.title: ‘We miss having a dog but it’s the price you pay’: the village that banned pets to save wildlife
articles.trailText: Australian eco community is a sanctuary for native animals and a showcase of sustainable living
articles.summary: Currumbin Ecovillage on Australia’s Gold Coast spans 272 acres as an intentional eco-community and wildlife corridor that bans cats and dogs—deemed lethal predators except service animals—to protect native species. Established twenty years ago on a former dairy farm, its ~500 residents share solar power, rainwater tanks, community gardens and a $2 million wastewater plant to ensure self-reliance. A reforestation program attracts wallabies, kangaroos, koalas, platypuses and more. Homes initially met strict green-design standards; today sustainability remains central. Communal governance of finances and projects, regular events, shared meals and mutual support reinforce social bonds.

articles.title: La Niña is here for the summer – but it may not bring what Australians expect
articles.trailText: Expert says the weather pattern, which typically brings wetter and cooler conditions, may be weakened by global heating
articles.summary: La Niña’s onset in early October usually ushers in cooler, wetter Australian summers, but the Bureau of Meteorology warns this year’s event is relatively weak and short-lived. Forecasts indicate average rainfall across major capitals—Brisbane, Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth—while central Queensland, northern NSW and north-western WA may be drier. Despite La Niña’s cooling tendency, global warming is driving above-average maximum and minimum temperatures nationwide. Experts point to the event’s reduced strength, shifts in westerly winds, Indian Ocean warmth and rising sea surface temperatures that could fuel severe storms. The system may break down early, adding uncertainty to rainfall outcomes.

articles.title: Thirsty work: how the rise of massive datacentres strains Australia’s drinking water supply
articles.trailText: The demand for use in cooling in Sydney alone is expected to exceed the volume of Canberra’s total drinking water within the next decade
articles.summary: Australia’s AI-driven datacentre boom in Sydney and Melbourne is forecast to require up to 250 ML/day of potable water—exceeding Canberra’s entire supply—while Victorian hyperscale proposals outstrip usage of the top 30 business customers. Older sites rely on water-intensive evaporative or chiller cooling; NextDC pilots liquid-to-chip systems to reduce WUE toward benchmarks (e.g., Malaysia’s 1.8) and hit PUE as low as 1.15. Utilities plan recycled and stormwater schemes, with operator-funded network upgrades. Community groups demand a ban on drinking-water cooling and mandatory reporting amid health and environmental risk concerns around mega-campuses. Some operators, like CDC, deploy closed-loop cooling with near-zero ongoing draw (WUE 0.01).

articles.title: A diving prince, sunken treasure and snared by the Titanic: Joe MacInnis on his ‘rip-roaring’ life as an ocean adventurer
articles.trailText: At 88, the Canadian reflects on a golden era of underwater discovery and how shipwrecks and the cruel sea are the ‘greatest of all teachers’
articles.summary: At 88, Joe MacInnis, pioneering Canadian undersea explorer and doctor, reflects on a career of ‘rip-roaring’ ocean adventures—from snagging the Titanic wreck 2.5 miles down with Anatoly Sagalevich, to first dives on the Edmund Fitzgerald, Arctic polar stations and 16th-century silver reefs. Collaborating with Cousteau, Ballard and Buzz Aldrin during a golden age of exploration, he learned the sea’s unforgiving lessons on mortality, survival psychology and leadership. Now, after a heart attack and stroke, he channels his fear and optimism into writing on crisis, collective action and environmental urgency as he grapples with his own final arc.

articles.title: Water plant that caused Tunbridge Wells supply failure was given risk notice in 2024
articles.trailText: Watchdog investigating South East Water contamination issue had previously warned of potential health danger
articles.summary: South East Water’s Pembury treatment works, previously warned in 2024 by the Drinking Water Inspectorate over pesticide and bacterial contamination risks, failed at the weekend, cutting off tens of thousands in Tunbridge Wells. A 10-day boil water notice forces schools, businesses and GP surgeries to shut or source bottled water. DWI has launched a live investigation into potential negligence amid South East Water’s wider financial distress and underinvestment. Campaigners warn the UK’s aging water infrastructure faces similar single-point failures, with enforcement or legal action possible if safety breaches are confirmed.

articles.title: Global race to secure critical minerals for weapons threatens climate, warns report
articles.trailText: Study reveals US earmarked billions to stockpile critical minerals for military use, including precision-guided weaponry and AI-driven warfare
articles.summary: A Transition Security Project report finds the Pentagon has earmarked billions under its National Defense Stockpile to hoard at least 38 critical minerals—lithium, cobalt, graphite and rare earths—for precision weapons, AI-driven platforms and communications systems. It warns diverting 7,500 t of cobalt alone could instead provide 80 GWh of battery storage (powering roughly 100,000 electric buses), stalling solar, wind and EV deployment. With a $1 trillion budget and equity stakes in 20 North American mining ventures since 2023, the DoD’s actions prioritize militarism over decarbonization, undermining global climate security.

articles.title: High levels of ‘forever chemical’ found in cereal products across Europe – study
articles.trailText: Pesticide Action Network Europe study finds average concentrations 100 times higher than in tap water
