articles.summary: A Pesticide Action Network Europe analysis of 65 conventional cereal products from 16 EU countries detected trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)—a PFAS breakdown byproduct—in 81.5% of samples, with concentrations up to 100 times higher than in tap water. Wheat-based foods, especially Irish breakfast cereals and Belgian, German and French wholemeal breads, showed the highest contamination. TFA is reprotoxic and linked to thyroid, liver and immune damage. Campaigners demand EU safety limits, mandatory TFA monitoring and a ban on PFAS pesticides to prevent further soil and food-chain pollution.

articles.title: Country Diary: A lonely chapel that whispers and roars | Sara Hudston
articles.trailText: Abbotsbury, Dorset: Long ago this was the place to come and wish for a husband. It is empty today, but still so full of presence
articles.summary: On St Catherine’s feast day (25 November), the writer climbs alone to the 14th-century chapel on its Dorset hill, once famed for women whispering a blunt marriage charm in its south-wall recess. Golden sandstone walls, a boarded-up east window and stripped interior stand silent yet full of life, as wind roars through doors and archways like waves. Set amid barrows, stone circles and hillforts, the chapel’s atmosphere evokes layers of ritual devotion—perhaps stretching back to the nearby Iron Age teenager buried at Langton Herring.

articles.title: ‘It moved … it was hopping!’ One man’s search for a wild wallaby in the UK
articles.trailText: Reports of escaped wallabies are on the rise, especially in southern England. But how easy is it to spot these strange and charismatic marsupials – and why would a quintessentially Australian creature settle here?
articles.summary: On a dark November night in Warwickshire, 19-year-old Molly Laird filmed a hopping red-necked wallaby on a country lane, sparking a search by bushcraft tracker Darren Parkin and ecologist Anthony Caravaggi. Caravaggi outlines how escaped wallabies—adept at digging and popular in private collections—have formed a continuous southern England population aided by milder winters. He’s mapped sightings from Cornwall to the Chilterns but cautions their browsing may alter flora and compete with deer or sheep, and any control risks public backlash. Parkin and the reporter eventually spot the escapee before it’s recaptured.

articles.title: How an invasion of purple flowers made Iceland an Instagram paradise – and caused a biodiversity crisis
articles.trailText: Nootka lupins, introduced in the 1940s to repair damaged soil, are rampaging across the island, threatening its native species
articles.summary: In the 1940s Iceland’s chief forester introduced Alaska’s Nootka lupin to bind eroded volcanic soils and boost nitrogen. Its vivid purple fields now draw hordes of summer tourists and feature in wedding photos and adverts, coating fjords, mountain slopes and lava flats. But scientists warn it’s invasive—covering 0.3% of the land and set to triple by 2027—displacing native plants, altering soil structure and raising landslide risk. With eradication impossible, experts recommend targeted containment around biodiversity hotspots.

articles.title: UK farmers lose £800m after heat and drought cause one of worst harvests on record
articles.trailText: Many now concerned about ability to make living in fast-changing climate after one of worst grain harvests recorded
articles.summary: Analysis by the ECIU estimates UK arable farmers lost over £800m in 2025 due to record hot, dry spring and summer, driving yields of wheat, oats, barley and oilseed rape 20% below the 10-year average. England’s second-worst harvest since 1984 follows multiple extreme weather events, pushing cumulative losses past £2bn since 2020. With four-fifths of growers now questioning economic viability, stakeholders warn delayed green farming incentives undermine climate adaptation, urging funding for resilient crops and soil management to safeguard food security.

articles.title: More than 520 chemicals found in English soil, including long-banned medical substances
articles.trailText: Fertilising arable land with human waste leaves array of toxins that could re-enter food chain, study finds
articles.summary: University of Leeds researchers found over 520 chemicals—including pharmaceutical products like lamotrigine, carbamazepine and long-banned toxins—in English agricultural soils after fertilising fields with treated human biosolids. Close to half of detected pharmaceuticals had not been previously reported in soil monitoring. Persistent emerging contaminants risk leaching into crops and the food chain, potentially harming soil and plant health. While EU plans advanced quaternary wastewater treatment, the UK relies on less effective tertiary systems. Scientists call for regulation, improved treatment technologies and further study of contaminant pathways and removal strategies.

articles.title: ‘The dinosaurs didn’t know what was coming, but we do’: Marina Silva on what needs to follow Cop30
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Brazil’s environment minister talks about climate inaction and the course we have to plot to save ourselves and the planet
articles.summary: Brazil’s environment minister Marina Silva, Amazon native and veteran defender, says Cop30 exposed decades of insufficient climate action, warning the rainforest is drying fastest in 3 years. Urgent, high-quality measures are needed to narrow the “tiny crack” for action: roadmaps for phasing out fossil fuels and deforestation, endorsed by 80+ nations but removed from the final text under oil-state pressure. She urges a values-driven, just transition, noting Brazil cut Amazon deforestation by 50% while boosting agribusiness by 17%, and will push debates and lead by example ahead of a Colombia conference.

articles.title: Country diary: A broken leg and singing crossbills – am I having a strange dream? | Nicola Chester
articles.trailText: Inkpen, Berkshire: Drifting in and out of sleep on the woodland floor, I’m in searing pain, but far from alone
articles.summary: In Inkpen, Berkshire, Nicola Chester lies on the damp floor of Long Copse after a collision with three dogs shatters her lower leg, leaving her drifting in and out of consciousness. Amid searing pain she is soothed by her mother, a neighbor’s sweet tea and the pine-scented sycamore leaves beneath her. A dragonfly’s cellophane wings crackle and high in the conifers she hears chip-chip chyops of crossbills. She refuses an ambulance—even though her husband is a paramedic—and ultimately hobbles back to the road, thoughts alight with red and green crossbills.

articles.title: Reuse and return schemes could help eliminate plastic pollution in 15 years, says report
articles.trailText: Pew Charitable Trusts finds plastic pollution will more than double globally by 2040 unless action taken
articles.summary: The Pew Charitable Trusts report Breaking the Plastic Wave 2025 warns that without action, annual plastic packaging pollution will rise from 66 m to 280 m tonnes by 2040, fueled by a 52 % spike in production. Packaging—33 % of current waste—could see pollution slashed by 97 % via deposit-return and reuse schemes, polymer bans, and material substitution. Systemwide reforms could cut overall plastic pollution 83 %, GHG emissions 38 %, health impacts 54 %, saving governments $19 bn/year by 2040.

articles.title: ‘They’re a lot like us’: saving the tiny punk monkeys facing extinction
articles.trailText: In the tropical dry forests of northern Colombia, a small team is gradually restoring the degraded habitat of the rare cotton-top tamarin
articles.summary: In northern Colombia’s tropical dry forests—now just 8% of their original size—a coalition of former loggers, farmers and biologists from Fundación Proyecto Tití is restoring nearly 1,000 hectares of habitat to save the critically endangered cotton-top tamarin, of which fewer than 7,500 remain. Decimated by 1960s-70s export for medical research, deforestation and the illegal pet trade, the species is returning to newly planted corridors of native trees. Field teams fit transmitters to dominant males, monitor family groups and work with over 100 farmers. Early evidence shows tamarin numbers are stable or rising, and other wildlife like turtles, toucans and pumas are reappearing.

articles.title: ‘I kept smelling a horrible nasty smell’: the risks of England’s old dumping grounds
articles.trailText: For some, the smell brings on nausea and headaches. Others fear ‘forever chemicals’ seeping into the water
articles.summary: In Fleetwood, Lancashire, reopening of Jameson Road landfill in late 2023 has released hydrogen sulfide odours causing headaches, nausea, respiratory issues among residents. Environment Agency issued enforcement orders; gas extraction infrastructure added but stench persists. Investigations found PFOA and PFAS leaching into the River Wyre above safety standards amid legacy waste from AGC Chemicals and ICI. Community fears groundwater contamination, asthma exacerbations, and long-term “forever chemicals” risks. Similar PCB pollution at Commonside landfill highlights threat of historic dumps predating regulation.

articles.title: UK and Europe’s hidden landfills at risk of leaking toxic waste into water supplies
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Rising flood risks driven by climate change could release toxic waste from ageing sites – posing threats to ecosystems
articles.summary: First continent-wide mapping by the Guardian, Watershed Investigations and Investigate Europe of over 61,000 landfills across the UK and Europe reveals up to 140,000 sites in flood-prone areas; many hold legacy plastics, construction debris, PFAS, PCBs and toxic metals. About 90% of an estimated 500,000 landfills predate regulatory linings, including 22,000 UK sites near drinking water sources or protected reserves. Scientists warn climate-driven floods and coastal erosion (346 sites in UK/France) could release leachate into groundwater, rivers and ecosystems. Fragmented EU member-state records hinder risk targeting. Authorities cite EU drinking water and landfill directives and increased monitoring, while experts urge funded remediation of ageing, highest-risk dumps.

articles.title: Few do magnificence quite like the mandarin duck | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Fernilee, Derbyshire: You could hardly blame them for flaunting their spectacular plumage, and that’s what the males do in their glittering mating display
articles.summary: In Derbyshire’s Fernilee reservoir Mark Cocker describes an unprecedented gathering of 80 mandarin ducks—once confined to elite southern estates like Windsor Great Park and Virginia Water—in shining breeding plumage. Imported from China in the 19th century and sold at exorbitant prices (£70 for two pairs in 1864), their UK population has soared to 4,400 pairs by 2011. Males flaunt cinnamon sails atop the back, emerald forecrowns, purple necks and glittering white breast fans in courtship displays. These luminous drakes rotate to scatter sparkles across upland water, punctuated by their shrill twittering calls against a winter chorus of wrens.

articles.title: Zillow deletes climate risk data from listings after complaints it harms sales
articles.trailText: Site deletes feature after real estate agents and some homeowners say scores appear arbitrary and hurt sales
articles.summary: Zillow has removed its climate-risk index showing individual property exposure to wildfire, flood, extreme heat, wind and poor air quality from 1m listings after real estate agents and homeowners argued the scores were arbitrary and hurt sales. The site now links to First Street’s external data instead. First Street CEO Matthew Eby warns buyers will be “flying blind,” facing post-purchase liability like unaffordable insurance. Experts note model granularity limits and call for standardized, government-backed risk assessment amid rising disasters and insurance scarcity.

articles.title: Hole in Antarctic ozone layer shrinks to smallest since 2019, scientists say
articles.trailText: EU’s Copernicus monitoring service hails ‘reassuring sign’ of progress observed this year in hole’s size and duration
articles.summary: This year's Antarctic ozone hole shrank to a maximum area of 21 m sq km in September, the smallest and shortest-lived since 2019, closing early as Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service data show. Down from 26 m sq km in 2023, it marks two consecutive years of smaller depletions. Scientists attribute recovery to the 1987 Montreal protocol banning ozone-depleting substances, with the WMO forecasting full return to 1980 levels by 2066. Volcano-driven anomalies in 2020–23 underscored the stakes without coordinated global action.

articles.title: Get shucking: South Australians urged to eat oysters and donate shells for reef restoration project
articles.trailText: Shrimp soundtrack will be played underwater to lure baby oysters in program aimed at fighting algal blooms
articles.summary: South Australians are urged to eat local oysters and donate cleaned shells to rebuild 1,500 km of once-extinct native reefs along the SA coastline. Dr Dominic McAfee’s program sinks shell-filled biodegradable cages and limestone blocks, playing underwater snapping shrimp sounds to attract oyster larvae and boost spat settlement. Each oyster filters 100 L/day, improving water quality and combating toxic algal blooms likened to underwater bushfires. The government is funding 25 community reefs, four large limestone reefs and seagrass restoration; volunteers can join via the state’s bloom response portal.

articles.title: Sri Lanka braced for more damage after torrential rain kills hundreds across Asia
articles.trailText: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in US
articles.summary: Sri Lanka braces for fresh floods as Cyclone Ditwah drags torrential rain across the island after flash floods and landslides triggered by a rare cluster of tropical cyclones killed over 300 in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with Sri Lanka’s toll nearing 200 and hundreds missing. Across South and Southeast Asia, more than 1,300 have died and millions are affected. In Iran, a sixth year of drought forced the Karkheh dam to halt hydropower and cut Tehran’s water pressure. The US Midwest and Northeast face lake‐effect snow, up to 1ft in Michigan, and temperatures 10°C below normal.

articles.title: Australia could miss clean energy target as solar and wind investment slumps, investors warn
articles.trailText: Expert warns large pipeline of potential projects will not deliver required energy capacity unless companies make final investments
articles.summary: Investors warn Australia risks missing its 82% clean‐electricity target by 2030 as large‐scale solar and wind investment slumps to 2.5 GW FID this year (down from 4 GW), the lowest since 2017. They point to deep structural issues—state planning delays, grid connection uncertainty, transmission constraints, rising costs and lack of long‐term revenue certainty. While the government’s expanded underwriting scheme has generated a large project pipeline, few projects have reached financial close. Regulators and AEMO say renewables deployment must more than double and system‐security infrastructure be fast-tracked to meet emissions and energy goals.

articles.title: Wood-burning stoves could face partial ban in Labour’s updated environment plan
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Pollution targets set out alongside nature recovery projects to allay concerns over housebuilding
articles.summary: Labour’s environment secretary Emma Reynolds has unveiled an updated Environment Improvement Plan tightening England’s annual PM2.5 limit from 25 to EU level of 10 µg/m3 by 2030, slashing domestic combustion emissions—20% of PM2.5—via stricter smoke-control areas, approved-only wood stoves and potential bans on outdated appliances. Complementary measures include £500 m for 250,000 ha of habitat restoration by 2030, 15-minute green-space access, PFAS reduction, illegal waste crackdowns and published delivery plans mapping actions to targets. Reynolds says strategic nature recovery will coexist with housing and infrastructure growth.

articles.title: Country diary: A rusting shipwreck that’s part of the family | Nick Acheson
articles.trailText: Blakeney Point, Norfolk: The old steamer, called Yankee, has long been abandoned on the shingle, dwindling in the elements. I take the four-mile walk to visit
articles.summary: Nick Acheson recounts a four-mile pilgrimage from Cley to Blakeney Point, Norfolk, to revisit the rusting 19th-century steamer Yankee, once owned by his ancestor Martin Fountain Page of Page and Turner. Abandoned on a shingle spit now dubbed Yankee Ridge, her corroded steel plates cradle seablite amid sea campion and thrift. A weary redwing from Scandinavia and a startled hare pull him back to the present as he lays hands on the lichen-spattered hull, sensing 150 years of family and Norfolk’s enduring winds and tides.

articles.title: EPA urged to ban spraying of antibiotics on US food crops amid resistance fears
articles.trailText: Use of 8m pounds of antibiotics and antifungals a year leads to superbugs and damages human health, lawsuit claims
articles.summary: Public health and farmworker groups filed a petition urging the EPA to ban the annual use of 8 million pounds of antibiotic and antifungal pesticides on US fruits and vegetables, warning overuse fosters antibiotic-resistant superbugs, links to MRSA, disrupts the gut microbiome, harms pollinators and drinking water, and risks low-income and Latino workers. CDC studies have flagged medically important antibiotics on crops as a driver of resistance. The petition demands action within five years, citing alternatives such as crop spacing and resistant varieties, and warns delays could prolong litigation over a decade.

articles.title: ‘We need to speak collectively’: can parliament solve the problem of ‘deprivation bingo’ in the UK’s seaside towns?
articles.trailText: Labour knows it needs to win over the ‘sea wall’ cohort of coastal voters in the next election. But as anger over inequality grows, time is running out
articles.summary: Labour MP Polly Billington and Lib Dem Steff Aquarone warn that England and Wales’s seaside towns face chronic “deprivation bingo”: failing transport, limited jobs, geographic isolation and youth mental-health gaps. They’ve relaunched a coastal PLP and demand a cabinet-level minister for coastal communities to coordinate cross-departmental resources—echoing a “London Challenge” for seafront schools and vocational pathways, especially into social care. With nine of the top ten most deprived areas on the coast and coastal seats at risk in the next election, they urge policy makers to listen, invest in education, housing and transport, and reshape the national narrative around coastal inequality and opportunity.

articles.title: Water shortages could derail UK’s net zero plans, study finds
articles.trailText: Tensions grow after research in England finds there may not be enough water for planned carbon capture and hydrogen projects
articles.summary: A Durham University study for Wave warns that carbon capture and hydrogen projects could boost England’s industrial water demand by up to 860 Ml/day by 2050, risking shortages in Humberside, the North West and other clusters from 2030. Water companies say regional plans already factor in hydrogen needs but blame Ofwat’s funding caps and the Environment Agency’s omission of low-carbon growth in forecasts. The government cites sustainable sourcing requirements, £104 bn private investment for reservoirs and leakage cuts, and strict standards for new schemes. Oxford’s Dieter Helm proposes real-time smart-meter data and an independent catchment regulator to oversee water use under climate pressures.

articles.title: ‘We had to swim to safety. I didn’t think we would make it out alive’: the people fleeing climate breakdown – in pictures
articles.trailText: Photographers Mathias Braschler and Monika Fischer capture the families, farmers and fishers who have been forced to leave their homes by extreme weather – and the landscapes they left behind
articles.summary: Swiss photographers Mathias Braschler and Monika Fischer’s Displaced (2025) revisits their 2009 Human Face of Climate Change portraits, gathering 60+ images across 12 countries of people—often women—forced from ancestral lands by drought, floods, wildfires, sea-level rise and desertification. From Senegalese fishers displaced by coastal erosion and Mongolian herders bereft of livestock after extreme winters to Iraq’s drying marshes, German flood survivors, Kenyan pastoralists, Louisiana hurricane victims, Guatemalan Dry Corridor migrants, Brazilian flood refugees, Bangladeshi coastal dwellers, Swiss rain-storm victims and Filipino typhoon evacuees, their slow, dignified method foregrounds the creeping, human toll of climate displacement.

articles.title: ‘Deeply demoralizing’: how Trump derailed coal country’s clean-energy revival
articles.trailText: Biden earmarked billions for former coal communities in Appalachia – and his successor came and took it away
articles.summary: After the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act earmarked billions to help former coal communities transition to solar and advanced energy, Trump’s administration immediately suspended or terminated Biden-era grants—including the $3bn Environmental and Climate Justice Program—via the so-called department of government efficiency led by Elon Musk. Coalfield Development founder Jacob Hannah and partners had mobilized a coalition to deploy over $900m for workforce training, mine repurposing and flood mitigation, but projects in Huntington, Pennington Gap, Dante and across Appalachia have stalled. Nonprofits like Solar Holler and Appalachian Voices face paused reimbursements, canceled tax incentives and mounting litigation as distrust deepens.

articles.title: Revealed: Europe’s water reserves drying up due to climate breakdown
articles.trailText: Exclusive: UCL scientists find large swathes of southern Europe are drying up, with ‘far-reaching’ implications
articles.summary: UCL researchers using 2002–24 GRACE satellite gravity data show freshwater storage plummeting across southern and central Europe – from Spain, Italy and France to Poland and south‐east England – while Scandinavia and north‐west Europe wet. Groundwater depletion mirrors this trend as heavier summer downpours drive runoff and shorter recharge seasons. Despite a 2000–22 EU drop in total water use, groundwater abstraction rose 6%. Scientists warn of risks to food security, public supply and ecosystems, and urge emission cuts, infrastructure modernisation and water‐reuse strategies such as rainwater harvesting.

articles.title: Country diary: My Black Friday? A night-time skulk in the woods | Nic Wilson
articles.trailText: Purwell Ninesprings, Hertfordshire: A chilly evening spent interpreting rustles and admiring the silhouetted trees – now that’s what I call a bargain
articles.summary: Aided by a sliver of moon at Purwell Ninesprings in Hertfordshire on Black Friday 2019, Nic Wilson discovered the richness of nocturnal woodland life. As his eyes adjusted, he heard the full-throated rush of a stream, glimpsed silhouettes of oak, birch and hawthorn against Hitchin’s skyglow, and sensed wood mice in brambles, treecreepers under poplar bark, elf cup fungus in deadwood and wasp larvae in oak galls. Embracing November darkness has since become a seasonal ritual, inviting deeper engagement with his local wood beyond daylight distractions.

articles.title: Mike Alexander obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Nature reserve warden who developed a computer system to create a better framework for conservation management
articles.summary: Mike Alexander, who died aged 77, was a pioneering Welsh nature reserve warden whose decade on Skomer Island led to a transformative conservation career. Frustrated by ad hoc reserve management, he co-created the NCC’s Countryside Management computer system in 1986—now used globally—and later oversaw all national nature reserves in Wales. He authored the standard text Management Planning for Nature Conservation (2008) and Skomer Island: Its History and Natural History (2021). Alexander chaired Pori Natur a Threftdaeth (2005–21) and the Wildlife Trust for South and West Wales (2021–24). An accomplished photographer and woodcarver, he is survived by his wife, Rosanne, and siblings Jeff, Anne and Tina.

articles.title: City life is reshaping raccoons – and may be nudging them toward domestication
articles.trailText: Scientists say urban raccoons’ shorter snouts and calmer reactions to people mirror traits found in domesticated animals across species
articles.summary: A University of Arkansas study using 20,000 iNaturalist photos shows urban US raccoons have 3.56% shorter snouts than rural counterparts, alongside calmer, less aggressive behavior. Researchers link abundant trash, lack of predators and close human contact to selection for tameness, invoking the Neural Crest Domestication Syndrome hypothesis: shifts in embryonic neural crest cells reshape skull and behavior. Similar urban-driven cranial changes occur in city foxes. While experts call for more data to confirm an actual domestication pathway, the findings highlight rapid morphological and behavioral adaptations to city life.

articles.title: FDA poised to kill proposal that would require asbestos testing for cosmetics
articles.trailText: RFK Jr signed order withdrawing rule that would mandate testing for the cancer-linked toxin in talc-based makeup
articles.summary: FDA cancels proposed rule requiring asbestos testing in talc-based cosmetics after health secretary RFK Jr. withdraws it, citing “unintended consequences” for drugmakers. Despite decades of evidence that talc can harbor carcinogenic asbestos—linked to 40,000 annual deaths and lawsuits against Johnson & Johnson—campaigners criticize the reversal as endangering consumers, especially users of baby powder. The move halts efforts from the 2022 Cosmetics Modernization Act and underscores political shifts in regulating toxins in personal care products.

articles.title: ‘I have watched politicians failing yet and yet again’: lessons from a life as an environment writer
articles.trailText: Paul Brown looks back at his career reporting on the climate crisis, failed summit and nuclear power – and how to do it well
articles.summary: Paul Brown, diagnosed with terminal lung cancer, reflects from his hospital bed on 45 years as the Guardian’s environment correspondent. He recounts pioneering Greenpeace missions, first Antarctic dispatches, Rio ’92 and COP coverage, praises Thatcher’s scientific briefing but decries the enduring “Thatcher syndrome” of political inaction. He chronicles the rise of climate denial, nuclear power’s false renaissances and government subsidies for Sizewell C and SMRs. After leaving in 2005 he authored hundreds of columns, tutored emerging journalists worldwide and saw the Guardian expand its environment team five-fold. Brown urges journalists to expose real costs, lobbyist influence and the wasted resources fueling further fossil fuel dependence.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Snowfall cuts power in Poland and flooding devastates Sri Lanka
articles.trailText: Temperatures dip to -8.5C in Poland and 250mm of rain falls in 24-hour period across Sri Lanka
articles.summary: Across the Alps and eastern Europe, temperatures plummeted as Arctic air collided with Balkan low, dropping to –20°C in the Alps and –8.5°C in Zakopane, Poland, where 15–20cm of snow fell (over 40cm in the south). 2,900 emergency call-outs, 75,000 homes in Rzeszów lost power, and a Warsaw–Vilnius Embraer E170STD skidded off the runway, delaying flights. Meanwhile in Sri Lanka, orographic enhancement amid heavy monsoon downpours dumped over 250mm of rain in 24 hours, triggering floods and mudslides that damaged 425 homes, displaced 1,800 families and killed 40 people, including 18 in Badulla and Nuwara Eliya. Further rainfall is expected.

articles.title: Africa’s forests transformed from carbon sink to carbon source, study finds
articles.trailText: Alarming shift since 2010 means planet’s three main rainforest regions now contribute to climate breakdown
articles.summary: African tropical forests switched from a net carbon sink (2007–10 gains) to a source after 2010, losing ~106 bn kg biomass annually—equivalent to 106m cars—driven by agricultural clearing, infrastructure, mining and fossil-fuel heating. A Scientific Reports study (Univ. of Leicester, Sheffield, Edinburgh) used satellite and machine-learning data, identifying tropical moist broadleaf forests in DRC, Madagascar and West Africa as worst affected. Authors call for rapid scaling of Brazil’s $100 bn Tropical Forest Forever Facility—though only $6.5 bn has been invested to date—to meet Cop26 deforestation targets.

articles.title: Beyond the negative headlines, some truly good things came out of Cop30
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: Ultimately, climate progress will come from real-world action, and this year’s summit made some promising strides on that front
articles.summary: Although COP30 didn’t secure a legally binding fossil-fuel phaseout or immediate NDC upgrades, it marked the first direct summit discussion of oil, gas and coal and saw Brazil launch a “plan B” consultative roadmap for transition ahead of COP31. Developing nations won a tripling of adaptation finance (delivered by 2035 from existing pledges), and the summit reinforced that nonbinding, bottom-up commitments and real-world action—renewable investment now outpacing fossil fuels, EVs at 25% of new car sales, half of China and India’s power capacity low-carbon—are driving climate progress.

articles.title: Many ships found breaching pollution limits despite tighter controls
articles.trailText: Researchers using aircraft to sample exhaust plumes say infringements persist – even in stricter zones
articles.summary: Using the UK’s FAAM research aircraft, Prof James Lee’s team sampled 130 individual ship exhaust plumes in 2019, 2021 and 2022. In 2019, 8 of 19 vessels—including a 61,900-tonne container ship and an 86,100-tonne tanker—exceeded IMO sulphur limits in the open ocean. Under stricter Channel and North Sea rules, 5 of 78 ships breached limits overall and 2 of 33 in-zone. One 200,000-tonne container switched to compliant fuel only near shore. Shipping fuels cost the UK £1.5 bn in 2017 health impacts. With road transport cleaner, shipping may rise as a nearshore pollutant, prompting a new Atlantic control area from 2027.

articles.title: Country diary: A stag red deer, totally still, totally dominant | Elizabeth-Jane Burnett
articles.trailText: Raddon Hills, Devon: I spend a watchful moment with a mixed herd. Rutting season is over, but there’s no doubt who is in charge
articles.summary: In Raddon Hills, Devon, Elizabeth-Jane Burnett observes a mixed red deer herd at dawn. Amid golden beech and oak leaves and utter stillness, the group materializes, ears pricked. A mature stag emerges, its broad, multitined antlers signaling the UK’s largest land mammal and asserting dominance now rut season ends. Moving quietly toward a dense blackthorn, holly and gorse hedge, the author circles back to the world waking—tractor, gunshots, crows, cars, even a passing plane—by which time the deer have vanished.

articles.title: Beaches reopen after bull shark kills Swiss tourist with police reviewing GoPro footage from scene
articles.trailText: Shark attacked 25-year-old woman first then her partner who ‘has done everything he could to get them both into shore,’ authorities say
articles.summary: In Crowdy Bay NP off NSW, a 3m bull shark attacked a Swiss couple at Kylies Beach at dawn on Nov 28. The 25-year-old woman died; her 26-year-old partner was airlifted to John Hunter Hospital in stable condition after a bystander applied a makeshift tourniquet. Police are reviewing GoPro footage. Beaches reopened with drone and jetski patrols detecting no further threats, and nippers sessions continue. NSW DPI deployed smart drumlines to tag and relocate sharks offshore. Experts call the rare double attack a freak defensive incident, unlikely to signal ongoing danger, while Swiss consular support is aiding victims' families and authorities urge adherence to SharkSmart advice.

articles.title: Scientists warn of severe climate-related risks to UK economy and security
articles.trailText: Experts lay out scale of changes needed in ‘first-of-its-kind national emergency briefing’ in Westminster
articles.summary: At a first-of-its-kind national emergency briefing in Westminster attended by over 1,000 leaders, eminent scientists warned that climate change and ecosystem breakdown threaten the UK’s economy, public health, food security and national defence. Experts including Mike Berners-Lee, Kevin Anderson, Nathalie Seddon and Tim Lenton urged deep, rapid decarbonisation, biodiversity restoration and keeping warming below 1.5°C to avert chaotic social upheaval, potential AMOC collapse and import dependence. Actor Mark Rylance highlighted inequality’s role and billionaire-funded misinformation, while retired General Richard Nugee warned climate risks now outpace threats like Russia, calling for resilient infrastructure to maintain security.

articles.title: ‘Nature feeds us more than it floods us’: Asheville after-school program teaches kids to forage
articles.trailText: In the wake of Hurricane Helene, No Taste Like Home aims to rebuild trust between students and the land
articles.summary: After Hurricane Helene devastated Asheville in September 2024, herbalist Alan Muskat’s No Taste Like Home launched an after-school foraging program for 5–12-year-olds from City Mountain Public Montessori. Three times weekly this fall, guides taught students like 12-year-old Juniper Stewart to identify and harvest regional edibles—plantain, jewelweed, sourwood leaves, turkey tail and chicken-of-the-woods mushrooms—emphasizing safety (“don’t overgeneralize”) and self-reliance. With sessions costing $4–8, the initiative aims to rebuild trust in nature, bolster food security after storm-shuttered markets and teach sustainable wildcrafting. Despite delays over bus drivers and safety concerns, No Taste Like Home is expanding with chaperoned field trips and weekend family tours.

articles.title: ‘We like it a lot’: how Romania created its hugely popular deposit return scheme
articles.trailText: In the two years since the system was launched, beverage-packaging collection and recycling has risen to 94%
articles.summary: Launched late 2023, Romania's public–private 0.50-leu deposit return scheme transformed beverage-packaging recycling from ~14% to up to 94% monthly returns. By Sep 2025, Romanians returned 7.5bn containers (4bn PET, 2bn cans, 1.5bn glass), yielding 500,000 tonnes of recyclables. Villagers like Dana Chitucescu earn ~40 leu/week collecting bottles. With 9 sorting centers, reverse vending or manual returns, 90% population adoption and reinvested profits, it's the world's largest integrated DRS. Experts cite modern traceability, legal mandates and a national "hora" campaign. Plans exist to expand beyond drinks.

articles.title: Ministers to crack down on ‘for-profit’ litter enforcers in England
articles.trailText: Councils will end contracts allowing private enforcers to receive 50% to 100% of each fine served
articles.summary: Ministers have announced a statutory crackdown on ‘for-profit’ litter enforcement in England, requiring councils to end contracts where private firms receive 50–100% of fixed penalty notices (FPNs) for littering and PSPO breaches. FPNs typically range from £100–£200 (rising to £500 from July), or up to £1,000+ via prosecution. Critics, including Manifesto Club’s Josie Appleton and Lib Dem peer Tim Clement-Jones, warn that profit motives drive excessive fines and undermine due process, leaving individuals like Nayan Kisten trapped in lengthy appeals. New guidance and a refreshed Code of Practice will be published in early 2025.

articles.title: Cuddling capybaras and ogling otters: the problem with animal cafes in Asia
articles.trailText: A boom in places offering petting sessions is linked to a rise in the illegal movement of exotic and endangered species, say experts
articles.summary: Exotic pet cafes featuring capybaras – the world’s largest rodent – have proliferated across Asia, from Bangkok to Jakarta, driven by social media fame. While Thailand claims local breeding, experts warn illegal trade and laundering underpin supply, with threatened species like otters also trafficked. China’s petting zoos surged from under 100 in 2020 to 1,800 in 2025. Conservationists cite growing demand, invasive risk and call for stricter international regulation and enforcement.

articles.title: Country diary: The river has risen to meet the trees. This is Storm Claudia’s work | Paul Evans
articles.trailText: Welsh Marches, Shropshire: All the ditches and drains from the hills of mid-Wales to here burst with rain. The Severn has a deadly seriousness now
articles.summary: Storm Claudia’s torrential rains have swollen the River Severn from mid-Wales to Shrewsbury’s Frankwell footbridge, lifting water to golden willows and casting uncanny doppelgänger shadows across the banks. Roiled by runoff, debris and pollutants, the river moves with deadly seriousness, pushing fish, birds and roads underwater. Fields and car parks become silent lakes; hedges vanish beneath the flood’s still, memory-laden expanse. This animistic surge, indifferent to human barriers, reveals the Severn’s growing power and the ecological stakes of intensifying storms in the Welsh Marches.

articles.title: Large bull shark kills woman and injures man in attack at NSW beach
articles.trailText: Swimmers aged in their 20s bitten by shark at Kylies beach in Crowdy Bay early on Thursday morning, with woman dying at the scene
articles.summary: At Kylies Beach in Crowdy Bay on NSW’s mid-north coast, a large bull shark attacked two swimmers in their 20s early Thursday, killing the woman and seriously injuring the man, whose life was likely saved by a bystander’s make-shift tourniquet. Emergency services, including a rescue helicopter, airlifted him to John Hunter Hospital. NSW DPI deployed non-lethal “smart” drumlines and drones; nearby beaches are closed for 24 hours. Experts warn bull sharks frequent warm shallow waters and note rising shark encounters driven by coastal growth and climate factors, although fatalities per capita have declined thanks to faster responses and better first aid.

articles.title: Environmental activist Ben Pennings declares ‘massive victory’ after Adani drops its years-long legal pursuit
articles.trailText: Queensland supreme court orders Pennings, a campaigner against the Carmichael coalmine, not to seek to acquire Adani’s confidential information
articles.summary: Adani has dropped its five-and-a-half-year legal action against environmental campaigner Ben Pennings after a Queensland Supreme Court order that Pennings refrain from obtaining or soliciting Adani’s confidential Carmichael coalmine data. The company also abandoned its bid for up to $600m in damages. Pennings, national spokesperson for Galilee Blockade, hailed the outcome as a “massive victory” over what he calls Australia’s largest SLAPP suit and vowed to resume direct action. He urged federal law reform to ban corporate SLAPPs. Adani said its goal was protecting staff and contractors from harassment.

articles.title: ‘A win for nature and people’: Elizabeth line soil used to create Essex bird haven
articles.trailText: A record 39,000 birds are overwintering on Wallasea island wetlands thanks to soil transported from London tunnels
articles.summary: Three million tonnes of excavated earth from the Elizabeth line tunnels have been transported from London to Wallasea Island in Essex, where the RSPB removed a 400-year-old sea wall and sculpted new lagoons, salt marshes and islands. This regeneration has created thriving wetlands now sheltering a record 39,000 overwintering birds—including 800 avocets, 10,000 knot, 3,000 grey plover and 3,000 bar-tailed godwits—and offers flood protection by absorbing storm surges. Project managers hail the initiative as proof that large-scale infrastructure and nature restoration can deliver mutual benefits.

articles.title: Why the plan for a ‘forest city’ is not as green as it sounds | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Jon Reeds of Smart Growth UK says the proposed development in Cambridgeshire’s countryside would see precious farmland destroyed
articles.summary: Jon Reeds of Smart Growth UK warns that a proposed ‘forest city’ in east Cambridgeshire would cover 18,000 hectares, obliterating prime grade 2 farmland, while only allocating 4,800 hectares to new woodland. This threatens UK food security—currently reliant on domestic production for just over half its needs as Ukraine’s output is jeopardized. He argues true sustainability demands balanced land use: modern arable fields support soil biodiversity and farmland birds, and urban sealing with air, noise and light pollution beside planted forests undermines ecological benefits.

articles.title: Protests, tears and a baby: five key images that tell the story of Cop30
articles.trailText: Emotions ran high at the UN climate summit in Brazil, which was hit by its first major protest in four years
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, Indigenous Munduruku protesters blocked the summit entrance, demanding a voice in climate talks; president of the conference André Corrêa do Lago held a painted baby before convening three hours of dialogue. A first major COP protest in four years featured a fossil fuel ‘funeral,’ a 40-ft globe and chants of “Nothing about us without us.” Colombia and the Netherlands announced a high-ambition process for phasing out oil, gas and coal as delegates averted a gaveling crisis over the mutirão text. In the closing plenary Brazil’s environment minister Marina Silva, moved to tears by stalled progress, rallied delegates with defiance, promising the fight for forests and emissions cuts will go on.

articles.title: Country diary: Once a plain old field, now a thriving forest garden | Anita Roy
articles.trailText: Wellington, Somerset: The five years we’ve spent transforming this patch has been recognised with an RHS award. We’re proud, but we’re not done yet
articles.summary: In Wellington, Somerset, volunteers from Transition Town Wellington have spent five years converting an 8.5-acre field once overrun by grass and nettles into a flourishing forest garden ringed by a food hedge. Knee-high saplings have matured alongside woodchip paths, herbs, cardoons and foraged hazelnuts. Teams clear and compost old hay, mulch, and remove invasive docks under all-weather conditions. Their grassroots stewardship earned a Royal Horticultural Society award for sustainable community gardening, underscoring the project’s ecological benefits and TTW’s ongoing guardianship of Fox’s Field.

articles.title: Plastic nurdles found at 84% of UK sites of special scientific interest
articles.trailText: Environmental charity Fidra says 168 of 195 SSSIs it surveyed are contaminated with tiny pellets
articles.summary: Environmental charity Fidra’s nurdle hunts found tiny plastic pellets in 168 of 195 UK SSSIs (84%) and six national parks—Loch Lomond & the Trossachs, North York Moors, New Forest, Pembrokeshire Coast, Snowdonia (Eryri) and South Downs. Produced and shipped nationwide from plants like Grangemouth, an estimated 53bn pellets may spill annually through industrial mismanagement. Nurdles contain toxins, harm wildlife via ingestion, and fragment into microplastics that enter the human food chain. Hotspots include the River Itchen and Firth of Forth. Fidra calls for global policy coordination, binding supply-chain rules and mandatory IMO shipping measures to curb spills.

articles.title: Simon Rietbergen obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Expert who worked to protect endangered forests, especially in Africa
articles.summary: Simon Rietbergen, 65, Dutch tropical forestry expert, died from multiple brain tumours. Educated at Wageningen University, he served at IIED (1986–91), the World Bank (1992–97), IUCN (1997–2007), the Prince’s Rainforest Project (2007–09) and FAO (2014–25). Renowned for livelihood-sensitive conservation in the Congo Basin and Sahel, he led multi-country teams and in July 2025 launched the $150 m African-led Great Green Wall initiative to re-establish vegetation across 5,000 miles of the Sahel. He is survived by wife Jennifer McCracken, children Emma, Sam and Lily, and brothers Evert Jan and Hans.

articles.title: ‘A precarious position’: almost 3,000 species at risk of disappearing from Wales, report finds
articles.trailText: Environmental body says modest investment and changes can help preserve long list of animals, fungi and lichen
articles.summary: Natural Resources Wales’ first ‘Species in Peril’ report finds 2,955 terrestrial and freshwater species in Wales confined to five or fewer sites—including 25 birds, five fishes, six mammals, the natterjack toad, 2,000+ invertebrates, 309 fungi and 321 lichens. Since 2000, 11 species (eg turtle dove, belted beauty moth) are extinct locally. Pressures include local habitat loss (woodland management, peatland water levels, pollution) alongside climate and agricultural intensification. Yet many species can be secured through low-cost tweaks—scrub clearance, grazing goats, better habitat management—on existing protected sites. Hotspots like Newborough Forest and Warren on Anglesey host 130 imperiled species. Welsh govt’s Nature Networks, Natur am Byth programmes and the upcoming biodiversity bill aim to reverse declines.

articles.title: US, Russia and Saudi Arabia create axis of obstruction as Cop30 sputters out
articles.trailText: Trump puts US in unflattering company as lack of representative at climate talks reveals disdain for climate progress
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém Brazil, the US under Trump skipped the summit for the first time in 30 years, joining Russia and Saudi Arabia to block “fossil fuel” language. A coalition of some 90 nations pushing a phase-out roadmap was stymied by consensus rules. Meanwhile, Trump’s administration expanded drilling in US waters and rolled back environmental safeguards. Observers label this trio an “axis of obstruction” unlikely to halt but only slow the global shift—driven by double the investments in renewables��and China’s rise as a clean-energy superpower.

articles.title: UK can create 5,400 jobs if it stops plastic waste exports, report finds
articles.trailText: Campaigners say closure of loophole making it cheaper to export rather than recycle will boost circular economy
articles.summary: The UK could generate 5,400 jobs and build up to 15 new recycling facilities by ending unprocessed plastic waste exports by 2030, unlocking £800m of private investment and £900m in annual economic value plus £100m in new tax revenue, Hybrid Economics finds. Exports rose 5% in 2024 to 600,000 tonnes, including 24,000 tonnes to Indonesia, while 21 domestic recycling plants have closed. Campaigners call to close the export loophole, boost the recycled-content tax from 30% to 50% and phase out unprocessed waste exports.

articles.title: One in seven English bathing spots rated as polluted in latest testing
articles.trailText: Scarborough and Bognor Regis among places where water is so polluted it is not recommended for swimming
articles.summary: England’s latest Environmental Agency classifications show 13% of 449 designated bathing waters rated “poor” and 7% so polluted they’re unsafe for swimming. Famous beaches at Bognor Regis, Scarborough South Bay and Littlehaven (South Shields) featured in the poor category. Overall, 87% achieved “good” or “excellent” and 93% at least “sufficient,” a slight improvement on 2024. Agricultural run-off and sewage from water companies are blamed, though the EA also cited birds and dogs, drawing criticism from campaigners like Feargal Sharkey. New feasibility tests may bar polluted sites—especially rivers—from future bathing designations under existing EU-based standards; ministers and the EA vow continued regulation and investment.

articles.title: Country diary: The lone seal pup isn’t ready for the sea yet
articles.trailText: Hayle, Cornwall: Grey seals are born in winter and have to quickly become self-sufficient. With the water crashing in, this one is seeking shelter
articles.summary: In Hayle, Cornwall’s rugged winter coastline, a lone grey seal pup, roughly four to five weeks old, lies tucked beneath a rocky outcrop as crashing waves erase the beach. Born with insulating but non-waterproof lanugo and separated from its mother after three weeks, it must now learn to swim, dive and hunt unaided in strong currents. With 30% of pups dying within their first month and half within a year from starvation, disease and pollution, its survival remains precarious.

articles.title: ‘It fully changed my life!’ How young rewilders transformed a farm – and began a movement
articles.trailText: At Maple Farm, nature is returning in droves: nightingales, grass snakes, slowworms, bats and insects. All due to the vision of a group determined to accelerate its recovery
articles.summary: At Maple Farm in Surrey, the youth-led Youngwilders have accelerated rewilding over four years by removing fences, cutting invasive species, planting hedgerows and letting fields regenerate. Their habitat improvements have attracted nightingales, grass snakes, slowworms, bats, wild bees and butterflies. Founded by ecology-minded students inspired by Knepp’s wilding, the group partners with landowners, secures grants and trains 18–30 year-olds in field skills through workshops, volunteering and a biannual summit. With 12 UK sites now active, they’re building a movement linking young people to nature and biodiversity recovery.

articles.title: ‘Fossil fuel giants finally in the crosshairs’: Cop30 avoids total failure with last-ditch deal
articles.trailText: It took some oblique wording, but Saudi Arabia made a last-minute decision to sign deal that marks departure for Cop
articles.summary: After a 12-hour stalemate at Cop30 in Belém, delegates secured a last-ditch ‘Belém political package’ when Saudi negotiator Khalid Abuleif agreed to obliquely reference the Cop28 commitment to ‘transition away from fossil fuels’ as the ‘UAE consensus’, breaking an Arab-Group/Russian blockade. The accord calls for voluntary work on a Brazil-led fossil-fuel phase-out roadmap, defers major emissions cuts to 2026, and triples adaptation finance to $120 bn by 2035 alongside a just-transition fund for high-carbon workers. Critics deem it cautious but note it’s the first multilateral fossil-fuel nod in decades.

articles.title: Developing nations need climate justice, not debt | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Countries that contributed least to historical emissions don’t seek charity but fairness, writes Nirbhay Rana. Plus, a letter by John Green
articles.summary: Nirbhay Rana argues that regions least responsible for emissions—e.g., India’s cotton farmers and garment workers—face worsening heat, erratic rain and water shortages, yet lack grant-based finance, accessible technology and capacity-building partnerships. Treating climate support as debt undermines equitable transitions; true justice demands fairness grounded in science, history and the Paris agreement. John Green highlights a parallel bias in climate data and AI, where non-Western knowledge is marginalised, skewing decision-making. Both letters call for structural reforms to ensure representative data and a just, resilient global south.

articles.title: Weather tracker: heatwave roasts Israel as 90 die in Vietnam downpours
articles.trailText: Temperatures over 35C break November records in Israel while some areas of Vietnam have nearly 2 metres of rainfall
articles.summary: Israel has endured a record late-Nov heatwave 10–12°C above normal, topping 36.2°C in Beit Dagan and 37.3°C in Eilat; Jerusalem reached 27°C vs a 19°C average. In Vietnam’s south-central region, almost 2 m of rain in one week caused floods and landslides, destroyed or damaged hundreds of thousands of buildings, wiped out 3 m livestock and 80 000 ha of crops, and left at least 90 dead. Western Australia’s northern Kimberley braces for landfall of Cyclone Fina, now Category 3-equivalent after Darwin recorded 85 mph gusts and 168 mm rainfall; a further 100–150 mm is expected with flash-flood risk. Fiji faces a major flood alert as over 100 mm of rain may trigger more flash floods.

articles.title: UK ‘most expensive place’ to build nuclear power, review finds
articles.trailText: Government panel’s final report calls for ‘radical reset’ of planning and environmental rules to get reactors built faster and cheaper
articles.summary: Government taskforce led by John Fingleton warns UK is now the "most expensive place" globally to build nuclear power due to fragmented, conservative regulations. Its final report recommends a "radical reset": merge multiple regulatory bodies into a single nuclear commission, overhaul planning and environmental regimes, simplify safety rules to save tens of billions and accelerate projects. Proposals include reducing fish-protection costs, maintaining or enhancing safety, and introducing a modern, agile regulatory strategy. Energy Secretary Ed Miliband, NIA’s Tom Greatrex and Britain Remade’s Sam Richards support the reforms; civil society groups warn of safety risks.

articles.title: Zombie fires: how Arctic wildfires that come back to life are ravaging forests
articles.trailText: Blazes that smoulder in the permafrost, only to reignite, are extending fire season though winter, leaving vegetation struggling to recover
articles.summary: In May 2023 a lightning strike ignited Canada’s Donnie Creek boreal forest; thanks to a warm spring and dry autumn the blaze became one of the province’s largest. Instead of extinguishing under snow, the fire smouldered in permafrost as a “zombie fire,” resurfacing in spring 2024 to burn until August and consume over 600,000 ha. Such holdover fires, once rare across Siberia, Canada and Alaska, now extend fire seasons, destabilize soil carbon stores—releasing ancient CO2—and destroy seed banks, hindering forest recovery. Scientists race to spot them via satellites, warning that intensifying Arctic warming could fuel multi-year burn cycles.

articles.title: Search is on for the German hairy snail in London
articles.trailText: Conchologists, and citizen scientists team up to seek out endangered mollusc species along River Thames
articles.summary: The German hairy snail (Pseudotrichia rubiginosa), a fingernail-sized endangered mollusc, is being sought for the first time across London. Citizen Zoo and ZSL have mobilized over 100 volunteers to survey the tidal Thames. Native since at least the Neolithic, this tiny hairy-shelled snail clings to driftwood and riverside plants, using shell hairs to manage moisture and adhesion. Discoveries at Kew, Richmond, Isleworth Ait and Cody Dock highlight fragmented populations. Surveys aim to map its distribution, inform habitat restoration, pollution control and possible translocations under the London biodiversity action plan, safeguarding this rare species and green spaces for future generations.

articles.title: ‘Culture cringe’: experts dismiss Coalition claims Chris Bowen cannot remain minister while leading Cop31 negotiations
articles.trailText: Coalition claims key diplomatic role at next year’s conference in Turkey would make Bowen a ‘part-time minister’ while Australians face inflated energy prices
articles.summary: After Turkey won the Cop31 summit in Antalya, Australia’s climate and energy minister Chris Bowen was named Cop31 vice-president and president of negotiations, leading talks from Australia while retaining his ministerial duties. The Coalition attacked him as a ‘part-time minister’, but experts dismiss this as ‘culture cringe’, noting that past Cops have been led by serving ministers, diplomats or prime ministers. Bowen will focus on implementing existing commitments rather than forging new deals, and observers argue he can juggle both roles if Australia fully backs his leadership to drive global emissions action.

articles.title: Country diary: Unlocking the magic of our local lime | Amy-Jane Beer
articles.trailText: Welburn, North Yorkshire: Our house is made from the ground around us, so it’s only fitting that we fix it in the same spirit
articles.summary: At her stone house in Welburn, North Yorkshire, Amy-Jane Beer explores restoring its walls with lime mortar made from locally quarried limestone. After a damaging 1980s cement repointing, she enrolls her family in a workshop led by lime expert Ian Womersley, who demonstrates ancient techniques—quicklime slaked into putty, natural hydraulic limes mixed with sand and water. They practice mixing and raking joints before dry-churning to reveal neat pointing. Beer highlights lime’s breathability, moisture-wicking, self-healing, and reuse qualities, and its sustainability compared to cement. Enthused by the accessible process rooted in four millennia of history, she anticipates transforming her whole house.

articles.title: UN warns world losing climate battle but fragile Cop30 deal keeps up the fight
articles.trailText: Reaching agreement in divisive political landscape shows ‘climate cooperation is alive and kicking’, says UN climate chief
articles.summary: UN climate chief Simon Stiell warns world still losing climate battle as Cop30 delivers only a fragile deal. The Belém summit secured a pledge from 194 countries on an irreversible low-carbon transition, tripled adaptation finance, a just transition mechanism and Indigenous rights recognition. However, fossil fuel phase-out, deforestation roadmaps and timely adaptation funding (pushed to 2035) were shelved, and Indigenous delegates faced limited inclusion. Despite US absence and geopolitical headwinds, multilateralism held but critics decry an incremental outcome, amid protests and civil society calls for stronger action ahead of Cop31.

articles.title: Trump, war, absent media: five threats to climate progress that dogged Cop30
articles.trailText: Did the talks succeed or fail? The verdict must take account of the geopolitical minefield they took place in
articles.summary: COP30 in Belém faced five key threats: absence of US-China leadership due to Trump’s climate denial and China’s limited finance; Brazil’s split between agribusiness and conservation weakening Amazon protection; EU’s delayed finance promises and far-right divisions; diversion of funds and media coverage by global conflicts; and outdated UN consensus decision-making spurring high-ambition states to seek parallel fossil-fuel phase-out processes. Despite agreements and Indigenous participation, outcomes fall short on 1.5C targets, adaptation finance, and explicit fossil-fuel phase-out, prompting calls for revamped governance ahead of COP31 in Turkey.

articles.title: How ambitious ‘forest city’ plan for England could become a reality
articles.trailText: Cross-party coalition behind proposals hope eco-friendly scheme for million people could begin before end of decade
articles.summary: Campaigners led by ex-Guardian journalist Shiv Malik propose a ‘forest city’ for one million people east of Cambridge by decade’s end: wooden modular, four-bed homes from £350k under a community land trust, pedestrian-first with trams, new rail, schools and hospitals. A dedicated development corporation would harness special planning powers to deliver 12,000 acres of new native forest linking ancient woodlands, restore chalk streams and build reservoirs to address East Anglia’s water shortfall. Plans target industrial farmland and protect sites of special scientific interest. Nature campaigner Paul Powlesland joins the board to ensure ecological restoration, with pledges to enrich, not degrade, biodiversity.

articles.title: Cop30’s watered-down agreements will do little for an ecosystem at tipping point
articles.trailText: Delegates made minimal headway on timetable for replacing oil and gas or on firm commitments to reducing carbon emissions
articles.summary: At COP30, 194 nations cobbled together non-binding language on fossil fuels and carbon cuts, while agreeing to ‘call for efforts to at least triple adaptation finance’ to $120 bn a year by 2035—far short of the $360 bn developing countries need now. Most nationally determined contributions remain late or inadequate, locking in a 2.5 °C trajectory. Voluntary talks on phase-out roadmaps replace firm timetables; critical mineral impacts go unaddressed. Civil society welcomed a just-transition mechanism, but experts warn that without concrete commitments and accelerated emissions cuts, the 1.5 °C goal is slipping away soon.

articles.title: End of fossil fuel era inches closer as Cop30 deal agreed after bitter standoff
articles.trailText: Wealthy countries should triple funds for countries to tackle climate impacts, but deforestation and critical minerals blocked from final deal
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, 194 countries agreed a voluntary roadmap to phase out fossil fuels after an all-night standoff between an 80-country coalition and oil exporters led by Saudi Arabia and Russia. Rich nations pledged to triple adaptation funding to $120 billion annually by 2035—below demands for a 2030 deadline and not additional to the existing $300 billion. Negotiators dropped a deforestation roadmap, critical-minerals safeguards were blocked by China and Russia, and a new “accelerator” for under-ambitious NDCs was created. Talks also recognized a “just transition” but fell short of binding emission cuts.

articles.title: Compromises, voluntary measures and no mention of fossil fuels: key points from Cop30 deal
articles.trailText: A deal is welcome after talks nearly collapsed but the final agreement contains small steps rather than leaps
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, 194 nations narrowly agreed to modest steps: tripling adaptation funding to $120 billion by 2028, establishing a rights-based just transition mechanism and reaffirming the 1.5 °C goal. The final text omitted any binding fossil-fuel phase-out roadmap and scrapped deforestation targets. In response, about 90 countries will pursue a voluntary fossil-fuel exit plan outside the UN process and Brazil launched the Tropical Forest Forever Facility, a multibillion-dollar fund to protect rainforests.

articles.title: That syncon feeling: the 150 tonnes of spinning steel that could help stabilise Australia’s energy transition
articles.trailText: Australia’s largest synchronous condenser begins testing in Victoria, joining an expanding network operators say will reduce the grid’s reliance on fossil fuels
articles.summary: Australia’s largest synchronous condenser began testing near Ararat, Victoria: a 150-tonne rotor spun at 750 rpm inside a shed adjacent to the grid terminal. Supplied by Andritz, the device uses pressurized air bearings and cooling to provide grid inertia, stabilizing frequency and voltage as coal and gas plants retire. At $137 m capital cost and one of 12 Victorian grid-strengthening projects ($480 m investment), it will unlock 600 MW of renewables. Earlier syncons in Ouyen and South Australia paved the way, with NSW ordering five more. AEMO projects up to 40 machines may be needed to secure a 100% renewable grid.

articles.title: ‘The new narcotics’: how waste crime is causing environmental disaster across the UK
articles.trailText: Organised criminals face few repercussions for dumping toxic rubbish as Environment Agency struggles to keep up
articles.summary: Organised criminals are dumping toxic waste across the UK, most visibly in Hoad’s Wood, Kent, where a £15m biohazard cleanup began five years after residents exposed 35,000 tonnes of illegally tipped rubbish. The Environment Agency knows of six more mega-dumps from Lancashire to Cornwall—two still active—and faces resource gaps and slow legal processes that hinder cleanups. Notorious prosecutions, such as John Allison’s, recoup no removal costs, while MPs and a House of Lords inquiry decry the EA’s sluggish response. Recent mass tipping by the River Cherwell in Kidlington underscores calls for a serious organised-crime approach despite a 50% budget boost to £15.6m.

articles.title: Will pay-per-mile raise Reeves money or drive people away from electric vehicles?
articles.trailText: Need for new road taxes is clear – but there are concerns that pricing plan could stall transition away from petrol
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves will introduce at next budget a pay-per-mile charge for EVs (c.3p/mile from 2028) atop VED to plug falling fuel duty revenues, potentially raising £375m/year from 1.4m cars. Details (self-declaration or MOT check) are pending. Critics warn it could deter EV adoption – NZ saw sales slump when road-user charges and grants ended – urging incentives be maintained. Stakeholders call for simple, fair design, clear messaging that EV operating costs stay below petrol, and caution against complex tracking. Government insists on a “fairer system for all drivers” while supporting the transition to electric vehicles.

articles.title: Sycamore Gap tree saplings to be planted across UK
articles.trailText: National Trust begins planting the 49 ‘trees of hope’ so the illegally felled tree can live on in a positive way
articles.summary: National Trust begins planting 49 'trees of hope' saplings from the illegally felled 19th-century Sycamore Gap tree, one representing each foot of its original height. First five go in public sites during National Tree Week, including Greenham Common’s peace camp tower, Strabane in County Tyrone, Minnie Pit memorial, Coventry’s Tree Sanctuary and Coton Orchard (Cambridgeshire). Later plantings will honour motor neurone disease research, veterans and hospitals in Leeds, Northumberland and Sunderland, symbolising resilience, peace and environmental stewardship.

articles.title: Cyclone Fina: severe tropical storm intensifies to category 3 as it tracks towards Darwin
articles.trailText: It is the first cyclone of this strength in Australian waters in November in 20 years, with gusts up to 205km/h
articles.summary: Severe Tropical Cyclone Fina, Australia’s first November category-3 cyclone in 20 years with gusts to 205 km/h, closed Darwin airport and supermarkets as it neared the city with sustained winds of 150 km/h. Forecast to strengthen to category 4 over Joseph Bonaparte Gulf, Fina prompted SEWS alerts and evacuation shelters from Darwin to Cape Hotham, deployment of NT Police and ADF on standby. Residents were urged to activate 72-hour emergency plans amid torrential rain, storm surge and flood watches across the Top End.

articles.title: Miliband urges Cop30 to find ‘creative’ routes to roadmap on phasing out fossil fuel
articles.trailText: UK energy secretary says UN climate talks must find way to keep proposals alive despite significant resistance
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Brazil UK energy secretary Ed Miliband called for “creative” routes—such as a voluntary initiative—to preserve a global roadmap to phase out fossil fuels after binding language was dropped from the draft. Over 80 countries back the plan, but the Saudi-led Arab Group, Russia, Bolivia and some African states oppose. The UK and EU are lobbying for support, linking ambition to adaptation finance, a move decried by Tanzania’s envoy as holding poor nations ransom. China is not blocking; India insists developed states shoulder historical emissions. The talks also address closing NDC gaps to stay within 1.5°C.

articles.title: Cop30 delegates ‘far apart’ on phasing out fossil fuels and cutting carbon
articles.trailText: President of talks urges ministers and high-ranking officials to find common ground as conference nears its end
articles.summary: At COP30 in Brazil, delegates from over 190 countries remain divided on phasing out fossil fuels. President André Corrêa do Lago urged unity, but more than 80 countries, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, blocked references to a transition roadmap. Developed and developing nations pushed for self-determined timelines, while petrostates resisted. The EU warned of a 'no deal' outcome as texts lack strong commitments to limit warming to 1.5°C. High-ambition states like Colombia and the Netherlands plan a separate fuels transition conference, and small island and climate advocates warn delays jeopardise survival.

articles.title: Labor to rule out controversial ‘national interest’ exemption for coal and gas if Greens back nature laws
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Concession follows fierce criticism of the workaround but may not be enough to convince minor party
articles.summary: Labor has offered to remove a proposed “national interest” exemption allowing coal and gas approvals from its EPBC Act overhaul in exchange for Greens support, after criticism from Graeme Samuel, Ken Henry and environmental groups. Environment Minister Murray Watt is in negotiations with the Greens and Coalition to secure passage before parliament rises, while the Greens demand native forest safeguards, a climate trigger and genuine EPA independence. Opposition leader Sussan Ley would back the bill only if environment protections are weakened. An alliance of NGOs seeks removal of ministerial discretion, logging loopholes, and stronger First Nations engagement.

articles.title: How to make sustainable seafood choices this Christmas to ease the pressure on Australia’s oceans
articles.trailText: Australian Marine Conservation Society’s GoodFish guide aims to showcase the most environmentally friendly seafood sources
articles.summary: Facing record sea temperatures, algal blooms and overfishing in 2025, the Australian Marine Conservation Society’s GoodFish guide recommends eco-friendly festive seafood. Swap imported vannamei prawns for locally caught Spencer Gulf king prawns or Aussie-farmed tiger and banana prawns, and avoid Tasmanian Atlantic salmon in favour of barramundi, Murray cod or New Zealand/Australian king salmon. New green-listed NSW dusky flathead, plus farmed oysters and mussels, offer low-impact options. South Australian fisheries, monitored post-bloom, deliver safe, sustainable catch. Sydney Fish Market’s Pyrmont site hosts a final 36-hour Christmas trading spree before relocating. The guide rates 90% of Australia’s seafood and supplies preparation tips for a responsible holiday feast.

articles.title: ‘It’s like arguing with robots’: negotiators on the state of Cop30 talks
articles.trailText: Three representatives of developing countries speak candidly about meetings behind closed doors in Belém
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, negotiators from vulnerable developing nations accused richer and ‘like-minded developing’ blocs (Saudi Arabia, China, India) of denying IPCC science and resisting the 1.5 °C goal, describing talks as ‘like arguing with robots.’ They stressed adaptation is a survival imperative—urging tripling finance from $40 bn to $120 bn—and criticized developed countries for stalling on Paris Agreement Article 9.1 public grants, resisting a dedicated finance negotiation space and saddling them with intrusive adaptation indicators. Without significantly increased targeted public funding, they warn that adaptation, loss and damage efforts and the Paris goals are at risk.

articles.title: Weather tracker: US storms linked to ‘atmospheric river’ phenomenon
articles.trailText: California faced evacuation warnings over flood risk while Japan experienced heavy early season snowfall
articles.summary: California faced evacuation warnings as an “atmospheric river” funneled record rainfall and landslide risk along the Pacific coast. These moisture-laden storms also contrasted with Colorado’s prolonged snowless streak—Denver logged its highest November temperature (28 °C), pushing ski openings to December. Northern and eastern Australia endured severe thunderstorms, hail and flash floods that cut power to 11,000+ homes and fueled lightning-triggered bushfires under hot, windy conditions. In Japan, early-season dumps delivered over one meter of snow to Sukayu and heavy falls in Hokkaido, breaking timing records. In Italy’s northeast, 25 cm of rain in eight hours caused the Torre River to burst banks, triggering mudslides, two fatalities and village evacuations.

articles.title: Cop30 draft text omits mention of fossil fuel phase-out roadmap
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Summit leadership releases new text despite 29 nations threatening to block progress without commitment
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, a secretariat-published “mutirão” draft omitted any reference to a fossil-fuel phase-out roadmap despite 29 countries, including EU members and small island states, threatening to block the agreement without it. An earlier draft offered to start drawing up a “transition away from fossil fuels” roadmap, but Brazil, under pressure from Saudi Arabia, Russia, India and like-minded developing countries, removed the text. Over 80 nations back a non-binding forum to craft a just, equitable phase-out over the next year. Delegations remain deadlocked as talks, suspended by a conference fire, extend into the weekend amid wider finance, emissions and adaptation disputes.

articles.title: Three-metre giant oarfish, ‘palace messenger’ of doom, washes up on Tasmanian beach
articles.trailText: The enormous, serpentine fish, regarded in Japanese folklore as a herald of disaster, usually live deep below the surface and are only sighted when sick or dying
articles.summary: A three-metre giant oarfish washed ashore at Preservation Bay near Penguin, Tasmania, attracting seagulls and local resident Tony Cheesman, who spotted its silvery ribbon-like body and long chin and head fins. Macquarie University’s Prof Culum Brown explains these deep-sea fish (200–1,500 m) surface only when sick or dying. In Japanese folklore they’re ryūgū-no-tsukai, sea-god messengers of doom, though studies find no link to disasters. Every stranding offers rare scientific data on this elusive species.

articles.title: Country diary: A precious moment with a robin and its soft autumn song | Claire Stares
articles.trailText: Winkworth Arboretum, Surrey: This song is not the same as the full-throated spring version, and it’s impossible not to reply to
articles.summary: Winkworth Arboretum in Surrey is described as a slow­transitioning landscape ablaze with maroon, crimson, copper, amber and gold foliage, while leaves drift earthward. Claire Stares notes spongy redwood bark and a downy feather marking a tree creeper’s roost. Birdlife is muted—carrion crows caw, pheasants croak, goldcrests probe maples—until at a wetland viewpoint a robin perches inches away and sings its whisper song: a soft, breathy, closed‐bill courtship or low‐key territorial melody distinct from spring’s full song and juveniles’ subsong. This structured, deliberate undertone avoids provoking aggression. Observers’ whispered compliments evoke a reciprocal head-tilt response, framing an intimate conversation amid nature’s shift toward dormancy.

articles.title: Cop30 climate summit in Brazil disrupted after fire breaks out in venue
articles.trailText: Event thrown into confusion and 13 treated for smoke inhalation after conference centre evacuated
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil, a fire—likely sparked by an electrical device such as a microwave—erupted in the conference centre's pavilion on Nov. 20, forcing evacuation of the blue zone and treatment of 13 delegates for smoke inhalation. Brought under control in six minutes, the blaze interrupted crucial negotiations on fossil fuel phase-out roadmaps, delaying meetings of the EU, the Alliance of Small Island States and presidency’s drafting of the mutirão decision. Earlier, UN chief António Guterres had urged clarity on fossil fuel exit at talks meant to conclude Friday. Organisers and UN security responded swiftly; talks face potential overtime.

articles.title: ‘We can no longer predict the seasons’: why Indonesia’s coal mindset has to change
articles.trailText: It’s a climate-vulnerable nation, while also being the world’s sixth-largest greenhouse-gas emitter. Global investment in climate action is vital
articles.summary: Indonesia, the world’s sixth-largest greenhouse-gas emitter and a climate-vulnerable nation, faces deadly floods and droughts while depending on coal for 70% of electricity and exporting 40% globally. Rapid growth has entailed deforestation, peatland drainage and renewables stagnation. A domestic price cap and captive coal plants loophole lock in emissions. Forest clearance, palm-oil biofuel expansion and industrial mineral drives worsen carbon output. The updated NDC pledges up to 43% cuts by 2030—relying on land-use changes, peatland restoration and increased renewables—but needs $470 billion in investment. At COP30, Indonesia seeks climate finance and equity, pushing carbon markets and a clear plan to phase out coal.

articles.title: The two extraordinary young activists making me feel optimistic at Cop30
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Despite valid criticisms, the summits are filled with smart, passionate people dedicating their lives to fighting the climate crisis
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil—dubbed the “Cop of Truth”—two young activists spark optimism. Juan Carlos Monterrey-Gómez, Panama’s special climate representative, delivers four blunt “truths”: emissions have doubled in 33 years; we need fewer reports and more fossil-fuel phaseout; all environmental crises share roots in an unchecked economic system; and governments subsidize “criminal” fossil producers. Ayisha Siddiqa, a 26-year-old American-Pakistani law student and UN adviser, founded the Future Generations Tribunal to legally secure climate rights for those yet to be born. By gathering global youth testimonies and innovating personhood concepts, she aims to enshrine future generations’ rights and empower lawsuits against polluters—fueling belief that justice can prevail.

articles.title: Thousands of toxic sites across US face risk of coastal flooding
articles.trailText: Study finds rising seas could flood facilities handling waste, sewage, and oil and gas – and coastal states most at risk
articles.summary: New research in Nature Communications projects over 5,500 US coastal hazardous facilities—from sewage plants to oil terminals—will face 1-in-100-year flooding by 2100 if emissions remain high, concentrated chiefly in Florida, New Jersey, California, Louisiana, New York, Massachusetts and Texas. A lower-emissions path only reduces at‐risk sites by 7% by century’s end. Nearly 3,800 sites are already locked into flood risk by 2050. Disadvantaged communities—renters, low-income, Hispanic, linguistically isolated and older residents—are disproportionately exposed. Experts warn flooding contaminated with toxic waste and sewage threatens health and demands equitable land-use planning and mitigation.

articles.title: Ford UK boss warns Rachel Reeves against higher taxes on electric vehicles
articles.trailText: Lisa Brankin says new levies could discourage switch to EVs amid reports chancellor mulling pay-per-mile charge
