articles.summary: Ford UK MD Lisa Brankin urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to drop plans for a 3p-per-mile EV levy in next week’s budget, warning that higher EV taxes and fragile demand risk undermining the government’s 80% EV sales target by 2030. Brankin said new levies would be 'another brake' amid market distortions from heavy discounting and weak second-hand values, and urged retention of company car tax benefits. Ford, which reintroduced a £3,750 grant earlier this year, warns that without support meeting targets will be impossible.

articles.title: Australia’s failed bid to host Cop31 looks like a mess – but it may actually be the best result possible | Adam Morton
articles.trailText: While the outcome is a let down for those who want Australia to do better on climate, Chris Bowen looks set to play a pivotal role in the UN talks
articles.summary: Australia’s three-year campaign to host UN climate summit COP31 failed, with Antalya, Turkey chosen over Adelaide after mixed signals from PM Anthony Albanese and DFAT’s disengagement. Climate minister Chris Bowen instead forged a deal for Turkey to host and preside while he leads negotiating sessions for nearly 200 nations, highlighting Pacific island concerns. Bowen’s consensus-building role may salvage multilateral momentum despite Turkish geostrategic tensions and civil society crackdown risks. This creative split-host model could deliver an ambitious, inclusive climate outcome if finalized.

articles.title: Country diary: Golden leaves in the valley and holly trees stripped bare | Virginia Spiers
articles.trailText: St Dominic, Tamar Valley, Cornwall: The frost is yet to arrive and we’re awash with autumn colour as the mild weather continues
articles.summary: At St Dominic in Cornwall’s Tamar Valley, mild November weather keeps frost at bay as yellow lime leaves glow against lichened eucryphia and an early white camellia remains pristine. Squirrels ignore dogwood fruit, while fieldfares strip a holly bare. Blue rosemary blooms and ivy-clad undergrowth hosts polypodies and pennywort on mossy oaks. Before 8 am, a quad bike escorts Devon cattle into fresh pasture; nearby, a bare beech clump and Dupath farm’s Aberdeen Angus graze. Downstream, russet oaks border Cotehele mill, their falling leaves set to wash into the tidal river—a nod to historic leaf-mould fertiliser collection.

articles.title: Nazi bombs, torpedo heads and mines: how marine life thrives on dumped weapons
articles.trailText: Scientists discover thousands of sea creatures have made their homes amid the detritus of abandoned second world war munitions off the coast of Germany
articles.summary: In the Bay of Lübeck’s shallow, muddy Baltic seafloor, over 1.6m tonnes of WWII bombs, torpedoes and mines dumped after 1945 have rusted into a carpet that supports surprisingly dense marine life. Researchers led by Andrey Vedenin documented >40,000 animals per m²—starfish, fish, crabs, anemones and mussels—colonizing metal shells and TNT casings, compared with 8,000/m² in surrounding sediments. The armaments function as artificial reefs, replacing pre-war boulders removed by dredging, and mirror rig-to-reef programmes. As nations plan munition removal, scientists warn that marine communities built on these “weapons reefs” must be protected or substituted with safe hard substrates to preserve biodiversity.

articles.title: Turkey to host Cop31 climate conference after Australia drops push to hold it in Adelaide
articles.trailText: Fortnight-long event to be held in Antalya but Australian climate change minister Chris Bowen expected to lead the negotiations
articles.summary: Turkey will host the COP31 climate conference in Antalya in November 2026 after Australia unexpectedly abandoned its Adelaide bid. At COP30 in Belém, ministers Chris Bowen and Murat Kurum agreed on a compromise: Turkey assumes the COP presidency while Australia takes a new “president for negotiations” role, backed by a proposed pre-COP31 Pacific pledging event for a resilience fund. The deal, pending UN plenary ratification, aims to avoid a deadlocked summit in Bonn. Pacific leaders, clean energy investors and South Australian authorities voiced disappointment, though PM Albanese hailed it as a pragmatic resolution.

articles.title: Papua New Guinea ‘not happy’ as Australia walks away from bid to host Cop31
articles.trailText: Australia had been pushing to host climate conference next year with south Pacific nations, which are increasingly threatened by rising seas and climate-fuelled disasters
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea’s foreign minister, Justin Tkatchenko, condemned Australia’s withdrawal from its proposed ‘Pacific Cop’ bid to co-host next year’s COP31 climate summit, handing hosting rights to Turkey while Australia leads negotiations. Pacific island states, already grappling with rising seas and disasters, lamented the lost opportunity to amplify their concerns and hold major emitters accountable. Tkatchenko dismissed COP as a “talk fest.” Tuvalu’s ex-PM accused Australia of lacking commitment to climate justice and urged a rethink of regional ties.

articles.title: We must improve public awareness of flood risk and build resilience | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Thorough reform of how flooding is managed is necessary to reconnect people to their watery environments, says Dr Ed Rollason . Plus a letter from Moira Robinson
articles.summary: Dr Ed Rollason argues that despite detailed flood-risk maps from the Environment Agency and community resilience officers, UK public awareness and preparedness remain low (45% aware of risk, 7% aware of property risk in a 2016 poll). He attributes this to a centralised, technocratic approach that excludes communities and calls for devolving flood-management powers to well-funded local authorities, fostering trusted relationships, unified risk understanding, and combining infrastructure, nature-based solutions and community action. Moira Robinson adds that Nathalie Lees’s illustration would suit Ian McEwan’s new novel What We Can Know, suggesting its relevance for planning committees.

articles.title: Divide over fossil fuels phaseout can be bridged, Cop30 president says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: André Corrêa do Lago says rise of clean energy must be acknowledged and rich countries need to do more
articles.summary: At COP30 in Brazil, summit president André Corrêa do Lago urged oil producers to recognize the rise of clean energy and called on wealthy nations to boost sustainable finance and technology—through better leverage of existing funds, debt-for-nature swaps and multilateral bank resources—to bridge the deep divide over fossil fuel phase-outs. Over 80 delegates back a transition roadmap, but petrostates resist. Corrêa do Lago argues negotiations can move beyond binary standoffs by addressing internal contradictions, endorsing “coalitions of the willing” and Brazil’s pragmatic “action agenda” for net-zero progress outside formal consensus.

articles.title: People in the US: tell us how the climate crisis has affected your life in small ways this year
articles.trailText: We want to hear about how these shifts showed up in your everyday lives this year
articles.summary: Guardian invites US readers to share firsthand accounts of how the climate crisis has reshaped everyday routines and personal rituals this year. Beyond record storms and species decline, contributors may recount subtle yet poignant losses—a childhood fishing spot dried up by drought, summer campfire gatherings canceled due to wildfire risk, the fall of a beloved backyard tree, or lifestyle adjustments made to reduce emissions. The outlet seeks diverse voices documenting private grief, adaptive measures and small sacrifices that often go unreported, offering a window into local-scale changes across America.

articles.title: Tropical cyclone Fina intensifies to category two and could hit NT coast on Friday
articles.trailText: If it makes impact on Friday, it would be the earliest cyclone of the season to make landfall in Australia since 1973
articles.summary: Tropical cyclone Fina intensified to Category 2 on Wednesday night and is tracking east of Darwin before turning south, with potential NT landfall on Friday or Saturday. A 21–22 November impact would match Australia’s earliest record (Ines, 21 Nov 1973) and set a Northern Territory record, surpassing Alessia (27 Nov 2013). Darwin’s last major hit was Cyclone Marcus in 2018 (Category 2, 130 km/h gusts). Above-average Timor Sea temperatures and Fina’s compact size could drive rapid intensification. Experts warn climate change is reducing cyclone frequency but increasing peak intensity.

articles.title: Researchers say real impact of deforestation being hidden in Australia’s official figures by ‘sleight of hand’
articles.trailText: Report commissioned by conservationists suggests some recorded new growth is misclassified or otherwise not equivalent to losses in species-heavy forests
articles.summary: New analysis by Griffith University’s Climate Action Beacon, commissioned by the Australian Conservation Foundation, reveals Australia's net forest cover gains mask gross losses of old‐growth, high‐biodiversity forests. Official figures since 2008 use net accounting, offsetting diverse old‐growth clearances against regrowth in low‐carbon dry woodlands, skewing conservation and carbon storage data. The report finds misclassification of change areas and that clearance regions emit up to 120× more greenhouse gases per hectare than carbon sequestered elsewhere. Experts urge switching to gross loss/gain metrics to meet Glasgow forest commitments, biodiversity targets and net‐zero goals.

articles.title: China doesn’t want to lead alone on climate policies, senior adviser warns
articles.trailText: Exclusive: A top official in Beijing’s Cop delegation says China is committed to clean energy – but US’s absence is a problem
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, senior Chinese climate adviser Wang Yi says China remains committed to a low-carbon transition—scaling up wind, solar, green hydrogen and EVs, funding vulnerable nations and flattening emissions for 18 months—but won’t lead solo without US participation. He urges multilateral cooperation, warns against a one-size-fits-all roadmap and flags trade barriers and high EU carbon prices as obstacles. With potential US policy reversals under Trump and EU distraction, China calls on wealthier nations to deliver on $1.3 trn climate finance and share leadership in steering global energy targets.

articles.title: Mountain of waste dumped in Oxfordshire field contains rubbish from councils
articles.trailText: Evidence of waste from primary schools and local authorities in south-east England points to possible large-scale corruption, expert says
articles.summary: An illegal dump up to 6m high and 150m long in a Kidlington field beside the River Cherwell contains rotting household and local authority waste – including from primary schools across south-east England. Evidence of macerated refuse suggests organised crime and possible large-scale fraud in council waste management, warn lawyers. The Environment Agency is pursuing a criminal probe and cease-and-desist orders but won’t clear the site; MP Calum Miller urges urgent government action as leachate, microplastics and hydrocarbons threaten the floodplain ecosystem and drinking supplies.

articles.title: ‘Deathly silent’: two out of three corals in world heritage-listed Ningaloo reef have been killed, scientists confirm
articles.trailText: One expert says she is ‘starting to visualise the point where all we have left of corals and reefs is memories’
articles.summary: Two-thirds of corals at Ningaloo reef’s popular northern lagoon died after a marine heatwave last summer/autumn, leaving keystone species lost and “deathly silent” habitats. Curtin University’s survey of 1,600 corals in March found extensive bleaching; by October, about 1,000 had perished. Though nearby Exmouth Gulf fared better, northern sites saw marked biodiversity loss and habitat simplification. Part of the fourth global mass bleaching linked to greenhouse-driven ocean warming, scientists warn reefs are nearing ecosystem collapse and may soon exist only in memory.

articles.title: Heat-pump homes put less strain on grid than expected, study shows
articles.trailText: Analysis of new-builds in Birmingham suggests all-electric homes not only use less energy but vary in peak usage
articles.summary: Year-long monitoring of seven all-electric social homes in Birmingham’s Project 80 reveals air-source heat pumps, high insulation and rooftop solar (no batteries) produced peak demands lower than predicted and varied load timings that ease grid stress. Annual consumption was 40–67% below UK averages, outstripping Energy Performance Certificate forecasts and underscoring the need for realistic modelling. Resident behaviors (e.g., unnecessary immersion-heater use) indicate further savings. Occupants report no damp or mould, improved health, and support scaling to 95 homes with battery storage under 2027 standards mandating heat pumps and solar panels.

articles.title: Country diary: The green in this gully has conquered all | Derek Niemann
articles.trailText: Frome, Somerset: The dampness lingers here, and there is no wind – perfect conditions for a total victory for fern, ivy, and, most of all, moss
articles.summary: In a secluded gully near Frome, Somerset, lingering dampness and still air have created perfect conditions for ivy, a profusion of lime-loving hart’s-tongue, buckler and shield ferns, and an all-enveloping carpet of moss to conquer every surface. Hart’s-tongue and shield ferns coat gorge walls in glossy green; spleenwort emerges from crumbling ironworks masonry. Soft, turf-like moss swathes trunks, branches and stones, trailing like lime tinsel in every fork. This lush, emerald realm, framed by distant gold and brown woodlands, testifies to nature’s subtle dominance.

articles.title: Keeping promises on renewables, energy efficiency and methane ‘would avoid nearly 1C of global heating’
articles.trailText: Analysis published at Cop30 summit shows adhering to pledges offers world hope of avoiding climate breakdown
articles.summary: A COP30‐published analysis shows that if governments deliver on promises to triple renewable energy by 2030, double energy efficiency, and cut methane emissions by 30%, they could avoid roughly 0.9 °C of warming this century. In G20 nations alone, these measures would lower emissions by 18 billion tonnes by 2035, slowing the warming rate by a third this decade and nearly halving it by 2040, reducing projected temperature rise from 2.6 °C to about 1.7 °C—close to the Paris 1.5 °C target. While renewables investment has topped $2 trillion, led by China and India, methane reductions lag amid underreporting and political resistance. COP30 must shift from pledges to implementation, secure finance for poorer countries, and begin planning a fossil‐fuel phaseout roadmap.

articles.title: More than 80 countries at Cop30 join call for roadmap to fossil fuel phase-out
articles.trailText: Countries from Africa, Asia, Latin America, Pacific and Europe plead for transition to be central outcome of talks
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, over 80 nations—from Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Pacific plus EU states and the UK—demanded a clear roadmap to phase out fossil fuels, framing it as essential to meet 1.5°C goals and strengthen weak NDCs. Spearheaded by Marshall Islands envoy Tina Stege and supported by Greenpeace, they challenged petrostates’ pushback after Cop28’s watered-down resolution. Brazil’s draft decision now includes an optional phase-out plan, but proponents like Vanuatu’s minister call for binding targets and measurable steps. The coalition stresses tailored transitions, financial and technology support for developing countries, and warns that Saudi Arabia, Russia and other veto-prone states could still block consensus.

articles.title: Bhutan PM on leading the first carbon-negative nation: ‘The wellbeing of our people is at the centre of our agenda’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tshering Tobgay says his country is doing ‘a lot more than our fair share’ on climate and west must step up ‘for the happiness of your people’
articles.summary: Bhutan’s Prime Minister Tshering Tobgay says his carbon-negative Himalayan nation—home to 750,000 people and 72% forest cover—demonstrates that prioritizing Gross National Happiness alongside hydro, solar, wind and green hydrogen projects, strict transport, building and agriculture regulations, and constitutional safeguards (60% forest mandate) can drive robust social, environmental and economic progress. Bhutan graduated from the UN’s LDC category in 2023 without sacrificing conservation, yet still endures floods, droughts and glacial melt. Tobgay urges wealthy emitters to reduce emissions, transfer finance and technology, and reward effective climate stewardship, citing Bhutan’s leadership in founding a carbon-neutral alliance with Panama, Suriname and Madagascar at COP29.

articles.title: ‘Sustainable’ Cambridge busway will cause irreversible ecological harm, inquiry told
articles.trailText: Planned route linking Cambourne to Cambridge will go through one of county’s last traditional orchards
articles.summary: Planned £160m off-road busway from Cambourne to Cambridge would cut through Coton Orchard – one of Cambridgeshire’s last 24-ha traditional orchards and an irreplaceable habitat of veteran Bramley trees, rare moths, bats and birds. At a public inquiry until 21 Nov, Greater Cambridge Partnership touts the route for housing growth, congestion relief, unlocking the 3,500-home Bourn Airfield scheme and 20% biodiversity net gain, while opponents (24,000+ signatories, Coton parish council) argue consultants misclassified habitat, offsetting claims are invalid and irreversible ecological loss looms. On-road A1303 alternatives are urged, with national precedent at stake.

articles.title: ‘Without our expertise, mistakes get made’: the Cop30 campaign to give workers a voice
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: The green transition’s effect on workers is a hot topic, as advocates push for those working at the frontlines to have a say in climate policy
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil, labour and climate justice advocates are pushing the Belém Action Mechanism (BAM)—a proposal backed by the G77+China—to embed worker input and monitor a “just transition” in UN climate policy. Canadian stormwater supervisor Konrad Beston (CUPE, B.C.) highlighted his understaffed team struggling to replace undersized infrastructure amid heavy rainstorms, atmospheric river floods and to protect salmon. BAM aims to ensure green jobs are stable, well-paid and benefit communities, reflecting Indigenous seven-generations principles and preventing worker disillusionment that fuels “greenlash.”

articles.title: California farms applied millions of pounds of Pfas to key crops, study finds
articles.trailText: ‘Forever chemicals’ sprayed on almonds, grapes, tomatoes and other crops as activists warn of ‘obvious problem’
articles.summary: From 2018–2023 California cropland saw ~2.5m lb/year (15m lb total) of PFAS-laced pesticides applied to almonds, pistachios, grapes, tomatoes and more, per EWG’s review of state pesticide data. Short-chain PFAS in 51 compounds across 58 counties (notably Fresno, Kern, San Joaquin, Napa, Riverside) persist in soil, water and produce, raising cancer, liver, kidney and immune risks. Advocates warn the Biden EPA downplayed findings, while the EU has banned key PFAS, underscoring regulatory gaps and exposure uncertainties.

articles.title: At least 15 English sewage plants use plastic beads spilled at Camber Sands
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Experts urge water companies to update plants to avoid another catastrophe, as analysis reveals scale of use
articles.summary: Guardian analysis finds at least 15 sewage works along England’s south and south-west coasts (Sussex, Cornwall, Devon, Dorset) still use floating plastic bio-beads—contaminated in the recent 650m spill at Camber Sands—to treat sewage. Built around 30 years ago, these plants hold billions of beads in purification tanks, separated only by mesh screens. Experts warn mesh failures release microplastic beads carrying toxins (PAHs, heavy metals), harming wildlife and entering food chains. The government holds no nationwide tracking; campaigners urge water firms (Southern, South West, Wessex) to retrofit with membrane tech or phase out beads, raising infrastructure-investment concerns in coastal communities.

articles.title: The rainforest the world forgot: the Congo basin is the second largest on Earth, so why is it being neglected?
articles.trailText: It is one of the world’s most vital carbon sinks, but this tropical rainforest is losing out when it comes to climate policy and funding
articles.summary: The Congo basin, Earth’s second-largest rainforest and a critical carbon sink absorbing an estimated 600 Mt of CO₂ annually, shelters 10,000 plant species (30% endemic) and endangered wildlife. Despite intact forests and vital rainfall feeding the Sahel and Nile, it received just 16% of global rainforest funding from 2008–22—and only 0.1% for research—versus 47% for the Amazon and 37% for Southeast Asia. Experts warn deforestation is rising, data gaps impede monitoring, and regional scientists are scarce. They urge mobilizing immediate finance, training 1,000 PhD-level researchers, and reframing support as a global climate imperative rather than charity.

articles.title: More than 300 big agriculture lobbyists have taken part in Cop30, investigation finds
articles.trailText: Lobbyists representing industry responsible for a quarter to a third of global emissions participated in key talks at the UN climate summit
articles.summary: Investigation finds over 300 industrial agriculture lobbyists at UN Cop30 in the Brazilian Amazon—a 14% increase on last year and exceeding Canada’s 220 delegates. One-quarter sit within official delegations, six with privileged negotiation access. Agriculture drives 25–33% of global emissions; cattle ranching and soy production spur Amazon deforestation, risking a 2050 tipping point. Delegations include 72 meat/dairy, 60 agrochemicals and 38 biofuels lobbyists (+138%). Major firms—JBS (8), Bayer (19), Nestlé (9)—push biofuel mandates and climate finance, prompting critics to decry big ag’s co-option of talks.

articles.title: Bam! What is the acronym everyone is talking about at Cop30?
articles.trailText: Securing the Belém Action Mechanism is a top priority for climate justice advocates at the talks in Brazil
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, civil society is championing the Belém Action Mechanism (BAM), a proposal to embed a 'just transition' into climate negotiations by requiring states to track progress, coordinate policies, share best practices and prioritise non-debt finance and technology transfer. Originating in labour movements and formalised in Paris (2015) and subsequent COP work programmes, BAM aims to safeguard workers and frontline communities from harms of shifting to a low-carbon economy. Backed by the G77+China plus NGOs, Indigenous, gender and labour groups (representing 80% of the world), it faces resistance from countries like the UK and Japan.

articles.title: Country diary: What is the thrust of the song thrush song? It has to be joy | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Hogshaw, Derbyshire : To hear one in December isn’t totally unheard of – any excuse to revel in that uplifting, deceptively simple sound
articles.summary: In Derbyshire in early December, Cocker hears a rare song thrush singing at dawn, its clear, repeating phrases (“did-uu…did-uu”) demonstrating joyous conviction. Robert Browning praised such double refrains as wise, and public polls rank the thrush Britain’s favourite songbird. Though thrushes normally sing in spring—mistle first, song thrush next, blackbird last—this likely first-year bird was lured by unseasonal warmth. With some 130 distinct phrases, including mimicry of lapwing and snipe, its confident refrains convey pure delight amid a cold winter.

articles.title: European wildcats could be seen again in England for first time in 100 years
articles.trailText: Two-year study finds area of woodland in Devon to be ideal habitat to support a controlled release of the creatures
articles.summary: A two-year South West Wildcat Project led by Devon Wildlife Trust, Forestry England and Derek Gow Consultancy finds mid-Devon’s connected woodlands, low-intensity grasslands and scrub ideal for reintroducing 40–50 European wildcats by 2027. Surveys show 71–83% local support. Wildcats vanished from Exmoor by the mid-19th century and only about 115 now survive in Scotland. The species poses minimal risk to people, livestock or protected wildlife. Success depends on neutering feral and domestic cats to prevent hybridisation; offspring from the RZSS-managed captive breeding programme would be released.

articles.title: ‘This is survival’: Jamaica leads calls from vulnerable nations at Cop30
articles.trailText: Countries including Mauritius and Cuba reiterate life-or-death nature of cutting emissions, calling it ‘a moral duty’
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, Jamaica, joined by Mauritius, Cuba and other vulnerable states, urged immediate cuts by wealthy emitters and increased financial aid, framing climate action as a life-or-death moral duty. Jamaican minister Matthew Samuda cited Hurricane Melissa’s $10bn damage as proof of a “new phase of climate change” and demanded protection of the 1.5°C limit. Cuba’s Armando Rodríguez Batista and Mauritius’s Dhananjay Ramful echoed existential stakes. While procedural gains on agriculture and loss-and-damage aid were made, ministers now tackle contentious finance, trade, transparency and NDC upgrades, guided by a COP president’s proposed NDC roadmap.

articles.title: Three sugar cubes worth of plastic enough to kill a puffin, study finds
articles.trailText: Scientists find tiny amounts can be a ‘fatal dose’ for marine life in the most comprehensive study of its kind
articles.summary: Ingesting under three sugar-cube volumes of plastic yields a 90% mortality risk for Atlantic puffins, the new PNAS study by Ocean Conservancy shows. By analysing over 10,400 necropsies, researchers modelled lethal plastic doses across seabirds, sea turtles and marine mammals: two baseball‐sized volumes trigger 90% death in loggerheads, one football’s volume kills porpoises, and under one sugar cube causes 50% puffin fatalities. Rubber and hard plastics proved most deadly for seabirds; soft and hard plastics for turtles; soft plastics and fishing gear for marine mammals. With plastics found in 47% of turtle, 35% seabird and 12% mammal deaths, authors urge policy to cut production, improve waste management and target high-risk items like bags and balloons.

articles.title: Schools in Australia have closed over asbestos in play sand fears – here’s what you need to know
articles.trailText: Tasmania and the ACT shut schools as recalls issued for products at large chainstores but consumer watchdog says risk to children is low
articles.summary: More than 70 public schools in the ACT closed after the ACCC recalled children’s sand products (Kadink, Educational Colours, Creatistics, KD Magic, Active Sandtub, Magic Sand) sold via Officeworks, Kmart and Target due to asbestos contamination detected in samples. A subsequent ACCC test found no respirable fibres, and experts deem inhalation risk extremely low. Products, manufactured in China where asbestos is still used, may have slipped past Australian import controls. Closures extended to Tasmania, Queensland and NZ for assessment, cleaning and safe disposal. Officials advise wearing gloves, masks and sealing bags before disposal and are reviewing customs protocols and potential further recalls.

articles.title: South Korean decision to close all coal-fired power plants by 2040 sounds alarm for Australian exports
articles.trailText: Decision announced at Cop30 climate conference signposts risks for Australia’s reliance on fossil fuel exports, analysts say
articles.summary: At the Cop30 climate summit, South Korea announced it will retire all 62 of its coal-fired power plants by 2040, joining the Powering Past Coal Alliance. As the world’s fourth-largest thermal coal importer, responsible for 8% of global trade and supplying 30% of its electricity from coal, this pledge signals a significant reduction in demand and risks A$2.3bn of Australian thermal coal exports this year. Analysts warn Australia’s reliance on fossil fuel exports faces a mid-term decline and urge a pivot to renewables, green metals and critical minerals to align with global decarbonisation trends.

articles.title: AI is guzzling energy for slop content – could it be reimagined to help the climate?
articles.trailText: Some experts think AI could be used to lower, rather than raise, planet-heating emissions – others aren’t so convinced
articles.summary: At UN climate summit COP30, a coalition including UN bodies and Brazil launched the AI Climate Institute, promoting “AI for good” to cut emissions through optimized transit, agriculture, energy grids and faster weather and disaster forecasting. Proponents cite analyses by Climate Change AI and LSE forecasting a 3.2–5.4 bn-tonne CO2 reduction over the next decade. Critics note surging data centre demand could add 44 m tonnes by 2030, fuel oil expansion and that true solutions require phasing out fossil fuels, not a techno-utopian AI fix.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Storm Claudia brings more flooding to Portugal and Spain
articles.trailText: Heavy rainfall hit Galicia region first before slowly moving across western parts of the Iberian peninsula
articles.summary: Storm Claudia, named by Spain’s AEMET, stalled northwest of the Iberian peninsula, delivering 80–150 mm of rain across Galicia and heavy showers in Portugal. Flooding from the overflowing Tagus River killed an elderly Lisbon couple. In Albufeira, a tornado struck a campsite and hotel, killing an 85-year-old British woman and injuring 28. Claudia set a record 29.8 °C in south-west France before clashing with a cold front to form a rain band from Ireland to Russia, causing severe Welsh flooding. As it weakens, cold air will usher in winter. Meanwhile, an “atmospheric river” brought 100–200 mm of rain to California, sparking flash floods, mudslides and three deaths.

articles.title: ‘Damned if we do but completely stuffed if we don’t’: heatwaves will worsen longer net zero is delayed
articles.trailText: A new study suggests heatwaves will not revert back towards preindustrial conditions for at least 1,000 years after emissions target reached
articles.summary: Simulations show delaying net zero from 2030 to 2060 intensifies heatwaves—hotter, longer and more frequent globally, with equatorial regions set to break records annually by 2050. Even if net zero is achieved, stabilising at 1.5–2 °C locks in unprecedented heat for centuries and preindustrial extremes won’t return for ~1,000 years. Lead author Prof Sarah Perkins-Kirkpatrick warns 'we’re damned if we do but completely stuffed if we don’t,' stressing we’re already locked into warming. Researchers urge immediate decarbonisation and adaptation planning. The CSIRO-ARC 21C Weather Access model defines heatwaves as >3 consecutive days above the 90th percentile of daily maxima; independent expert Prof David Karoly notes a clear CO₂-temperature link but flags model resolution and rainfall uncertainties.

articles.title: Country diary: Walking the storm path through an ever-changing pinewood | Amanda Thomson
articles.trailText: Abernethy, Cairngorms: Even in this part-plantation where there is much uniformity, high winds ensure the woodland can never stay the same
articles.summary: In Abernethy's mixed Scots pine plantation, ravaged by Storm Amy, Amanda Thomson traces a diagonal 'storm path' of windthrown larches and pines. The fresh canopy gaps reveal ancient 'granny' pines and begin ecological succession: deadwood hosts rare beetles, ants, fungi; light encourages birch, rowan and juniper pioneers; root plates collect water for amphibians and dragonflies; dust-bathing sites for capercaillies. As daylight filters through flickering bronze leaves under strengthening gusts, the woodland's dynamic transformation epitomises nature's resilience and vulnerability by late autumn.

articles.title: France’s birds start to show signs of recovery after bee-harming pesticide ban
articles.trailText: Analysis shows small hike in populations of insect-eating species after 2018 ruling, but full recovery may take decades
articles.summary: France’s first post-ban study, published in Environmental Pollution, finds that four years after the EU banned field use of neonicotinoids in 2018, insectivorous bird numbers in France rose 2–3%, based on data from 1,900 sites and 57 species in the French Breeding Bird Survey. Sites with neonicotinoid use still had 12% fewer insect-eating birds than untreated areas. Species like blackbirds, blackcaps and chaffinches led gains; generalists saw little change. Researchers warn full recovery may take decades due to soil persistence and call for long-term monitoring and sustainable farming to boost biodiversity.

articles.title: Have courage to create fossil fuel phaseout roadmap at Cop30, Brazilian minister urges
articles.trailText: Marina Silva says contentious plan would be ‘ethical answer’ to climate crisis but does not commit Brazil to it
articles.summary: At COP30 in Brazil, Environment Minister Marina Silva urged countries to voluntarily draw up an “ethical” fossil fuel phase-out roadmap—self-determined and non-binding—to match scientific consensus on the climate crisis. As host, Brazil remains neutral on the formal agenda but, backed by President Lula, secured off-agenda discussion. COP28’s open-ended commitment stalled at COP29 due to oil-exporter opposition. Silva said a structured, multiyear process with criteria, governance and safeguards could begin if roughly 60 of the 195 UNFCCC members support it, despite an estimated 40 against it.

articles.title: Can Cop30 begin the process of phasing out fossil fuels?
articles.trailText: Ending use of coal, oil and gas is essential in tackling climate crisis – but even talking about it is controversial
articles.summary: Two years after Cop28’s historic inclusion of a pledge to “transition away from fossil fuels,” the phaseout remains contentious at Cop30 in Brazil. Formal agenda items are limited by consensus rules, so discussions will shift to parallel “action agenda” sessions. Coal, oil and gas remain the major emission sources, and a coalition led by the UK, EU states, Colombia and small island and vulnerable countries aims to launch a multi‐year forum toward a nonbinding roadmap. Opposition from Saudi Arabia, Russia and other petro‐states may stall binding commitments, though a “coalition of the willing” could emerge for Cop31 or Cop32.

articles.title: South Pacific nation of Tuvalu rebukes Trump’s ‘shameful disregard’ at Cop30
articles.trailText: Minister from islands facing extinction is one of few delegates directly calling out Trump’s climate policies
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, Tuvalu’s climate minister Maina Vakafua Talia publicly denounced the Trump administration’s “shameful disregard for the rest of the world,” marking the only direct rebuke of the US absence. He warned that his low-lying nation—facing extinction from sea-level rise—cannot stay silent while Washington pulls out of the Paris agreement and cuts adaptation funding. Delegations privately criticize US threats to block shipping emissions and impose tariffs, but fear retribution. Observers say Trump’s climate denial and clean-energy rollbacks imperil global negotiations and vulnerable states’ survival.

articles.title: Inside Trump’s scramble to reduce US dependence on Chinese rare-earth metals
articles.trailText: The White House has made it a top priority to return the rare-earth industry to US shores. But is it really feasible?
articles.summary: Trump administration prioritizes domestic rare-earth magnet production to break China’s 90% processing, 70% mining dominance vital for chips, EVs, defense. Tariffs pushed export cuts and spurred alliances with Australia, Japan, Cambodia and Malaysia; Pentagon invested in MP Materials’ Mountain Pass mine-to-magnet plant for jets and drones. US imported 80% of its 2024 rare earths; dysprosium and samarium refinement remain nearly 99% in China. New deposits in California, Wyoming, Missouri, Ukraine, Greenland and Brazil face long development timelines and low-cost competition from China’s state-backed capacity, prompting Interior Secretary Burgum to propose a sovereign wealth fund. Challenges persist in scaling extraction, refining and competitive pricing over years.

articles.title: Bristol to launch world-first ‘clean power hub’ for festivals and film crews
articles.trailText: City council and regional authority collaborate to guarantee renewable mobile energy for next summer’s festival season
articles.summary: Bristol city council and the West of England combined authority will establish a world-first mobile “clean power hub” next summer, delivering 100% renewable grid electricity stored in deployable battery arrays to festivals, large gigs and film/TV crews. Two storage sites in Bristol will supply more than 20 events—including Love Saves the Day and Forwards Bristol—reducing reliance on diesel generators, cutting emissions and improving air quality. Project lead Mark Donne and local leaders Tony Dyer and mayor Helen Godwin hail it as a carbon-neutral, clean-air strategy, with Tyndall Manchester set to evaluate its climate impact.

articles.title: Can methane cuts pull us back from the brink of climate breakdown?
articles.trailText: With temperatures breaching the Paris limit, experts say tackling the powerful gas could buy crucial time as the clean-energy shift stalls
articles.summary: For two years temperatures have exceeded 1.5 °C, risking tipping points like Amazon dieback and ice-sheet collapse. Methane, 80× more potent than CO₂ but lasting ~20 years, has driven a third of recent warming. New satellite data show underreported leaks from oil, gas, livestock and waste. A 40 % methane cut could shave 0.3 °C by 2030, deliver net-zero cost reductions and triple economic returns. Over 150 nations backed the Cop26 pledge, but China, India, Russia and the US lag. Proven fixes—leak detection, ending flaring, coal-mine capture and agricultural reforms—make cuts cheap and urgent. A binding global methane treaty at Cop30 is vital to buy time for the clean-energy transition.

articles.title: Biodiversity offsets didn’t work in NSW. Will Labor make the same mistake nationwide?
articles.trailText: Offsets were meant to be a last resort for mitigating environmental damage from development projects, but rapidly became the default
articles.summary: Scientists and legal experts warn federal plans to replicate NSW’s flawed biodiversity offset scheme nationwide risk repeating failures: offsets intended as last-resort mitigation became default, with many never delivered or on already-protected land. The proposed “restoration contributions” fund lets developers pay rather than secure on-ground offsets, overturning a Greens’ ban and weakening like-for-like rules. Audits in NSW found offset supply lags demand, harming species, while pay-and-go schemes enrich funds without habitat gains. Despite NSW tightening fund-use limits, the federal bill preserves pay-to-play mechanics and adds taxpayer-backed top-up provisions funding offset shortfalls, shifting costs to the public.

articles.title: These parrots came to Los Angeles as pets – then went wild. Now scientists are unlocking their mysteries
articles.trailText: Once escapees from the pet trade, Los Angeles’s feral parrots have become a vibrant part of city life, and could even aid conservation in their native homelands
articles.summary: Los Angeles hosts thousands of escaped parrots—red-crowned, lilac-crowned, yellow-crowned and Nanday parakeets—imported as pets in the 1970s. Researchers at Occidental College are mapping their adaptation, hybridization and genetics, comparing century-old Mexican specimens to L.A. birds that interbreed outside native ranges. Thriving on ornamental plants, facing few predators, they occupy palms, sycamores and urban niches. Studies reveal behavioral resilience—roosting on roads, long-distance calls—and potential range expansion into coastal canyons. Endangered in Mexico, these non-invasive feral populations could aid future repopulation efforts. Despite legal gaps, 3,000+ red-crowned parrots now shape L.A.’s urban biodiversity.

articles.title: Thousands hit streets of Belém to call for action during crucial Cop30 summit
articles.trailText: Funeral for fossil fuels held as part of ‘Great People’s March’ calling on governments to step up climate efforts
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, an estimated tens of thousands joined the “Great People’s March,” blending indigenous chants, Brazilian songs and theatrical protests—a funeral for coal, oil and gas—to pressure negotiators on climate finance, biodiversity and ending fossil fuels. Indigenous leaders from Roraima and the Tapajós region decried mining, land invasions and agribusiness; Quilombola activists opposed a hydrovia project; art collectives unfurled a 30 m “cobra” calling for Amazon finance. Anti-capitalist slogans, Palestine solidarity and demands to strengthen national climate plans underscored frustration as talks stall on finance, trade, transparency and NDC adequacy.

articles.title: Fly-tippers dump ‘mountain’ of waste in Oxfordshire field
articles.trailText: Area’s MP says it would cost more than local council’s annual budget to remove the 10-metre high pile of waste
articles.summary: Fly-tippers deposited a 10-metre-high, hundreds-of-tonnes pile of illegal waste in an Oxfordshire field between the A34 and River Cherwell near Kidlington, prompting warnings from local MP Calum Miller that removal costs exceed the district council’s annual budget. Friends of the Thames and other charities call it an "environmental catastrophe", highlighting floodplain risks of toxic runoff. The Environment Agency, criticised for slow enforcement, has closed the site for six months and launched investigations to trace organised crime gangs behind the dump.

articles.title: Indigenous lands must be recognised as part of climate policy, says Brazilian minister
articles.trailText: Sonia Guajajara tells Cop30 the rights of traditional communities must be maintained in the face of exploitation by the mining industry
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil’s Indigenous affairs minister Sonia Guajajara urged that formally demarcating Indigenous lands be integral to climate policy, warning mining interests threaten Amazon territories and contaminate rivers with mercury. She cited peaceful protests that briefly halted talks and appealed to Congress to uphold constitutional land rights. Guajajara also promoted the new Tropical Forest Forever Facility—seeking $25bn in public seed funding—and lamented the UK’s decision not to invest while China’s pledge remains unquantified.

articles.title: ‘We feel we’re fighting a losing battle’: the race to remove millions of plastic beads from Camber Sands
articles.trailText: A huge cleanup effort has seen volunteers working to remove beads by hand and machine. They can only wait and see the extent of damage to wildlife and dune habitat
articles.summary: After a mechanical failure at Southern Water’s Eastbourne treatment works, millions of black biobeads—used to cultivate bacteria in wastewater filters—spilled onto Camber Sands, embedding rare dune and shingle habitats and threatening terns, oystercatchers and marine life. Over 40 volunteers from Strandliners and local residents have laboured hand-picking beads using sieves and dustpans, while Joshua Beech’s Nurdle machine vacuums and density-separates pellets. Ecotoxicology experts warn microplastics can enter food webs and harm hormones. Adjacent Rye Harbour reserve is now contaminated. MPs demand independent investigation and Southern Water–funded remediation, but cleanup costs and ongoing tidal deposits make eradication elusive.

articles.title: Cop30 was meant to be a turning point, so why do some say the climate summit is broken?
articles.trailText: Swamped by lobbyists and hobbled by a lack of urgency, there are fears Cop could become a sprawling spectacle that betrays those who depend on it most
articles.summary: Delegates and lobbyists gather in Belém for COP30, once hailed as a decisive moment to curb climate breakdown, but critics warn the summit is bogged down by misinformation, fossil-fuel lobbying and procedural inertia. Developing nations—underrepresented due to limited resources—struggle amid massive delegations from wealthy states and 2,500+ fossil-fuel lobbyists, diluting ambition and sidelining urgency. Experts argue the COP framework excelled at consensus-building (Paris Agreement, loss-and-damage fund) but is failing in the “implementation decade,” with rising emissions and weakened carbon sinks. Calls grow to overhaul power dynamics and prioritize delivery over diplomacy.

articles.title: Protesters blockade Cop30 summit over plight of Indigenous peoples
articles.trailText: Munduruku people demand to speak to Brazil’s president, saying they are never listened to
articles.summary: Munduruku protesters and international green allies blockaded Cop30’s main entrance in Belém, Amazon basin, to demand President Lula address Indigenous grievances over land demarcation, oil exploration and deforestation. A heavy police presence diverted delegates to side entrances. Cop president André Corrêa do Lago met them for over an hour. The UN-backed summit, first in a democracy in four years, features river flotillas, a parallel people’s summit and calls for a Belém Action Mechanism to secure a just, people-centered transition. Indigenous leaders like Raoni Metuktire highlight fossil fuel lobby dominance and press for finance, transparency and stronger land rights.

articles.title: From Australia to Turkey and, reluctantly, Germany: the tug-of-war over hosting Cop31
articles.trailText: A years-long standoff over who should host the 2026 climate summit leaves Brazilian hosts, and other states, frustrated
articles.summary: Australia and Turkey have been deadlocked for over three years over hosting COP31 in November 2026. At COP30 in Belém, their pavilions were placed side by side, highlighting the unresolved contest. Australia’s PM Albanese champions a “Pacific COP” in Adelaide to spotlight existential threats to island nations, backed by Palau and Papua New Guinea. Turkey insists on Antalya, framing itself as a north–south bridge. Under UN rules, WEOG consensus is required; most members back Australia, none support Turkey. Failing agreement, Germany would be obliged—though reluctant—to host, as Brazil and the UK broker talks ahead of ministers’ arrival.

articles.title: Donald MacIntyre obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Farmer, botanist and founder of Emorsgate Seeds, a leading supplier of native wildflower and grass seed in the UK
articles.summary: Botanist and farmer Donald MacIntyre (1948–2025), founder of Emorsgate Seeds and holder of a royal warrant since 2014, pioneered native wildflower and grass seed restoration in the UK. Educated at Royal Holloway and Glasgow, he developed the first brush harvester for meadow seeds in 1986 at North Meadow reserve. Co-founder of Flora Locale (1998) and member of the European Native Seed Producers Association (2018), he published Restoring the Wild in 2024. A mentor to ecologists, he farmed near Bath with wife Jane Lipington, leaving four daughters, seven grandchildren and a sister.

articles.title: What are bio-beads used for and how did they get spilled on to Camber Sands beach?
articles.trailText: Plastic pellets attract algae and smell like food so can be eaten by birds, fish and dolphins, which can prove fatal
articles.summary: Southern Water accidentally released millions of 5mm ‘bio-beads’—plastic filter pellets used to host wastewater biofilms—onto Camber Sands, East Sussex, after a treatment-plant malfunction. These dimpled beads trap bacteria yet persist as microplastics, attract algae, and smell edible, leading birds, fish and dolphins to ingest harmful pathogens, heavy metals and carcinogenic PAHs. Past 2010 and 2017 spills still linger. Volunteers spent days handpicking beads despite their persistence, raising concerns for wildlife, microplastic accumulation and local tourism. Alternatives include glass beads, coconut-shell filters, porous bio-blocks and electrocoagulation, but these remain costlier or less adopted.

articles.title: Plastic beads spreading on Sussex coast after ‘catastrophic’ spill, meeting told
articles.trailText: Local people describe devastating impact of millions of toxic beads from Southern Water site near Camber Sands
articles.summary: Millions of toxic plastic beads spilled from a broken screen at Southern Water’s Eastbourne sewage works two weeks ago have washed up along 30 miles of Sussex coast—from Hastings to Dungeness—and into the Rye Harbour SSSI. Estimated at 10 tonnes (c.650 million beads), this is likely one of England’s worst plastic pollution events, devastating local wildlife, tourism and mental health. Residents, fishers and kitesurfers have spent days manually sieving beaches. The Environment Agency may upgrade to a category 1 pollution. Southern Water apologised, pledging a shareholder- and customer-funded cleanup while phasing out bead filtration in new plants.

articles.title: Facebook community groups and maggot-infested rats: the inner workings of Australia’s climate misinformation war
articles.trailText: Senate inquiry hears how ‘propagandised misinformation’ is drowning out legitimate concerns in Australia’s regions over renewable energy
articles.summary: Facebook groups dubbed “castles of propagandised misinformation” at a Senate inquiry were blamed for sinking a $500k community battery in Narrabri by spreading fire-risk rumours. Witnesses testified that mis/disinformation on windfarms, electric-vehicle fires and phoney transmission schemes drowned legitimate concerns, polarised rural communities and fuelled online harassment—dead maggot-infested rats among threats. The National Rational Energy Network, with ties to Barnaby Joyce, and the Institute of Public Affairs (backed by Gina Rinehart) helped drive Coalition U-turns on net-zero targets. Experts warn this climate misinformation crisis undermines trust and demands urgent global action.

articles.title: Weather tracker: US hit by exceptional early winter cold spell
articles.trailText: Midwest struck by extreme snowfall and 80 southern weather stations tied or broke low-temperature records
articles.summary: An exceptional early winter cold spell gripped the eastern US on 11–12 Nov, shattering low‐temperature records at 80 southern stations—Jacksonville plunged to –3°C, 17°C below average—and unleashing intense lake‐effect snow across IL, IN and WI (up to 31 cm at Cedar Lake, 5–7 cm in Chicago; even thundersnow). Bands eased as colder air shifted. In the western Pacific Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall in Taiwan as a weakened tropical storm, dumping record rainfall (648 mm in Suao), inundating homes to 61 cm, forcing 8,300 evacuations and injuring 51, before fading to a depression.

articles.title: Yellow fever and dengue cases surge in South America as climate crisis fuels health issues
articles.trailText: Disease outbreaks from South America to Europe have been worsened by rising global temperatures, experts say
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, experts report 356 yellow fever cases and 152 deaths in South America in 2025—the largest since 1960 apart from 2017–18—and nearly 6.5 m dengue cases with 5,000 deaths in Brazil last year. Europe saw 304 dengue cases, reflecting Aedes mosquitoes’ expanded range due to rising temperatures and erratic rainfall. Deforestation, urbanization and globalization further boost zoonotic and vector-borne spread. The Belém Health Action Plan, led by Brazil, WHO and backed by $300 m from philanthropies, will enhance surveillance, capacity building and best practices against climate-driven health threats.

articles.title: Mining firm BHP found liable in UK for disastrous Brazilian dam collapse
articles.trailText: About 600,000 people seeking compensation a decade on from disaster that killed 19 and devastated villages
articles.summary: London High Court Judge O’Farrell ruled BHP Group liable for the 2015 Fundão dam collapse in Mariana, Brazil, despite not owning it then, finding that foreseeable warning signs of saturated tailings and seepage were ignored. The breach released over 40 million cubic meters of toxic waste, killed 19 people, devastated Bento Rodrigues and downstream villages, and fouled 600 km of the Doce River, harming indigenous Krenak communities. The decision paves the way for claims by roughly 600,000 Brazilians seeking up to £36 bn, with damages to be assessed in a second phase. BHP, owning 50% of Samarco, plans to appeal, citing parallel Brazilian proceedings.

articles.title: ‘Eat out to help out’ scheme added to air pollution in London, study finds
articles.trailText: Commercial cooking shown to be cause of unusual peaks when policy was operating during pandemic in autumn 2020
articles.summary: Analysis of London air quality data reveals the UK’s Eat Out to Help Out hospitality subsidy in August 2020 generated unique particle pollution peaks on Monday–Wednesday evenings. Imperial College London researchers found reduced diesel soot but spikes rich in cooking-derived fatty acids and wood/charcoal combustion markers, peaking even on bank holiday Monday. Elevated levels persisted through September–October, indicating lasting behavioral shifts. Commercial kitchens, often ignored in urban pollution control, may account for at least 8% of London’s particulate emissions. Authors urge regulators to recognise and regulate cooking emissions using proven filtration technologies.

articles.title: Graeme Samuel calls for Labor to ditch ‘national interest’ workaround for environment laws
articles.trailText: Former ACCC chair condemns proposed exemption allowing minister to approve projects that don’t comply with law
articles.summary: Former ACCC chair Graeme Samuel urges Labor to abandon its proposed ‘national interest’ exemption in EPBC Act reforms, warning it empowers ministers to override environmental protections under lobbyist pressure. Speaking to a Senate committee, Samuel recommends treating national interest as a factor within enforceable environmental standards rather than a legal bypass. He also denounces the de facto native forest logging exemption, insisting it be removed or subjected to strict national standards. Ex–environment minister Robert Hill and Atticus Fleming back tougher land-clearing rules and equal assessments for logging, mining and development.

articles.title: Country diary: Autumn is a time to rake in the wildlife | Phil Gates
articles.trailText: Crook, County Durham: There’s a contemplative pleasure to gathering up the leaves this time of year, and it’s a benefit to legions of invertebrates and toadstools too
articles.summary: Phil Gates recounts raking fallen leaves around his Crook, County Durham garden, redistributing them under trees and hedges to build humus-rich soil. Over six years this practice has produced lilac-tinted wood blewits, sepia boletes and pallid puffballs, while offering winter refuge to ground beetles, ladybirds, shield bugs, moth caterpillars, spiders, earthworms, millipedes, slugs and springtails. A garden blackbird eagerly forages in the leaf litter each day. By closing this nutrient loop, Gates turns autumn’s melancholy of decay into anticipation and delight, nurturing a vibrant wildlife habitat.

articles.title: Fossil fuel lobbyists outnumber all Cop30 delegations except Brazil, report says
articles.trailText: One in every 25 participants at 2025 UN climate summit is a fossil fuel lobbyist, according to Kick Big Polluters Out
articles.summary: Analysis by Kick Big Polluters Out finds 1,602 fossil fuel lobbyists at Cop30 in Belém—one in 25 participants—outnumbering every national delegation except host Brazil. This marks a 12% rise from Cop29, raising total UN summit fossil fuel presence to 7,000 over five years. Industry delegates received 60% more passes than the 10 most climate-vulnerable nations combined, while transparency gaps persist. Advocates warn of ‘corporate capture’ undermining climate governance and urge a ban on fossil lobbyists after the ICJ flagged continued fossil expansion as wrongful.

articles.title: ‘We’re proud to be pioneers’: inside Spain’s community energy revolution
articles.trailText: From Taradell to Galicia, cooperatives are supplying cheap, clean electricity to homes and helping tackle fuel poverty
articles.summary: Taradell Sostenible, a 111-member cooperative founded in 2019 in Taradell, Catalonia, supplies solar electricity to 100+ households—charging vulnerable members €25 instead of €100—by installing panels on public roofs funded by Spain’s IDAE via EU Next Generation and Sun4All grants. Since abolishing the 2015 “sunshine tax” in 2018, photovoltaics have grown 17-fold. IDAE has earmarked €148.5 m for 200 energy-community projects, expanding the service radius from 500 m to 2 km. Similar initiatives will bring solar microgrids to Galicia’s Ons and Cíes islands, tackling fuel poverty and grid resilience.

articles.title: Multiple ACT schools shut after alert over asbestos in coloured sand products
articles.trailText: Testing and remediation to take place in 16 schools after a consumer safety recall was issued for coloured sand used in sensory play and arts and crafts
articles.summary: Sixteen ACT schools and six preschools were fully closed, and eight more partially shut, after chrysotile asbestos was detected in imported coloured sand used for sensory play and crafts. The ACCC recalled Kadink Sand, Educational Colours Rainbow Sand and Creatistics Coloured Sand sold nationwide since 2020. WorkSafe ACT ordered immediate closures and weekend remediation by licensed contractors, aiming to reopen Monday. A Brisbane special school also shut. Other states issued safety alerts but no further closures; initial air monitoring found no airborne fibres and risk is considered low.

articles.title: Plan for Australia’s largest carbon capture project near Darwin criticised as creating ‘dumping ground’
articles.trailText: Climate advocates fear the project, proposed by Japanese oil and gas giant Inpex, would turn the area into the ‘world’s largest carbon dumping ground’
articles.summary: Inpex, alongside TotalEnergies and Woodside, has lodged plans for the Bonaparte CCS project to inject 8–10 MtCO2/yr into an offshore aquifer 250 km west of Darwin, sourcing emissions from local LNG plants and potential Asia-Pacific imports via a pipeline through Darwin harbour. If realised, it would be the world’s largest carbon capture facility, yet critics warn most CCS schemes underdeliver, risk turning the Top End into a ‘carbon dumping ground’ and serve as a greenwashing tool to justify further gas expansion. The Albanese Government awarded it major project status in July.

articles.title: As Cop30 meets, climate is slipping down the boardroom agenda | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Sonia Falconieri fears the fight against the climate crisis is losing ground in among businesses. Plus letters from Pat Ready and Pete Lavender
articles.summary: Sonia Falconieri warns that corporate interest in climate action is waning: OECD finds only 8% of global patents green, while sustainability committees and pay metrics remain largely symbolic. She calls for stronger R&D incentives and tech sharing to drive transformative change. Trump-era greenhushing and collapsed initiatives threaten to reverse progress. Pat Ready highlights Indigenous exclusion from Cop30’s Blue Zone due to passport rules. Pete Lavender questions the environmental cost of a new highway built for Cop30 despite calls for a global forest fund.

articles.title: Fears for elephant seals as bird flu kills half of population in South Atlantic
articles.trailText: Study estimates 53,000 females have died on South Georgia since 2023, with ‘dramatic impact’ on future of the species
articles.summary: Bird flu H5N1 struck South Georgia’s remote elephant seal colony in 2023, killing an estimated 53,000 breeding females—about 47% of the population—and causing high pup mortality. Aerial imagery from three beaches comparing 2022 and 2024 reveals dramatic declines that threaten the future stability of an island hosting 54% of the global breeding stock, as females take years to reach breeding age. Blocked tourist routes near Shackleton’s grave exposed the scale of die-offs. Researchers warn the virus remains active, spreading across bird and mammal species in the Antarctic, and call for urgent monitoring to gauge long-term ecosystem impacts.

articles.title: Row over definition of ‘gender’ hangs over Cop30 plans to support women
articles.trailText: Advocates say conservative states’ push to define gender as ‘biological sex’ would backslide on decade-old language within the UN
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Brazil, conservative states including Argentina, Paraguay, Saudi Arabia and Russia push to define 'gender' as 'biological sex'—excluding trans and non-binary people—to stall the UN’s gender action plan and roll back a decade of women’s empowerment. Advocates from the Kaschak Institute and WEDO warn this will undermine climate policy inclusivity as women—disproportionately affected by climate impacts—face funding gaps (only 4% of adaptation aid targets gender), rising food insecurity and violence. EU, Norway and Canada call for intersectionality and recognition of women and girls in all their diversity, but face strong pushback.

articles.title: Despite America’s absence, Trump’s influence looms large over Cop30
articles.trailText: Fear of retribution from the unpredictable president has left negotiators in Belém feeling nervous and vulnerable
articles.summary: Under Trump, the US has jettisoned climate policy and actively sought to block renewables. At COP30 in Belém, America’s first-ever no-show initially relieved delegates, enabling progress toward closing the emissions gap. Yet fear of Trump’s unpredictable reprisals lingers: Energy Secretary Chris Wright labels the talks a “hoax” and may return next year, while Christiana Figueres welcomes US departure. Veteran negotiator Bill Hare warns that any concrete consensus could trigger diplomatic pushback, leaving smaller nations feeling exposed.

articles.title: Country diary: Feeding frenzies really live up to their name | Mary Montague
articles.trailText: Tyrella Beach, County Down: The surface of the sea is churning with desperate fish and hungry seabirds. This is life and death down the end of a telescope
articles.summary: At Tyrella Beach in County Down, Mary Montague uses a telescope to witness a feeding frenzy as juvenile great black-backed gulls, adult herring gulls, common gulls, razorbills, guillemots and cormorants converge on a bait ball of sprat and young herring. Individual predators such as mackerel, cod and sea bass corral the shoal from below while gannets slash at the mass. The swirling sphere of fish and diving seabirds churns the surface before dissipating almost as quickly as it formed.

articles.title: News Corp Australia chair says outlets not part of climate crisis ‘denial machine’
articles.trailText: Michael Miller tells Senate misinformation inquiry platforming climate deniers and net zero critics part of ‘great democracy and healthy debate’
articles.summary: At a Senate inquiry into climate misinformation, News Corp Australia exec chair Michael Miller rejected claims his outlets form a coordinated ‘denial machine’, insisting they’re a ‘debate machine’. Under questioning by Greens senator Peter Whish-Wilson—citing submissions from Climate Action Against Disinformation and Climate Communications Australia accusing The Australian and Sky News of bias—Miller defended platforming climate sceptics as healthy debate, disputed definitions of misinformation, defended bushfire coverage (3335 stories, 12% mention climate, 5% arson), denied coordination with thinktanks, and downplayed James Murdoch’s 2020 board resignation over climate concerns.

articles.title: US ‘disappointed’ that Rolls-Royce will build UK’s first small modular reactors
articles.trailText: As Keir Starmer announces SMRs to be built in Wales, US ambassador says Britain should choose ‘a different path’
articles.summary: Labour PM Keir Starmer confirmed three Rolls-Royce SMR small modular reactors (each 470MW) at Wylfa, Anglesey, with £2.5bn government backing and Derby-based assembly, marking Britain’s first SMR deployment. US ambassador Warren Stephens, citing cheaper, approved Westinghouse alternatives and a Trump-era $80bn deal, urged a ‘different path’. Officials insist domestic SMRs—backed by Qatar’s QIA, France’s BNF Resources, US Constellation and Czech CEZ—will drive clean power, jobs and exports, while Great British Energy eyes future gigawatt sites like Torness and Hunterston. Unite warns smaller units yield fewer jobs than a single large plant. Industry bodies praise the boost to the UK supply chain and energy security.

articles.title: World still on track for catastrophic 2.6C temperature rise, report finds
articles.trailText: Fossil fuel emissions have hit a record high while many nations have done too little to avert deadly global heating
articles.summary: Two reports warning that new COP30 pledges leave the world on track for a 2.6C rise by 2100 – far above Paris goals. Climate Action Tracker finds record fossil-fuel emissions and unchanged warming forecasts despite renewed NDCs, risking coral collapse, ice-sheet melt and Amazon loss. Global Carbon Project projects a 1% emissions rise in 2025 and weakened natural sinks, with atmospheric CO2 reaching 425 ppm. Renewable deployment has slowed growth but not surpassed demand. G77+China backs a just transition away from fossils, while experts urge accelerated phase-out and stress climate policy effectiveness.

articles.title: Tussles break out between protesters and security at Cop30 in Brazil
articles.trailText: Dozens storm venue at climate conference that has encouraged NGOs and Indigenous groups to play unprecedented role in talks
articles.summary: At the UN’s Cop30 climate conference in Belém, dozens of Indigenous and allied activists stormed the Blue Zone, forcibly pushing through the entrance and clashing with UN security. Chanting “Our forests are not for sale” and “they cannot decide for us without us,” they were removed after minor injuries to two guards and slight venue damage. Protesters criticized lavish spending on the conference city over education, health and forest protection, and decried Indigenous exclusion. Brazilian and UN forces say the site is secure and talks continue amidst unprecedented civil society mobilization ahead of planned mass demonstrations.

articles.title: California governor calls Trump ‘an invasive species’ at Cop30 climate talks
articles.trailText: Gavin Newsom is most senior US politician at annual talks, heading alternate delegation in Trump’s absence
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil, California governor Gavin Newsom, the highest-ranking US politician present, slammed Donald Trump as an “invasive species” and “wrecking-ball president” for dismantling climate policies, exiting the Paris accord and planning offshore drilling in California. Newsom, leading a 100+-strong alternate US delegation and US Climate Alliance governors, warned Trump’s absence and fossil-fuel push benefit China’s clean-energy dominance. He argued subnational actors must fill the void, transform the climate debate around cost-of-living impacts and grassroots action, and vowed to block federal drilling plans “over my dead body.”

articles.title: Removing CO2 from atmosphere vital to avoid catastrophic tipping points, leading scientist says
articles.trailText: 10bn tonnes must be captured from the air every year to limit global heating to 1.7C, says Johan Rockström
articles.summary: Johan Rockström warns removing 10 bn t of CO₂ annually is essential even to limit warming to about 1.7 °C, necessitating direct air capture on a scale second only to oil and gas and costing ~$1 tn/yr, alongside drastic emissions cuts. Experts predict a 1.5 °C overshoot within a decade, risking tipping points in the Antarctic, Greenland, AMOC and coral reefs. CO₂ removal options—from forests at $50/t to industrial capture at $200/t—carry high costs and unintended consequences. The Cop30 Science Council urges carbon removal and tipping-point prevention be embedded in global climate policy.

articles.title: 55m-year-old eggshells unearthed in Queensland may be older relative of infamous ‘drop crocs’
articles.trailText: Scientists believe new discovery to be the oldest crocodilian eggshells ever found in Australia
articles.summary: Scientists uncovered 55m-year-old crocodilian eggshells in Murgon, Qld, the oldest in Australia, linked to extinct mekosuchine crocs of genus Kambara. Predating modern saltwater and freshwater crocodiles by ~51m years, these ‘drop crocs’ may have been semi-arboreal predators. Microstructural and geochemical analyses by Dr Xavier Panadès i Blas and Prof Michael Archer reveal unique shell features, nesting behaviors and evolutionary distinctiveness. Published in Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology, the find sheds light on crocodilian diversity before modern species’ arrival 3.8m years ago.

articles.title: The spectacular nonsense of the Coalition’s internal brawl over the 2050 net zero emissions target | Clear air
articles.trailText: The public stoush is really about whether the party will drop the charade or maintain it while shuffling some words
articles.summary: Coalition parties, which never backed the 2050 net-zero target since Morrison’s 2021 pledge, are feuding over ditching it or rewording it. Their scrapped nuclear plan would have stalled renewables and boosted coal and gas. Nationals leader David Littleproud repudiated net zero in favor of a vague “better, cheaper” approach. The public spat masks politics: energy bills rose due to the Ukraine war’s gas crunch, coal-mine floods and ageing infrastructure, not renewables. Globally, net zero remains central to the EU, UK, China and 140+ nations. Meanwhile, Labor’s support for fossil fuel exports, shaky carbon offsets and untested climate adaptation deserve scrutiny.

articles.title: Why ‘mob grazing’ may help protect drought-hit Senegal’s vast grasslands
articles.trailText: A regenerative scheme has shown early promise, with herders hopeful it can restore degraded pastures
articles.summary: In Senegal’s Thignol village, community leader Ibrahima Ka pilots ‘mob grazing’, confining 350 zebu cows and 2,000 sheep to intensively graze one football-pitch–sized plot daily, then resting it for a year. After 18 months, degraded semi-arid pastures show returning grasses, insects, saplings and 60% higher water absorption. While early biodiversity gains suggest potential to restore a third of Senegal’s overgrazed drylands, experts warn success hinges on precise herd size, rest periods, rainfall and strong community buy-in.

articles.title: Waiting for the tsunami: its big waves are loved by surfers – but this Canadian town is braced for disaster
articles.trailText: How do you plan for an event whose timing is unknown? For residents of Tofino on Vancouver Island the threat is distant but signs of preparedness are everywhere
articles.summary: Tofino, a remote surf town on Vancouver Island linked to the mainland by a single winding highway, braces for a ‘megathrust’ quake on the Juan de Fuca subduction zone that could trigger a 20m tsunami traveling at 32 km/h. A false alarm after July’s Kamchatka earthquake highlighted evacuation bottlenecks, seasonal tourists and limited sirens in town. Local authorities, led by emergency coordinator Hilary O’Reilly and catastrophe modeller Katsu Goda, are mapping community assets, planning siren expansion and proposing a vertical evacuation tower despite liquefaction risks. The plan balances fear management, Indigenous oral histories and a resilience ethos to ensure a coordinated response when “the big one” strikes.

articles.title: Violent reprisals after DRC whistleblowers discover profiteering in protected land
articles.trailText: Environmentalists seeking to end logging, smuggling and pollution in DRC’s Mangrove Marine park faced threats, violence and rape
articles.summary: An investigation reveals that Kim Rebholz, hired in 2022 to protect the DRC’s Ramsar-listed Mangrove Marine park, uncovered a 400 ha palm-oil plantation owned by ex-president Joseph Kabila, illegal logging ports linked to Chinese group Congo Dihao/Maniema Union and a fuel port—all inside protected boundaries. After demanding an inquiry, Rebholz and his family endured a faked execution, torture and rape by armed men. Despite US sanctions on implicated officials and Kabila’s trial in absentia, no domestic probe followed. Conservationists warn these profiteering schemes are devastating critical manatee, turtle and buffalo habitats.

articles.title: Country diary: A streak of lemon on a drab moorland day | Ed Douglas
articles.trailText: Blacka Moor, South Yorkshire: Even among the yellowing birch leaves the goldcrest stood out, a slight creature with a mighty presence
articles.summary: In South Yorkshire’s Blacka Moor, a cloudy, drab afternoon brightens as sunlight restores colour to yellowing birches and a Russula cyanoxantha mushroom. A goldcrest—Britain’s smallest bird—appears, its narrow lemon stripe indicating a female. Carotenoids from its insect diet both colour its crest and boost immunity; males convert more into orange hues via testosterone to attract mates. Females lay two broods of 10–12 chicks, each growing from half a gram to 6 g in two weeks. This vibrant crown suggests strong winter survival.

articles.title: China’s CO2 emissions have been flat or falling for past 18 months, analysis finds
articles.trailText: World’s biggest polluter on track to hit peak emissions target early but miss goal for cutting carbon intensity
articles.summary: China’s CO2 emissions have remained flat or declined for 18 months, analysis by Crea’s Lauri Myllyvirta shows, driven by 46% solar and 11% wind growth in Q3 and 240GW of new solar and 61GW of wind capacity in nine months. Emissions in travel, cement and steel fell, offsetting rises in chemicals. China likely peaked emissions early but is off‐track on its 2020–25 carbon‐intensity target. Renewables and low‐carbon energy will feature in its 15th five-year plan as COP30 convenes.

articles.title: ‘It will never be forgiven’: UN climate chief warns world to act or face disaster
articles.trailText: Faltering governments will be blamed for famine and conflict abroad, and face stagnation and inflation at home, says climate chief at start of Cop30
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, UN climate chief Simon Stiell warned nearly 200 governments that failure to shift to a low-carbon economy will be blamed for famine, conflict, and economic stagnation driven by climate disasters that shave double-digit percentages off GDP. With global temperatures exceeding 1.5C, Stiell urged rapid methane cuts and a fossil-fuel phase-out to reverse warming. Delegates adopted a full agenda amid disputes over finance, emissions pledges and fossil-fuel transitions. Small island states and Brazil’s Lula pressed for a 1.5C roadmap, while wealthy and oil-exporting nations resist tighter targets.

articles.title: Southern Water apologises for catastrophic spill of plastic biobeads in Sussex
articles.trailText: Resulting pollution on Camber Sands beach poses threat to wildlife including dolphins and seals
articles.summary: Southern Water has admitted that a mechanical failure of a screening filter at its Eastbourne sewage plant released millions of toxic plastic biobeads into the sea during Storm Benjamin, polluting Camber Sands and neighboring Sussex beaches. The beads, containing PAHs and heavy-metal toxins, threaten dolphins, seals, seabirds and risk entering the food chain. Southern Water apologised, is investigating, and is working with Rother District Council and volunteers on cleanup. Environment Agency and water minister Emma Hardy are probing the incident. MP Helena Dollimore demands an independent inquiry and full ecological restoration funding.

articles.title: Trump officials set to approve ‘forever chemical’ as pesticide ingredient
articles.trailText: Critics say that fifth Pfas Trump’s EPA has proposed for approval this year would put food and water supply at risk
articles.summary: Trump’s EPA plans to approve Epyrifenacil, the fifth PFAS ‘forever chemical’ pesticide ingredient in his second term, to be sprayed on corn, soy and wheat. Critics warn it breaks down to trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), a persistent toxin linked to cancer, birth defects and immune disorders, risking food and water safety. Despite campaign pledges to curb harmful pesticides, the agency, led by former industry lobbyists, has loosened oversight, fueling clashes between MAGA and Maha factions and frustration from health advocates like Nathan Donley and Kelly Ryerson.

articles.title: Jailed climate activist facing deportation from UK fights ‘crazy double punishment’
articles.trailText: Marcus Decker is supported by climate experts, religious leaders and celebrities as he fights being first person in UK to be ‘deported for peaceful protest’
articles.summary: German teacher and musician Marcus Decker, jailed for 2 years 7 months in 2022 for climbing the Queen Elizabeth Bridge with a Just Stop Oil banner, is fighting automatic deportation from the UK as "crazy double punishment." Released in February 2024, he remains under an ankle tag. A long-term partner and stepfather to two children, he argues deportation would devastate his family. His appeal in London is backed by the UN environmental defenders rapporteur, 22 Nobel laureates, 562 artists, Lord Hain, Sir David King, Juliet Stevenson and Rowan Williams.

articles.title: The temperature at Cop30: Trump’s absence better than a US wrecking ball
articles.trailText: After bully-like behavior last month over a small emissions levy, diplomats will be relieved if the US stays away from climate talks
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém, diplomats welcome the absence of senior US delegates under Donald Trump—who labelled climate change a 'con job.' The White House shuttered its climate office and used 'bully tactics' to derail a shipping emissions levy. Former US envoys warn Trump’s administration now not only neglects but actively undermines talks, pushing fossil-fuel deals while global clean energy builds accelerate. Small island states decry the vacuum from US Paris withdrawal, urging others to step up. EU officials fear US pressure on carbon border taxes, even as state and city leaders attend to signal domestic climate commitments.

articles.title: ‘I used to be a bit naughty’: Portsmouth defied funding cuts and saved its youth centres – here’s what happened
