articles.trailText: Two decades ago, Portsmouth city’s council chose to fund and prioritise playgrounds and youth clubs to help its poorer families – and the benefits are plain to see
articles.summary: Portsmouth city council shielded six playgrounds and four youth centres from austerity, maintaining postwar-era adventure playgrounds like Buckland that serve three generations of families in a ward with 24% of children in relative poverty. Staff and volunteers such as Maureen Maplesden and her daughter Nicky manage play and youth services for 91,000 annual users, offering safe spaces, mentoring and affordable activities. Studies link closures to poorer GCSE results and higher crime; Portsmouth funds £2.2m/year via rents, retaining facilities that boost social cohesion, mental health and educational outcomes for vulnerable children.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Fung-Wong becomes second in a week to hit the Philippines
articles.trailText: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanas
articles.summary: Typhoon Fung-Wong (Uwan) made landfall on Luzon Sunday with sustained winds of 115 mph and gusts up to 140 mph, following deadly Typhoon Kalmaegi a week earlier, and prompting warnings of over 200 mm of rain, storm surges and suspension of rescue operations for 100+ missing. The system will move into the South China Sea then toward Taiwan, while southwestern Europe braces for 100–200 mm rainfall and 60 mph winds. In the US southeast, a polar cold snap in Florida may plummet temperatures 15 °C below normal, immobilising iguanas and causing them to fall from trees.

articles.title: ‘The tigers are hungry’: endangered but deadly, the world’s largest big cat is sowing fear in Siberia’s villages
articles.trailText: The spread of African swine flu among the wild boars the animals eat has led to the deadliest winter for attacks on people in the Russian region for decades – and a spike in tiger killings
articles.summary: A deadly winter in Siberia has seen unprecedented Amur tiger attacks on dogs, livestock and people as African swine fever decimates wild boar—tigers’ primary prey. Starving big cats are forced from the taiga into villages, fueling a 1,000% rise in human–tiger conflicts. Between October 2024 and September 2025, 17 tigers were killed and 27 captured, many injured or emaciated. Experts blame swine fever, unchecked logging, poaching and politicised conservation under Putin’s tiger centre. They warn only stronger forest protection and independent monitoring can avert further ecological collapse.

articles.title: Country diary: The muted beauty of moth-trapping in November | Susie White
articles.trailText: Allendale, Northumberland: It’s not too late to set the trap for some wonderful species – not least the remarkable angle shades moth
articles.summary: In Allendale, Northumberland in November, White sets a light trap at 10°C despite rain. Moths’ super-hydrophobic wings deflect water, enabling flight; she finds her first December moth (Poecilocampa populi), identifies it by its comb-shaped antennae and dense insulation. Using a black tub trap and egg-box panels, she records species like red-green carpet, small wainscot, chestnut, winter and feathered thorn, then marvels at the angle shades moth’s geometric camouflage. Winter trapping is quieter but yields rich autumnal patterns and fuels her long-held fascination.

articles.title: Rich countries have lost enthusiasm for tackling climate crisis, says Cop30 chief
articles.trailText: Brazil’s André Corrêa do Lago says countries should follow China’s lead on clean energy as conference begins
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, president André Corrêa do Lago warns that wealthy nations have lost momentum on climate action while China races ahead in clean energy production and deployment. Delegates from 194 countries will negotiate stronger 1.5 °C-aligned national emission plans, a fossil-fuel phase-out roadmap and implementation of existing pledges on renewables and efficiency. Small island states demand deeper cuts and reliable finance. Frictions over the agenda persist. Meanwhile, satellite data reveal methane emissions rising among major signatories to the 2030 methane pledge, underscoring calls for a binding treaty.

articles.title: Q&A: what are the main issues at Cop30 and why do they matter?
articles.trailText: Cop returns to its Brazilian roots and attempts to map a path to crucial emissions cuts that navigates financial, scientific and ethical aspects of the climate crisis
articles.summary: COP30 in Belém reunites parties under the UNFCCC to map a 1.5°C pathway amid under-ambitious NDCs that cut emissions only 10% by 2035. Key debates cover overdue NDC submissions, bridging a $1.3 trillion climate-finance gap, and advancing the fossil-fuel phase-out resolution first adopted at Dubai. Brazil champions a $125 billion Tropical Forests Forever Facility to protect the Amazon, plus a global ethical stocktake elevating Indigenous, gender and equity concerns. Proposals to curb methane leaks offer quick wins. The US absence under Trump tests multilateral unity, while Turkey and Australia vie to host COP31.

articles.title: From net zero to NDCs: your comprehensive Cop30 jargon buster
articles.trailText: Brief explanations of 19 key terms likely to be heard at the Cop30 summit in Brazil
articles.summary: This COP30 jargon buster decodes 19 key climate terms ahead of the UNFCCC summit in Belém, Brazil. It explains mutirão (collaborative working meeting), the Tropical Forest Forever Facility’s $125 bn forest-preservation fund, Brazil’s ethical stocktake on climate justice, “loss and damage” finance for extreme weather recovery, “innovative finance” options (carbon/wealth taxes, flight levies), mitigation vs adaptation, UNFCCC/Kyoto/Paris frameworks (NDCs, 1.5 °C, net zero), IPCC findings, methane and SLCPs, carbon offsetting debates and the COP28 “transition away” consensus (para 28).

articles.title: Twice as effective as nets: shark-spotting drones to become ‘permanent fixture’ on Queensland beaches
articles.trailText: State government says ‘traditional measures’ like nets and drum lines will continue to be used despite evidence of deadly impact on other marine life
articles.summary: Queensland will expand shark-spotting drones to 20 beaches after a 2020–24 trial across 10 sites found drones detected 676 sharks (190 over 2 m) versus nets’ 284 detections (133 over 2 m), more than doubling detection rates. Drones provide real-time surveillance, aid rescues and have negligible bycatch compared to nets and drum lines, which trapped 123 non-target animals—including dolphins, whales, turtles and dugongs, half dead. Despite this, traditional nets and drum lines will remain in the 2025–29 Shark Control Program.

articles.title: Climate disasters displaced 250 million people in past 10 years, UN report finds
articles.trailText: Floods, storms and droughts have uprooted people across the globe as rising temperatures intensify conflict and hunger
articles.summary: A UNHCR report finds that climate-related disasters—floods, storms, drought, extreme heat, desertification and sea-level rise—have forcibly displaced 250 million people since 2015 (about 70 000 per day), including repeated movements. By mid-2025, 117 million were already displaced by conflict and persecution. The climate emergency, described as a “risk multiplier,” intensifies existing inequalities and tripled the number of countries reporting both conflict and disaster displacement since 2009. Fragile host states receive just 25% of needed climate finance, leaving refugees in high-hazard countries (Sudan, Syria, DRC, etc.) exposed to repeated shocks. Without radical action, camps could face nearly 200 days of dangerous heat annually by 2050. UNHCR urges COP30 negotiators to prioritize real funding for frontline communities.

articles.title: Slim pickings: what explains the unusual apple shortage in this Blue Mountains orchard?
articles.trailText: Growers are reporting a difficult apple season, which is having a knock-on effect for local tourism
articles.summary: Pine Crest Orchard in Bilpin, Blue Mountains, typically welcomes 1,000 pick-your-own visitors daily. This season heavy spring bloom produced virtually no fruit: blossoms and stalks dropped before setting pea-sized apples. Owner John Galbraith reports similar losses across local orchards, jeopardizing tourism and income. A workshop convened growers and experts considered pollination failures due to wind, varroa mite-killed European bees, and eucalypt blooms diverting hives. Galbraith’s mite-free apiary and regular soil tests show no obvious pathology. Uncertainty prevents preventive measures; Apple and Pear Australia declined comment.

articles.title: Peter Edwards obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Farmer who became the creator of the UK’s first commercial windfarm, in north Cornwall
articles.summary: Peter Edwards, 90, pioneered UK wind energy by founding Delabole’s first commercial windfarm in 1991 on his north Cornwall farm: ten 400kW turbines powering 3,000 homes, rebuilt in 2010 with four 9.2MW turbines for 7,800 homes. Through Windelectric Management with son Martin, he brokered land deals for other farmers and served in Parliament’s renewable energy group. He chaired the British Wind Energy Association (1996–98) and Renewable Energy Association (2002–04). An agriculture graduate, he farmed Delabole from 1961 and, after selling his herd in 1987, pivoted to wind energy as a green response to a proposed Luxulyan nuclear plant. Survived by three children, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

articles.title: ‘Existential and urgent’: what impact will ICJ climate ruling have on Cop30?
articles.trailText: Decision by international court of justice hailed as a gamechanger for climate justice and accountability
articles.summary: In July 2025 the ICJ unanimously ruled that states have an urgent, existential legal duty under customary international law to prevent, mitigate and remedy climate harm—regardless of treaty ratification. On day one of Cop 30, UN experts urged full compliance, a ban on fossil‐fuel lobbyists and transparency. The advisory opinion elevates 1.5 °C from aspiration to binding benchmark, demands NDCs reflect “highest possible ambition” and CBDR, and obliges wealthy polluters to phase out fossil fuels, regulate emitters and finance adaptation and loss‐and‐damage. While enforcement rests with domestic and international courts, small island and climate‐vulnerable states will use the ruling to press for accountability, reparations and transformative action at Cop 30.

articles.title: Forty per cent of Australian women without kids hesitant to have children because of climate change, survey finds
articles.trailText: More than a third of Coalition voters believe temperatures will not rise at all, poll shows
articles.summary: Roy Morgan survey (n=2,000), commissioned by ethicist Clive Hamilton, found 40% of childless Australian women are hesitant to have children because of climate change; 50% of Australians are very/extremely concerned, and two-fifths expect 2050 to be “much hotter.” Concern is three times higher among Labor, Greens and independent voters than Coalition supporters and correlates more with education than age. Over a third of Coalition voters deny future warming. Women exhibit a “gendered risk” calculus, and rising climate anxiety may depress Australia’s birthrate. Among parents, 60% of Labor vs 20% of Coalition voters worry about their children’s climate future; living through floods and fires had little lasting effect on concern.

articles.title: Last youth centre in one of England’s most deprived coastal areas faces closure
articles.trailText: Pie Factory Music in Ramsgate, Kent, runs creative projects and provides a range of support services, but the building that houses the centre is due to be sold off in February
articles.summary: Pie Factory Music in Ramsgate, Kent, the lone youth centre serving one of England’s most deprived coastal districts, faces closure after Kent County Council, now led by Reform UK, rejected proposals to rent or buy the council-owned building. The centre, which supports 1,000 young people annually with counselling, life skills, employment advice and creative projects, delivers an estimated £580,660 in annual savings to public services and a £1.2m taxpayer return. Cuts to youth services and a planned February auction threaten vital mental health and social care support for local 8- to 25-year-olds.

articles.title: Lula’s balancing act: Cop30 Amazon summit juggles climate and social priorities
articles.trailText: Brazil’s president welcomes world leaders while navigating divided government, promising action on deforestation and emissions
articles.summary: At the first Amazon-hosted COP30 in Belém, President Lula navigates a divided government to champion forest conservation and social development. Under Environment Minister Marina Silva deforestation is down 50% and emissions 16.7% in his third term, and Brazil’s $125bn Tropical Forest Forever Facility has raised $5.5bn so far. Yet extractivist pressures—oil and gas licences offshore, BR-319 highway upgrades, waterway privatisation, mining in Indigenous territories—persist under a ruralista-dominated Congress. Scientists warn the Amazon nears a tipping point as drought and degradation intensify. Lula’s summit commits to reversing deforestation and energy transition while balancing agribusiness and community health concerns.

articles.title: Cutting home insulation funding will imperil UK’s climate goals, Reeves told
articles.trailText: Energy firms and charities urge chancellor to avoid short-term fix that could also harm low-income households
articles.summary: Energy firms, charities and environmental groups urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves not to cut the Energy Company Obligation (ECO) in her upcoming budget, warning that slashing home insulation funding undermines the UK’s carbon budgets and fuel poverty targets. More than 60 organisations including Age UK, Citizens Advice, Energy UK, Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth cautioned cuts risk thousands of jobs in the £20 bn efficiency sector—previously costing 10,000 roles—and leave low-income households in draughty homes facing higher bills. They advocate funding insulation via taxation for sustainable bill reductions and carbon cuts rather than short-term levy cuts.

articles.title: England facing drastic measures due to extreme drought next year
articles.trailText: Government and water companies are devising emergency plans for worst water shortage in decades
articles.summary: England faces its worst drought in decades: government and water firms plan emergency measures as the Met Office forecasts below-average winter rainfall. Reservoir levels stand at 63% (vs. 76% average), with some sites below 30%, and groundwater remains depleted. South East Water has applied for local business restrictions; further curtailments may go beyond hosepipe bans. Experts warn a second dry winter could trigger severe shortages, urging rapid water-efficiency measures—leak repairs, smart meters, rainwater harvesting—alongside new reservoirs to avert supply failures next spring and summer.

articles.title: Less arguing, more action: will Brazil’s unorthodox approach to Cop30 work?
articles.trailText: Host uses Indigenous concepts and changes agenda to help delegates agree on ways to meet existing climate goals
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil eschews the traditional 'cover decision' to focus on implementation of existing climate commitments via an 'action agenda'. Hosts invoke the Indigenous concept of mutirão, establishing cross-sector 'circles'—including past COP presidents, finance ministers, Indigenous communities, energy, agriculture and business envoys—to foster cooperation. Early participation by heads of state attracted global attention despite logistical criticism. Environment Minister Marina Silva’s Global Ethical Stocktake embeds equity and justice, while six thematic days span low-carbon energy, forests, agriculture, resilience, social development and finance, aiming for tangible progress over protracted negotiations.

articles.title: Country diary: Lambing in autumn? That’s a local specialty here | Sara Hudston
articles.trailText: Bridport, Dorset: The appropriately named Dorset Horns are perfectly content to have lambs in cooler months, thanks to an obscure genetic quirk
articles.summary: Dorset Horn sheep in Bridport, Dorset, lamb in autumn thanks to a centuries-old genetic quirk originating in 17th-century west Dorset and south Somerset flocks. Registered as a breed in 1891 under royal patronage, their lineage includes the world’s longest-established flock founded by Frederick Fooks in 1906 and now run by his great-grandson Francis Fooks. Horned and hornless Poll variants share white faces and pink nostrils. Their thick fleeces supply felting wool and fibres for biodegradable coffins, while careful breeding supports three lambings in 24 months.

articles.title: Severe storms forecast for parts of NSW as Victoria and Queensland face wet weather
articles.trailText: BoM says destructive winds and ‘very dangerous thunderstorms’ are most likely across the Hunter, mid-north NSW coast and northern tablelands
articles.summary: On Saturday the Bureau of Meteorology warned of severe thunderstorms across eastern Australia, with destructive winds over 125km/h, large hail (>2cm) and flash flooding possible. In NSW the greatest risk spans the Hunter, mid-north coast, northern tablelands and Sydney metro (late morning to early afternoon), threatening property damage, downed trees, power outages and travel delays. Ahead of a cold front, central and eastern NSW face highs around 30–32°C and elevated fire danger. Queensland can expect showers and inland storms moving toward the southeast coast. Victoria may see 15–30mm of rain across Gippsland to the NSW border, with some river rises and isolated minor flooding.

articles.title: ‘Giving up would be a betrayal’: Miliband says 1.5C target still alive before Cop30
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Environment secretary says global tipping points are possible as he rejects far-right climate ‘defeatism’
articles.summary: UK energy secretary Ed Miliband frames climate action as a progressive counter to hard-right populism, rejecting defeatism on the eve of Cop30. He vows to defend the 1.5°C target, citing positive solar-led tipping points and surging clean-energy investment by China, India and global markets. At the Belém pre-COP summit, leaders from Somalia and Kenya pleaded for urgent climate finance amid extreme droughts and floods. Brazil’s Lula da Silva kept fossil-fuel phaseout on the table, while Zimbabwe stressed collective survival. Delegates will negotiate emission cuts, forest protection and funding to avoid a 2.5°C world.

articles.title: Toby Carvery owner urged to fund ‘life support’ for felled Enfield oak
articles.trailText: Sprinklers could save 500-year-old tree that had branches cut off without authorisation in April, says expert
articles.summary: Toby Carvery operator Mitchells & Butlers Retail faces calls to underwrite a ‘life support’ scheme for a 500-year-old oak in Whitewebbs Park, Enfield, chainsawed without consent in April. A Forestry Commission probe and a land-use dispute with Enfield council follow. Arborist Russell Miller says a £10,000 sprinkler and tank system could boost resprouting sprouts; Woodland Trust’s Adam Cormack urges experimental efforts to preserve the ancient veteran. M&B maintains contractors deemed felling a safety necessity and has not committed to funding revival works.

articles.title: ‘If there’s a free alternative, I’ll eat healthily’: how Sweden devised brilliant school meals
articles.trailText: A pilot scheme where students eat nutritious breakfasts using donated surplus food builds on the ‘folkhem’ welfare model to boost health and sustainability
articles.summary: Since 2018 Vinnova’s pilot at Mariebergsskolan in Karlstad has revamped Sweden’s free, universal school-meal programme—anchored in the folkhem welfare model—by using donated supermarket surplus for juice shots, energy bars and oats; redesigning canteens via student-led workshops into multi-zone ‘restaurants’; and enabling public chefs to buy local produce with Environmental Protection Agency support. Employing a bottom-up 'snowball method', the initiative feeds into Sweden’s National Food Strategy 2.0 and 2025 guidelines, boosts student engagement, and has cut 1.7 t of food waste via a digital counter tied to a SEK1 m prize.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Thunderstorms and heavy rain hit Iberian peninsula
articles.trailText: Severe conditions caused by deep area of low pressure to north-west of Spain in the Atlantic Ocean
articles.summary: Orange warnings were issued across Spain as a deep 989 hPa low northwest of the country drove a cold front over the Iberian Peninsula. Heavy rain (30–60 mm in 24 h across Galicia; 50 mm at Cáceres) caused surface flooding and impassable roads. Hail up to 6 cm struck Cádiz and gusts reached 55–65 mph, peaking at 99 mph in Ouria. Elsewhere in Europe, an upper-air cut-off low dumped over 60 mm on Skiathos, Greece. Meanwhile Typhoon Kalmaegi (Tino), formed 31 Oct, hit the Philippines with 80 mph winds (Cat 2), leaving 188 dead, 135 missing and 500 k displaced, then restrengthened to Cat 3 before landing in Vietnam with 93 mph gusts, 10 m waves, one fatality and 260 k evacuated.

articles.title: How thousands of fossil fuel lobbyists got access to UN climate talks – and then kept drilling
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Research shows oil, gas and coal firms’ unprecedented access to Cop26-29, blocking urgent climate action
articles.summary: New KBPO research shows 5,350+ lobbyists from 859 oil, gas and coal entities attended COP26–29 (2021–24), including 90 firms responsible for 57% of 2024 production (33.7bn barrels, enough to blanket Spain at 1cm) and 63% of new upstream projects covering 2.6m km² (seven European countries). State-owned majors from UAE, Russia and Azerbaijan topped the list. Their influence amid record extreme weather prompted calls by Indigenous and climate groups to bar polluters. COP30’s limited disclosure rules for funding omit official delegates, so advocates warn transparency without exclusion is performative.

articles.title: Over 100 US leaders to attend Cop30 climate summit as Trump stays away
articles.trailText: Dozens of US state and local leaders will be at talks in Brazil with president’s team expected to send no representatives
articles.summary: Despite no high-level US delegation, over 100 governors, mayors and local officials from America Is All In, Climate Mayors and the US Climate Alliance will attend COP30 in Brazil. Led by New Mexico’s Michelle Lujan Grisham and Wisconsin’s Tony Evers, plus Phoenix mayor Kate Gallego, the coalition covers two-thirds of the US population, three quarters of GDP and over half of emissions. Concerns persist after US interior secretary’s UAE oil-field visit that Washington may still try to influence negotiations. Youth activists will spotlight NYC mayor Zohran Mamdani’s fossil-free agenda as nations debate Paris Agreement implementation.

articles.title: How we’re killing our internal ecosystem – and what we can do to reverse it
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: Preserving and nurturing the human microbiome has long been linked with improved health. This holistic approach is finally gaining scientific credibility
articles.summary: In this newsletter, Dr James Kinross labels the decline of our internal microbiome—trillions of bacteria, fungi and viruses across gut, skin, vaginal and oral ecosystems—as an "internal climate crisis." Overuse of antibiotics, ultra-processed foods and urban isolation reduce microbial biodiversity essential for wound healing, immunity and metabolic health. Finland's rewilded kindergartens, green walls and soil-contact studies demonstrate rapid boosts in skin Lactobacillus and immunity. Research underscores reconnection with nature—through biodiverse soils, pets, communal eating and outdoor exposure—to restore microbial exchange. Holistic conservation strategies can rebuild microbial ecosystems and bolster human health.

articles.title: Country diary: Red-hot spindle sets the hedgerow ablaze | Nic Wilson
articles.trailText: Braughing, Hertfordshire: This fiery plant is one of the most startling sights of autumn – and it has a place in history in this county
articles.summary: In Braughing, Hertfordshire, Euonymus europaeus (spindle) discards its green anonymity each autumn, its leaves glowing deep crimson and cerise fruits revealing orange arils. William Turner recorded it in 1548—the first wild plant note in Hertfordshire and earliest British spindle sighting—along the old coach road. Today, along the chalky B1368 verge and over the disused Buntingford branch, this shrub alone sets the hedgerow ablaze among lime-loving ash, field maple, dogwood and clematis. Spotting the season’s first red-hot spindle by the old station, the author muses on its centuries-long heritage.

articles.title: Amazon lakes hit ‘unbearable’ hot-tub temperatures amid mass die-offs of pink river dolphins – study
articles.trailText: Droughts and heatwaves causing water in some areas to reach 41C, killing fish and endangered dolphins, say researchers
articles.summary: Research published in Science finds Amazonian lakes are overheating due to drought and heatwaves, with temperatures in shallow bodies like Lake Tefé (only two metres deep) reaching 41°C—hotter than a spa bath—killing up to 200 endangered pink river dolphins and countless fish over a six-week period in September 2023. Surveying ten central Amazon lakes during the 2023–24 drought, researchers recorded record-breaking low-water levels, 75–90% surface loss, and warming rates of 0.3–0.8°C per decade, exceeding global averages. Experts warn repeated extreme heating will devastate aquatic biodiversity, disrupt breeding cycles and food webs, and urge systemic action on fossil fuel emissions to curb further warming.

articles.title: Missing 1.5C climate target is a moral failure, UN chief tells Cop30 summit
articles.trailText: UN secretary general António Guterres urges opening session in Brazil to bring about a ‘fundamental paradigm shift’
articles.summary: Guterres at COP30 in Belém condemned failing to cap warming at 1.5°C as a “moral failure,” warning any overshoot risks ecosystem tipping points, unliveable conditions and security threats. He noted record greenhouse emissions in 2025, a projected 2.3°C trajectory under current pledges and urged a “paradigm shift.” Speakers including China’s Ding Xuexiang, Colombia’s Gustavo Petro, Prince William and UK PM Keir Starmer called for stronger finance, trade reforms and Indigenous rights. Brazil launched a $3 bn Tropical Forest facility and a first-ever Indigenous land tenure pact covering 160 m hectares by 2030.

articles.title: Who are the major players at Cop30 and what do they want?
articles.trailText: Delegates from global giants and smaller nations expected to clash at Brazilian summit over how to tackle the climate crisis and who should pay
articles.summary: Cop30 in Belém pits Brazil, the US, China, India, the EU, small island states (AOSIS) and least developed countries (LDCs) against each other over emissions cuts, climate finance and forest protection. Host Brazil promotes its $125bn Tropical Forest Forever Facility but has weak NDCs. The US under Trump is expected to obstruct through intimidation. China’s modest 2035 target belies rapid renewable growth. India demands richer states fund developing nations’ transition. The EU delayed its NDC amid internal politics. AOSIS, backed by an ICJ ruling, and LDCs will press for firm finance, loss-and-damage and a fossil-fuel phase-down.

articles.title: How could Tropical Forest Forever fund proposed at Cop30 tackle deforestation?
articles.trailText: Scheme aims to raise $125bn to invest in bonds, with returns used to reward tropical countries for conservation
articles.summary: Tropical Forest Forever Facility (TFFF), unveiled at Cop30 by Brazil’s environment minister Marina Silva, seeks to raise $125bn—$25bn in seed public funds and $100bn in leveraged private bonds—to create an endowment whose annual returns (~$800m) will pay tropical nations and indigenous communities (20% share) to preserve standing forests. Hosted by the World Bank, the scheme aims to correct market incentives that favor deforestation. So far only Brazil and Indonesia have pledged. Its success hinges on securing broader government and institutional investments at Cop30, despite concerns over bond-market volatility.

articles.title: Triple-whammy of hottest ever years risks ‘irreversible damage’, says UN
articles.trailText: Experts say 2023, 2024 and 2025 the three hottest years in 176 years of records, with 1.5C Paris agreement target now ‘virtually impossible’
articles.summary: The UN’s WMO warns 2023–25 will be the three hottest years in 176-year records, with the past 11 years now the warmest. It deems the 1.5 °C Paris limit virtually unattainable without temporary overshoot, urging urgent CO₂ removal via afforestation and carbon-capture to restore levels by century’s end. António Guterres cautions each year above 1.5 °C deepens inequalities, economic harm and irreversible impacts. 2024 saw record CO₂ rise and historic glacier loss driving sea-level rise; extreme weather intensifies. Nations must accelerate renewables, EVs and expand early-warning systems—40 percent still lack them—to avert tipping points.

articles.title: Misleading UK adverts for ’very low emission’ wood-burning stoves banned
articles.trailText: ASA action won approval of clean air campaigners, who said some ‘seriously misleading myths’ had been debunked
articles.summary: The ASA has banned adverts by the Stove Industry Association claiming modern wood-burning stoves are “very low emission.” It ruled two claims unsubstantiated: that stoves used correctly or with dry wood produce very low emissions or significantly lower emissions than open fires or older stoves. Analysis shows home wood and coal burning causes about 2,500 UK deaths and costs the NHS £54m annually. Campaigners urged phasing out domestic wood burning. The SIA plans an independent review. The ASA noted modern stoves still emit more PM2.5, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide and other toxins than older models.

articles.title: Scientists criticize ‘straw man’ arguments in Bill Gates climate memo
articles.trailText: Tech billionaire relying on ‘false binary’ with call to focus less on emissions and more on aid for poor, experts say
articles.summary: Bill Gates’s 17-page climate memo urges a strategic pivot from emissions cuts toward poverty relief, drawing swift rebuke from scientists as a straw-man ‘false binary.’ Zeke Hausfather argues funding for climate and development isn’t zero-sum, while Katharine Hayhoe calls Gates’s claim that warming won’t increase suffering a mischaracterization of scientific warnings. Daniel Swain adds policymakers must address the real spectrum of risks—sea-level rise, floods, heat stress. Donald Trump misused the memo to declare victory over the ‘climate hoax,’ a reading Gates says is ‘gigantic’ misinterpretation. Critics stress continued emissions action ahead of COP30 in Brazil.

articles.title: Flooded UK coalmines could provide low-carbon cheap heat ‘for generations’
articles.trailText: Report says proven technology could benefit thousands in poor quality housing and help UK meet carbon reduction targets
articles.summary: New report shows flooded UK coalmines could deliver low-carbon geothermal heat via mine water geothermal heat (MWGH) systems to a quarter of homes above disused workings, cutting UK emissions 10–20% while lowering bills. Heat exchangers and district networks have been proven at scale in Gateshead (6MW supplying 40% of city heat) and Lanchester Wines (heating 30,000sqm). MWGH creates local skilled jobs, stabilises costs and stores summer heat, but faces high upfront costs and a fragmented regulatory regime. Experts call for central grants, coordinated planning and community ownership models.

articles.title: ‘There is no money’: As carbon markets collapse, what happens to the forests they promised to protect?
articles.trailText: After it was found most offsets did not represent real carbon reductions, the money dried up. But successful schemes such as Kasigau in Kenya now face a stark future
articles.summary: The collapse of the $2bn voluntary carbon offset market after revelations that Verra-certified credits overstated emissions reductions has dried up funding for forest-protection schemes like Kenya’s Kasigau corridor, which once drew financing from Netflix, Shell and major banks. Analyses published in Science and PNAS found over 90% of offsets unreliable, triggering a market crash and halting community payments that backed schools, clinics and anti-deforestation monitoring. The elephant habitat now lacks revenue, threatening its survival. Verra’s reform of credit protocols and hoped-for compliance markets could restore demand, but corporate green commitments remain fragile.

articles.title: Country diary: Sci-fi fungi round a favourite old ash | Gwyneth Lewis
articles.trailText: Cwmtydu, Ceredigion: The tree has been laid low by dieback, but the treasures nearby bring to mind miniature brains, the smell of leather and bread-and-butter pudding
articles.summary: In Cwmtydu, Ceredigion, Gwyneth Lewis scales Banc Pen y Parc to admire a massive ash—16 m trunk, 21 m crown—still thriving amid dieback. She catalogues its fungi: yellow dryad’s saddle, parasol mushrooms, dog-vomit slime mould, cedar waxcap (leathery scent) and yellow brain fungus. A lone raven flips overhead. Later at the National Botanic Garden’s Waun Las reserve, she surveys 30 waxcaps (seven IUCN-vulnerable): scarlet, butter and slimy waxcaps, ballerina waxcaps, golden spindles and honey fungus at another dying ash.

articles.title: ‘The ultimate free Uber around the sea’: suckerfish find dream solution to transport woes
articles.trailText: Not only do remora fish enjoy a sumptuous feast of whale skin by hitching a ride on cetaceans, they even breathe easier
articles.summary: Rare footage off Queensland shows remora fish hitchhiking on humpback whales via suction discs. Captured by Dr Olaf Meynecke’s whale-tag cameras, the remora detach during breaches then reattach, sensing speed and depth. While increasing drag for whales, they gain free transport, easier respiration and a feast of whale skin and parasites. Once thought host-specific, remora also attach to sharks, turtles and divers. Whales further ferry barnacles, underscoring their role as mobile marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Still a chance to return to 1.5C climate goal, researchers say
articles.trailText: Report calls for scaling-up of renewable energy and electrification of key sectors to limit peak of global heating
articles.summary: Climate Analytics warns governments’ current NDCs will lead to 2.3–2.5°C warming, risking irreversible tipping points. Ahead of Cop30 in Belém, their roadmap urges revising targets, scaling renewables and electrifying transport, heating and industry to cap warming at 1.7°C by 2050, then phasing out fossil fuels and deploying carbon removal to return to 1.5°C by 2100. Achieving this demands 20% global emissions cuts by 2030 (vs 2019), 11% annual reductions in the 2030s and 30% methane cuts by 2035.

articles.title: ‘We’re leading the way’: Starmer defends plans for green economy before Cop30
articles.trailText: PM defies critics calling for a slowdown as he flies to Brazil, where he may have frosty reception after opting out of tropical forest fund
articles.summary: Keir Starmer travels to Brazil for COP30, insisting the UK is “leading the way” by shifting to a low-carbon economy to cut energy bills, boost growth and secure energy independence. He’ll announce new clean-energy investments as the UK green sector outpaces others threefold. However, his decision to withhold funding for Brazil’s $125bn Tropical Forests Forever Facility underscores caution over the untested fund, risking a frosty reception and embarrassment for Prince William’s Earthshot prize. Starmer reaffirms net-zero by 2050 amid global emissions target debates.

articles.title: Experts call for new taxes on worst polluters to help poorer nations with climate crisis
articles.trailText: Report to be discussed at Cop30 says global agreements should target carbon intensive activities and ‘ultra high net worth individuals’
articles.summary: The Baku to Belém roadmap, authored by Brazil and Azerbaijan for COP30, urges global taxes on ultra-high-net-worth individuals, fossil fuels, financial transactions and carbon-intensive activities to help poor countries meet a £1.3 trn annual climate finance target by 2035. With only $300 bn pledged by rich states, it proposes strengthened international tax cooperation, voluntary sector contributions, debt-for-climate swaps and cheaper private capital alongside safeguards for development and trade. It also calls for social equity measures—including support for workers, women, Indigenous Peoples—and replenishment of multilateral development banks.

articles.title: We need to restore Britain’s connection to nature | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The country must implement a truly connected system of protected areas to preserve the natural world, says Dr Marcelo Lima. Plus a letter from Elia Kabanov on all the ways nature is around us to notice and enjoy
articles.summary: Dr Marcelo Lima warns that despite the UK’s green image and strong environmental laws, habitat loss (98% of native woodland gone) and fragmented protections undermine biodiversity. He critiques reliance on goodwill (“good chaps theory”) instead of accountability, urging a coherent, publicly accessible network of large, connected nature reserves. Elia Kabanov adds that everyday nature—hedgerows, rivers, footpaths—remains abundant across Britain if people take the time to notice it.

articles.title: UK opts out of flagship fund to protect Amazon and other threatened tropical forests
articles.trailText: Decision is bitter blow to Brazil ahead of fund’s launch at Cop30 – and an embarrassment to Prince William
articles.summary: The UK has refused to directly fund the Tropical Forests Forever Facility (TFFF)—a $125 billion investment vehicle to safeguard the Amazon, Congo and other tropical forests—on the eve of Cop30, even after helping design its structure. President Lula had pressed for $25 billion in public pledges; Norway remains committed, Germany is wavering, and the US under Biden would have contributed were Trump in office. The abstention, viewed as a snub to Brazil and an embarrassment for Prince William, drew criticism from ex-minister Zac Goldsmith, WWF-UK and Fauna & Flora, who argue TFFF is a vital, self-sustaining climate-nature finance tool.

articles.title: Scientists thought Great Barrier Reef doomed if global temperatures rise 1.5C – but a new study finds hope
articles.trailText: University of Queensland modelling says reef will suffer ‘rapid coral decline’ in coming decades but could still recover if targets met
articles.summary: UQ’s eco-evolutionary model of 3,800 reefs predicts rapid coral decline: at 1.5C warming, cover halves by 2040; at 2C it nears collapse—yet if warming stays under 2C, slow recovery towards historical levels is possible. The model accounts for heat-tolerant strains, larval dispersal and cooler refugia, highlighting priority areas for conservation. Under current policies (≈2.8C by 2100), cover could plummet to 4%. Lead authors urge emissions cuts as top priority, supplemented by targeted local interventions; experts caution that hope hinges on urgent climate action.

articles.title: Celebrity chefs urge Britons to ‘bang in some beans’ to boost legume consumption
articles.trailText: Jamie Oliver, Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall and major supermarkets want to double amount of beans Britons eat
articles.summary: Celebrity chefs Jamie Oliver and Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, with supermarkets including Lidl, Sainsbury’s, M&S, Waitrose and Ocado, have launched the Bang in Some Beans campaign aiming to double UK bean consumption by 2028 to tackle diet-related disease, rising food prices and climate change. Beans fix soil nitrogen, need 5,000 litres of water per kg versus 15,400 for beef, cost 4.5 times less than meat alternatives, and are rich in fibre—only 4% of Britons get enough. The Food Foundation reports intake must increase sevenfold to meet Eat-Lancet standards. Retailers pledge 15%-50% sales boosts; more partners sought.

articles.title: Britain’s red-tailed bumblebees may have an unlikely saviour in solar farms
articles.trailText: Though intensive farming has ravaged its habitat, could sensitive planting at energy sites aid the species’ revival?
articles.summary: Over the past 30 years, intensive farming has driven UK red-tailed bumblebee (Bombus lapidarius) numbers down. A survey of 1,042 solar farms shows wildlife-managed sites with flower-rich margins and hedgerows more than doubled bumblebee counts compared to turfed installations. While benefits remain localized, linking pollinator-friendly solar arrays across sterile farmland could create continuous forage corridors, aiding queens emerging from winter hibernation and boosting colony establishment and foraging success through the summer.

articles.title: Low-income areas in England and Wales face worst air pollution, analysis finds
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Experts say impact on people of colour and those who do not drive is ‘grave environmental injustice’
articles.summary: Analysis by Friends of the Earth shows that although overall air pollution in England and Wales has fallen by a third over the last decade, the 5% of neighbourhoods still exceeding WHO limits for NO2 or PM2.5 are overwhelmingly low-income urban areas. These hotspots now comprise 48% income-deprived households, 50% people of colour and 60% non-drivers, housing roughly 600,000 children and 1,234 schools. Campaigners decry this ‘grave environmental injustice’ and urge the UK government to align legal limits with WHO guidelines, boost public transport, walking and cycling infrastructure and accelerate electric vehicle adoption to protect vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Country diary: The strange familiarity of moving a mile away | Nicola Chester
articles.trailText: Inkpen, Berkshire: With autumn in full swing, I walk the local area from my new centre, seeing farmhouses and woodland from fresh angles
articles.summary: Nicola Chester describes relocating a mile in Inkpen, Berkshire, where autumnal light transforms familiar farms—Manor Farm, Pinks, Northcroft and the moated Balsdons—and a long-known hill. Beech leaves tumble like toffee pennies, orange clay caps chalk heath edges by pinewoods, while goldcrests, long-tailed tits, treecreepers, siskins and redpolls flit unseen. She passes glossy thoroughbred mares and foals, hears a fallow buck’s rutting call, spots an enormous cooking apple fit for a cart horse, marvels at a molehill fortress and fairy-ring hoofprints, then meets a majestic, antlered buck—everything magnified by her slight shift in centre.

articles.title: ‘A meeting of voices’: flotillas head into Belém ahead of Cop30 climate summit
articles.trailText: Indigenous leaders, environmental activists and forest defenders are determined to make this a summit like no other
articles.summary: More than 100 Indigenous leaders, scientists, artists and forest defenders are travelling by river flotilla to Belém ahead of COP30, staging panel discussions, music and ‘forest university’ sessions on boats doubling as lodgings. Organised by Amazon news group Sumaúma and NGO Health and Happiness, the voyages include the 3,000 km Yaku Mama from Ecuador, the Mato Grosso Answer Caravan led by Rãoni Metuktire and Alessandra Korap Munduruku, the zero-carbon Flotilla 4 Change Atlantic crossing, a Franco-Brazilian scientific river caravan and Greenpeace’s Rainbow Warrior. Their goal: amplify civil society pressure for radical climate action, forest protection and justice.

articles.title: New Zealanders warned to steer clear of ‘bird of the year’ after dive-bomb attacks
articles.trailText: The kārearea becomes territorial during nesting season and walkers have been swooped by the fast-flying falcon in recent weeks
articles.summary: During nesting season New Zealand’s threatened kārearea falcon—the country’s fastest bird, clocked at 200 km/h and named 2025 bird of the year—has been dive-bombing walkers who venture within its 400 m nesting territory, notably on bush tracks near Wellington and Hanmer Springs. Conservation bodies advise avoiding ‘kārearea nesting’ zones and calmly retreating if swooped. With only 5,000–8,000 individuals remaining, habitat loss and introduced predators are pushing nests closer to popular walking paths, increasing human–falcon encounters.

articles.title: New set of forest towns to be built between Oxford and Cambridge
articles.trailText: Communities in the middle of new national forest to show how housebuilding can be delivered alongside nature
articles.summary: Ministers will build a network of new ‘forest towns’ in the Oxford–Cambridge corridor, embedding mass housing within a national forest of millions of trees to marry development with nature. Nature minister Mary Creagh likens it to a postwar garden‐city vision, offering green jobs and climate resilience, while chancellor Rachel Reeves aims to boost the “Ox‐Cam” economy by up to £78 billion by 2035 with new towns and rail links. Residents will live within a 10‐minute walk of woodlands. A second national forest in northern England is slated via a competition next year, complementing the recently launched Western Forest, as part of a £1 billion tree‐planting drive supporting 14,000 jobs and carbon‐rich woodlands under Defra’s plan.

articles.title: Solar geoengineering in wrong hands could wreak climate havoc, scientists warn
articles.trailText: Blocking the sun may reduce global heating – but ‘rogue actor’ could cause drought or more hurricanes, report finds
articles.summary: Royal Society review warns that unilateral solar geoengineering—spraying sulphur dioxide or brightening marine clouds—in select regions could trigger severe regional impacts: stronger North Atlantic hurricanes, Sahel droughts, Amazon dieback or Mediterranean drought. Globally coordinated, long-term deployment could lower temperatures at low cost but masks symptoms, risking abrupt termination shock and failing to cut emissions. Scientists stress the necessity of international governance, transparent research and emission reductions alongside any geoengineering. Debate persists as private actors fund trials and the UK’s ARIA launches experiments, highlighting the urgent need to weigh geoengineering risks against unchecked climate heating.

articles.title: Galápagos had no native amphibians. Then it was invaded by hundreds of thousands of frogs
articles.trailText: Scientists are only beginning to grasp the scale of the issue and understand what impact the tree frogs may have on the islands’ rare wildlife
articles.summary: In the late 1990s, Scinax quinquefasciatus treefrogs—likely stowaways from mainland Ecuador—established explosive populations across Isabela and Santa Cruz, reaching hundreds of thousands per island. Recording nocturnal mating calls, researchers led by Miriam San José estimate thousands per pond but lack precise counts. As voracious insectivores, these invasive frogs threaten endemic insects, pollination and bird food chains, and may disrupt scarce freshwater and brackish habitats with variable metamorphosis timings. Previous control—hand removal and increased lagoon salinity—failed; untested methods like coffee sprays risk non-target species. Without basic ecological data or funding, scientists struggle to assess impacts and devise safe eradication strategies.

articles.title: Australians have been promised three free hours of solar power a day. Here’s what you need to know
articles.trailText: Customers won’t need solar panels to benefit from the scheme – but will need a smart meter
articles.summary: Australia’s federal government will introduce from July a ‘solar sharer’ scheme giving households in NSW, Qld and SA three free midday hours of solar-generated electricity daily—no rooftop panels required but a smart meter is essential. Retailers will offer plans meeting Australian Energy Regulator criteria; rollout may extend nationally by 2027. Several private offers already exist (AGL, Red Energy, GloBird, OVO) and comparison tools are available via Energy Made Easy and state sites. Shifting heavy appliances or EV charging to daylight maximizes savings, though low-use or vacant homes may gain little, and experts debate the need for regulation.

articles.title: Third of British farmers made no profit in past year, report finds
articles.trailText: Only 14% of farmers surveyed for Farmdex report had 10% or more profit margin amid drop in subsidies since Brexit
articles.summary: A third of UK farmers made no profit or operated at a loss last year, while just 14% reported margins of 10% or more, McCain Foods’ Farmdex finds. Post-Brexit subsidy cuts—replaced by smaller, delayed environmental payments—plus a £100m budget reduction, inheritance tax on farms over £1m and extreme weather have squeezed incomes. Half have considered quitting, over 60% report mental health strains and 70-hour peak weeks. Even high-value farms (≥£2.5m) saw 28% non-profit, only 4% deem current support adequate. NFU data show upland businesses lost 37% of support under SFI and Countryside Stewardship.

articles.title: Country diary: Pearls of the ocean that might just return to British shores | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Holkham, Norfolk: A local company is attempting to revive not just European flat oysters, but a whole wealth of species on a nearby seabed
articles.summary: At Holkham, Norfolk, Oyster Heaven is reviving functionally extinct European flat oysters, once abundant enough to inspire Caesar’s invasion and paid in gold. Leasing seabed off Blakeney, the team will deploy 40,000 clay bricks preloaded with weeks-old oyster spats, enabling each mature oyster—capable of releasing about one million eggs annually—to rebuild keystone reefs that harbour 466 marine species. Decimated by Victorian dredging across 90% of wild reefs, these projects, also in Essex, Yorkshire, Solent and Thames, face human regulatory hurdles more than environmental ones.

articles.title: Ofwat letting water firms charge twice to tackle sewage, court to hear
articles.trailText: River Action bringing legal action against water regulator over who should foot bill for firms’ past failures to invest
articles.summary: River Action is taking Ofwat to court in Manchester, arguing its PR24 plan unlawfully allows water companies to pass on more than £100bn in sewage pollution–reduction costs twice to customers via average annual bill hikes of £123. Thames Water, Southern Water and United Utilities are raising household bills by 35%, 53% and 32% respectively, to averages of £588, £642 and £535. Lawyers say past underinvestment should be borne by shareholders, not households. Ofwat defends its safeguards against double charging and rejects the claim.

articles.title: Almost 120 flying foxes hospitalised after giant hail smashes Queensland colony
articles.trailText: Rescued bats taken to RSPCA wildlife hospital in Brisbane’s south-west with injuries including ‘faces that were smashed and broken wings’
articles.summary: In a weekend hailstorm in Esk, Queensland, nearly 120 black, little red and grey-headed flying foxes suffered severe injuries from golf ball–to–cricket ball–sized hail, including smashed faces, broken wings and about 60 orphaned pups. Bat Conservation and Rescue Queensland volunteers and RSPCA rescuers retrieved them, and RSPCA Wacol vets triaged, warmed and treated survivors. Most were euthanised; only eight adults and ten pups remain in fluid therapy, pain relief and hand-rearing before rehab. The Bureau of Meteorology cited widespread severe thunderstorms. Public advised to ring wildlife rescue, not handle bats.

articles.title: Only 3% of international climate aid going to transitioning communities: ‘This is absurd’
articles.trailText: New report on funding to slash carbon emissions finds startlingly low engagement with the people affected
articles.summary: A new ActionAid analysis of nearly 650 projects funded by the Green Climate Fund and the World Bank’s Climate Investment Funds reveals just 1 in 50 meet “just transition” criteria—supporting workers, women and communities through reskilling, systemic shifts and inequality mitigation. Over a decade only $630 m (1 in $35) of climate aid targeted transitions, deepening social risks and fueling resistance. The report warns that sidelining labor justice undermines action, citing a failed Bangladesh agro-scheme. At COP30 in Belém stakeholders demand a Belém Action Mechanism, trillions in grant-based southern finance, GCF principles overhaul and sunset of the CIF to center justice in climate policy.

articles.title: Littleproud says the world is ‘re-pivoting’ on net zero commitments – but is that just spin? | Temperature Check
articles.trailText: The Nationals argue the 2050 emissions target is already causing financial pain and the rest of the world is walking away from it. Neither of these things is true
articles.summary: After months of brinkmanship, the Nationals, led by David Littleproud, formally withdrew support for Australia’s 2050 net-zero greenhouse gas target, claiming it imposes financial pain and that other countries are abandoning their commitments. Evidence contradicts these assertions: recent power-price increases stem largely from fossil fuel market volatility, not rising renewables; Net Zero Australia modelling forecasts A$7–9 trillion in capital investment to 2060 could create roughly 550,000 new energy jobs. Meanwhile 69% of nations maintain net-zero pledges, most enshrined in law, yet the Nationals propose only a vague, undeveloped nuclear-energy strategy. Exiting net zero would breach Australia’s Paris Agreement obligations.

articles.title: The Philippines braces for 20th tropical cyclone this year as Tino looms
articles.trailText: Storm locally known as Kalmaegi expected to make landfall by Tuesday, while a supercell rocks Queensland
articles.summary: Tropical Cyclone Tino (Kalmaegi) formed east of the Philippines with 52 mph sustained winds and 65 mph gusts, rapidly intensifying toward typhoon status. As the 20th cyclone of 2025, it’s forecast to hit Caraga or Eastern Visayas by Tuesday morning, bringing 50–100 mm of rain, flash floods, landslides, rough seas, and prompting school/business closures, evacuations, and travel suspensions. After crossing Luzon it will re-emerge over the West Philippine Sea en route to Vietnam. Meanwhile, a supercell in SE Queensland dumped 90 mm hail, hailstones up to tennis-ball size, torrential rain and destructive winds fueled by low-pressure trough, convergence and wind shear, causing structural damage, injuries, and widespread disruption.

articles.title: Exxon funded thinktanks to spread climate denial in Latin America, documents reveal
articles.trailText: Texas-based fossil fuel company financed Atlas Network in attempt to derail UN-led climate treaty process
articles.summary: Newly released documents reveal ExxonMobil secretly gave Atlas Network about $50,000 (≈$100K today) from the late 1990s to early 2000s to enable free-market thinktanks in Latin America (e.g., Argentina’s Fundación República para una Nueva Generación and Brazil’s Instituto Liberal) to translate and distribute climate denial materials, host US denialists like Patrick Michaels, and lobby policymakers against UN climate treaties. This behind-the-scenes strategy aimed to sow doubt among developing nations, exacerbating resistance at key COP negotiations. Critics warn its legacy persists as global emissions soar and irreversible environmental tipping points neared with COP30 looming in Brazil.

articles.title: Drinking Water Inspectorate ordered action over ‘forever chemicals’ risk
articles.trailText: Analysis finds regulator for England and Wales raised issues with untreated water at facilities serving millions
articles.summary: The Drinking Water Inspectorate has ordered companies across England and Wales to act after PFAS—persistent ‘forever chemicals’ including PFOS and PFOA—were detected above safety limits in untreated water at hundreds of treatment works, reservoirs and boreholes serving over 6 million people. Anglian, Wessex, Severn Trent, South Staffordshire, South West, Affinity and United Utilities must step up PFAS monitoring, improve treatment or blend sources by mandated deadlines. PFAS limits have been tightened to 100 ng/L, but contamination from airports, military sites, chemical plants and sewage sludge endures. Experts warn UK standards trail stricter EU thresholds, cleanup could cost £1.6 trn and urge polluter-pays enforcement.

articles.title: Country diary: A little remote control goes a long way in farming | Andrea Meanwell
articles.trailText: Tebay, Cumbria: It could take me hours to find my cattle on some mornings. Introducing tech has helped enormously
articles.summary: In this Country Diary entry from Tebay, Cumbria, farmer Andrea Meanwell describes deploying GPS-enabled electric collars on her Belted Galloway herd to locate cattle grazing at 1,200ft, cutting wasted search time during short winter days. The collars transmit positions to a phone app, enable planned virtual fencing for habitat restoration grazing, and can alert to abnormal behavior. Combined with deferred pasture grazing under an environmental scheme, this low-tech innovation boosts efficiency, supports woodland restoration and could streamline future TB-testing and remote grazing management.

articles.title: Rare white Iberian lynx captured on film in Spain by amateur photographer
articles.trailText: Researchers to investigate whether environmental factors may have affected female animal’s pigmentation
articles.summary: Amateur photographer Ángel Hidalgo captured short camera‐trap footage of a white‐coated Iberian lynx near Jaén, Spain, prompting research into its unusual pigmentation. Identified by LIFE Lynx-Connect as Satureja, a female born in 2021, the animal changed from typical brown spots to a snow-white coat without albinism or leucism. Her behavior and breeding remained unaffected. Scientists recall a second regional case with reversible color shifts, suggesting environmental triggers or hypersensitivity. Authorities plan to sample Satureja briefly to pinpoint causes. Conservationists hail the species’ rebound from endangered to vulnerable status.

articles.title: Sadiq Khan calls on Reeves to bring ‘authentic’ Labour budget that boosts green investment
articles.trailText: London mayor says government should stay true to its beliefs and face down those who claim net zero adds to cost of living
articles.summary: London mayor Sadiq Khan urged chancellor Rachel Reeves to deliver an “authentic” Labour budget prioritising green investment, backing energy secretary Ed Miliband’s target of an 81% emissions cut by 2035. Speaking ahead of the C40 summit in Rio, he said government must regain confidence in net-zero policies, unite Cabinet behind clean growth and fund green jobs—from heat-pump installers to electric-bus makers—and Transport for London projects like a Thamesmead DLR extension. Khan also welcomed Starmer at COP30, condemned Trump’s climate denial and called for candid ‘special relationship’ diplomacy with the US.

articles.title: ‘If you ignore emissions, we did great’: Germany’s challenging fight to go green
articles.trailText: Despite progress in cutting carbon pollution, climate groups say country’s toughest hurdles are yet to come
articles.summary: Germany, one of Europe’s biggest polluters, cut emissions almost 50% since 1990 and aims for net-zero by 2045, driven by renewables now 59% of power. Yet decisions to phase out nuclear before coal, stalled transport and buildings reforms, and weakened recycling erode its green reputation. Political shifts—centrist coalition favoring gas, conservative push to dilute EU Green Deal, rising far-right AfD climate skepticism—and public fatigue post-pandemic and Ukraine war threaten the 65% emissions reduction target by 2030. Strong institutions and legal rulings boost ambition, but biggest challenges loom in industry, transport, finance.

articles.title: UK charging industry could face £100m bill under business rate changes
articles.trailText: Industry bodies say proposals will force site closures, slow investment and cost drivers up to £300 a year more
articles.summary: Industry body ChargeUK warns that requiring public EV charging operators to pay business rates on some 64,000 bays from April could generate a £100m annual bill, potentially passed to drivers as up to £300 higher charging costs. With 86,000 UK public chargers now serving over 1m EVs, Osprey Charging’s CEO says remote hubs risk closure or delayed roll-out. The Valuation Office Agency plans to list individual bays as rateable—possibly backdated to April 2023—prompting ChargeUK to call for an exemption in the 26 November budget to protect EV uptake.

articles.title: St Kilda’s little penguin colony to be ‘cherished and protected’ as free public tours return at long last
articles.trailText: A new, purpose-built 150m viewing platform is giving visitors the chance to ‘connect with nature in the city’
articles.summary: After a five-year hiatus, free guided sunset and after-dark tours to St Kilda’s little penguin colony have resumed on a new 150m purpose-built platform at the $53m pier. Managed collaboratively by Phillip Island Nature Parks and Earthcare St Kilda, this elevated walkway prevents trampling of nests and curbs flash photography and crowding. The colony, officially acknowledged since the 1970s, has grown from 57 in 1986 to over 1,400. Volunteers emphasise its resilience amid climate, light and plastic threats and the value of urban wildlife connections.

articles.title: Australian wholesale electricity prices are falling. So when will power bills stop rising?
articles.trailText: The cost of generating power is definitely getting cheaper but the savings may take time to flow through
articles.summary: AEMO reports a 27% drop in wholesale electricity prices in Q3 year-on-year, driven by record 42.7% renewables share and battery uptake, with regional averages from $72/MWh in Queensland to $104/MWh in South Australia. Wholesale costs are 38% of a typical bill; network charges 39%, retail margins 16% and environmental schemes 7%. Falling generation costs may take months to filter through as retailers hedge years ahead. Rising transmission investments and global fuel prices still pressure default tariffs. Solar and battery households pay 18% less, and 79% could save by switching plans.

articles.title: Britain’s canals and rivers face lack of funds amid climate pressures, campaigners warn
articles.trailText: Many waterways vulnerable to breaches and closures and face mounting maintenance costs, charity says
articles.summary: Campaigners warn Britain’s 2,000-mile canal and river network faces severe funding shortfalls and climate threats, with the Inland Waterways Association mapping showing 99% of navigable waterways at higher risk under a 2°C heating scenario. Three-quarters of navigation authorities fall into ‘severe deficit’ or ‘amber’ categories; drought closures on the Leeds and Liverpool canal and the Bridgewater embankment collapse underscore growing vulnerability. Waterways deliver £1.5bn in NHS savings, support 80,000 jobs and serve 10m users, yet the Canal & River Trust spent £10m on emergency repairs last winter. IWA calls for a government review to secure sustainable, long-term funding and avert irreversible decline by 2050.

articles.title: Britain one of least ‘nature-connected’ nations in world – with Nepal the most
articles.trailText: Others languishing near bottom of 61-country study include Canada, Germany, Israel, Japan and Spain
articles.summary: Global survey: Britain's citizens rank 55th of 61 nations for psychological “nature connectedness” in a 57,000-person study led by Uni of Derby’s Miles Richardson. Nepal leads, followed by Iran, South Africa; Spain ranks last. Spirituality and religiosity predict stronger bonds with nature, while business-friendliness, urbanization, income and internet use correlate with weaker ties. Despite high environmental group membership, Britain lags. Researchers call for embedding nature in healthcare, law, business decision-making and urban design to boost wellbeing and biodiversity. Environmental organisation membership had little effect. Proposed interventions include nature-based mental healthcare treatments, biodiversity net gain regulations and ‘sacred’ urban greenspaces.

articles.title: Country diary: Helping salmon make the leap | Tim Earl
articles.trailText: Laxey, Isle of Man: I’m lucky to see my first ever wild Atlantic salmon, but it’s no fluke that they are present in our rivers
articles.summary: Tim Earl spots his first wild Atlantic salmon in the River Laxey on the Isle of Man, a testament to decades of local conservation. Facing threats from sea overfishing and polluted mine runoff, authorities disconnected the Lady Isabella waterwheel’s piston rod and replaced obstructive flood defenses with boulder weirs to create 'salmon slaloms.' A government hatchery now collects wild eggs and sperm, rears fry for four months, and returns adults upstream, preserving each river’s unique genetics and boosting salmon numbers.

articles.title: Gumnuts, baby! How two abseiling horticulturalists rescued specimens from an endangered tree
articles.trailText: The threatened Jillaga Ash ( Eucalyptus stenostoma ) was spotted 90m down a cliff in Wadbilliga national park, in southern New South Wales
articles.summary: Threatened species ecologist Stan Wawrzyczek teamed up with RBGV horticulturalist Amy Downie and abseiler Ollie Sherlock to collect gumnuts from four Eucalyptus stenostoma (Jillaga Ash) trees perched nearly 90m down a 300m cliff in Wadbilliga National Park, NSW. Using rope rigs and pole pruners, they secured seeds and cuttings to propagate seedlings, store specimens in RBGV’s state botanical collection and nurseries at Melbourne and Cranbourne, and build back-up populations for the fire-vulnerable, endemic tree. The five-day, off-grid trip involved 4WD, hiking, surveying and abseiling, prompting plans to use drones for future rescues.

articles.title: No high-level US representatives will go to UN climate talks, Trump officials say
articles.trailText: Decision to stay away from Cop30 meeting in Brazil underscores administration’s hostility to climate action
articles.summary: The Trump administration will send no high-level US officials to next month’s COP30 talks in Belém, Brazil, marking the first time in three decades the US has entirely skipped UN climate negotiations. Labeling climate policies “a hoax” and withdrawing from the Paris Agreement, the administration has closed its State Department climate office, axed the climate envoy, and shifted to bilateral energy deals—securing $750 billion in EU oil and gas purchases and pacts on rare earths, nuclear and fossil fuels with Japan and South Korea. Subnational actors will attend unsupported, while global delegates face delayed emissions plans and lodging shortages.

articles.title: ‘This is the future!’: inside the next generation of electric cars that fly and drive themselves (but the doors are a bit tricky)
articles.trailText: Caitlin Cassidy takes a test-drive in some of the cutting-edge vehicles at the Sydney International EV Motor Show – with a mixed verdict
articles.summary: At the Sydney International EV Motor Show, Caitlin Cassidy explores cutting-edge models from $30K entry-level EVs to $500K supercars. She tests XPeng’s X2 flying-car prototype (35-minute flight, illegal locally) and its $55K G6, praising its self-parking, lane-change autopilot, climate presets and drowsiness sensor. Organisers highlight explosive growth: 96 EV models now versus four post-Covid, 16% of new Australian car sales (versus China’s 80%). Tradie electric utes and 4x4s loom. Doors can be tricky, but importers insist petrol’s era is ending as EV adoption accelerates.

articles.title: Three Just Stop Oil activists cleared over Stonehenge protest
articles.trailText: Trio argued orange powder protest day before 2024 solstice was justified because of focus on climate emergency
articles.summary: At Salisbury Crown Court, three Just Stop Oil activists—74-year-old Rajan Naidu, student Niamh Lynch (23) and carpenter Luke Watson (36)—were acquitted of public nuisance and ancient monument damage after using orange powder “colour blasters” at Stonehenge on the eve of the 2024 summer solstice. The jury found removal costs (£620) and lack of lasting harm, plus the proportionality of convicting peaceful protesters over climate-emergency claims, did not justify interference with their freedom of expression. Defence counsel hailed the verdict as a vindication of the right to protest. Just Stop Oil said it drew more global attention than any earlier action.

articles.title: ‘No regrets’: activists who sprayed Stonehenge orange proud of ‘magic trick’
articles.trailText: Just Stop Oil protesters say they knew action would not harm stones and law used to prosecute them was ‘insane’
articles.summary: Just Stop Oil activists Rajan Naidu (74), Luke Watson (36) and Niamh Lynch (23) were acquitted after spraying three of Stonehenge’s sarsen stones with cornflower-and-food-dye powder. They argued the non-porous stones suffered no harm and challenged section 78 of the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act 2022, calling its public nuisance charge unjust. Describing their stunt as a proportionate, magic-trick–style protest, they urged focus on a fossil fuel non-proliferation treaty and the climate emergency rather than their verdict.

articles.title: ‘We must protect and we must understand’: using shipwrecks to rebuild fish populations
articles.trailText: Research by marine scientists in Thailand is revealing how shipwrecks can benefit the undersea environment
articles.summary: Marine researchers working with Thailand’s navy and Global Reef collected pre- and post-scuttling data on two decommissioned Royal Thai Navy vessels (HTMS Hanhak Sattru and HTMS Suphairin) sunk in 2023 off Koh Tao. Early results support both attraction and production hypotheses: adult snappers, fusiliers and endangered species aggregate on wrecks while juveniles breed there, with dive-tourist activity deterring fishers. Artificial reefs, deployed since the 1970s, alleviate pressure on damaged natural reefs threatened by warming, overtourism and trawling. Government-backed studies align with Thailand’s 2030 goal to protect 30% of its marine zones, reflecting a culturally rooted ethic of conservation.

articles.title: Harrison Ford says Trump’s assault on climate policy ‘scares the shit out of me’
articles.trailText: Indiana Jones star calls US president one of history’s greatest criminals for attacks on science and boosting of fossil fuels
articles.summary: Harrison Ford warns that Donald Trump's rollback of climate and clean-air policies, promotion of fossil fuels and withdrawal from the Paris deal scares the shit out of me, calling the president one of history's worst criminals. Ford cites halted clean-energy projects, bans on climate change in government and Trump's drill, baby, drill push aiding global heating. Drawing on his own wildfire evacuation, he laments disasters-from Category 5 storms to heat-related deaths-yet remains hopeful that public will, technology and conservation efforts like the EO Wilson half-Earth vision can avert catastrophe.

articles.title: The nature extinction crisis is mirrored by one in our own bodies. Both have huge implications for health
articles.trailText: Modern life is waging a war against ecosystems around us and inside us. Keeping our own microbes healthy is another reason to demand action to preserve the natural world
articles.summary: Human bodies host diverse microbial ecosystems crucial for digestion, immunity and hormone regulation; modern habitat loss mirrors global biodiversity declines inside us, fueling rises in allergies, asthma and autoimmune diseases. The biodiversity hypothesis, exemplified by the Karelia Allergy Study, links reduced nature exposure to inflammatory disorders. With over 8m hectares of forest lost annually and 70% of people projected to live in cities by 2050, deforestation and urbanisation accelerate inner and outer extinctions. Urban greening—from tree planting to soil contact—restores environmental and human microbiomes, boosting physical and mental health, immunity and resilience to disease and climate extremes.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Hurricane Melissa leaves trail of destruction across Caribbean
articles.trailText: Category 5 storm is most powerful to strike Jamaica and has caused death and destruction in Cuba and Haiti
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa struck Jamaica Oct 29 as a category 5 storm with 185 mph winds—destroying or stripping roofs off 90% of homes in Black River, cutting power to 75% of the country and killing at least 19. It weakened to category 3 for Cuba landfall (120 mph) and triggered floods and landslides in Haiti, killing around 30. The system is heading toward Bermuda and the Bahamas. Meanwhile, Cyclone Montha made landfall in Andhra Pradesh, prompting 38,000 evacuations and causing ₹53 bn in damage. In Vietnam, record rains (up to 1,700 mm) flooded 128,000 homes, killed 10, displaced 40,000 tourists, and swamped heritage sites.

articles.title: Kenya’s growing towns are leaving elephants with nowhere to go
articles.trailText: As settlements expand across northern Kenya, people and elephants are increasingly clashing over land, food and water
articles.summary: In Oldonyiro, northern Kenya, expanding settlements and roads now block historic elephant migratory corridors, forcing semi-nomadic Samburu herders and wildlife into competition for acacia pods, water and land. Bottlenecks through narrow mountain gaps funnel herds past primary schools and bomas, where drought-driven resource scarcity has spiked trampling incidents and fatalities, including a boy crushed by a bull elephant. Experts say human-elephant conflict now rivals poaching in threat level. Conservationist Benjamin Loloju of Save the Elephants urges integrating protected corridors into town planning to safeguard both community safety and elephant migrations.

articles.title: Tackle wood burning and road traffic to improve Europe’s air quality, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers measure toxicity of air samples across continent to advise on ‘efficient’ policies to reduce harm
articles.summary: An international Nature study measured the oxidative potential (OP) of over 11,000 particulate samples from 43 sites in six European countries by exposing them to lung fluid. It found road-adjacent air to be roughly three times more toxic than rural, with winter wood burning in valleys—especially Sarajevo—driving peak OP. Mass-based PM reductions in Grenoble and Bern did not cut toxicity. Researchers recommend policies targeting the most harmful sources, including vehicle tyre and brake wear and domestic wood combustion.

articles.title: Country diary: A hellish fungus, foul of stench and spindly of finger | Charlie Elder
articles.trailText: Dartmoor, Devon: Of all the British wildlife with ‘devil’ in its name, the devil’s fingers fungus surely earns it the most
articles.summary: In Dartmoor’s Merrivale valley, writer Charlie Elder tracks down a rare devil’s fingers fungus (Clathrus archeri) first spotted by a hiker—a foreign hitchhiker from Australia/New Zealand introduced to Britain during WWI. Emerging from a pale gelatinous “witch’s egg,” its red, spindly tentacles claw the air, releasing a stench akin to rotting flesh that lures flies to disperse spores. Slightly desiccated but intact amid gorse-sprinkled turf, this grotesque stinkhorn epitomizes nature’s macabre spectacle and earns its devilish name.

articles.title: BoM says October will be hottest ever for Queensland and NT as heat records tumble
articles.trailText: Sydney, Brisbane and Darwin are predicted to hit hottest October in terms of maximum temperatures, the Bureau of Meteorology says
articles.summary: Australia’s Bureau of Meteorology predicts October 2025 will be the warmest on record for Queensland and the Northern Territory across maximum, minimum and mean temperatures, and the third-hottest nationwide. Sydney, Brisbane and Darwin also face unprecedented heat, with Darwin airport averaging 34.8°C. Outback Wanaaring hit 44.9°C and Birdsville 46.1°C on 21 October, breaking records since 1910. Persistent high pressure, a negative Southern Annular Mode and rare sudden stratospheric warming drove drier, hotter conditions and below-average rainfall. Sea surface temperatures have ranked among the warmest since July 2024, fueling storm and cyclone intensity, and the BoM forecasts continued above-average temperatures into early 2026.

articles.title: Paint me cool: scientists reveal roof coating that can reduce surface temperatures up to 6C on hot days
articles.trailText: Sydney researchers commercialising a product they say can cool indoor spaces and will cost little more than standard premium paints
articles.summary: Australian researchers at the University of Sydney have developed a passive radiative roof coating that reflects 96% of solar radiation and emits heat to cool surfaces by up to 6°C below ambient. The porous film also condenses atmospheric moisture, yielding up to 390 ml/m²/day and roughly 70 L per 200 m² roof under favourable conditions. Tested over six months at the Sydney Nanoscience Hub with a UV-resistant topcoat, the water-based version is now being commercialised at a price comparable to premium paints. Beyond cutting indoor heat during extreme events, it could mitigate urban heat islands and bolster water supplies in remote or drought-prone areas.

articles.title: Despite what a thinktank bleats to the Coalition, heat deaths are in fact ‘a thing’ | Temperature Check
articles.trailText: Centre for Independent Studies points to climate risk report to back up its dismissal of heat-related deaths, but neglects to use the part that actually concerns the future
articles.summary: The free-market Centre for Independent Studies told Coalition MPs heat deaths “aren’t a thing,” citing current data from Australia’s National Climate Risk Assessment but omitting projections showing heat fatalities would nearly triple in Sydney and more than double in Melbourne at 2°C warming. The assessment warns all major Australian cities face surging heat mortality, a finding echoed by a Lancet report estimating 546,000 global heat deaths annually and 980 in Australia. Experts say heat already causes more deaths and hospitalisations than cold and is widely underestimated, with lasting non-fatal impacts on vulnerable communities.
