articles.summary: America’s rapid AI datacenter build-out by Google, Amazon, Microsoft, OpenAI and others is set to triple in power demand to over 14% of US electricity by 2030—equivalent to running six cities—and force utilities to lean on fossil fuels under the Trump administration, reversing decades of clean-energy gains and potentially doubling data-center emissions by 2035. Beyond climate risks, facilities in hotspots such as Virginia and Texas consume billions of gallons of water for cooling and are driving up household bills by roughly 8% over five years. Growing voter opposition across parties suggests cost-of-living worries may be the decisive brake on expansion.

articles.title: Wood burning and gas cooking hugely costly to healthcare systems, New Zealand study finds
articles.trailText: Experts suggest replacing gas hobs with electric ones, saying it is a win–win for health and the climate
articles.summary: Peer-reviewed New Zealand research estimates indoor air pollution from 523,000 wood burners causes 446 hospitalisations, 101 early deaths annually; gas cooking leads to over 1,000 admissions, 208 fatalities and 3,000 new childhood asthma cases. Open fires impose NZ$53,400 per four-person household each year in health and economic losses; modern wood stoves NZ$1,800; gas hobs NZ$9,200. Outdoor emissions add NZ$3,200 per stove and NZ$26,800 per open fire. Researchers urge switching to electric cooktops and avoiding new gas or wood appliances to cut healthcare costs and climate impacts.

articles.title: Country diary: The potatoes are out of the ground, bringing untold stories with them | Mary Montague
articles.trailText: County Roscommon, Ireland: As harvest comes to a close, I visit the National Famine Museum, an important place of myth-busting and memory
articles.summary: In County Roscommon, Mary Montague marks October’s traditional potato-lifting season by touring the National Famine Museum at Strokestown Park. She explores the tuber’s 16th-century arrival and later elevation to dietary staple that fed Irish tenant families on poor soils, names heirloom varieties from kerr’s pink and golden wonder to the 19th-century Irish lumper, and scent-traces the Phytophthora infestans blight of Samhain 1845 that decimated crops, led to famine, forced migration and controversial export policies. The museum, founded 150 years later, confronts myth and memory while drawing uneasy parallels with suffering in Sudan and Gaza, asking when their memories will be released.

articles.title: Brazil to ask countries at Cop30 to vastly increase biofuel use, leak suggests
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Document sets draft pledge for leaders gathering at Cop30 summit to increase use of controversial fuels
articles.summary: Leaked draft pledge for Cop30 in Belém urges a fourfold rise in global “sustainable fuels” (biofuels, biogas, hydrogen) by 2034 versus 2024. Brazil, the world’s second-largest ethanol producer, claims these fuels will cut fossil emissions, but environmental groups warn they spur deforestation, monocultures, food insecurity and 16% higher CO2 emissions due to land-use change. A T&E report projects biofuel crops will need land the size of France by 2030 and water-intensive processes, while solar could deliver equivalent energy using 97% less land. Critics say the initiative distracts from renewables and fossil-fuel phase-out.

articles.title: Sponge, baby, sponge to deal with flooding risks | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Alastair Chisholm and Laurie Wilcockson on the steps the government needs to take to ensure we can buy and live in homes without fear of flooding
articles.summary: Alastair Chisholm and Laurie Wilcockson warn that government’s ‘record’ £10.5bn flood-defence pledge over ten years is dwarfed by over £100bn by water firms and falls short of Environment Agency’s risk estimate. They urge landscape-scale reforestation, activation of paused sustainable farming incentives, and adoption of China-style ‘sponge city’ drainage—currently sidelined to protect housing targets. Insurer concerns and conflicts between the sequential test and 1.5m-home plan expose misaligned policy. To legitimize development on low/medium risk sites, ministers must streamline local authorities’ flood-risk data access and mandate mitigations to ensure insurability.

articles.title: ‘Summer is coming sooner and it’s lasting longer’: what has the weather got in store for Australia?
articles.trailText: Abnormal heat is expected, especially in Tasmania, but a ‘tug of war’ between climate drivers means the rainfall forecast is uncertain
articles.summary: Australia’s forthcoming summer is set for abnormally high daytime and nighttime temperatures nationwide, with Tasmania having a 60–70% chance of exceeding heat norms. Record-warm sea-surface temperatures—warmest since July 2024—are expected to persist, especially off southern NSW due to a strengthening East Australian Current. Rainfall outlook remains neutral (wet/dry odds ~50:50) except wetter odds in far north Queensland, driven by a potential weak La Niña and Indian Ocean dipole. October–December brings elevated severe thunderstorm risk on the east coast; cyclone season runs November to April, and bushfire risk remains high from December to February.

articles.title: Different croaks: new frog and gecko species discovered on remote island in Australia’s north
articles.trailText: Researchers on expedition to Dauan Island heard two distinct frog calls in the rain and ‘sure enough, they were species new to science’
articles.summary: Researchers from James Cook University discovered three new species on Dauan Island (3 km²) in the far northern Torres Strait: a banded, long-legged gecko (Nactus simakal) among granite boulders and two microhylid frogs heard calling in the rain. Choerophyrne koeypad, a fingernail-sized climber with oversized toe pads and a metallic high-pitched tap, and Callulops gobakula, a larger boulder-dweller with a green tree frog-like croak, are both terrestrial breeders. Their closest relatives are in New Guinea’s central ranges; these endemics rely on deep boulder fields for thermal buffering. Findings published in Zootaxa.

articles.title: ‘When I pass piles of fishing nets, I see piles of money’: a one man recycling revolution on the Cornish coast
articles.trailText: Determined to find a solution to the discarded plastic nets, Ian Falconer found a way to convert them into filament for 3D printing, for use in products from motorbikes to sunglasses
articles.summary: Since 2017, Ian Falconer’s OrCA micro-factory in Newlyn, Cornwall, recycles discarded fishing nets—1m t/yr globally—by shredding and extruding them into 3D-printing filament with under 3% of virgin nylon’s carbon footprint. Its patented machinery processes 20 kg/hr of blue-green nylon beads, selling at £12k/t (pure) or £35k/t (carbon-fibre blend) for products from sunglasses to bike parts. Backed by £1m+ from 40+ countries, clients include Philips, Ford and L’Oréal. Falconer now offers containerised plants for harbours worldwide.

articles.title: Plug-in hybrids pollute almost as much as petrol cars, report finds
articles.trailText: Analysis of 800,000 European cars found real-world pollution from plug-in hybrids nearly five times greater than lab tests
articles.summary: Analysis of onboard data from 800,000 European plug-in hybrids (2021–23) by Transport and Environment found real-world CO2 emissions in 2023 nearly 5× higher than lab tests, cutting just 19% vs petrol cars instead of the presumed 75%. A 27% actual electric driving ratio versus 84% assumed and frequent engine use in “electric” mode drove the gap. Planned EU utility-factor corrections will narrow but not close it. Under-reported PHEV emissions saved automakers €5 bn in fines and cost drivers €500 extra yearly, fuelling debate over post-2035 CO2 targets as German leaders push PHEV flexibilities.

articles.title: Download your free official Australian bird of the year 2025 poster
articles.trailText: Guardian Australia and BirdLife Australia proudly present this year’s free downloadable poster featuring the art of Pete Cromer
articles.summary: Following over 300,000 public votes in Guardian Australia and BirdLife Australia’s 2025 Australian Bird of the Year contest, the official free poster is now available for download. Rendered in Pete Cromer’s distinctive watercolour style, the commemorative PDF highlights the 2025 winning species alongside past champions and runners-up. Designed to celebrate and raise awareness of Australia’s diverse birdlife, the high-resolution poster can be accessed via a direct link, enabling enthusiasts to print or display the artwork at home or in educational settings.

articles.title: Tawny frogmouth named 2025 Australian bird of the year winner
articles.trailText: Perennial runner up finally claims the crown in the biennial Guardian/BirdLife Australia poll, ahead of Baudin’s black cockatoo and gang-gang cockatoo
articles.summary: In the biennial Guardian/BirdLife Australia poll, the tawny frogmouth—third-time runner-up in 2019, 2021 and 2023—claimed 2025’s Bird of the Year with 11,851 votes out of 310,000+, topping Baudin’s black cockatoo (7,688) and gang-gang cockatoo (6,256). This nocturnal, tree-bark–camouflaged nightjar relative nests on large branches and mates for life. BirdLife Australia highlights its wider conservation messaging—from habitat loss threatening Baudin’s cockatoo and southern emu-wren to the upcoming Aussie Bird Count on 20 October. Rounding out the top ten were the willie wagtail, bush stone-curlew, kookaburra, emu-wren, pardalote, eagle and little penguin.

articles.title: Australian tropical rainforest trees switch in world first from carbon sink to emissions source
articles.trailText: Researchers say carbon emissions change in Queensland tropical rainforests may have global climate implications
articles.summary: New research published in Nature reveals Queensland’s tropical rainforests have flipped from net carbon sinks to sources in their trunks and branches over the past 25 years, driven by hotter, drier conditions. Although roots still sequester carbon, accelerated tree mortality and insufficient growth mean overall emissions now exceed uptake. Based on 50 years of data on 11,000 trees across 20 sites, this tipping point could undermine global carbon budgets and necessitate revisions to climate models and emission policies.

articles.title: Winner of the Australian bird of the year 2025 to be announced on Guardian live stream today
articles.trailText: Will the tawny frogmouth finally take the top perch? Could conservationist backing propel Baudin’s black cockatoo to the skies? Or will the gang-gang gang prove triumphant?
articles.summary: Guardian Australia and BirdLife Australia will reveal the 2025 Australian Bird of the Year today via a live stream (12.30–1.30pm AEDT across web, YouTube, Instagram and TikTok) following 313,000 votes. Top contenders include the tawny frogmouth (runner-up in three past polls), newcomer Baudin’s black cockatoo (threatened by WA bauxite mining), gang-gang cockatoo (backed by political and media figures), Willie wagtail and nine others. With the final tally hidden, a surprise upset remains possible, joining past winners from the magpie to the swift parrot.

articles.title: Record leap in CO2 fuels fears of accelerating global heating
articles.trailText: CO 2 in air hit new high last year, with scientists concerned natural land and ocean carbon sinks are weakening
articles.summary: UN data shows atmospheric CO2 rose 3.5 ppm to 424 ppm in 2024—the largest annual jump since 1957—driven by unabated fossil fuel combustion, record wildfires and possibly weakening land and ocean carbon sinks. WMO scientists warn that hotter, drier conditions and El Niño patterns reduce the ability of forests and seas to absorb CO2, creating feedback loops that could accelerate warming. Methane and nitrous oxide also hit record highs. Experts stress urgent emission cuts and enhanced greenhouse gas monitoring ahead of COP30.

articles.title: Trump threatens vulnerable countries before key shipping emissions vote
articles.trailText: American officials have threatened supporters of measure to reduce emissions with tariffs and other retaliatory action
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s administration is pressuring IMO member states ahead of a vote on a 2028 shipping carbon levy that could raise $10bn annually, writing letters and making calls to threaten tariffs, visa restrictions and port charges on supporters. After walking out of April talks approving the levy, US officials and allies including Saudi Arabia are targeting vulnerable developing and Pacific island nations to block its two-thirds ratification. The levy, funding clean-fuel transition and aid for poorer countries, is now in jeopardy as several states reportedly waver under threats of reciprocal measures.

articles.title: ‘She died because of the flood’: Filipinos rise up as outrage over corruption scandal grows
articles.trailText: Allegations related to flood control projects have sparked widespread anger and protests in the Philippines
articles.summary: Philippine health worker Christina Padora drowned when electrocuted in waist-high July flood in Bulacan, spotlighting alleged corruption in flood-control projects. Since 2022, ₱545 bn funded nearly 9,855 schemes, many ghost projects with overpricing and 20% kickbacks for lawmakers. A senate inquiry uncovered 421 nonexistent works. Youth-led protests and social-media campaigns demand convictions as the ombudsman readies cases and freezes ₱4.6 bn in assets. Experts warn concrete dykes won’t withstand worsening typhoons and urge reforestation and relocations. The scandal has toppled parliamentary leaders, triggered reshuffles and intensified calls for systemic reform.

articles.title: Country diary: Eyes to the skies for autumn’s mass migration | Lev Parikian
articles.trailText: Hampstead, London: Spring has the dawn chorus, autumn has ‘vismig’, the changing of the guard of millions of birds – an early start for me, then, to try and glimpse this remarkable phenomenon
articles.summary: Lev Parikian describes autumn’s ‘vismig’ visible bird migration over Hampstead Heath, noting seasonal signs—mushrooms, conkers, acorns—and forecasts. Millions of birds, including 1.5m swallows bound for Africa, 700k redwings from Scandinavia, 200k redstarts to the Sahel and 500k wigeons from Iceland, traverse Britain. On a bleary pre-dawn vigil with thermos and gloves he glimpses just half a dozen specks—meadow pipits or sand martins—before train ride home, where trickles of swallows overhead mark the journey’s start.

articles.title: UK must prepare buildings for 2C rise in global temperature, government told
articles.trailText: Climate advisers warn that current plans to protect against extreme weather are inadequate
articles.summary: Britain’s Climate Change Committee warns that current plans leave the UK dangerously unprepared for at least 2 °C of warming by 2050—and that all new, long-lived buildings should be designed for 4 °C above pre-industrial levels. Without upgrades, heatwaves will hit four out of five years, drought duration will double, July wildfire days will triple and peak river flows may rise 40 %. CCC chair Julia King calls adaptation “underresourced” in health, transport, schools and energy networks and urges cross-government action, funded via fossil-fuel levies. A detailed adaptation roadmap is due in May, while a separate report demands radical food-system reform to bolster security, cut emissions and protect nature.

articles.title: Queensland’s pandering to climate deniers is making it even tougher for Australia to drive down emissions | Clear Air
articles.trailText: Queensland is Australia’s top polluter – even worse than Western Australia, which has no climate target and adores its fossil fuel industry
articles.summary: Queensland’s LNP government released an energy roadmap scrapping Labor’s 80% renewables-by-2035 target and planned coal-plant closures, pledging $1.6 billion to keep coal online until 2046, $479 million to add gas capacity (including a 400 MW plant), and only 6.8 GW of renewables by 2030—projects already backed by investors. After 2030, clean energy growth slows to 4.4 GW by 2035. The roadmap omits “climate change” and “fossil fuels,” prioritizes “pragmatic” economics over emissions cuts, further delays coal retirement, undermines national targets, and deters renewables investors. Queensland, Australia’s biggest emitter (64% coal), rivals WA’s fossil bias and complicates the Albanese government’s drive to meet national targets.

articles.title: Ed Miliband approves UK’s biggest solar farm at Lincolnshire site
articles.trailText: Tillbridge solar farm will be built in county where Reform UK’s anti-renewables agenda has rising support
articles.summary: Energy secretary Ed Miliband has approved the 700MW Tillbridge solar farm near Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, the UK’s largest, covering 1,200ha and powering 300,000 homes. It is the ninth project granted “nationally significant” status under Labour, bringing total NS clean-energy approvals to 17—enough for 7.5m homes. Labour aims to double onshore wind, triple solar and quadruple offshore wind by 2030 to cut gas use to 5% and reduce bills by up to £300. Facing Reform UK’s local anti-renewables surge, Miliband defended net-zero law in parliament, touting faster green growth and warning of higher costs and volatility from continued gas reliance.

articles.title: Switching 50km/h speed limits to 30km/h would protect cyclists while barely affecting commutes, research finds
articles.trailText: One expert says a cyclist hit by a car travelling 50km/h has about a one-in-10 chance of surviving, while at 30km/h it is a nine-in-10 chance
articles.summary: RMIT University researchers modelled lowering residential speed limits in greater Melbourne from 50 to 30 km/h and found it doubled low-stress cycling routes without slowing car travel, boosting safety especially for children and less confident riders. The change aligns with Victoria's new law allowing councils to set 30 km/h limits on local and school streets. Published in Cycling and Micromobility Research, the study notes 30 km/h zones offer a 90% survival rate versus 10% at 50 km/h. Experts urge infrastructure tweaks and modal filters to curb rat-running and grow Australia’s 2% commuter cycling share.

articles.title: ‘Dismal’ health of world’s forests is threat to humanity, report warns
articles.trailText: Financial institutions pouring money into land clearance and undermining efforts to stop destruction, says Climate Focus
articles.summary: Global forest health has dropped to "dismal" levels, jeopardizing humanity, warns the annual Forest Declaration Assessment by Climate Focus and partners. Since 2021, deforestation rose due to $409bn in annual agricultural subsidies fueling livestock, monocrops and logging, vs just $5.9bn for conservation. Last year saw 8.1m ha lost—half England's size—and Amazon fires released CO2 seven times the prior two-year average. Banks have financed deforestation with $26bn since Paris. With zero deforestation by 2030 now 63% off track, the report urges binding financial reforms and backing Brazil's $125bn Tropical Forests Forever Facility at Cop30 to reverse the trend.

articles.title: Towns may have to be abandoned due to floods with millions more homes in Great Britain at risk
articles.trailText: Every constituency projected to be at greater risk, with many areas likely to be uninsurable, Guardian investigation finds
articles.summary: Guardian investigation of Aviva data finds every GB constituency will face more flood risk by mid-century; properties at risk rising 27% in England (6.3m to 8m), flash-flood risk up 66%. High-density areas (London, Manchester) worst hit; towns like Tenbury Wells are now uninsurable after four floods in six years. Bermondsey & Old Southwark, Boston & Skegness may see ~90% homes at risk by 2050. New homes continue in high-risk zones. Experts warn some towns may be abandoned and urge urgent upgrades to the Thames Barrier. Flood Re ends in 2039, raising insurance costs for low-income households. Government pledges £10.5bn for 900k properties.

articles.title: Country diary: An easy-going bunch doing hard work on the moor | Ed Douglas
articles.trailText: Big Moor, Derbyshire​: The change from sheep to cattle grazing here was intended to restore wildlife – and it’s working
articles.summary: Flocks of goldfinch swirl over Big Moor in Derbyshire as red poll and Welsh black cattle replace sheep to restore biodiversity. Unlike sheep, cattle uproot tussock grass and trample soil, promoting seed germination and boosting wildlife—whinchat numbers nearly tripled in five years. Weekend walkers now share the hills with these gentle breeds (advised to keep a respectful distance), under guidance from the Eastern Moors Partnership. While more photogenic Highland cattle and proposed elk stir social media, this "easy-going bunch" quietly reshapes the moor’s ecology.

articles.title: Doors, drains and paving perils: protecting your home from flooding
articles.trailText: Climate breakdown and crumbling defences mean more homes in England are at risk – but you are not completely defenceless
articles.summary: With climate breakdown and ageing flood defences raising flood risk across England, homeowners can mitigate damage by sealing doorways with Kitemarked flood barriers or absorbent cushions, replacing impermeable paving with permeable lawns, fitting non-return valves on appliances (or toilet bungs), and installing self-closing or raised airbricks. External cavity drains, sump or portable “puddle” pumps help expel water, while raising sockets, boilers, tiled floors and using plastic or stainless finishes ensures faster recovery. Register for flood warnings, prepare evacuation plans and pressure MPs for enhanced infrastructure and nature-based defences.

articles.title: Almost all external insulation fitted under Tory scheme needs repair or replacing, report finds
articles.trailText: Homeowners who took advantage of government programmes left with cladding likely to cause damp
articles.summary: A National Audit Office investigation found that 98% of the roughly 23,000 homes fitted with external wall insulation under the Energy Company Obligation and Great British Insulation Scheme require repair or replacement due to poor workmanship. An additional 9,000–13,000 internal insulation installs (29%) also face major defects, while over 3,000 installations pose immediate health and safety risks. Weak government oversight, fragmented roles among DESNZ, Ofgem and certification bodies, and audit “gaming” allowed substandard and fraudulent work—potentially costing energy suppliers £56m–£165m—to proceed. Homeowners report damp, mould, blocked ventilation and exposed wiring, hindering sales and remortgages. The energy minister vows free remediation, clearer accountability and system reforms; installers remain liable and households are urged to contact Ofgem.

articles.title: The flood-prone Worcestershire town being abandoned by insurers
articles.trailText: One more deluge could bankrupt Tenbury Wells yet its application for flood defence funding has been rejected
articles.summary: Tenbury Wells, a historic Worcestershire market town plagued by near-annual floods, has been deemed uninsurable after insurers withdrew coverage citing “almost certain flooding.” A £30m Environment Agency defence plan was dropped and its bid for £2.65bn of government flood funding was rejected. With shops, cinema and town hall uninsured, local businesses face closure or relocation. Owners warn one more deluge could bankrupt the town, while volunteers patch facades but lack funds to rebuild permanent defences, leaving Tenbury a blueprint for climate-driven abandonment.

articles.title: Microplastics are brought into the wilderness on hiking shoes and gear, study shows
articles.trailText: Research comparing Adirondack mountain lakes in New York suggests foot traffic is significant source of pollution
articles.summary: Study in Adirondack Mountains found microplastic levels about 23-fold higher in heavily-trafficked Lake Tear of the Clouds (16.54 particles/mL) than in remote Moss Pond (0.73 p/mL), implicating shedding from soft-soled trail shoes and synthetic gear via hikers rather than airborne deposition. Microplastics carry toxic additives such as BPA, phthalates and PFAS, linked to inflammation and cancer; prior research found apparel accounts for 70% of ocean microplastics. Conducted in early 2025 by Sacred Heart data scientist Tim Keyes with Evergreen Business Analytics and Adirondack Hamlet to Huts, the study underscores need for industry innovation and hiker practices to limit microplastic pollution in remote waterways.

articles.title: Climate investment is only growth opportunity of 21st century, says leading economist
articles.trailText: Lord Stern says fossil-fuelled growth is futile as the damage it causes ends in economic self-destruction
articles.summary: Economist Nicholas Stern argues that climate investment—not fossil-fuelled growth—is the 21st century’s sole viable growth engine. Falling costs of renewables, EVs and batteries (down ~80%), plus health and productivity boosts, can drive growth, reduce poverty and avert catastrophic warming. Stern challenges leaders from Trump to UK hard-liners to heed the science and back low-carbon tech. His new book reinforces his 2006 finding: inaction costs far exceed climate action, with tipping points looming at ~2 °C.

articles.title: ‘It’s a road to destruction’: climate defenders facing surge in reprisals, says UN expert
articles.trailText: Mary Lawlor, UN special rapporteur for human rights defenders, accuses US, UK and other governments of paying lip service to climate goals while criminalizing activists
articles.summary: UN special rapporteur Mary Lawlor warns of a global surge in state reprisals—smears, SLAPP suits, bogus criminal charges ranging from terrorism to trespass, police violence and surveillance—against climate defenders, especially by major governments professing support for 1.5°C goals. Her "Tipping points" report documents jailing of Just Stop Oil protesters in the UK, US Line 3 prosecutions and Les Soulèvements de la Terre ecoterrorism allegations in France. She also cites Vietnam’s detention of environmental lawyer Bach and Kenyan villagers shot opposing a nuclear plant. Lawlor urges ending repression and partnering with activists for a just transition.

articles.title: Country diary: Giants of the garden, our hollyhocks grow where they like | Susie White
articles.trailText: Allendale, Northumberland: Their sheer presence makes them a source of delight, and they’ve taken root in unlikely places. Now it’s time to collect their seeds
articles.summary: In Allendale, Northumberland, Susie White celebrates the ten-foot-tall hollyhocks that have thrived since spring, swaying through autumn storms and providing height even as their leaves shrivel. Grandchildren, red admirals and peacocks, bumblebees and moth caterpillars all found refuge and nectar among the hibiscus-like blooms of single-flowered Alcea rosea, engineered for cross-pollination. After managing rust by pruning, White harvests the dry seed pods—each a five-sepaled parcel—and stores them to share, as she marks the onset of autumn with seed-collecting and wild weather.

articles.title: A new island erupted from the sea – can it show us how nature works without human interference?
articles.trailText: The volcanic island of Surtsey emerged in the 1960s, and scientists say studying its development offers hope for damaged ecosystems worldwide
articles.summary: In November 1963 a submarine volcano off southern Iceland built Surtsey, a new island that has been strictly protected since 1965 to study ecosystem development without human impact. Seeds of sea rocket washed ashore first, bypassing expected algae and moss stages. Colonisation stalled at around ten plant species until black-backed gulls arrived in the early 1980s, their guano dispersing non-fleshy seed plants and grasses. Grey seals now haul out and enrich soils with nutrients. Surtsey’s rise and eventual erosion illustrate nature’s unpredictable resilience and inform global ecosystem restoration.

articles.title: National Trust and TV wildlife expert team up on autumn nature campaign
articles.trailText: People urged to savour sights, sounds and smells of the season as poll shows disconnect during darker months
articles.summary: The National Trust has teamed with wildlife presenter Hamza Yassin to launch “Wild Senses,” an autumn–winter campaign tied to the BBC’s Hamza’s Hidden Wild Isles series, urging people to reconnect with nature’s sights, sounds and smells year-round. A YouGov poll for the Trust found 90% of respondents say nature boosts wellbeing but only 34% feel connected across all seasons and just 13% in autumn. The initiative includes three free Naturehood walking routes via Go Jauntly in London, Manchester and Birmingham. Trust director Hilary McGrady calls autumn a vital sensory feast supporting mental health as days darken.

articles.title: Planet’s first catastrophic climate tipping point reached, report says, with coral reefs facing ‘widespread dieback’
articles.trailText: Unless global heating is reduced to 1.2C ‘as fast as possible’, warm water coral reefs will not remain ‘at any meaningful scale’, a report by 160 scientists from 23 countries warns
articles.summary: Scientists warn the planet has hit its first catastrophic climate tipping point as warm-water coral reefs enter irreversible dieback, threatening hundreds of millions of livelihoods. A report by 160 scientists from 23 countries finds reefs passed a 1–1.5°C threshold—central estimate 1.2°C—while global warming stands at 1.4°C and could breach 1.5°C within a decade. Since January 2023 the worst global bleaching event has hit over 80% of reefs in 80 countries. The report also warns the Amazon, major ocean currents and ice sheets are on the brink. Experts urge rapid emission cuts, protection of refugia and positive societal tipping points like EV adoption.

articles.title: The plastic inside us: how microplastics may be reshaping our bodies and minds
articles.trailText: The particles are in our blood, brains and guts – and scientists are only beginning to learn what they do
articles.summary: Microplastics from packaging, clothing, tyres and more infiltrate human tissues—blood, lungs, brain—often crossing barriers into cells. Austrian study finds exposure alters gut microbiome, producing chemicals linked to depression and colorectal cancer. US rodent research links brain-deposited plastics to depression-like behaviour and GFAP depletion. Human autopsies reveal plastic in dementia and heart-disease patients, with higher stroke and fatality risk. Measurement methods vary; no safe threshold is known. Experts advise reducing heat-with-plastic, choosing glass/steel containers, natural fibres, loose-leaf tea, and improving air quality. Future work must clarify particle types, sizes and clearance mechanisms.

articles.title: Number of wild bee species at risk of extinction in Europe doubles in 10 years
articles.trailText: Number of endangered butterfly species also surging amid habitat destruction and global heating, finds study
articles.summary: Recent IUCN assessments show wild bee species at risk in Europe more than doubled over the past decade—172 of 1,928 species—while endangered butterflies rose from 37 to 65, with the Madeiran large white extinct. Declines driven by habitat loss from agricultural intensification, land abandonment, pesticide use and climate change (52% of at-risk butterflies are imperilled by warming). Critical listings include 15 bumblebees, 14 cellophane bees and the mining bee Simpanurgus phyllopodus. Mountain-top and Mediterranean endemics face drought and fire, Arctic species suffer habitat shifts. EU restoration law targets pollinator recovery by 2030; measures like flower-rich field margins are vital.

articles.title: Country diary: Panic, stress, glory – my day scaling the Inaccessible Pinnacle | Merryn Glover
articles.trailText: Black Cuillin, Skye: The rough rock tears the skin and is slippery when wet. But the only way is up
articles.summary: Merryn Glover recounts her ascent of the Inaccessible Pinnacle—a 50m basalt fin atop Sgùrr Dearg—on Skye’s Black Cuillin as the climax of the 12 km Skye Ridge Traverse covering 11 Munros above 3 000 ft. She details gabbro’s rough grip and blocky basalt’s peach-hued lichens, warning how rain turns it fiendishly slick. Amid fog and damp, guided and roped, she grapples with sheer drops, panic and stress, before surmounting the leaning crest. At the summit, mist lifts to reveal sea-lit panoramas; the abseil descent feels surprisingly easy, leaving her elated and relieved.

articles.title: Baby numbats spotted at two wildlife sanctuaries in hopeful sign for one of Australia’s rarest marsupials
articles.trailText: Video shows some of the juveniles exploring outside their den at Mallee Cliffs national park in south-western NSW
articles.summary: Australian Wildlife Conservancy recorded seven numbat joeys (five at Mallee Cliffs NP in SW NSW—including a quadruplet—and two at Scotia wildlife sanctuary) exploring outside their dens. These endangered, termite-eating marsupials, extinct in NSW, are being reintroduced into predator-free reserves. Footage capturing morning routines (emerging around 8 am, playing within 50 m) confirms successful breeding; Mallee Cliffs juveniles descend from a 2020 cohort. Optimism grows as populations recover post-2018-19 drought, marking progress for one of Australia’s rarest marsupials.

articles.title: Orange-bellied parrots have swelled back from imminent extinction – but now they face a new threat
articles.trailText: Experts warn approving a windfarm in the habitat of one of Australia’s most critically endangered birds could be ‘rolling the dice’ on their survival
articles.summary: Australia’s rare orange-bellied parrot has rebounded from just 17 individuals in 2016 to around 172 this spring, aided by captive-breeding and protection at its sole wild site, Melaleuca in Tasmania. Yet only half of migrants survive the hazardous Bass Strait journey. Conservationists warn the federally approved Robbins Island windfarm—approved with a three-year monitoring requirement and potential turbine shutdowns—threatens this fragile recovery: tiny 40-gram birds evade detection and may collide. Critics call the project a “roll of the dice” on the species’ survival, as glimpses of just ten wild birds highlight its ongoing vulnerability.

articles.title: Baby giant tortoises thrive in Seychelles after first successful artificial incubation
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Trial that has produced 13 hatchlings could help other threatened species avoid extinction
articles.summary: Conservationists in Seychelles have hatched 13 Aldabra giant tortoise hatchlings through a pioneering artificial incubation protocol developed with Nature Seychelles and University of Sheffield researcher Alessia Lavigne. Eggs were screened for fertilization after early embryo death affected 75% of undeveloped wild clutches, revealing environmental stressors, not genetics, as the main hatching barrier. The vulnerable species, once decimated by 19th-century hunting and protected on the UNESCO–listed Aldabra islands, now benefits from ex-situ support on Cousin Island amid emerging resort development threats. While artificial incubation offers short-term boosts, teams will prioritize improving natural nest conditions and sharing results with Galápagos scientists to aid broader tortoise conservation.

articles.title: More than half of world’s bird species in decline, as leaders meet on extinction crisis
articles.trailText: Biodiversity losses are growing, the IUCN reports as summit opens, but green turtle’s recovery ‘reminds us conservation works’
articles.summary: On the eve of the IUCN summit in Abu Dhabi, a global bird assessment reports 61% of assessed species declining—up from 44% nine years ago—driven by deforestation and habitat loss from agriculture and development. Birds’ roles in pollination, seed dispersal and pest control underscore cascading ecosystem risks. While green sea turtles have rebounded by 28% since the 1970s, shifting from endangered to least concern through coordinated nest-site protections, Arctic bearded and harp seals are nearing extinction as retreating sea ice undermines their breeding, resting and prey availability, signaling acute climate-driven biodiversity threats.

articles.title: Country diary: A wild morning at the ploughing match | Rev Simon Lockett
articles.trailText: Wye Valley, Herefordshire: There’s a sense of deep history to events like this, where mesmerising horses and precision ploughing fall under the judges’ eye
articles.summary: At the 181st Wormside Annual Ploughing Match in Wye Valley amid Storm Amy’s gusts, horses and tractors compete in hand-trip reversible, two-wheeled garden and heritage high-cut ploughing. Developed mid-1800s to protect broadcast seeds, high-cut grooves are polished by metal boats then harrowed. Entrants travel from Cornwall to the Isle of Sheppey for judges seeking 7in-deep, straight furrows and level seedbeds. Fifteen-year-old Josh, driving a Massey Ferguson 135 with a David Brown plough, eyes his third win. Under a rainbow, Open, Vintage and marquee exhibits of flowers, produce, cakes and jams vie for silver cups.

articles.title: Prince William to attend Cop30 UN climate summit in Brazil
articles.trailText: Prince of Wales’s decision welcomed as a means of drawing attention to the event and galvanising talks
articles.summary: Prince William will attend COP30 in Belém, Brazil next month, where he’ll present the Earthshot Prize and join negotiations with 190+ governments on new emissions targets. Environmental experts say his high-profile presence—though largely a “stunt”—will boost media coverage and pressure leaders to commit, especially amid waning public attention. King Charles, who attended previous COPs, will skip COP30, while PM Keir Starmer has yet to confirm his participation, drawing criticism from Ban Ki-moon and Mary Robinson, who insist global leadership is essential to secure stronger commitments and finance for climate adaptation.

articles.title: Sally Seymour obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Smallholder, potter and illustrator who helped encourage thousands to turn to self-sufficiency
articles.summary: Sally Seymour (1933–2025), London-born artist, potter and illustrator, co-pioneered the modern self-sufficiency movement with husband John Seymour. After training in Australia she returned to Britain to illustrate and help write The Fat of the Land (1961) and The Complete Book of Self-Sufficiency, while running model smallholdings in Suffolk, Pembrokeshire and later New South Wales. Through books, workshops and hand-thrown pottery she inspired generations to adopt organic, land-based living. Survived by four children, ten grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

articles.title: Britain missing out on potential £2bn recycling industry by exporting plastic waste
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Government failure to close loophole allows 600,000 tonnes to be shipped elsewhere each year
articles.summary: UK government inaction on a plastic export loophole sends 600,000 t of waste abroad annually—an 84% rise—shuttering 21 domestic recycling plants, forgoing a potential £2 bn industry and 5,000 jobs. Exports to Indonesia (24,000 t) and Turkey, where two workers die monthly, exemplify unethical “waste imperialism.” Industry leaders demand a level playing field: raise the plastic packaging tax to 50% recycled content by 2030 and build 40 new UK sorting and processing facilities to hit a 65% recycling rate by 2035, capturing carbon and retaining jobs. Government pledges £10 bn for new infrastructure and a deposit return scheme.

articles.title: ‘We don’t want to be a toy town’: has Brexit sunk this historic UK fishing fleet?
articles.trailText: Struggling fishers in Hastings say the industry is dying after a deal giving away access to its waters made a tough job impossible
articles.summary: Hastings’s historic beach-launched fleet has plunged from 53 vessels in 2015 to just 18 today, with under-10m boats—79% of the UK’s fleet—largely idle amid unsustainable quotas, marine heatwaves and soaring fuel and safety costs. Fishermen blame a post-Brexit “reset” deal granting EU trawlers 12-year access to nearshore waters, while young crews abandon the trade despite a £360m support fund. Scientists urge a 77% cut in North East Atlantic mackerel catches to prevent collapse, and the 1831-founded Fishermen’s Protection Society reports nine of ten trainees quitting for better-paid jobs. Community leaders warn that without a national strategy, the Stade will become a museum piece rather than a working port.

articles.title: Melbourne’s skyscraper falcon chicks set for first flight as livestream audience becomes ‘permanent watch parties’
articles.trailText: Tens of thousands watch online as city’s beloved peregrine offspring prepare for first plunge
articles.summary: Three peregrine falcon chicks hatched atop Melbourne’s 367 Collins Street skyscraper are poised for their first flight in early November, drawing tens of thousands to a daily livestream. Viewers watch as the fluffy trio practices ledge-running and flapping under the guidance of expert Dr. Victor Hurley, who describes parents’ gradual food withholding and prey-taunting tactics to toughen them. The broadcast, part of a growing network of Australian wildlife webcams—from EagleCAM sea eagle nests to South Australia’s osprey barge—offers ad-free, 24/7 drama and educates urban audiences on raptor fledging behavior.

articles.title: Country diary: Pirates of the patio have found their treasure | Nic Wilson
articles.trailText: Hitchin, Hertfordshire: Some insects have evolved a long proboscis to reach the nectar of salvias and fuschias. Some take a cheeky shortcut
articles.summary: At a suburban patio in Hitchin, Nic Wilson chronicles how the long-tongued hummingbird hawk-moth (Macroglossum stellatarum) uses its 25-28 mm proboscis to feed legitimately on Salvia Amethyst Lips, then observes buff-tailed bumblebees (Bombus terrestris) and other bee species biting holes in corolla tubes to ‘rob’ nectar. These primary robbers (including white- and red-tailed bumblebees, mining and leaf-cutter bees) create punctures that secondary robbers (honeybees, early bumblebees) exploit—underscoring how tongue length shapes pollinator strategies on tubular flowers like salvias, fuchsias and aquilegias.

articles.title: Illegal gold mining clears 140,000 hectares of Peruvian Amazon
articles.trailText: Armed criminal groups tear down precious rainforest to capitalise on record gold prices, report finds
articles.summary: MAAP and Conservación Amazónica report that illegal gold mining has cleared 140,000 hectares of Peruvian Amazon rainforest since 1984, with dredge-based extraction accelerating amid record $4,000/oz gold prices. High-resolution aerial imagery reveals 989 dredges fouling 225 rivers in Loreto alone, spreading from Madre de Dios to Amazonas, Huánuco, Pasco and Ucayali. Mercury runoff is contaminating waterways, bioaccumulating in fish and Indigenous communities, causing neurological harm. Armed foreign criminal networks like Colombia’s Comandos de la Frontera and Brazil’s Comando Vermelho exploit state inaction, triggering violent clashes with riverside populations. The Andean Group has warned Peru of possible sanctions unless illegal mining is curbed.

articles.title: National security threatened by climate crisis, UK intelligence chiefs due to warn
articles.trailText: Report by joint intelligence committee delayed, with concerns expressed that it may not be published
articles.summary: Due to be published on 8 October, a delayed Joint Intelligence Committee report warns the UK’s national security is already at risk from the climate and nature crises. It highlights food supply chain disruptions and rising import costs as ecosystem collapse in the Amazon and extreme weather exacerbate dependence on overseas food, clothing and commodities. They warn food shortages and economic fallout could emerge within years as temperatures exceed 1.5°C. Cuts to overseas aid weaken preventive measures abroad. Sources fear Number 10 has blocked the report. Defence chiefs urge reclassifying climate finance as national security spending ahead of COP30.

articles.title: ‘From reef to retail’: experts warn global marine aquarium fish trade relies heavily on wild populations
articles.trailText: New research finds 90% of marine fish sold by major US retailers are wild-caught, including threatened or endangered species
articles.summary: Analysis of 734 marine aquarium fish species sold by major US e-retailers shows 90% are wild-caught, 7% mixed wild and farmed, and just 3% fully aquacultured, mainly sourced from the western Pacific and Indian oceans. Globally, the industry moves 55 million animals annually, valued at US$2.15 billion, with the US driving two-thirds of demand. At least 45 traded species are IUCN red-listed, yet CITES oversight often fails. Researchers call for tighter traceability, credible eco-certification and sustainable wild fisheries management to protect biodiversity and support local economies.

articles.title: My featherless cockatoo Doug looked like a monster – but his flaws only made me love him more | Hannah Parslow
articles.trailText: Doug and I were inseparable. He taught me a lot about human relationships, and how we are never too ugly to be loved
articles.summary: At nine, Hannah’s brother rescued a juvenile cockatoo, Doug, whose sparkling crest and affectionate nature forged an inseparable bond: he climbed her arm, learned to speak, and greeted her after school. Soon beak and feather disease ravaged his plumage and deformed his beak, turning him into a “monster.” Yet Hannah’s love deepened as Doug persevered—climbing trees despite inability to fly—until his eventual death taught her that flaws make us lovable. Doug’s legacy: our imperfections can define and deepen the bonds of love.

articles.title: The hidden cost of ultra-processed foods on the environment: ‘The whole industry should pay’
articles.trailText: Industrially made foods involve several ingredients and processes to put together, making it difficult to examine their true cost
articles.summary: Ultra-processed foods (UPFs) such as M&Ms depend on complex, global supply chains—cocoa, sugar, milk, dyes, emulsifiers—driving deforestation and high greenhouse gas emissions through energy-intensive agriculture and chemical processes. CarbonCloud estimates 13.2kg CO2e per kilogram of M&Ms, implying US output generates ~3.8m tons of CO2 annually. Lack of transparent carbon accounting leaves the true impact obscured as corporations underreport or use rough emission factors. Experts urge regulation to internalize environmental costs, shift consumption toward local whole foods and hold the food industry financially accountable.

articles.title: Thousands take legal action over ‘widespread pollution’ of three UK rivers
articles.trailText: Environmental group seeks damages from Welsh Water and two chicken producers, alleging responsibility for pollution in Wye, Lugg and Usk
articles.summary: Nearly 3,943 residents and businesses across England and Wales have filed a landmark group claim against Welsh Water and chicken producers Avara Foods and Freemans of Newent, alleging six years of sewage and poultry manure pollution in the Wye, Lugg and Usk rivers. They seek substantial damages and court-ordered remediation for biodiversity losses—otters, freshwater pearl mussels and Atlantic salmon—arguing regulators’ pledges and investments have failed. Defendants deny wrongdoing: Welsh Water cites limited infrastructure funding despite £70m spent on the Wye and £33m on the Usk, while poultry firms claim no direct manure spreading from their operations. Campaigners warn all UK rivers remain in poor biological and chemical health.

articles.title: UK plastic waste exports to developing countries rose 84% in a year, data shows
articles.trailText: Campaigners say increase in exports mostly to Malaysia and Indonesia is ‘unethical and irresponsible waste imperialism’
articles.summary: UK plastic waste exports rose by 84% in H1 2025 vs H1 2024, shipping 24,006 tonnes to Indonesia and 28,667 tonnes to Malaysia, pushing non-OECD share from 11% to 20%. The Last Beach Cleanup’s UN Comtrade analysis labels it ‘unethical waste imperialism’, criticising ministers for failing to ban exports to poorer nations despite the EU’s 2026 ban. Campaigners urge closing loopholes that make export cheaper than domestic recycling. As Malaysia tightens imports and trade shifts via the Netherlands and Turkey—where deadly labour abuses occur—UK government pledges stricter controls and £10 bn for domestic recycling investment.

articles.title: Canada’s former climate minister on making a change, ‘aloof’ Trudeau and sexism
articles.trailText: Catherine McKenna’s memoir delves into thorny parts of being in office including death threats and being referred to as ‘climate Barbie’
articles.summary: Catherine McKenna’s memoir Run Like a Girl mixes personal narrative with political reflection on her tenure as Canada’s environment and climate change minister. She exposes sexism—being derided as “climate Barbie”—and online abuse including death threats, while detailing policy wins like a revenue-neutral carbon tax rebating middle-income Canadians. McKenna calls Justin Trudeau “aloof,” criticizes the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion and Canada’s rising emissions, yet defends the Paris agreement’s legacy. An “optimistic realist,” she urges systemic industry engagement, stronger renewables policy and public protest to drive climate action. Her story highlights challenges women and young activists face in making change.

articles.title: Britain’s tiniest waders delight birdwatchers in Somerset
articles.trailText: Smaller than a robin, only about 50 Temminck’s stints are seen in the UK each year
articles.summary: At Cheddar reservoir beneath the Mendip Hills, summer drought has driven water levels to record lows, exposing mudflats that have attracted a range of waders including glossy ibises, great white egrets and, remarkably, Temminck's stint. Only about 50 of these tiny waders, smaller than a robin, visit the UK annually, and Somerset recorded its first sighting as birds foraged among teal along the shoreline. Little stints also appeared in small groups. With migration to African waterholes looming, these rare visitors have become a major draw for birdwatchers and passersby.

articles.title: Country diary: The marshes are graced with a little catwalk glamour | Nigel Brown
articles.trailText: Ynys Môn (Anglesey): What a pleasure it is to watch a pair of glossy ibis – true head-turners, and an increasingly common sight
articles.summary: At RSPB’s Cors Ddyga reserve on Ynys Môn, newly excavated wetland scrapes amid autumn reeds host teals, redshanks and black-tailed godwits, but the highlight was a pair of glossy ibis – with iridescent maroon, bronze and emerald plumage and curved bills probing for invertebrates. Once confined to the Mediterranean, these ibis have expanded into France, the Low Countries and the British Isles, producing their first UK brood in 2022 and a record 605-strong influx on Sept 8, 2025, driven by climate warming and milder winters. Ynys Môn had hosted just six before 2009 and logged 21 more mostly in autumn.

articles.title: Plans to weaken protections for national parks will have ‘disastrous consequences’ say green groups
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letter from 170-plus organisations calls on government to drop proposed changes to planning law
articles.summary: More than 170 organisations, including the RSPB, Wildlife Trusts and National Trust, have written to PM Keir Starmer warning that proposed planning-law changes would strip councils of their duty to conserve and enhance England’s national parks—created in 1949—threatening landscapes such as Dartmoor, the Lake District and the New Forest. They argue there is no evidence this duty blocks development, and that weakening protections to fast-track housing and infrastructure will damage biodiversity, undermine £36bn-a-year tourism and public health benefits, and contradict Labour’s own commitments. The government disputes these claims.

articles.title: Brexit has done nothing to stem sharp decline of UK fish populations, shows study
articles.trailText: Experts call for urgent strategy to end overfishing as report shows just 41% of stocks of species such as cod and mackerel considered healthy
articles.summary: Brexit’s promise of UK control failed: a 2025 Oceana UK report finds only 41% of 105 stocks (cod, herring and mackerel) are at safe levels after five years of ‘gross mismanagement’ and overfishing driven by excessive catch limits and international trawlers. North Sea cod, Celtic Sea cod and Irish Sea whiting are critically low. Conversely, West of Scotland haddock and North Sea plaice remain healthy under scientific quotas. Experts warn ministers must deliver an urgent, legally binding plan to end overfishing, set annual stock rebuilding targets and audits, or risk ecological collapse and coastal economic decline.

articles.title: Glacier melt will lead to ice-free peaks in California for first time in human history
articles.trailText: New research shows massive glaciers in Sierra Nevada projected to melt away by the beginning of the next century
articles.summary: New Science Advances research reconstructs the four largest Sierra Nevada glaciers—Conness, Maclure, Lyell and Palisade—showing they’ve endured since 30,000 years ago and will vanish by the century’s end under current warming trends. Using exposed bedrock samples, scientists mark this potential first ice-free era since human arrival in the Americas (~20,000 years ago). As bellwethers amid projections that 40–75% of global glaciers may disappear, their loss carries ecological disruptions and stark symbolic weight.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves clears planning blockage amid ‘good relationship’ with developer
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Chancellor says 20,000 homes were being held up due to ‘some snails that are a protected species or something’
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves privately intervened to unblock a stalled Sussex development of 20,000 homes after a developer ‘friend’ alerted her that a protected, 5 mm-wide ramshorn snail was halting planning. Caught on tape telling tech execs not to publicize the fix before the official announcement, Reeves emphasized her “good relationship” with the developer while the government pursues pro-building reforms—including diluting EU-derived habitats regulations—drawing fire from Wildlife Trusts CEO Craig Bennett and planning lawyer Alexa Culver for sidelining ecological science. A Treasury spokesperson insisted the overhaul will deliver 1.5 m much-needed homes and infrastructure.

articles.title: Britain’s big, baffling ladybird glut: ‘My house is literally crawling with them’
articles.trailText: These little spotted beetles are looking for a comfortable new home for the winter – and it could be yours
articles.summary: Across Britain, homeowners are alarmed as native and invasive ladybirds swarm indoors in October, seeking winter hibernation sites. Experts explain that on warm autumn days, seven-spot species normally shelter under leaf litter, while non-native harlequin ladybirds (Harmonia axyridis), red/orange beetles introduced in 2004, often crawl into houses. Professor Helen Roy says this seasonal migration is normal, and Natural History Museum curator Max Barclay reassures that although ladybirds can host surface fungi and parasites, they pose no threat to humans. Parasitic wasps are beginning to curb populations, promising a natural balance by next season.

articles.title: Tawny frogmouths take patience to appreciate. They will reward you with insights into their remarkable lives | Stephanie Convery
articles.trailText: Spotting tawnies is a bit like completing a crossword: it’s easier once you are familiar with the patterns yet you can always get stumped
articles.summary: Stephanie Convery recounts discovering a pair of tawny frogmouths in the decommissioned Elsternwick Park golf course now Yalukit Willam reserve in Melbourne’s Elwood. These nocturnal, mottled grey birds mate for life, fiercely defend territory and use minimalist nests—often scant sticks or reused structures—to raise fluffy, wide-eyed chicks. They camouflage on knobbly bark, adopt log-mode when threatened and display loyal bonds noted by ornithologist Gisela Kaplan. After one partner’s death and a breeding-season absence, the resilient pair re-emerged in new cypress clumps before returning to their original copse, enriching evening walks with intimate wildlife encounters.

articles.title: UN plastics treaty chair to step down with process in turmoil
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Luis Vayas Valdivieso says he is quitting for personal and professional reasons after reports of pressure behind the scenes
articles.summary: Luis Vayas Valdivieso, chair of stalled UN plastics treaty talks, is stepping down amid reports of covert UNEP pressure led by Inger Andersen’s staff. Negotiations in Geneva collapsed in August after his draft, stripped of production caps, chemical controls and lifecycle provisions, was rejected as the “lowest common denominator” by the UK, Ghana and NGOs. He cited personal reasons but lodged an inquiry into UNEP’s clandestine meeting to oust him. Industry lobbying and governance conflicts have deepened mistrust. Vayas Valdivieso calls for fresh leadership, transparency and state-driven process to salvage the treaty’s future.

articles.title: Marine heatwaves to become more frequent off UK and Irish coasts, experts say
articles.trailText: Scientists find 10% chance that similar events to the ‘unheard of’ temperatures in 2023 could occur each year
articles.summary: Research by the University of Exeter, Met Office and Cefas finds the 2023 ‘unheard of’ marine heatwave—2.9C above June normals for 16 days—now has a roughly 10% annual chance of occurring, up from 3.8% in 1993 in the Celtic Sea and 0.7% in the North Sea. Experts warn such events stress fish, shellfish, kelp and phytoplankton, disrupt reproductive timing, boost harmful bacteria, and intensify land heat and rainfall. They say steady climate warming drives exponential increases in marine extremes and call for urgent emissions cuts to protect ocean health.

articles.title: Country diary: The unlikely success of wildlife in lead country | Mark Cocker
articles.trailText: Bonsall, Derbyshire: It was, in fact, the poison in the ground that prevented this patch from becoming cattle country – then nature took care of itself
articles.summary: At Bonsall Moor, Derbyshire, centuries of lead mining inadvertently fostered biodiversity: toxic galena seams halted cattle grazing, leaving small, irregular fields now studded with mature hawthorn copses, elders, gorse and scattered elms and ashes. A celebrated mast year sees hawthorns heavy with fruit, priming the patch for winter thrush flocks. 17th-century miners dug extensive soughs—one 4.5 miles long over 21 years—for drainage. This poisoned, overlooked landscape contrasts with the surrounding monocultural pastures, illustrating how industrial pollution can preserve complex, wildlife-rich habitats.

articles.title: ‘It’s Sellafield or nothing’: what life is like growing up in the shadow of Europe’s oldest nuclear site
articles.trailText: Young people growing up in Whitehaven on England’s north-west coast rely on the power plant for everything from jobs to civic investment. But for those who see their future elsewhere, options can be limited
articles.summary: Whitehaven’s identity and economy revolve around Sellafield, Europe’s oldest nuclear site now in decommissioning until 2125. With 60,000 local employees—80% Cumbrian—the plant fuels civic investment in digital hubs, river clean-ups and Pride sponsorship, and offers apprenticeships paying up to £30k. Yet many youths, like art-focused Cole McAvoy, report limited non-STEM pathways, underfunded creative classes and teacher turnover to better-paid nuclear roles. Local care-experienced and mental-health cases exceed national rates, compounded by unreliable transport. A new £20m government “Pride in Place” fund aims to broaden youth facilities, but residents warn reliance on a single industry risks marginalising diverse careers and leaving young people feeling there’s “Sellafield or nothing.”

articles.title: Global renewable energy generation surpasses coal for first time
articles.trailText: Record solar expansion and steady wind growth driving world’s shift away from fossil fuels in 2025, report finds
articles.summary: In H1 2025 wind and solar farms globally generated more electricity than coal for the first time, driven by a 33% surge in solar and 7% in wind that met 83% of rising demand and cut coal and gas use. China and India led the shift, while the US and EU still saw higher fossil output. The IEA predicts global renewables, led by solar PV, will more than double by 2030 with China and India as top markets.

articles.title: Thames Water removes 100-tonne fatberg from west London sewer
articles.trailText: Toxic mass chiselled out of Feltham pipes amid campaign to stop people tipping harmful substances down drains
articles.summary: Thames Water engineers spent a month chiselling and high-pressure washing a 100-tonne fatberg—wet wipes bound by congealed fat, oil and grease—from a 125-metre sewer 10 m beneath Feltham, west London. Equivalent to eight double-deck buses, the clog coincided with a campaign highlighting how household wipes and fats pollute waterways. Amid creditors seeking up to 15 years’ regulatory leniency to fund overdue upgrades after decades of underinvestment, Thames Water spends £18���m yearly clearing 3.8 bn wipes and tackles 14,810 fat and 28,899 rag blockages. A planned ban on plastic-containing wipes contrasts with survey data showing 48% of Britons still pour fats down drains.

articles.title: Carbon offsets fail to cut global heating due to ‘intractable’ systemic problems, study says
articles.trailText: Analysis of 25 years of evidence shows most schemes are poor quality and fail to lower emissions
articles.summary: An Annual Reviews meta-analysis by Oxford’s Smith School (Lezak et al) reviews 25 years of voluntary carbon markets, diagnosing systemic failures in most offset schemes—non-additionality, impermanence, leakage and double-counting—that render credits ineffective. UN climate summit rules and industry-led standards (ICVCM, offset ratings agencies) have barely improved quality; a Nature Communications study found under 16% of offsets deliver real cuts. The paper calls for phasing out non-removal offsets, redirecting markets to high-quality carbon dioxide removal/storage, adopting contribution-based funding, and salvaging select projects (cookstoves, landfill gas capture) with stricter protocols.

articles.title: Marine park threatens to euthanize 30 whales if Canada does not provide funding
articles.trailText: Marineland’s warning comes after Canadian official blocked the transfer of the beluga whales to a theme park in China
articles.summary: Marineland, an Ontario amusement park in financial crisis, has warned it will euthanize its 30 remaining beluga whales by Oct 7 unless Ottawa funds its operations or allows their export. Fisheries minister Joanne Thompson this week blocked a planned transfer to China’s Chimelong Ocean Kingdom, citing animal welfare. The park, which closed for summer and is up for sale after decades of public entertainment, has recorded 20 cetacean deaths since 2019. Activists and Ontario authorities threaten legal action or provincial seizure to secure sanctuary care.

articles.title: As forests are cut down, butterflies are losing their colours
articles.trailText: The insects’ brilliant hues evolved in lush ecosystems to help them survive. Now they are becoming more muted to adapt to degraded landscapes – and they are not the only things dulling down
articles.summary: As tropical forests are replaced by eucalyptus plantations, butterfly wing colours have dulled: research in Espírito Santo, Brazil, shows vibrant species vanish in deforested zones, leaving brown and grey generalists. Loss of colour signals threatens mating, camouflage and ecosystem complexity. Part of a broader “discoloration” project, the study also compared species richness—21 in plantations versus 31 in native forest—and links colour loss to altered light, temperature and moisture regimes, warning of cascading biodiversity declines if deforestation persists unchecked.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Matmo batters southern China
articles.trailText: About 350,000 flee homes as heavy rain and winds sweep region, while Hurricane Priscilla forms near Mexico
articles.summary: Typhoon Matmo, the 21st storm of 2025, made landfall on China’s southern coast and Hainan, prompting China’s highest red alert and the evacuation of 350,000 in Guangdong and Hainan. Sustained winds of 94 mph and over 50 mm of rain in six hours forced flight and ferry suspensions in Haikou, Wuchang and Wenchang. As it weakens into a 55 mph depression inland, heavy rains of 130–150 mm threaten flooding in northern Vietnam and Yunnan. Offshore, Hurricane Priscilla intensified to 75 mph off Mexico’s Pacific coast, triggering watches for Baja California Sur and up to 200 mm of rain in Michoacán and Guerrero. In the Arabian Sea, Cyclone Shakhti spurred IMD coastal alerts for Maharashtra.

articles.title: Country diary: Where the Herdwicks are the star of the show | Andrea Meanwell
articles.trailText: Eskdale, Lake District: In a traditional event that includes hound trials and wrestling, there’s also a ‘world champion’ title at stake
articles.summary: In Eskdale, Lake District shepherds have met each September since 1866 to celebrate native Herdwick sheep, crafts and produce. Sponsored by the National Trust, which awards the world champion Herdwick sash, the event pits local Eskdale flocks against entrants from across the Lake District. This year Patrick Fitzwilliam of the Duddon Valley won his second world title, beating Eskdale champion Thomas Postlethwaite. Afterwards crowds enjoyed Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling, hound trials and fell races. Success here enhances breeders’ reputations and drives higher livestock prices.

articles.title: Going extinct ‘right under our noses’: the quiet plight of Australia’s rarest bird of prey
articles.trailText: Restricted now to the tropical north, the mysterious red goshawk is fast disappearing as a result of climate change and habitat loss
articles.summary: Restricted to tropical savannas from the Kimberley to Cape York, Australia’s endemic red goshawk has vanished from eastern states since the 2000s. Federally uplisted to endangered in 2023, just 1,300 mature birds—likely under 1,000—persist in scattered coastal woodlands. Only 10 mainland breeding pairs remain, alongside 10 on the Tiwi Islands. Habitat loss from agriculture, logging, mining, fragmentation and extreme heat threatens nest success across home ranges up to 600 km². BirdLife Australia and UQ researchers use satellite tracking and train Indigenous rangers to monitor metre-wide nests, map breeding areas and refine conservation strategies to avert extinction.

articles.title: I used to think birds made life worth living only for those of us obsessed with them. Now I know the truth
articles.trailText: It wasn’t until I was in my 20s that I realised birds could have a powerful significance even for people who weren’t bird-nerds like me
articles.summary: Writer and conservationist Sean Dooley recalls how a fleeting encounter with a white-plumed honeyeater broke a friend’s emotional spiral, illustrating birds’ power to ground us. He cites studies showing birdsong in hospitals lowers pain, anxiety and discharge times, and that local species diversity can boost well-being as much as a $150 weekly income increase. Dooley outlines BirdLife Australia’s annual Bird of the Year vote—juxtaposing iconic birds like the kookaburra and magpie with lesser-known species such as the fairy tern, red goshawk and imperiled regent honeyeater—to celebrate wildlife’s value and rally conservation action.

articles.title: Stolen views, shipping containers and ‘shame signs’: do Australia’s tree wars need a new solution?
articles.trailText: Conservationists and councils have called for bigger fines, a national database about illegal tree removals and even jail time to deter tree killers
articles.summary: After trees in Sydney’s Brighton-Le-Sands were hacked and poisoned to open views, Bayside council parked a muralled shipping container to block it, one of many ‘shame signs’ used by councils from Mosman to Burnside. Faced with illegal clearing for harbor views and higher property values, NSW and other states plan doubled fines, jail terms and a national illegal-tree-removal register. Mayors and experts warn councils lack resources and data; they call for federal support, enforcement officers and centralised monitoring to protect urban canopy.

articles.title: Australian bird of the year: an avian popularity contest with a deeper purpose
articles.trailText: Voting is now open in the 2025 poll, but as you cast your ballot, here are some critical numbers to bear in mind
articles.summary: Australia’s annual Bird of the Year poll opens at 1am AEDT on 6 October, inviting over 300,000 votes across nine days. From roughly 850 native species—half endemic—the field has been narrowed to 50 finalists. Voters cast one ballot per day; each evening the five lowest-voted birds are eliminated. A final vote among the last ten birds ends at 6am AEDT on 15 October; the winner is livestreamed the following midday. Beyond celebrating icons like the swift parrot and superb fairy-wren, organisers want to spotlight urgent conservation: 164 species are government-listed as threatened, including 18 critically endangered, driving momentum for upcoming nature-law reforms.

articles.title: Trump’s hatred for renewables means the US is falling behind the rest of the world
articles.trailText: As well as embracing ‘beautiful coal’, the president has set about obliterating clean energy projects
articles.summary: Under Trump’s return, his administration withdrew from Paris, abolished the State Dept. climate office, halted offshore windfarms, banned solar and wind on federal land, cut renewables and EV subsidies and boosted coal and oil drilling. Branding coal "clean, beautiful coal," these rollbacks spooked businesses, shuttering $22bn in projects and costing 16,000 jobs, raising energy prices, eroding US climate leadership as rivals surge ahead and ceding ground to China. He’s even pressured the UK and EU to buy US oil and gas, waging a rearguard fight to keep the world mired in fossil fuels.

articles.title: Embrace autumn! 20 reasons to be cheerful – from red wine to sensational star-gazing
articles.trailText: From light festivals and Bonfire Night to spectacular forest walks and mushroom foraging, there’s plenty to enjoy. Or if you’d rather stay in, sip mulled wine as you take in a fantastic season of TV
articles.summary: This autumn offers 20 reasons to celebrate, from a vivid display of red, orange and gold foliage thanks to a long, hot summer (with top leaf-peeping spots like Westonbirt and Kielder) and a mast year boosting acorn crops and wildlife, to natural spectacles (seal pups, starling murmurations, deer rutting), plus perfect light for photography and cooler temps ideal for running. Dark nights bring Orionid meteors, supermoons and stargazing festivals, alongside Diwali and new light events. Enjoy Halloween’s Celtic roots, Bonfire Night traditions, seasonal soups, foraging, red wine, rich fashion hues, autumn blooms, cultural highlights (Frieze, film festival, TV premieres), saunas and off-peak travel deals.

articles.title: Hot public holiday expected for Sydney and Brisbane after record rain for parts of NSW and Queensland in September
articles.trailText: Warm weather follows deluges in more than a dozen places in NSW and Queensland which topped daily records for the month
articles.summary: Sydney and Brisbane brace for a scorching Monday public holiday (31°C and 32°C) after a record‐wet September along Australia’s east coast. Twenty‐one Queensland locations—including Topaz with 700 mm—and six in New South Wales broke their highest monthly rain totals, with multiple daily records (e.g., 379 mm in 24 hours at Topaz). In contrast, South Australia and Victoria saw rainfall 44–45% below average. A cold front will deliver showers and cooler conditions to southern states later in the week. Australia’s climate is now 1.5°C warmer than in 1910.

articles.title: A new soft plastics recycling scheme is replacing Australia’s failed REDcycle. Will it mean consumers have to pay more?
articles.trailText: A consortium of manufacturers aims to fund the sorting and processing of soft plastics for reuse – but critics say it will pass costs on to consumers
articles.summary: A new industry-led scheme, Soft Plastics Stewardship Australia (SPSA), backed by major supermarkets (Coles, Woolworths, Aldi) and manufacturers (Nestlé, Mars, McCormick), aims to collect, sort and process up to 300,000 t of soft plastics annually, replacing the collapsed REDcycle program. Subject to ACCC approval, participants pay levies starting at A$160/t (rising to A$200/t in 2026), potentially adding 1–2 c to grocery prices. Critics warn the voluntary model covers only ~15% of soft plastics, lacks closed-loop recycling, may pass costs to consumers and risks greenwashing without mandatory targets.

articles.title: The great butterfly heist: how a gentleman collector stole thousands of butterflies from Australian museums
articles.trailText: Scientists are still unravelling the thefts of Colin Wyatt, an English adventurer, artist and naturalist who charmed the entomological community
articles.summary: Colin Wyatt, a charismatic English naturalist, orchestrated a serial heist in 1946–47, stealing over 3,000 rare butterfly specimens from Australia’s state museums (Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide). Among them was the holotype of Pseudalmenus chlorinda barringtonensis (“flame hairstreak”), replaced with a thinly painted decoy. Most stolen specimens were repatriated in 1947, but the original holotype remained hidden in England until 2016, when ANU entomologist Michael Braby exposed the forgery. The scandal revealed deep vulnerabilities in museum collection protocols dependent on amateur access and highlighted the colonial legacies embedded in natural history archives.

articles.title: ‘Baudin’s or bauxite?’ Stark warning black cockatoo won’t survive mining expansion
articles.trailText: BirdLife WA calls consequences of Alcoa’s proposals to clear 11,000ha of jarrah forest ‘irreversible and catastrophic’ for endangered bird
articles.summary: Conservationists warn that Alcoa’s and South32’s proposals to clear over 14,800 ha of WA’s northern jarrah forest for bauxite mining will push the endangered Baudin’s black cockatoo to extinction. BirdLife WA highlighted a 90% population drop in 40 years and a failed 2023 bid to list it as critically endangered. The cockatoo relies on centuries-old tree hollows in the Darling Range for winter habitat. A record 59,000 EPA submissions—90% templated—reflect public outcry. BirdLife predicts irreversible loss and functional extinction within 50 years without halting forest clearing. Alcoa insists it will avoid high-value conservation areas and buffer nesting sites as the EPA reviews impacts early next year.

articles.title: Advocates raise alarm over Pfas pollution from datacenters amid AI boom
articles.trailText: Tech companies’ use of Pfas gas at facilities may mean datacenters’ climate impact is worse than previously thought
articles.summary: Public health advocates warn that soaring demand for AI-driven datacenters is fueling unreported PFAS “forever chemical” emissions from f-gas refrigerants, water cooling chemicals and electronics disposal. Tech giants like Google and Amazon use PFAS-laden cooling systems that leak or degrade into toxic compounds. No mandatory reporting exists on volumes released. Environmental groups and the EPA fast-tracking chemical reviews call for state laws demanding disclosure, citing risks including cancer, reproductive harm and persistent contamination. Industry insists releases are minimal, but mounting evidence of PFAS and TFA accumulation in air, water and waste prompts legal and legislative challenges aiming for transparency and stricter controls.

articles.title: Country diary: Ragged butterflies, comatose bees – these are the last of the summer sights | Phil Gates
articles.trailText: Blanchland, Northumberland: Today’s perfect autumn day captures the dying embers of a memorable summer
articles.summary: Phil Gates sketches an idyllic late-September afternoon in Blanchland, Northumberland, as oak acorns carpet the path, overripe brambles decay, and spiders’ webs glisten over sun-bleached grasses. Dark umbels of angelica yield seeds and blackthorn blossom has given way to wrinkled sloes. On windless heathland, gorse pods crackle, goldfinches scatter thistledown, while greenbottle flies, hoverflies, devil’s-bit scabious and comatose bumblebees visit final wildflowers. A ragged small copper butterfly, its fiery orange wings dulled and frayed, perches on lichens—summer’s dying ember.

articles.title: Australia’s magpie swooping season returns with a vengeance – and cyclists are their main targets
articles.trailText: Statistics for the 2025 breeding season show almost two in three attacks are on cyclists. But there are measures to avoid their wrath
articles.summary: Australia’s 2025 magpie swooping season has seen 3,431 reported attacks—63.9% targeting cyclists—over its six-week spring breeding period. Protective adults use beak-clapping, overhead whooshes and screeches to defend nests, perceiving fast-moving bikes as predators. BirdLife Australia notes 11.3% of swoops caused injuries, with rare sightings even in Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Magpies recognize faces and may re-target individuals, but friendships can form. Common deterrents—fake eyes on helmets, pipe cleaners, umbrellas—offer mixed success. Experts advise slowing down, dismounting, backing away from nest sites and taking evasive action to diffuse threats.

articles.title: Asad Rehman’s journey from antiracism campaigner in Burnley to head of Friends of the Earth
articles.trailText: Climate crisis is ‘interconnected crisis of inequality’, says Rehman, who began organising at his school in the 1970s
articles.summary: Asad Rehman, who moved from Pakistan to Burnley aged four, first organised antiracism walkouts in the 1970s amid National Front attacks. He later campaigned at the Newham Monitoring Project and Amnesty UK—shifting human rights discourse to include economic and social rights—before joining Friends of the Earth in 2006 to launch the climate justice movement. As director of War On Want from 2017, he integrated anti-poverty and environmental struggles.
