In October 2025 he became chief executive of Friends of the Earth England, Wales and Northern Ireland (233 local groups, 250,000 supporters), pledging to expand community organising and centre social and racial justice in climate campaigns.

articles.title: ‘It proves this can be done’: Berlin the blueprint to bring goshawks to UK cities
articles.trailText: Conservationist plans release of 15 each of the apex predators sourced as chicks into Chester and London
articles.summary: Berlin’s success hosting urban goshawks—apex predators now nesting in Viktoriapark and other parks—inspires a UK pilot: Rewilding UK’s Dr Paul O’Donoghue plans to seek Natural England approval to ‘assist colonise’ 15 northern goshawks each in Chester and London, sourced from European nests and breeders, fitted with GPS and provided supplementary food. Expected to curb mesopredators (crows, magpies) and boost garden birds, the £110,000 project faces challenges over urban adaptation, dispersal and stakeholder engagement.

articles.title: Make green great again: Can appeals to the wallet make climate policy an election-winner?
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: At a major gathering in New York, climate advocates say that language has to change
articles.summary: At Climate Week NYC both Republican and Democratic leaders—from US energy secretary Chris Wright under Trump to former secretary Jennifer Granholm under Biden—reframed climate policy around affordability, pitching green energy as a way to cut households’ power bills. Proposals like the Cheap Energy Act seek to restore renewable incentives, while progressives led by NY mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani call for populist measures—fare-free transit and decarbonized housing—to deliver immediate savings. This strategy echoes the Green New Deal and Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act. Advocates say linking everyday costs—from rent to transit fares—to climate action can rally support, but critics warn mere messaging won’t stick without concrete relief for working-class households over corporate interests.

articles.title: Frailty in ageing populations worsened by air pollution, global review finds
articles.trailText: Coauthor of research says condition linked to heightened vulnerability and loss of independence – but is reversible
articles.summary: An international review led by Dr Zahra Jafari (Dalhousie University) of 10 studies across 11 countries finds outdoor air pollution, notably particulate matter, elevates frailty risk in middle-aged and older adults—accounting for 10–20% of UK cases—with men sometimes more vulnerable. Exposure to secondhand smoke raises frailty risk by ~60%, while solid cooking/heating fuels add further risk. Authors emphasize frailty is preventable, delayable and even reversible. Experts urge policies ensuring cleaner outdoor and household air, smoke-free environments and clean energy to extend independence, lower healthcare costs and inform dementia and chronic disease strategies for ageing societies.

articles.title: Country diary: I appear to be in a relationship with my local jackdaws | Jason Smalley
articles.trailText: Warton, Lancashire: They’ve fully moved into the area. Their conversation is our soundscape. All because of a bag of Garden Gourmet seed mix
articles.summary: In Warton, Lancashire, a visitor’s purchase of a seed mix spirals into an avian takeover: starting with sparrows and robins, then a pair of jackdaws from a nearby quarry grows to eighty corvids—including rooks, magpies and carrion crows—roosting in Scots pines and transforming the morning soundscape. The writer’s daily coffee and cat-feeding ritual must now include weekly sacks of grain to satisfy clamorous adults and fledglings, while neighbours fret over the uproar. The corvids, notorious for gifting shiny objects, have left an ink cartridge, prompting the diarist to document this unplanned relationship—before restoring local sanity.

articles.title: ‘Planetary health diet’ could save 40,000 deaths a day, landmark report finds
articles.trailText: Diet allows modest meat consumption and would also slash food-related climate emissions by half, says report by 70 leading experts from 35 countries
articles.summary: A landmark EAT-Lancet report by 70 experts from 35 countries finds that a flexible, locally adaptable "planetary health diet"—rich in plants, limited red meat (≈1/week), moderate dairy, eggs, poultry and fish—could avert ~40,000 deaths/day (15 m/year), halve food-system emissions by 2050, protect biodiversity and ensure sustainable nutrition for 9.6 bn people. Authors recommend reallocating subsidies, taxing unhealthy foods, labels and ads regulation, and tackling inequalities in food access to deliver health and climate gains.

articles.title: BrewDog sells Scottish ‘rewilding’ estate it bought only five years ago
articles.trailText: Latest disposal by ‘punk’ beer company follows £37m loss and closure of 10 pubs
articles.summary: BrewDog has offloaded its 3,764-hectare Kinrara rewilding estate near Aviemore, bought in 2020 for £8.8 m with plans to plant millions of trees and offset 550,000 t of CO₂ a year. The company later admitted the site covered just 37 sq km, with maximum CO₂ capture of 1 m t over 100 years, tree-growth failures and sold-off buildings. After a £37 m loss, 10 pub closures and widespread delistings, BrewDog’s new team sold Kinrara to Oxygen Conservation, a private rewilding investor owning 12 UK estates, funding restoration via carbon credits, renewables and eco-tourism.

articles.title: A pheasant coucal is a mass of contradictions: a bewildered bravo rolling through my house like a feathered wrecking ball | Bronwen Scott
articles.trailText: Swinging wildly from confident to confused, and permanently dishevelled, this most relatable of cuckoos blunders through life as best it can
articles.summary: A prowling pheasant coucal barged into the author’s enclosed Queenslander hallway, scattering books and folders yet unfazed by the chaos—a living wrecking ball embodying its species’ contradictions. Unlike Australia’s 11 brood-parasitic cuckoos, this big, awkward bird weaves its own grass nest, feeds and raises its unkempt, fluff-flecked chicks, and alternates swagger with skulk. In breeding plumage, its head and breast show dusty black replacing autumnal hues. Tumbling through life uncoordinated yet determined, the pheasant coucal’s bravado and bewilderment make it the most relatable of birds—a feathery reflection of human quirks.

articles.title: Lifting the ‘constant black cloud’: how a smog-bound city cut dangerous levels of air pollution
articles.trailText: A 30-year effort driven by long-term policies is finally paying off in Santiago in Chile – but the challenge is far from over
articles.summary: In Santiago, a 30-year atmospheric decontamination plan—modernising public transport, restricting vehicle circulation and banning wood-burning heaters—has cut hours of critical PM2.5 pollution by 66% since 2015, making 2025 the third-lowest on record. Winter (May–Aug) saw 23 critical episodes vs hundreds a decade ago. Though summer ozone and “energy poverty” rebound pose challenges, compliance rose (88% fewer wood-burning violations; 312,000 vehicles off road) and residents report fewer respiratory ailments, signaling sustained improvement.

articles.title: Senior Tories dismayed at Badenoch’s ‘catastrophic’ vow to repeal Climate Change Act
articles.trailText: Theresa May, Alok Sharma, business and church leaders say plan would harm UK and not even Margaret Thatcher would have countenanced it
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s pledge to repeal the 2008 Climate Change Act — abolishing statutory five-year carbon budgets and the 2050 net-zero target — has sparked fierce backlash from senior Conservatives, business leaders, scientists and churches. Theresa May called it a “catastrophic mistake,” Alok Sharma warned it would deter private investment (which added £83bn and nearly a million jobs last year) and harm the UK’s global standing, while Lord Deben said not even Thatcher would have countenanced it. CBI, EU carbon tariffs, and Church of England and Catholic leaders also decry the move’s economic and moral risks.

articles.title: Scientists to attempt to rear swallowtail butterflies from eggs frozen in nitrogen
articles.trailText: If successful, method could be used to support long-term conservation of species vulnerable to extinction
articles.summary: Researchers will freeze eggs of captive-bred European swallowtails in liquid nitrogen at –196 °C, then compare hatching and development against unfrozen controls to test cryopreservation for long-term conservation of Britain’s native swallowtail (Papilio machaon britannicus). Confined to Norfolk Broads and threatened by rising seas, the subspecies saw its worst year in 2024. Led by Anglia Ruskin University’s Dr Alvin Helden with Jimmy’s Farm & Wildlife Park and Nature’s Safe biobank, this pioneering effort could establish the first butterfly cryopreservation protocol and aid broader pollinator conservation.

articles.title: Dogs and drones: how scientists are saving Washington’s endangered orcas
articles.trailText: Experts are finding new and more humane ways to protect the last 74 southern resident killer whales
articles.summary: Scientists in the San Juan Islands use rescue dog Eba and conservation drones to monitor Washington’s 74 southern resident killer whales non-invasively in the Salish Sea. Eba detects floating faeces by scent, allowing remote collection of samples that reveal diet, hormones, toxins, microbiome, parasites and microplastics. Drones hover over surfacing whales to capture blow-hole plumes, yielding genetic, hormonal and thermal data. Facing Chinook salmon shortages, pollution and vessel noise, these methods minimise stress, support real-time interventions and inform efforts to protect genetically distinct orca populations integral to regional ecosystems and Indigenous cultures.

articles.title: ‘It’s been beyond difficult’: earthworks of HS2 take toll on Chilterns residents
articles.trailText: Locals complain of a changed landscape, flooding, dust and disruption as rail project cuts through area of outstanding natural beauty
articles.summary: Residents of the Chilterns national landscape between Great Missenden and Wendover report drastic changes as HS2 construction eats into 252 hectares of green space. For five years families like the Bunces have seen fields divided, homes overshadowed by 14m-deep cuttings and viaducts, and endured flooding, dust and noise. Historic sites such as Jones’ Hill Wood and Grim’s Ditch were partly destroyed despite legal challenges. HS2 pledges to restore most land with new woodlands, grass embankments and attenuation ponds, but locals fear their valley is irrevocably altered.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch vows to repeal Climate Change Act
articles.trailText: Tory leader says she would replace it with ‘cheap energy’ strategy, ending decades-long consensus on climate
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch has pledged to repeal the 2008 Climate Change Act, dismantling carbon budgets and the Climate Change Committee, and replace it with an energy strategy that puts 'cheap and reliable' power first to boost growth. She also plans to scrap the UK’s net zero target. Scientists warn fossil‐fuel dependence drove recent price spikes and subsidies, arguing only clean energy investment can sustain growth. Business and investors say the Act’s legal certainty underpins green investment, while critics warn repeal would undermine energy security and the climate consensus.

articles.title: UK fifth-worst country in Europe for loss of green space to development
articles.trailText: Exclusive: 1,680 football pitches of protected natural land in England, Wales and Northern Ireland lost in five years
articles.summary: An exclusive cross-border investigation by the Guardian and European partners reveals that between 2018 and 2023, the UK lost 604 sq km of natural and farmland—equivalent to the New Forest—and 12 sq km of highly protected “national landscapes” (1,680 football pitches) to development. Satellite imagery and ML analysis rank the UK fifth-highest in Europe for green-space loss relative to national area. Major projects—most notably HS2 through the Chilterns and large housing schemes in the Cotswolds, Dorset and Berkshire—show planning restrictions being overridden. Despite enough brownfield land to meet housing targets, greenfields are built upon, prompting CPRE to call for sustainable urban reuse and warning that the government’s planning bill could undermine protections for 5,000 sites.

articles.title: ‘Desecration of landscape’: the fight over development in areas of outstanding natural beauty
articles.trailText: Residents of Woodgate estate in West Sussex enjoy its open spaces and wildlife but conservationists say it has set worrying precedent
articles.summary: Thakeham’s 600-home Woodgate estate, from shared-ownership flats to £1.4 m detached houses, spans 45 ha of the High Weald AONB, Britain’s largest such development (2018–23). Integrated biodiversity net-gain features—ponds, wildflower meadow, bird boxes and hedgehog highways—sit alongside cycleways, village green and school. Campaigners condemn the “desecration” and warn AONB protections are being undermined as councils (Mid Sussex need 19,741 homes by 2040) grapple with housing targets. A further 1,450-home scheme near Cuckfield and Ansty looms amid landscape and ecological concerns.

articles.title: Country diary: Just how low can a stone circle go? | Sara Hudston
articles.trailText: Withypool, Somerset: This is a landscape where things can lie hidden – not least a bronze-age structure that is more trip hazard than landmark
articles.summary: On Withypool Hill, Exmoor, a modest Bronze-Age stone circle of 29 knee-high gritstone stubs lies hidden among heather, discovered in 1898 after centuries off maps. Originally thought too small due to scarce rock, archaeologists now believe its deliberate miniaturisation and buried elements hold deeper ritual meaning. The landscape’s subtlety, where features blend into its tawny contours, is echoed by local nature writer Hope Bourne (1918-2010), whose frugal, off-grid life and eco-art presaged modern environmentalism.

articles.title: From Karachi’s crowded markets and Kabul’s alleys to Australia’s vast sky: budgies are for me fragments of memory | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: The contrast between the captive birds of my childhood and the wild flocks of my new home has become more than an observation
articles.summary: Shadi Khan Saif recalls first encountering caged budgerigars in Karachi’s Empress Market—vibrant yet confined symbols of life and beauty that taught tenderness and responsibility amid cramped homes. In Kabul’s bazaar they reappeared in handcrafted wicker cages, woven into folklore as persistent comic relief. Now in Melbourne he marvels at wild flocks of budgies soaring free across eucalyptus skies. Through these shifting geographies and practices, Saif explores migration, memory, belonging and the interplay between captivity and liberation.

articles.title: Appliances were once built to last – now they’re built to break. How do we fix it?
articles.trailText: Calls echo Productivity Commission report that says mandatory labelling would facilitate repairs and help consumers make better decisions
articles.summary: Australian repair volunteers report that proprietary screws, tools and restricted manuals make fixing appliances near-impossible, forcing short lifespans. A Consumer Policy Research Centre survey finds 85% of Australians want clear durability and repairability info before purchase and broadly support mandatory labelling, mirroring France’s scheme and recommendations from the Productivity Commission. Audit of 1,000 e-waste appliances shows 70% working and 20% repairable, highlighting missed reuse opportunities. Experts urge government to mandate repair-friendly design and labels, reduce household costs, curb waste and advance a circular economy.

articles.title: Will Labour’s fracking ban end practice in the UK for good?
articles.trailText: Ed Miliband’s move to bring forward ban is gambit to stop would-be Reform voters from backing Nigel Farage’s pro-fracking party
articles.summary: Labour’s energy secretary Ed Miliband announced this autumn he will legislate a total ban on new onshore oil and gas licences, embedding the 2024 manifesto pledge in law. The move forces any future Reform government to secure a parliamentary vote to lift the fracking moratorium, rather than acting by ministerial decree. Fracking—linked to earthquakes, local protests and low-yield UK shale—has faced moratoria in 2011 and 2019 after tremors halted Cuadrilla’s sites. Friends of the Earth map 187 at-risk constituencies (141 Labour-held), where Miliband will mobilise activists under “Send the frackers packing.”

articles.title: He once worked at the world’s best restaurant. Now he wants to make US school food better
articles.trailText: An alum of Noma in Copenhagen, Dan Giusti is on a mission to transform institutional cooking – but getting fellow chefs to buy in hasn’t been easy
articles.summary: At Dream Mott Haven, Brigaid’s Dan Giusti—former Noma chef—demonstrated a $2.71 USDA-compliant school lunch to over 100 food-service professionals, emphasizing cost breakdown under a $4.62 federal reimbursement. Since leaving fine dining a decade ago, Giusti’s for-profit Brigaid has grown to 75 chefs across 45 partnerships in eight states, aiming to replace processed institutional meals with scratch cooking in schools, hospitals and prisons. Offering starting salaries around $90K with benefits, Brigaid tackles chef recruitment by framing institutional kitchens as leadership incubators. Districts like New London and Cupertino report improved menus and budgetary commitment for expanding Brigaid collaborations.

articles.title: UK fracking ban to be brought forward as Labour counters Reform promise
articles.trailText: Ed Miliband announces government will speed up plans to ban controversial practice supported by Nigel Farage
articles.summary: Labour energy secretary Ed Miliband will fast-track a permanent UK fracking ban via legislation in this autumn’s North Sea transition plan to pre-empt Reform UK’s pro-fracking pledge. The bill would enshrine a ban requiring a parliamentary vote to overturn, safeguarding 187 shale constituencies. Miliband’s 2022 opposition-day motion also helped bring down Liz Truss’s government by forcing a fracking vote. Labour will mobilise campaigners in nearly 200 seats to oppose drilling, highlighting seismic risks—nearly 200 tremors at Preston New Road—and UK geology hurdles.

articles.title: Revealed: Europe losing 600 football pitches of nature and crop land a day
articles.trailText: Investigation shows extent of green land lost across UK and mainland Europe to development from 2018 to 2023
articles.summary: Investigation by the Guardian and partners using satellite data shows Europe lost 9,000 sq km of natural and agricultural land between 2018–23—an average of 1,500 sq km a year (600 football pitches daily). Nature loss accounts for 900 sq km/yr and cropland 600 sq km, driven by housing, roads and luxury developments from Portugal’s dune golf course to Turkey’s marina and Germany’s Tesla factory. Methodology captures small, cumulative losses omitted by the EEA. Top hotspots include Turkey, Poland, France, Germany and the UK. Experts warn this trend undermines biodiversity, carbon storage, food security and EU climate commitments.

articles.title: The Santa Claus effect: how expanding tourism ate into Lapland’s green space
articles.trailText: The number of visitors to the region has risen 160% in 30 years as concerns grow for its fragile ecosystem and indigenous practices
articles.summary: Finnish Lapland’s visitor numbers surged 160% over 30 years to over 700,000 in 2023, with 100,000 from Britain, driving tourism developments that consumed green areas equal to London’s Hyde Park between 2018 and 2023. Holiday homes, ski slopes, VR aurora experiences and cottage plots have replaced parks, forests and Sámi reindeer pastures—reversing a 20-year settlement protecting indigenous grazing lands. Analysis across six hubs shows 2.7m sq m of nature lost, half tourism-related, threatening biodiversity, fragile Arctic ecosystems and Sámi culture. Regional plans aim growth to boost vitality but struggle with housing shortages, climate impacts and cultural concerns.

articles.title: Nine-spine sticklebacks: Britain’s tiny but mighty freshwater fish
articles.trailText: Hardy species with up to 12 spines can withstand oxygen-poor water and a variety of temperatures
articles.summary: The nine-spine stickleback (Pungitius pungitius), Britain’s smallest (≈8cm) freshwater fish, thrives in oxygen-poor, variable-temperature ponds, lakes, rivers and estuaries. Considered exceptionally hardy, it endures low oxygen and broad thermal fluctuations. Males construct nests and channel fresh water through with fin fanning to oxygenate eggs, guard them and the emerging fry—despite eight to 12 small spines—then drive juveniles away once spines develop. Unlike three-spine sticklebacks, males lack red breeding coloration, merely darkening below and lightening above, and their spines lock upright—though less prominent—to deter predators. A pioneer species, they often recolonise once-polluted waterways.

articles.title: Country diary: The red cross on the white horse is gone. For that we are thankful | Derek Niemann
articles.trailText: Frome, Somerset: The Westbury horse is a local landmark to us, but also a countryside icon to travellers from across the world, all of whom are welcome
articles.summary: After an anonymous daubing of St George’s flag on the Westbury White Horse mural, locals overpainted it with a diagonal cross reading “Frome says no to fascism. We are all human.” Derek Niemann evokes the ancient 300-year-old chalk figure—celebrated for a King Alfred victory or as Hanoverian emblem—recalled in Ravilious’s paintings and as a 50m-wide silhouette glimpsed from London-bound trains. Though the repainting left no lasting damage, the incident felt a divisive strike against countryside heritage, and Niemann hopes this politicized “violation” fades so the horse regains its status as an inclusive lodestar.

articles.title: Queensland’s biggest coal-fired power station could close six years early
articles.trailText: Crisafulli government wants coal plants to run longer – reversing previous Queensland Labor government’s plans to end reliance on coal power by 2035
articles.summary: Rio Tinto, co-owner of Queensland’s 1976 Gladstone coal-fired power station, has notified AEMO of a potential retirement in March 2029—six years earlier than the previously expected 2035 shutdown. While no final decision has been made and life-extension remains possible if market conditions permit, existing contracts run until 2029. GPS, plagued by average annual outages exceeding 4,200 hours since 2020, underpins regional heavy industry, risking $6 billion in output. The incoming Liberal-National government has signaled a reversal of Labor’s 2035 coal phase-out, seeking longer plant operation. Analysts and environmental groups demand a firm closure timetable, grid upgrades for renewables, and honest transition planning.

articles.title: News Corp embraces fantasy genre by turning climate crisis into ‘laughable’ science fiction | Temperature Check
articles.trailText: The National Climate Risk Assessment is attacked in the Daily Telegraph, while wind turbines became a frightening obstacle for firefighting planes and solar panels a source of mountains of landfill waste
articles.summary: Australia’s Daily Telegraph labeled the government’s National Climate Risk Assessment “SCIENCE FICTION” citing a single US sceptic’s views, ignoring expert consensus on 1.5C–3C warming impacts. It also sensationalised solar‐panel waste—despite 95% recyclability and ongoing recycling scheme development—and exaggerated wind‐turbine dangers to firefighting aircraft, dismissed by veteran firefighters. Temperature Check highlights a consistent News Corp pattern of undermining climate science and renewable energy with one‐sided reporting, minimal expert responses and skewed headlines.

articles.title: Common toad is becoming uncommon in UK, study shows
articles.trailText: Species’ population has almost halved in a generation and urgent action is needed to protect it, analysis finds
articles.summary: In a study led by Cambridge’s Silviu Petrovan, volunteer “toad patrol” counts reveal UK common toad populations have plummeted by 41% from 1985–2021. Parallel Swiss data show a one-third decline since 1973. Researchers link declines to road traffic mortality, pond loss, urbanisation and prey shortages. The study underscores an accelerating collapse of British wildlife and calls for urgent, long-term monitoring and habitat protection across the UK and Europe to prevent further losses of this once-ubiquitous amphibian. Once celebrated in myths and literature, including The Wind in the Willows’ Mr Toad, the species now faces an uncertain future without coordinated action.

articles.title: ‘So tiny and so vulnerable’: what chance will one of Australia’s smallest birds have against a rocket launchpad?
articles.trailText: When the federal government gave the go-ahead for a launch facility to be built at a site in South Australia that’s home to the endangered southern emu-wren, conservationists were astounded
articles.summary: At Whalers Way, South Australia, federal approval for a new rocket launch facility risks clearing 24ha of critical heathland habitat for the endangered Eyre Peninsula subspecies of the southern emu-wren. Weighing just 7g, these poor-flying, tail-heavy wrens rely on connected dense scrub for breeding; under 1,000 remain locally. Conservationists led by Therese Pedler and BirdLife’s Hugh Possingham warn fragmentation, noise, light and fire from the launchpad could drive this subspecies to extinction. Southern Launch argues coastal proximity and a biodiversity strategy justify the development, but critics demand relocation to already cleared land.

articles.title: The Woodside case proves what we’ve long suspected: Australia’s ‘environment protection’ law does no such thing
articles.trailText: Approval of the North West Shelf extension shows the purpose of the EPBC Act is to allow developments, not to protect and preserve
articles.summary: Approval of a 40-year extension for Woodside’s North West Shelf gas plant exposes the EPBC Act’s development bias: Minister Murray Watt’s initial push for zero detectable acidic emissions to protect Murujuga’s 50,000-year-old rock art was scaled back in private talks to only 60% cuts by 2030 and 90% by 2061, justified by economic benefits. Sparse enforcement, opaque negotiations and few blocked projects in 25 years fuel calls for an independent EPA and stronger environmental law reform.

articles.title: Is there such a thing as a ‘problem shark’? Plan to catch repeat biters divides scientists
articles.trailText: Some experts think a few sharks may be responsible for a disproportionate number of attacks. Should they be hunted down?
articles.summary: Marine biologist Eric Clua argues that 'problem sharks'—individuals that have learned to prey on humans—cause repeat bites in the Caribbean. After fatal and non-fatal tiger shark attacks off Saint-Martin and St Kitts and Nevis in 2020–21, Clua’s team used wound swabs and DNA analysis to link the same shark. Though culls persist, peer scientists dispute the concept, citing low bite frequency, ethical concerns, and favoring preventive measures over targeting specific sharks.

articles.title: Biomethane not viable for widespread use in UK home heating, report finds
articles.trailText: Gas derived from farm waste can meet only 18% of current gas demand by 2050, despite claims of fossil fuel lobbyists, study finds
articles.summary: A Regen study for the MCS Foundation finds UK biomethane from manure, sewage and farm waste can meet only up to 18% of current gas demand by 2050, limited by unsustainable feedstock and land-use constraints. Researchers and MCS chiefs argue biomethane has a role in industry and farming but is unsuitable for homes, urging ministers to abandon its widespread domestic use and focus on heat pump roll-out. The report warns gas firms push green gas to preserve pipelines and boilers and calls for a 2050 gas-grid decommissioning deadline. Government plans an early-year consultation on biomethane policy.

articles.title: Country diary: An unexpected vista of sky-light and symmetry | Amy-Jane Beer
articles.trailText: Yorkshire Wolds: What a difference a few years makes – this used to be an expanse of wet mud, now it’s a precious chalkland pond
articles.summary: Amy-Jane Beer revisits a chalkland washpit in the Yorkshire Wolds she saw three years earlier as a broken-bund mudhole. After contacting Jon Traill at Yorkshire Wildlife Trust, the trust secured landowner support to rebuild the bund and restore the dew pond. On her return she meets the farmer, discusses archaeology, rewilding and land stewardship, and discovers the once-dry basin now brimmed with clear, shallow water. The restored pond mirrors the sky and valley, a quiet triumph of collaboration and landscape revival.

articles.title: World’s major cities hit by 25% leap in extremely hot days since the 1990s
articles.trailText: Capitals from London to Tokyo need urgent action to protect people from deadly high temperatures, analysts say
articles.summary: IIED analysis shows 43 major capitals now suffer 25% more extreme-heat days than in the 1990s—1,335 days ≥35 °C in 2015–24 versus 1,062 in 1994–2003. Rome and Beijing doubled their hot-day counts; Manila tripled them; Madrid records 47 days ≥35 °C (up from 25); London’s >30 °C days doubled. Fossil-fuel-driven heating intensifies deadly heatwaves, threatening millions—particularly the elderly and slum dwellers. With emissions still rising, experts warn of mounting heat-related mortality unless cities boost adaptation: cooling centres, shading, improved housing and early warnings. The GCA’s “The Heat Is On” campaign calls for urgent action ahead of COP30.

articles.title: Rainbow lorikeets can be such bruisers, but this pair turns me into a cartoon princess | Johanna Roberts as told to Alyx Gorman
articles.trailText: The day I moved into my apartment, the birds appeared on the balcony. Now they come and sit on my arm every time I come outside
articles.summary: After moving into her apartment, Johanna Roberts quickly became the welcome host to a gang of rainbow lorikeets on her balcony. Two in particular return multiple times daily to quietly chirp for sunflower seeds, then boldly perch on her hand or arm—evoking a “cartoon princess” moment. Food-driven, they even attempt to wander indoors before she lures them back outside. Her free-range “pets” offer spontaneous companionship, colorful acrobatics, and a nostalgic beach-holiday vibe for family visits.

articles.title: Twelve whales have been tangled in shark nets off Queensland’s coast so far this year. Here’s why
articles.trailText: In the worst case, entanglements could cause drowning, one expert says, but whales can also suffer long-term effects from the nets
articles.summary: Researchers report a 50% increase in humpback entanglements off Queensland this year, with nine incidents involving 12 whales versus an average of six (eight in 2024). This rise aligns with peak southerly migration and a recovered population of 50,000, plus an inshore shift of the east Australian current’s thermal front that whales follow, especially around the Sunshine Coast ‘pinch point’. Entanglements can cause drowning or chronic stress. Trials of acoustic deterrents and smart drumlines have failed to stop incidents. Queensland’s government insists on expanding shark nets to protect swimmers, rejecting calls to remove them despite expert warnings.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Imelda could become second hurricane to hit Caribbean in days
articles.trailText: Imelda is forecast to strengthen as Hurricane Humberto continues to bring strong winds to region
articles.summary: While Hurricane Humberto holds as a category 4 in the Sargasso Sea—sending dangerous swells and rip currents toward the Lesser Antilles, US east coast and Bermuda—Tropical Storm Imelda has formed farther west and is forecast to become a category 1 hurricane by late Monday or early Tuesday. Imelda’s trajectory will carry it through the Bahamas, brushing Florida’s east coast before veering toward Bermuda by Thursday. Already, heavy rainfall (up to 90 mm in 12 hours) has caused flooding and two deaths in the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico, disrupted water supplies, triggered evacuations in Grand Bahama and closed airports. The Bahamas, Cuba and Carolinas face 150–300 mm rain, flash floods, mudslides and up to 3 ft storm surge through midweek.

articles.title: Country diary: The geese are safe from us, but are we safe from the geese? | Nicola Chester
articles.trailText: Inkpen, West Berkshire: Among the Michaelmas traditions, at the end of the agricultural year, was the giving of a fattened goose. Today they’ve got the run of the lanes
articles.summary: On Michaelmas in Inkpen, West Berkshire, the quarter-day marking harvest’s end, farm geese once gifted for prosperity now roam lanes, feasting on fallen nuts and confronting passersby. Nicola Chester recalls local flocks—Bob May’s famously aggressive guardians ambushing walkers with indignant honks, and Manor Farm’s descendants of Miss Julia White’s 1941 arrivals—acting as unwitting bouncers that halt cars, prams and cyclists. Though the stubble-goose gifting tradition has faded, these birds endure as symbols of rural rhythms: muesli-like hazel and beech nuts underfoot, the harvest’s end, the winter battle ahead, and countryside customs preserved in feathers and laughter.

articles.title: Environmental damage is putting European way of life at risk, says report
articles.trailText: EU officials warn climate breakdown and wildlife loss ‘are ruining ecosystems that underpin the economy’
articles.summary: An European Environment Agency report warns that unchecked environmental damage—from 80% of protected habitats in poor condition and a 30% drop in the EU’s carbon sink to stagnant transport and food emissions—threatens Europe’s economic foundations and quality of life. Only greenhouse gas and ozone-depletion targets are on track; most biodiversity, circular economy and adaptation goals are falling behind. Officials caution against rolling back green rules amid political and external pressures, urging sustained climate action to curb costs.

articles.title: What is ‘dunkelflaute’? And how will a new long-duration battery change Australia’s energy grid?
articles.trailText: Limondale project designed to store excess renewable power during day and dispatch when demand is high
articles.summary: Australia’s new Limondale battery in NSW is the country’s first eight-hour, 50 MW grid-scale storage, using 144 Tesla Megapacks beside a solar farm to store daytime surplus and dispatch through evening and morning peaks. Classified as medium-duration storage, it helps balance wind and solar variability and guard against “dunkelflaute” dark doldrums. As coal plants retire, such systems compete with pumped hydro more flexibly and cost-effectively, providing strategic reserves, firming renewable output and lowering infrastructure costs while bolstering grid reliability in a high-renewables future.

articles.title: Floating nests and decoys: how fairy terns are being charmed back to Port Phillip Bay
articles.trailText: These small seabirds are not faring well along Australia’s south-eastern coastline, but there is hope for their resurgence thanks to some novel tactics
articles.summary: BirdLife installed a floating island at Avalon coastal reserve, 55 km southwest of Melbourne, with sand, shell-grit flooring and twig nooks to mimic ideal beach nests. To attract the vulnerable fairy tern (just shy of 30 cm long, ~7,500 in southern Australia but only ~150 in Victoria), teams deploy 3D-printed, cadmium-yellow decoys and broadcast courtship calls, using social facilitation to lure real birds. This approach protects eggs from foxes and human disturbance after past failures on levees. Backed by state and catchment authorities, the project asks beachgoers to keep clear of nesting zones.

articles.title: ‘I couldn’t look’: European farmers on losing crops as the industry collides with worsening drought
articles.trailText: Global heating means annual drought losses across Europe could reach €17.5bn. Shipping and power generation are also being affected by low water levels
articles.summary: European farmers from Germany to England and Ukraine report 40–95% yield losses as severe drought driven by global heating parches soils and depletes rivers. South Brandenburg grower Thomas Goebel sold assets after sunflowers and corn wilted; Lilian Guzmán’s rapeseed failed; organic producer Adam Beer lost nearly all cabbages. Low Rhine levels halted inland shipping—costing BASF €250 million in 2018—and forced nuclear and hydropower cuts. Drought costs average €11.2 billion annually and could rise to €17.5 billion under 3 °C warming, squeezing credit, investment and export revenues.

articles.title: What are droughts and how worried should we be about them?
articles.trailText: Rising global temperatures are making dry spells longer and more intense, with profound effects on health, food and the economy
articles.summary: Droughts are prolonged periods of below-average precipitation that trigger meteorological, hydrological and agricultural crises. Rising global temperatures have roughly doubled the land area affected since 1900, intensifying water shortages, crop failures and livestock losses. In Somalia, drought contributed to an estimated 71,000 deaths between 2022 and 2024. Europe loses over €11bn a year in agriculture, power and shipping. Climate change amplifies evaporation and alters rainfall, making dry spells more frequent and severe. Mitigation strategies include efficient water management, drought-resistant crops, shifting away from water-intensive industries and personal conservation measures.

articles.title: Artists given chance to use wood from felled Sycamore Gap tree
articles.trailText: Two years after the tree was cut down, the National Trust says it wants to turn a sense of loss ‘into a sense of hope’
articles.summary: On the second anniversary of the Sycamore Gap tree’s illegal felling, the National Trust invites artists, collectives or creative agencies to propose a nationally significant artwork using half its seasoned timber. With a £200,000 commission budget, submissions open Oct 13–Nov 17, shortlisted entries receive £5,000 for development, and a public vote will select a winner in Feb 2026. The initiative aims to transform loss into hope, stimulate public reconnection with nature, and honor the tree’s legacy.

articles.title: ‘Huge energy challenges’: how can India make the leap to become a green, clean country?
articles.trailText: As deadly heatwaves become more frequent, demand for life-saving cooling is further straining India’s generation capacity
articles.summary: India’s grid was overwhelmed by early-season deadly heatwaves, exacerbating chronic energy poverty that affects two-thirds of households. While accounting for 70% of its electricity, coal remains India’s cornerstone energy source amid criticism of its status as the world’s third-largest CO2 emitter. New Delhi invokes equity under the CBDR principle, demanding developed nations finance and lead fossil-fuel phase-out. Simultaneously it has surged solar and wind capacity—now a top global producer—and targets 50% non-fossil power, expanded nuclear and green hydrogen. Experts urge a strategic, whole-system transition balancing development, adaptation and climate mitigation.

articles.title: Powerful lithium batteries in written-off EVs now hot property at salvage auctions
articles.trailText: Demand for secondhand electric vehicle batteries is surging across Australia, as buyers repurpose them for everything from solar storage to off-grid energy
articles.summary: Salvage auctions across Australia are seeing surging demand for high-powered batteries salvaged from written-off EVs—about 100 per month at Pickles—with buyers repurposing them into solar storage units and off-grid energy systems that beat diesel generators. Startups offering second-life battery solutions have emerged in the past 18 months as wrecked Teslas, BYDs and MGs—often only two to three years old—are prized for their cells, which are roughly five times more powerful than typical home batteries. Repurposed packs can power events (e.g. a Sunshine Coast music festival), extend up to 20 years, reduce battery shredding and bolster Australia’s energy storage needs.

articles.title: Meat is a leading emissions source – but few outlets report on it, analysis finds
articles.trailText: Sentient Media reveals less than 4% of climate news stories mention animal agriculture as source of carbon emissions
articles.summary: Sentient Media analyzed 940 climate-change stories from 11 major US outlets and found only 25% mention food and agriculture among emissions drivers, with a mere 3.8% noting animal agriculture or meat production—the largest source of food-sector emissions (60%). Despite food and agriculture yielding a third of global greenhouse gases, media coverage largely overlooks methane from ruminants, land-use changes and deforestation. With over half of habitable land used for farming—80% for livestock—experts warn that moderating meat intake, especially beef, could drastically reduce deforestation and emissions. They cite cultural sensitivity, industry lobbying and policy gridlock as barriers to comprehensive reporting.

articles.title: Mountain gorillas are back from the brink. But what happens if they run out of room?
articles.trailText: Humans have helped save the great apes from extinction, but are now the biggest threat to their survival as they compete for land in east Africa’s Virunga mountains
articles.summary: In the Virunga mountains spanning Uganda, Rwanda and the DRC, mountain gorillas have surged from around 250 in the 1980s to over 1,000 by 2018, thanks to Gorilla Doctors’ veterinary care, ranger patrols and habituation for ecotourism in Uganda’s Bwindi and Rwanda’s Volcanoes parks. With visitors paying $800–$1,500 per trek, tourism revenue funds parks and community buffer zones, but militia violence (220+ ranger deaths), human-transmitted disease and encroaching agriculture raise fears their shrinking habitat may soon hit its carrying capacity.

articles.title: Country diary: The magic and mystery of the New Forest ‘drift’ | Jeni Bell
articles.trailText: New Forest: The round-up of ponies is an earth-shaking annual tradition, and shows the remarkable skill of those who work the national park
articles.summary: Each year from mid-August to early November in the New Forest, over 5,000 semi-wild chestnut ponies are driven through dense gorse to holding pounds in an age-old ‘drift’ round-up. Overseen by verderers and managed by agisters, riders and walkers rely on intimate knowledge of terrain and herd behaviour to corral ponies for health checks, foal branding and tail-marking, then release them under commoners’ grazing rights—an earth-shaking spectacle of tradition and skill. Closed to public access, the unpredictable, thunderous event feels like an ancient secret unveiled for a moment.

articles.title: Australian bird of the year 2025: craft your own origami bird with this simple guide
articles.trailText: Follow these simple steps to build your very own bird
articles.summary: Ahead of Australian Bird of the Year 2025, this hands-on guide shows how to craft origami birds using an A4 sheet—convert it to a square, then follow folds (including inverse reverse for the beak). Printable templates for swift parrots and Carnaby’s cockatoos are available from Bush Heritage Australia. Voting opens 6 October, eliminates five lowest each day until the winner is announced on 16 October via livestream. Polls have run since 2017; past champions include the magpie, black-throated finch, superb fairywren and swift parrot.

articles.title: Will Labour’s climate plan survive the squeeze of tight budgets and rightwing attacks?
articles.trailText: As Donald Trump calls climate change a ‘con job’ and Reform UK weaponises net zero, Starmer faces pressure to hold the line on commitments
articles.summary: At the UN, Trump dubbed climate change a “con job,” echoing Reform UK’s net-zero attacks and pressuring PM Starmer, who last spring vowed a low-carbon revolution amid polls and tight budgets. Looming decisions—Gatwick expansion, North Sea licence rules, £13.2 bn home-insulation funding, wind-contract awards, 1.5 m housing-standard regs—and an Oct 29 legal deadline to set carbon budgets will test Labour’s resolve. Treasury clout, fossil-fuel and housebuilder lobbies clash with green commitments. Ministers tout record renewables and nuclear investment, but tensions over planning, grid pricing and tax-shielding green levies persist, with activists warning that backtracking risks ceding public support.

articles.title: What are the critical environmental decisions piling up in Labour’s inbox?
articles.trailText: From airport expansion to North Sea oil, the government is being pulled in multiple directions on a range of issues
articles.summary: Labour faces environmental deadlines: by 29 Oct deliver its carbon budget/growth plan covering transport, housing, industry and farming for net zero 2050; by late Oct launch a £13.2 bn warm homes insulation and heat-pump scheme; this autumn finalise a future homes standard mandating solar panels and setting rules on heat pumps, batteries and hydrogen; by year-end enforce its no-new North Sea licences pledge with a British jobs bonus; back airport expansion while mandating sustainable aviation fuels at 10% by 2030; publish CfD wind auction results before December; release its long-delayed environmental improvement plan; and set out post-Brexit farm subsidies.

articles.title: Abnormally hot days may hit Australia’s south-east after rare sudden warming over Antarctica
articles.trailText: Phenomenon extremely unusual in southern hemisphere and last occurred in 2019 when it contributed to worsening of black summer bushfires
articles.summary: A rare sudden stratospheric warming over Antarctica has raised stratospheric temperatures by about 30 °C to around –20 °C and halved polar vortex winds to roughly 100 km/h. Only three moderate-to-major events have occurred in the southern hemisphere since 1980 (1988, 2002, 2019), the last fueling Australia’s 2019–20 ‘black summer’ bushfires. Such events usually drive spring heat spikes and reduced rainfall in New South Wales, Victoria and southern Queensland by shifting the southern annular mode. This year, record-warm oceans may counteract drying, making outcomes uncertain. The warming also shrinks the Antarctic ozone hole.

articles.title: ‘It’s the best feeling’: how Copenhagen gave cyclists a green wave
articles.trailText: Traffic lights are synchronised so a rush-hour cyclist at 20km/h can catch green lights all the way
articles.summary: Copenhagen introduced 16 years ago a pilot “green wave” system synchronizing traffic lights on key corridors to allow cyclists traveling at 20 km/h to hit successive greens, cutting delays and boosting ridership. After positive feedback and minimal political pushback, the city’s new budget allocates DKK 602 m to expand green waves to 15 more routes, build Denmark’s longest cycle bridge, install smart “bicycle barometers” and improve lighting and 30 km/h zones. Planners hope smoother flows on superhighways will attract suburban commuters, reduce CO₂ emissions, ease car–cyclist tensions and cement Copenhagen’s bid as Europe’s top cycling city.

articles.title: Bird of the year is back – reminding us why joy matters in difficult times
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: from the red goshawk to the tawny frogmouth, the poll reveals the richness of Australia’s birdlife and the risks it faces
articles.summary: Guardian Australia’s biennial Bird of the Year poll returns on October 6, inviting global readers to vote on 50 nominated species—from reader favourites like currawong to the ever-popular tawny frogmouth. Highlighting conservation alongside joy, this year spotlights the critically endangered red goshawk—only about 1,000 remain—alongside Baudin’s black cockatoo, southern emu wren and orange-bellied parrot. It celebrates Australia’s 850 native birds (half endemic), and last poll drew 321,000 votes, proving appetite for nature’s delights amid climate and biodiversity crises. Guardian data teams monitor for voting anomalies, ensuring a fair, high-stakes showdown of feathery icons.

articles.title: ‘History will remember who showed up’: Keir Starmer faces call to attend Cop30 summit
articles.trailText: Response from leaders and key climate figures comes after PM’s aides advised non-attendance over concerns Reform may attack him
articles.summary: Keir Starmer is urged by UN climate chief Simon Stiell, Ban Ki-moon, Mary Robinson, Sir David King and Labour MPs to attend COP30 in Belém this November despite aides’ fears of Reform party attacks. They argue his presence would signal leadership, reinforce the UK’s 81% emissions cut pledge by 2035, spur global commitments and ensure negotiators focus on stronger climate action. Attendance remains undecided amid protocol issues over King Charles, potential Reform backlash and Donald Trump’s planned no-show. Two-thirds of Britons back climate action, and many MPs stress the summit’s high stakes for limiting warming to 1.5C.

articles.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa rampages through Taiwan, Hong Kong and southern China
articles.trailText: Peak winds of 165mph bring 17 deaths in Taiwan, while Storm Bualoi threatens to strengthen into typhoon on its way to the Philippines
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa battered Taiwan with 165 mph winds, breaching a barrier lake and causing 17 fatalities, then skirted Hong Kong (90 injuries, 197 mm rain) and made landfall in Guangdong at 150 mph, forcing million-plus evacuations in Shenzhen, Chaozhou, Zhuhai, Dongguan and Foshan before weakening into Vietnam. Meanwhile Storm Bualoi is forecast to intensify into a typhoon en route to northern Luzon, prompting school closures and flight cancellations over flood and landslide risks.

articles.title: Country diary: On harvest open day, celebration, relief – and flying gazebos | Anita Roy
articles.trailText: Wellington, Somerset: A little drama on the community farm, but, most important, we walked away laden with the fruits of our labour, hard-won in a difficult year
articles.summary: At Wellington, Somerset’s community farm harvest open day, chief growers Rose and Ruth defied forecasts as low grey clouds held off rain until a sudden gust sent gazebos cartwheeling across the field. Volunteers wrestled them down and sheltered in the new polytunnel, among ripening tomatoes, aubergines, and melons. What was a blank field two years ago now hosts brassicas under mesh, vivid rainbow chard, pumpkins and squash thriving despite drought. Rose argues that every town needs funded community growing projects for resilient local food systems. The author headed home laden with sunflowers, tomatoes, basil and chard.

articles.title: Big trees in Amazon more climate-resistant than previously believed
articles.trailText: Forest is ‘remarkably resilient to climate change’, but remains under threat from fires and deforestation
articles.summary: A 30-year Nature Plants study across 188 Amazon plots finds the largest trees’ trunks thickened 3.3% per decade—driven by rising atmospheric CO₂—enhancing carbon sequestration in intact forests. Dominant giants like castanheiras, sumaúmas and Angelim vermelho now constitute 1% of stems but handle 50% of carbon and water cycling, proving resilience to heat and drought. Yet fragmentation from fires, road building (e.g. BR-319) and agricultural expansion threatens to shift cleared areas into carbon sources. Protecting contiguous mature forest is critical for continued climate stabilization.

articles.title: Argyle Street ash in Glasgow wins tree of the year competition
articles.trailText: Beloved specimen triumphs in Woodland Trust contest over ‘King of Limbs’ oak in Wiltshire
articles.summary: Victorian-era Argyle Street ash in central Glasgow—immortalised by James Cowan in 1951 and protected under one of Glasgow’s first tree preservation orders—has won the Woodland Trust’s 2025 Tree of the Year contest. Standing 75ft tall outside sandstone tenements, the city landmark has endured the Clydeside blitz, urban redevelopment and ash dieback. Nominated by arborist David Treanor, MSP Paul Sweeney and musician Stuart Murdoch, it triumphed over Wiltshire’s “King of Limbs” oak and Wales’s “Lonely Tree.” Runner-ups included Leicester’s Lady Jane Grey oak and Chiswick House cedar. The winner will represent the UK in the 2026 European competition.

articles.title: Asheville’s slimmed-down restaurants make a comeback a year after Hurricane Helene: ‘Back to the basics’
articles.trailText: Many eateries in the North Carolina city now welcome tourists after navigating complex insurance rules to survive
articles.summary: Asheville’s restaurants one year post-Hurricane Helene have reopened with leaner operations: flagship Cúrate reopened but shuttered sister La Bodega, downsized menu and staff; Mellow Mushroom gave away 1,000 pizzas daily, lost $300K, then cut its menu 30% and staff 25%; high-profile closures (Laughing Seed, Bouchon, Bottle Riot, Vivian, Rhubarb) highlighted vulnerability; survivors like the Market Place and Luella’s Bar-B-Que trimmed hours, inventory and staff, leveraged wind damage insurance and bought generators. The scene now refocuses on small teams, slim menus, stronger insurance and future-proofing, while new spots like Crusco, ButterPunk and Fitz & Wolfe emerge.

articles.title: Country diary: It doesn’t pay to be a brightly coloured pigeon | Claire Stares
articles.trailText: Langstone, Hampshire: It’s always breeding season for feral pigeons, and the colony on the roof opposite are certainly playing their part in the web of life
articles.summary: From a Langstone, Hampshire rooftop vista, a feral pigeon flock—mostly pure white with one mottled male—breeds year-round beneath solar panels. Descendants of rock doves, they use steep slate and cavities to lay clutch after clutch beyond the March–July peak, exchanging incubation and feeding squabs with crop milk. Their nitrogen-rich droppings foster vivid Xanthoria parietina lichen across the tiles. A tabby cat’s chatter signals minor threat, but overhead sparrowhawks pose real predation risk, highlighting urban wildlife adaptation and survival strategies in a clandestine roof-top ecosystem.

articles.title: China’s plans to cut emissions too weak to stave off global catastrophe, say experts
articles.trailText: Xi suggested US not rising to the climate challenge in his UN speech, but critics say new cuts fall ‘far short’ of what is necessary
articles.summary: China’s 2035 plan to cut emissions just 7–10% from peak—well below the 30% experts deem essential to avert climate catastrophe—drew sharp criticism. Announced by Xi at the UNGA, the NDC targets >30% non-fossil energy and 3,600GW wind/solar capacity by 2035 en route to 2060 neutrality. E3G’s Kaysie Brown says it misaligns with China’s decarbonisation goals, while others cite Beijing’s ‘underpromise and overdeliver’ record. Critics warn weak near-term ambition and new coal approvals undercut leadership claims, though China’s $625bn clean-energy investments, steep renewables cost cuts and EV surge could sway markets ahead of COP30.

articles.title: ‘Science demands action’: world leaders and UN push climate agenda forward despite Trump’s attacks
articles.trailText: Leaders unveil new targets to cut planet-heating pollution after Trump called climate crisis a ‘con job’
articles.summary: 120 countries plus the EU unveiled new nationally determined contributions at a UN summit, with China pledging a 7–10% emissions cut from its peak by 2035 and a major boost to wind and solar capacity. UN chief António Guterres warned that current policies risk missing the 1.5°C target and called for "much further, much faster" cuts ahead of COP30 in Brazil. US President Trump derided climate science as a "hoax" and attacked green energy, drawing condemnation. Despite $2tn invested annually in renewables and 194 active Paris signatories, experts and vulnerable nations say these pledges remain inadequate to avoid catastrophic warming.

articles.title: ‘I worry about the future of my daughter’: the ‘silent majority’ who care about the climate crisis
articles.trailText: Readers who are part of the 80-89% of the population who want to see climate action tell us their ideas on how to make their voices heard
articles.summary: Recent studies reveal 80–89% of people worldwide back climate action but vastly underestimate their peers’ urgency. Contributors—from a Scottish paediatric radiologist calling climate the biggest health threat and urging carbon taxes, to London retirees demanding protests and US citizens pushing equitable aid—stress systemic reforms over individual fixes. Voices across Europe and the US urge proportional representation, legal accountability for fossil fuel firms, methane-leak regulation, Climate Superfund funding, and voting on climate issues. Many agree meaningful progress hinges on collective political pressure and industry responsibility, not just personal sacrifice.

articles.title: World’s oceans fail key health check as acidity crosses critical threshold for marine life
articles.trailText: Scientists call for renewed global effort to curb fossil fuels as seven of nine planetary boundaries now transgressed
articles.summary: An annual assessment by the Potsdam Institute finds global ocean acidity has crossed a critical pH threshold, marking the seventh of nine planetary boundaries to be transgressed. Since industrialization, surface pH has dropped ~0.1 units (30–40% acidity rise), endangering cold-water corals, reefs and Arctic ecosystems. Acidification reduces calcium carbonate availability, hurting shell-forming organisms and cascading up the food web, threatening fisheries, food security and the ocean’s heat absorption and carbon sequestration roles. Researchers call for immediate cuts in fossil fuel emissions, deforestation, pollution and stronger fisheries management to avert further planetary decline.

articles.title: Plant that mimics odour of half-eaten ants to attract pollinators discovered
articles.trailText: Botanist says new Japanese species of dogbane is first evidence of plants copying ants
articles.summary: Researchers led by Ko Mochizuki (Univ. of Tokyo) have discovered Vincetoxicum nakaianum, a Japanese dogbane that lures fruit flies by emitting a blend of volatile compounds (nonane, undecane, 8Ac, 10Ac, 6-MMS) identical to alarm pheromones released by ants under spider attack. In Y-maze trials, flies ignored crushed ants but sought the attacked-ant odor and pollinated the flowers. Reported in Current Biology, this is the first known ant-pheromone mimicry by a plant, boosting its reproductive success.

articles.title: Solitary, yes. Shy? Hardly, albatrosses trail after trawlers and dance for their partners
articles.trailText: A better term for the shy albatross comes from its scientific name: sea commander. Unfortunately, it’s now in a battle to survive
articles.summary: Australia’s shy albatross, Thalassarche cauta, breeds on three remote Tasmanian outcrops. With a 2.5m wingspan and a name meaning “sea commander,” it forages alongside trawlers. Once reduced from 20,000 to a few hundred pairs by egg collecting and feather hunting, numbers have rebounded to ~30,000 mature birds but remain near-threatened. Juveniles spend years at sea before performing elaborate dances to secure lifelong mates and raise one chick annually. Major threats include longline-fishing bycatch—mitigated by night-setting, weighted hooks and tori lines—and climate-driven food shortages. Rescues like “Banyo Alfred” spotlight its plight and fuel support in BirdLife Australia’s 2025 Bird of the Year poll.

articles.title: Can ‘bite-resistant’ wetsuits help protect surfers against sharks? Here’s what Australian researchers have found
articles.trailText: Study finds that some suits – incorporating materials such as Kevlar – can reduce the severity of puncture damage from shark bites
articles.summary: An Australian study in Wildlife Research tested four bite-resistant wetsuit materials—Aqua Armour, Shark Stop, ActionTX-S and Brewster (incorporating Kevlar and high-strength fibres)—against wild white and tiger shark bites. Using foam “bite packages” in Spencer Gulf and off Norfolk Island, researchers recorded damage from 84 white shark and 68 tiger shark strikes. All advanced fabrics significantly reduced substantial and critical puncture wounds and potential blood loss versus standard neoprene, though crushing and internal injuries remained. Authors and psychologists say bite-resistant suits, alongside deterrents and risk-based education, could empower surfers and save lives.

articles.title: Fossil fuel burning poses threat to health of 1.6bn people, data shows
articles.trailText: New interactive map tracking PM2.5 air pollution reveals 900m people in path of ‘super-emitting’ industrial facilities
articles.summary: Data from Climate Trace’s new interactive map shows PM2.5 from coal, oil and industrial fossil fuel facilities endangers 1.6B people globally, including 900M downwind of 2,500+ “super-emitters” like power plants, refineries and mines. Urban hotspots—Karachi, Guangzhou, Seoul, New York—face outsized toxic plumes. While the US government under Trump rolls back federal climate and EPA protections, it occasionally highlights pollution cleanup, prompting concern from environmentalists. Al Gore warns that particulate pollution kills 8.7M annually. Publicly available satellite-tracked plumes aim to identify at-risk communities and drive targeted emission cuts.

articles.title: How Trump’s assault on US wind industry threatens jobs and power for nearly 5m homes
articles.trailText: US president’s offshore wind crackdown targets nine projects, imperiling jobs and the clean energy transition
articles.summary: Trump’s administration has paused or is investigating nine permitted offshore wind projects—Revolution Wind, Vineyard Wind, Coastal Virginia Offshore, Sunrise and Empire Wind—threatening 12.5GW of capacity for nearly 5m homes and about 9,000 jobs. It barred new solar/wind on federal land, cut incentives and, citing unsubstantiated whale, security and rescue risks, filed legal motions against Maryland and Massachusetts projects. Critics warn higher power costs, supply-chain hit and danger to the clean-energy transition, even as most Republicans still back 'all-of-the-above' energy policy. Driven by Trump’s personal disdain for turbines—he’s called them 'ugly', 'disgusting' and a 'scam'—the administration uniquely targets an entire clean-energy sector.

articles.title: ‘You don’t get to aim big when you are somewhere small’: A teenager’s fight to end single use plastics on her Scottish island
articles.trailText: Groundswell of support for ban propels campaign of Tabby Fletcher, 17, from her island home on Jura to parliament
articles.summary: Tabby Fletcher, 17, from Scotland’s Isle of Jura, has launched a petition with over 26,000 signatures urging the Scottish Government to ban all single-use plastics after storm surges washed up entangled wildlife, including birds and a goat, on her local beaches. Backed by Highlands and Islands MSPs, the petition—focusing on single-use items rather than ‘ghost gear’ already slated for regulation—is due for MSP debate on September 24 and spotlights ingestion, entanglement and toxic microplastic threats. Campaigners note UK single-use products make up half of plastic waste and demand enforceable national action.

articles.title: Country diary: The allotment is flying at full mast
articles.trailText: Hove, East Sussex: I’m greeting friends with juice and jam and taking plums to the pub, although, there is still some mystery surrounding ‘mast’ years
articles.summary: In Hove, East Sussex, the allotment is experiencing a mast year: branches sag under apples, plums, pears, while sloes, hips, hazelnuts and haws ripen in the hedges. The author shares berries, juice and jam with friends, takes plums to the pub and reserves apples for visiting waxwings. Wildlife and detritivores feast, returning nutrients to the soil. Mast years, synchronized nationally, may result from underground fungal networks or pollen coupling and serve to overwhelm seed predators. The writer reflects on this cycle of abundance and wonders what next year will bring.

articles.title: Extreme weather and extreme politics go hand in hand – Trump and Musk are pushing both
articles.trailText: Rabble-rousing of far-right demagogues is a reminder that the battle for a fair and habitable planet cannot be fought alone
articles.summary: The article argues that extreme weather and extreme politics are mutually reinforcing: climate-driven fear fuels far-right demagogues like Trump and tech billionaires such as Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, who fund denial, stoke division and distract from coordinated global climate action. Drawing on an Amazon drought analogy, it warns that isolationist, “close the borders” rhetoric mirrors trees shutting down in stress – ultimately self-defeating. Despite apocalyptic visions of elites retreating into bunkers, large majorities worldwide support interdependent solutions, with leading renewables investments from China and forest-defending rulings in Brazil offering paths forward.

articles.title: I’ve always admired the magpie for its beauty and spite – so much so I got one tattooed on my arm | Patrick Lenton
articles.trailText: I love their monochromatic beauty, I adore the sound of their warble, and above all I relate to their commitment to revenge
articles.summary: Patrick Lenton’s Melbourne essay celebrates the sleek black-and-white magpie and its notorious spring swooping: he admires their musical warble, memory and capacity for revenge—traits he finds relatable, even tattooing one on his arm. To shield his greyhound Basil, Lenton brokers peace by offering cooked chicken and crickets, greeting each bird, and laying careful treats. His diplomatic ritual wins neighborly goodwill—lemons and rosemary in exchange—and underscores a larger lesson in community: respect, empathy and the mutual grudges that shape human–animal bonds.

articles.title: Coalition MPs say Australia’s emissions are a fraction of the world’s total. What kind of argument is that?
articles.trailText: Australia’s emissions are only about 1.1% of the global total. But it is scientifically wrong to say half a billion tonnes of CO 2 don’t matter, experts say
articles.summary: Coalition MPs, including Barnaby Joyce and Andrew Hastie, dismiss Australia’s 1.1% share of global CO2 as negligible to argue against net zero. Climate experts call this the “drop in the bucket” fallacy: if all smaller emitters abandoned targets, they’d account for 28.4% of global emissions. Every increment of CO2 matters for limiting warming, they say, and Australia’s per-capita emissions rank among the world’s highest. Under Paris, all nations must set and ratchet up NDCs to curb warming well below 2°C. An ICJ opinion affirms the legal obligation for 1.5°C compliance, so withdrawing or watering down Australia’s commitment would breach its international duties.

articles.title: Wild bird numbers continue to fall in UK with some species in ‘dramatic freefall’
articles.trailText: Species index fell by 4% between 2019 and 2024 – although data shows woodland populations beginning to stabilise
articles.summary: Between 2019 and 2024 the UK wild bird species index fell by 4% (7% in England) as intensive farming, pesticides and habitat loss drive accelerating declines. Farmland birds have plummeted 62% long term and 11% short term, with turtle doves, grey partridges and tree sparrows worst hit. Seabirds have also crashed amid avian influenza. Conversely, woodland populations show early stabilisation, though green woodpeckers are down 22% since 2018. Lapwings and yellowhammers have plunged over 65%. DEFRA aims to halt nature’s decline by 2030 via scaled-up biodiversity-friendly farming.

articles.title: ‘Food forests are everything’: creating edible landscapes helps nature thrive in Afro-descendant lands
articles.trailText: Agroforestry systems in Latin America practised by local communities are a boon to biodiversity, according to research
articles.summary: Afro-descendant communities in Latin America have cultivated “edible landscapes” – biodiverse agroforestry systems co-evolving with natural forests – across about 200 m ha, though just 5% enjoy legal recognition. A new Nature Communications Earth & Environment study of 9.9 m ha in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and Suriname reveals 56% overlaps with the planet’s top 5% biodiversity hotspots, deforestation rates 29% lower than protected areas and 55% lower than their edges. Tracing practices from African crop knowledge introduced during colonial plantations, these forest gardens blend cacao, yams, okra and native species. Community initiatives now seek cultural heritage status and expanded land titles to safeguard this conservation model.

articles.title: Dodging New York traffic: hundreds of humpback whaless on a collision course with ships
articles.trailText: Humpbacks are thriving in the warm waters off the coast of Manhattan but maritime restrictions have not kept pace
articles.summary: Humpback whales have surged in the New York Bight—from just five individuals tracked in 2012 to 470 today—drawn by rich forage near Manhattan. Juvenile whales feeding in shallow waters now intersect major shipping lanes, making vessel strikes the leading cause of mortalities in the region’s ongoing Unusual Mortality Event. Seasonal 10-knot speed limits cover larger vessels January–May, but NOAA withdrew broader year-round expansions in 2025 amid industry and funding pressures. Voluntary slowdowns remain patchy and rerouting lanes faces logistical barriers. Researchers warn warming waters drive whales closer to shore and call for permanent slow zones or reroutes to cut collisions.

articles.title: Global investment in renewable energy up 10% on 2024 despite Trump rollback
articles.trailText: Growth rate slightly lower than previous first-half years but sector still strong and resilient, experts say
articles.summary: In H1 2025 global renewables investment hit a record $386bn, a 10% increase year-on-year, edging below prior H1 growth rates of 12% (2023-24) and 17% (2022-23) but reflecting resilience despite US federal rollbacks under Trump. Onshore and offshore wind financing rose ~25% to £126bn, led by China and Europe. Zero Carbon Analytics reports $470bn in new clean energy finance since January, three-quarters earmarked for grids. Net Zero Tracker finds 70% of revenue from top 2,000 listed firms pursuing net zero, including 19 US states and 304 US companies. Experts warn corporates still must accelerate real emission cuts to meet targets.

articles.title: Country diary: The sound of a dragonfly is a 300m-year-old whisper | Paul Evans
articles.trailText: The Marches, Shropshire : It’s almost inaudible to us, but it’s there, a gentle turbulence with a percussive clicking, ancient and electric
articles.summary: Paul Evans evokes the near-inaudible resonance of a female southern hawker dragonfly in Shropshire, her four wings cycling 30–50 times a second to achieve 45 mph and instant six-directional turns (1,958 flight permutations). Each wingbeat generates micro-turbulence and percussive clicking, a stridulation reminiscent of birdsong or speech—softened by the pterostigma and wing microstructure to dampen noise. This ancient flight code stretches back 300 million years to the Carboniferous, linking a 30 m³ garden’s autumnal hush to deep evolutionary time.

articles.title: EU chemical firms plan to export rising quantities of ‘toxic’ pesticides, documents show
articles.trailText: Bloc urged to end ‘unethical double standard’ of allowing sale of products deemed too dangerous for EU farms
articles.summary: EU chemical firms’ planned exports of pesticides banned domestically rose from 81.6k tonnes in 2018 to 122k tonnes in 2024, even after a 2020 EU pledge to end 'toxic trade.' Export notifications detail shipments of reproductive toxins such as glufosinate and mancozeb to low- and middle-income countries and the US. NGOs call the 'unethical double standard' a betrayal of rights; the Commission is reviewing legislation while industry asserts global regulatory compliance.

articles.title: Government required to create plan to protect greater glider in major legal win for Wilderness Society
articles.trailText: Murray Watt agrees recovery plans for greater glider, ghost bat, lungfish and sandhill dunnart were not made by successive governments
articles.summary: After a federal court challenge by the Wilderness Society, Environment Minister Murray Watt conceded that governments unlawfully failed to produce mandatory recovery plans for the greater glider, ghost bat, Australian lungfish and sandhill dunnart, agreeing in settlement to enact them within statutory deadlines. The deal also restores plans for seven species, including Baudin’s and Carnaby’s cockatoos, previously allowed to sunset. Conservation groups hailed the ruling as precedent-setting, enforcing compliance with national environmental law and cutting through a backlog affecting over 575 species. The government confirms public consultations are underway and pledges over A$600 million to species recovery. An Auditor-General report found only 2% of plans met legal timeframes since 2013.

articles.title: ‘A heavy burden’: Belém residents evicted in rush for profits from Cop30 rentals
articles.trailText: As the Brazilian city prepares to host 50,000 delegates, local people are being pushed from their homes
articles.summary: Faced with a housing shortage and soaring rents, Belém landlords have been evicting residents to convert flats into lucrative short-term Cop30 rentals. In March, Suelen Freitas’s family was given 30 days to leave their two-bedroom home; after legal aid they secured costlier, distant housing. Similarly, Giovana Silva agreed to vacate her three-bedroom leased house for a fraction of projected profits, enduring months of disruptive remodeling. Real estate firms and local authorities have promoted profit-driven lettings, sidelining locals. In response, community platforms like Conexão Cop30 have emerged to offer affordable alternatives, while residents assert their right to host the summit.

articles.title: Are we there yet? Everything you need to know about the electric vehicle revolution in Australia
articles.trailText: After a comparably slow start ‘it’s going to snowball’ says one industry expert as prices become more competitive and charging infrastructure catches up
articles.summary: Australia’s EV market is accelerating from 9% of new sales (Apr–Jun 2025) to a projected 85% by 2035, with 120+ models now available. Top sellers in 2024 included Tesla’s Model 3/Y and BYD Seal/Atto; Geely’s EX5 and Zeekr 7X are rapidly gaining traction. Secondhand EV turnover nearly quadrupled in H1 2025 but still represents only 1% of used sales. Over 1,000 fast chargers operate nationwide, with more planned. Tax breaks for leased EVs cut costs by ~$10K over four years. Hitting 50% new-car EV targets by 2035 also requires investment in public transport, freight electrification and active travel.

articles.title: Whose tide is highest? Canadian towns battle it out over Guinness World Record title
articles.trailText: For years Nova Scotia’s Burntcoat Head Park claimed the superior tidal height, but now a challenger from the far north is seeking the crown
articles.summary: Bay of Fundy’s Burntcoat Head Park long held the Guinness record with a 14.5m tidal range, but Nunavik’s Inuit-run Makivvik says new 2024–25 sensor data at Tasiujaq in Leaf Basin recorded a 16.3m swing. After a failed 2003 survey, the latest study used strategic sensors and divers. Makivvik has submitted its findings to the Canadian Hydrographic Service, though Fisheries and Oceans tentatively call the sites tied. Exec Adamie Delisle Alaku disputes this and urges a swift review. A new title could boost remote tourism, navigational safety and real-time tidal info for northern communities.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Flash floods and landslides wreak havoc in California
articles.trailText: Two-year-old boy dies and homes buried as remnants of Tropical Storm Mario bring downpours and thunder
articles.summary: Remnants of Tropical Storm Mario triggered flash floods and landslides across central and southern California, dumping up to 68 mm in hours on Riverside and San Bernardino counties and drenching Death Valley with 15 mm—triple its September norm. Debris flows buried homes, trapped motorists and swept away a car, killing a two-year-old boy. Meanwhile, a slow-moving front lashed New Zealand’s South Island with 50–83 mm rain and 50–139 mph gusts; authorities issued red wind warnings in Canterbury, cut power to hundreds, cancelled trains and flooded roads, with further heavy rain forecast. In Asia, Super Typhoon Ragasa, recently a 165 mph category 5 storm, eyes landfall on China’s Leizhou peninsula before moving toward northern Vietnam, threatening record gusts in Guangdong, Hong Kong and Macau.

articles.title: Country diary: An autumn fireball that’s a sanctuary for insects | Kate Blincoe
articles.trailText: Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk: The Robin’s pincushion is a most rare vision – and has an unexpected origin for its unusual name
articles.summary: In Caistor St Edmund, Norfolk, amid fermenting damsons, blackberries and hop garlands, Kate Blincoe spots a mossy orb on a wild rose—the robin’s pincushion or bedeguar gall caused by the wasp Diplolepis rosae. Females lay eggs in unopened buds; the rose builds a fuzzy capsule that shelters developing larvae and, later, other insects like ladybirds. Named for Puck rather than the bird, these harmless galls redden to fiery orange, once used in folk remedies for coughs and kidney stones, embodying autumn’s rich interplay of plant, insect and folklore.

articles.title: Nations’ plans to ramp up coal, gas and oil extraction ‘will put climate goals beyond reach’
articles.trailText: New data shows governments now planning more fossil fuel production in coming decades than they were in 2023
articles.summary: The Production Gap 2025 report by SEI, Climate Analytics and IISD shows governments plan to boost fossil fuel extraction—coal, gas, oil—to levels that would more than double 2030 production consistent with limiting warming to 1.5C. Thirteen of 20 major producers, including US, Russia, China and India, plan higher output; only UK, Australia and Norway aim cuts. This overproduction breaches COP26/28 commitments and risks exhausting the carbon budget.
